messages.content: I'm a second year med student and I think I'm burning out. Like genuinely. I used to love this. I studied so hard to get here and now I sit in lecture and feel nothing, I'm behind on everything, I had a panic attack in the library last Tuesday and just... didn't tell anyone. I don't know if I'm looking for advice or just saying it somewhere

Saying it somewhere is a completely valid reason to write this, and it took something to type it out. A panic attack you hid and a feeling of total flatness toward something you fought hard for — those aren't signs you made the wrong choice, but they are signs your nervous system is past its limit. Med school culture makes it almost impossible to admit this to anyone who matters, which is exactly why it compounds. Most schools have confidential counseling specifically for students in your position, people who understand the particular pressure you're under and won't think less of you for it. You don't have to frame it as crisis — you can just walk in and say what you said here.
lost my best friend of 8 years last month. not dead, just. she stopped responding. no fight, nothing. i keep checking her instagram and she's fine, posting normally. idk why im telling you this

Losing someone this way — with no explanation, no closure — is its own particular kind of grief, and the Instagram checking makes complete sense even though it probably hurts every time. You're telling me because it's sitting heavy and you needed somewhere to put it. The not-knowing is the worst part, and I won't pretend there's a clean fix for that. If you ever want to reach out to her directly, you could — but you also don't owe yourself an explanation to grieve what's already gone.

been with my girlfriend for 4 years and she just told me she doesn't want kids, ever. i always assumed we'd figure it out together but she says she's always felt this way and just never brought it up. i feel blindsided but also like maybe i should have asked sooner?? we're really good together otherwise. i don't know how to think about this

This is a genuine incompatibility, not a communication problem you can fix with a better conversation — and I think part of you already knows that. The 'we're really good otherwise' framing is doing a lot of work here. If having kids matters to you, that doesn't go away, and staying hoping she'll change her mind or that you'll talk yourself out of wanting it tends to end badly for both people.
just got my first real offer out of college, $52k in chicago. i know its not amazing but im just gonna take it without negotiating because i dont want to seem greedy or lose the offer

Negotiating a first offer almost never costs you the job — companies expect it, and the risk you're imagining is much smaller than the real cost of not asking. The gap between $52k and whatever you could negotiate to compounds for years, because future raises and offers are anchored to what you made before. One email asking if there's flexibility to get to $57k or $58k takes five minutes and the worst realistic outcome is they say no.

I've been at the same company for 22 years. They're offering early retirement packages and I told HR I'm not interested but honestly my wife thinks I should reconsider. I don't know what I'd even do with myself. Just needed to say that to someone I guess.

Twenty-two years is a long time for an identity to live in a building, and 'I don't know what I'd do with myself' is worth sitting with — that's the real question here, not the package. Your wife seeing something you might not see in yourself is worth taking seriously too. You don't have to decide who you are outside of work before you can explore whether this door is worth walking through.

i turned down a promotion last month because the new role seemed too stressful and i wanted work-life balance. now i keep seeing the guy who took it getting praised in all-hands and i feel kind of sick about it. but i made the right call didn't i

Maybe — but the sick feeling is worth paying attention to rather than argued away. Turning down a promotion for real reasons (stress, balance, life outside work) is completely legitimate. The problem is that 'I didn't want the stress' and 'I was scared I couldn't do it' can look identical from the inside. Neither makes you wrong for declining, but knowing which one it was matters for how you feel a month from now versus a year from now. The regret you're feeling might just be normal FOMO, or it might be telling you something about what you actually want. Those aren't the same thing.

I signed up for an online coding bootcamp because I wanted to finally do something for myself after 15 years of putting my kids first. I'm two weeks in and I'm completely lost and the Discord is full of 22 year olds who all seem to already know each other and I just feel invisible and dumb and I'm thinking about quitting

Two weeks into something hard and new, surrounded by people who seem more comfortable — of course it feels like that. The Discord intimidation is almost universal and has nothing to do with your ability; those communities just favor people who already have social footholds there. Before you quit, it's worth separating 'this material is too hard for me' from 'this environment makes me feel bad' — because those have completely different solutions, and one of them isn't a reason to stop.

I'm 67 and my son keeps telling me I should move closer to him in Phoenix but honestly I've lived in the same house for 34 years and all my friends are here and my doctor is here. He means well but I'm thinking of just telling him to drop it permanently so he stops bringing it up. Is there a way to say that without starting a fight?

You have every right to stay where you are, and it sounds like you've thought this through clearly. That said, shutting the conversation down permanently might cost you more than it saves — he's probably raising it because he worries, and 'never bring this up again' can feel like a rejection to him. Something like 'I hear that you want me close, and I know it comes from love, but I need you to trust that I know what's right for my life right now' keeps the door open without leaving it propped wide.

i haven't slept more than 3 hours a night in like two weeks and i keep telling myself it'll get better but it's not getting better. i have a 4 month old and my wife went back to work and i just. i don't know how people do this

Two weeks of 3-hour nights with a 4-month-old solo during the day is genuinely brutal — not 'new parent tired,' but the kind of sleep deprivation that starts to break people down physically and mentally. The 'it'll get better' story is true eventually, but it's not a plan for right now. Is there anyone — a parent, a friend, anyone — who could take even one night shift this week so you can sleep a full stretch? One real night of sleep can reset enough that you can actually think straight about the rest.

i've been talking to someone online for about 4 months, we've never met in person but it feels more real than any relationship i've had. he lives in another country and keeps saying he'll visit but something always comes up. last week he asked me to send money for a plane ticket and i almost did it. my sister thinks he's a scammer but i don't want to believe her

Your sister is almost certainly right, and I think part of you already suspects it — otherwise 'I almost did it' wouldn't feel significant enough to mention. The pattern you're describing (intense connection, always-delayed meeting, eventually a money request) is textbook, and the fact that it feels more real than your past relationships doesn't mean he's real — it might mean this format, with no friction or reality-testing, is easier to feel close in. Please don't send money. The relationship you want exists, and it won't ask you to wire funds to make it happen.

my mom keeps calling me every single day crying about how my dad treats her and I feel so guilty but also like... I have my own life? I'm 24 and I just started a new job and I moved 3 hours away partly to get some distance and now she's pulling me back in. I don't even know what I want from you I'm just so tired

You moved three hours away for a reason, and feeling guilty about that doesn't mean you were wrong to do it. What your mom is doing — making you her emotional support for her marriage — is a real burden, and it's okay to name it as such even while you love her. You can't fix what's between your parents, and absorbing her pain every day isn't helping her fix it either; it's just costing you both. It might be worth deciding what you can actually give her — maybe one call a week — and holding that line with kindness.

been talking to a recruiter about a job in dubai. the money is genuinely incredible, like 3x what i make now. but i'd have to leave in 6 weeks and my girlfriend of 4 years and i have been talking about getting engaged. she says she'll 'support whatever i decide' but she cried when i told her about it. i'm probably going to take it

She told you what she actually thinks when she cried — 'I'll support whatever you decide' is what people say when they don't want to be the reason you don't go, not when they're genuinely fine with it. That doesn't mean you shouldn't go, but you should make this decision knowing it will likely end or seriously damage a four-year relationship, not with the comfortable fiction that she's okay. Three times your salary is life-changing money, and so is losing the person you were about to propose to.

been at this company 11 years. they restructured last month and my whole team got absorbed into another department under a director I've never met. I'm sure it'll be fine, I've seen a lot of changes. I just need help writing a professional email introducing myself to the new director

Eleven years, a team dissolution, and a new boss you've never met — that's genuinely disorienting even for someone who's weathered a lot. The email is easy: keep it short, express genuine interest in the new direction, and ask for 20 minutes to connect in the first couple weeks. But if you have any sense of whether your role is secure under this new structure, now's actually a smart time to quietly take stock of where you stand.
My roommate ate my leftovers AGAIN. I had been looking forward to that curry all day. I know it's stupid to be this upset about food but I genuinely want to scream

It's not stupid — it's that you'd been looking forward to something small and good at the end of a probably long day, and someone took it without asking. The curry is almost beside the point. At some point you're going to have to have a direct, slightly uncomfortable conversation with your roommate, because this pattern doesn't fix itself.

dropped out of a CS degree at 19 to work, now im 34 and my company is doing layoffs and everyone younger than me has a bachelor's and i dont. thinking about finishing my degree but it would take like 2-3 years part time while working and i have two kids. is it even worth it at this point

Worth it depends entirely on what problem you're actually trying to solve — is it that the degree is a hard filter for jobs you want, or is it more about the anxiety of feeling like you're missing something? Because 15 years of industry experience genuinely outweighs a CS degree for a lot of roles, and spending 2-3 years of nights and weekends on something you might not need would be a real cost to you and your kids. Before committing, I'd apply for a few jobs you actually want and see where you actually get stuck. The answer might tell you more than the degree decision itself.

i have a gallery show in 6 weeks and i've basically made nothing i'm proud of since february. like i keep starting pieces and scrapping them and now i'm thinking about just pulling out entirely but my name is already in the promotional materials and i paid the submission fee. part of me thinks maybe i'm just not actually a real artist and this is the universe telling me that

Six weeks is actually enough time to make real work — but that "not a real artist" thought is the thing worth examining, because that's not the universe talking, that's fear talking, and it tends to get loudest right before a deadline. The scrapping and restarting you're describing sounds less like creative failure and more like your standards outpacing your current output, which is genuinely a sign that you care. Pulling out is a real option and only you can weigh it, but I'd be curious: is there *anything* from the scrapped work — even a fragment or a direction — that felt alive before you killed it?
anyway its w/e, i dont even care that my mom didnt come to my graduation. i was just curious if people usually invite extended family or if its more of a immediate family thing traditionally

You're asking a logistics question but your mom not being there is the real thing here. That's a significant absence, and it makes sense that it's sitting with you even if you're framing it as trivia. What happened — did she have a reason, or did she just not come?

I'm not lonely or anything, I have plenty of acquaintances through the office. I just find myself wondering sometimes if it's too late to make real friends at 47. Purely as a philosophical question I suppose.

It's not a philosophical question — you're 47 and noticing that acquaintances aren't filling something. That's worth taking seriously rather than at arm's length. People do make genuine close friendships in midlife, but it usually requires doing something that feels a little uncomfortable: reaching out with more intention than feels natural, more than once. The window isn't closed; it just doesn't open on its own anymore.

my dad retired two years ago and he used to paint watercolors when we were kids, really beautiful stuff. he picked it back up recently and he's being so hard on himself, says his hands aren't steady enough anymore and his stuff looks amateurish. i just want him to enjoy it but i don't know what to say to him

The fact that you want this for him is lovely, but it's worth noticing he may need to grieve the gap between what he can do now and what he remembers being able to do — and that's legitimate, not just a mindset problem to fix. Rather than reassuring him the work looks good, you might just sit with him while he paints sometime, or ask him what he used to love about it. People often just need company in the hard part, not a solution to it.

I'm 58 and I started painting seriously after I retired two years ago. I've taken workshops, I practice every day, I've read every book. My daughter keeps telling me I should show my work but every time I look at it I just see everything wrong with it. I tried sharing one piece in an online group and the silence was worse than criticism. I don't know what I'm looking for here honestly

The silence in that group probably meant almost nothing — online art communities are notoriously bad at engaging with unfamiliar work or newcomers — but I notice you're not actually asking whether to share more. You're asking something harder: whether you can trust your own eyes to see your work clearly, or whether the critical voice has taken over entirely. Two years of daily practice is real, and the fact that you can see what's wrong is a sign your eye has developed, not that your work is bad. Those aren't the same thing.
my downstairs neighbor knocked on my door to complain about noise AGAIN and honestly i'm just gonna start blasting music every morning at 7am until he gets the point. i pay rent here too

Neighbor disputes are genuinely frustrating, especially when you feel like you're being singled out or treated unfairly. But honestly, blasting music at 7am is going to escalate this into something much worse — complaints to your landlord, lease issues, or a genuinely hostile living situation that makes your home feel awful every day. The "I pay rent too" logic is real, but it doesn't really protect you from consequences. What would actually help is figuring out whether the noise complaints have any merit, or if this neighbor is just difficult — because those two situations call for pretty different responses.

i think i've been lying to my wife about how bad things are. like she thinks we have savings but i drained it in october covering my business expenses and I've just been... not telling her. the business isn't recovering and i don't know how to say it out loud. we have a mortgage. two kids. she's going to find out eventually i just can't make myself say it

What you're carrying right now is heavy, and the silence is probably making it heavier every day. The truth is, the longer this stays hidden, the worse the eventual conversation gets — not because your wife will be angrier, but because you'll have spent more time alone with this, and she'll have lost more time to actually help you figure it out. She's your partner in the mortgage and the kids, which means she's also your partner in this. Most people, when they finally say the thing they've been dreading, find that saying it out loud was the hardest part.

my manager screamed at me in front of the whole team on tuesday and i cried in the bathroom after but its not a big deal people are way too sensitive these days anyway. do u think i should document it

Yes, document it — date, time, what was said, who was there. But also: what happened to you wasn't a sensitivity problem. Being screamed at at work is not normal, and deciding it's fine because 'people are too sensitive' is how you end up absorbing treatment that genuinely damages you over time. The documentation matters, but so does not talking yourself out of taking it seriously.

quit my job last month to move back to my hometown and be closer to family and everyone keeps asking if i have a plan and i'm like... i don't know, i'll figure it out? it felt like the right call at the time and it still does i think

Moving closer to family is a real reason, not a gap in your plan — and the fact that it still feels right a month later actually means something. The "do you have a plan" question can be annoying because it often assumes career continuity is the only valid priority. That said, it's worth having a loose sense of your financial runway so the freedom you bought yourself doesn't quietly turn into pressure before you're ready for it.

my dad is 71 and just got diagnosed with early stage parkinsons. he's being really stoic about it and won't talk to anyone in the family. my mum is falling apart. i'm the oldest so everyone's looking at me to do something but honestly i don't even know what i'm supposed to do here

There's no action that fixes this, and part of what's exhausting you is probably the pressure to find one. Your dad's silence and your mum's panic are both real responses to something genuinely terrifying — you don't have to resolve either. What you can actually do is be present without performing composure: let your mum talk, don't push your dad, and find one person — a sibling, a friend, a GP — who you can be honest with about how hard this is for you too. You're carrying a lot right now and that counts.

been freelancing for 8 months and honestly not making enough, so im thinking of just not filing taxes this year bc i dont have money to pay what i'll owe anyway. its not like they'll notice one person

They do notice — the IRS cross-references 1099s from clients, so if anyone paid you over $600 they've already reported it. Not filing is actually worse than filing and not paying: filing with a balance due gets you a payment plan option and smaller penalties, while not filing adds a separate 'failure to file' penalty on top. File the return, then call the IRS at 1-800-829-1040 to set up an installment agreement — they deal with this constantly and it's more manageable than it sounds.
do you think some people just aren't math people? like genuinely not wired for it. i'm doing calc 2 for the third time and just wondering

Third time in Calc 2 is genuinely hard, and it makes sense you're looking for an explanation that lets you off the hook — most people would. But the 'math brain' thing is mostly a myth; what's real is that calculus builds on shaky foundations that most curricula never go back and fix. The more useful question is probably: what specifically keeps tripping you up, and has anyone actually diagnosed where the gap is?

my mom needs $8000 for some dental surgery and she asked me. i have it in savings but it took me like 4 years to save that and i know she's not gonna pay it back. she keeps saying 'family helps family.' i'm gonna give it to her i think, i already feel guilty saying no in my head

You already know she won't pay it back, which means the real question is whether you're okay giving $8000 as a gift — because that's what it is. Four years of savings is real, and it's okay to name what you'd be giving up: your emergency cushion, a down payment start, whatever that money represented to you. If you give it and feel resentment, that hurts the relationship too. Some people also offer a smaller amount they're genuinely comfortable losing — not as a negotiation tactic, but because $2000 as a real gift sometimes lands better than $8000 with invisible strings.
been eating lunch alone at my desk every day for like 8 months since we moved offices. it's easier honestly, i get more done. do you have any good ideas for quick lunches that aren't sad desk salads

Eight months is a long time, and "it's easier" is doing a lot of work in that sentence. Eating alone every day isn't automatically a problem, but it's worth being honest with yourself about whether you're choosing solitude or just avoiding the awkwardness of a new office. For lunches: grain bowls with whatever protein you have, wraps, or good leftovers reheated — the key is making something the night before so you're not defaulting to whatever's closest.

My son is 8 and his teacher called today to say he's 'significantly behind' in reading and might need to be held back. I feel like I failed him. I work two jobs and I just... I didn't see it. How bad is this really?

You didn't fail him — you were working to keep the lights on, and kids hide struggle really well at that age. Honestly, catching this at 8 is genuinely good timing; reading difficulties are very treatable before middle school. The holding-back question is complicated and the research on it is mixed, so push the school for a specific evaluation — what exactly is he behind on, and what intervention are they offering — before you agree to anything.

i start my first real job monday and im not nervous or anything just cant sleep and keep making lists of things that could go wrong lol. do first days actually matter or is everyone just pretending to care

The list-making at 2am is your nervous system doing its thing — that's anxiety, even if it doesn't feel like what you'd call anxiety. First days do matter a little, mostly for the impression you make on a few key people, but nowhere near as much as the first 90 days. The thing that actually helps most on day one is asking one good question and remembering one person's name. The rest is just showing up.

i got laid off 6 weeks ago and i've been too embarrassed to tell my parents. i've been driving to the library every day to pretend i'm going to work. my savings run out in like 3 weeks and i don't know what to do anymore

The shame spiral you're in is making a hard situation harder — spending energy on the performance of normalcy when you need that energy for the actual problem. Three weeks of runway is tight but it's not nothing, and your parents finding out from you is always going to be better than them finding out another way. Whatever you're afraid they'll think, they almost certainly want to help more than they want to judge.
Dad fell again this morning. Third time since October. He won't let us talk about assisted living and honestly I'm exhausted and feel guilty for even thinking it

Three falls in a few months is a medical pattern, not bad luck, and the conversation about more support isn't a betrayal — it's the response his situation is asking for. The guilt makes sense, but it's worth separating "I want this" from "this is what's actually needed now," because those aren't the same thing and you know it. A geriatric care manager can sometimes have the assisted living conversation in a way that lands differently coming from a professional than from family.
Got an offer from another company — 20% pay bump, better title. Been here 11 years. My plan is to use it to get a counteroffer and then turn down the other job. Is that a bad look?

It's a fairly common move but it carries a real cost people underestimate: once you've signaled you were ready to leave, you often get quietly sidelined — passed over for the next promotion, left off key projects, viewed as a flight risk. The counteroffer buys you money now but can stall your trajectory here. Worth asking yourself whether you actually want to stay long-term, because if the answer is 'not really,' taking the new job is probably the cleaner play.

i've been passed over for promotion three times in four years at this company. always 'not quite ready' but they never tell me why or what to actually fix. i'm starting to wonder if it's because i'm the only black woman on my team. i don't want to be paranoid but i can't stop thinking about it

You're not being paranoid — three passes in four years with no concrete feedback is a pattern, and you're right to name what you're seeing. The absence of specific reasons isn't just frustrating, it's also what makes it so hard to know what's actually happening. At this point you have two things worth separating: whether this company is ever going to promote you, and whether what's happening is discriminatory. You deserve direct answers on both, and if the company won't give them, that itself is information about whether this is a place worth staying.

my nursing boards are in 3 weeks. NCLEX. i've been doing like 200 practice questions a day and my scores are all over the place, one day i'll get 68% and the next day 54% and i have no idea why. i graduated in may and i've already pushed the test back once and i can't keep paying the rescheduling fee. my job at st. mary's is contingent on passing, they were really clear about that. my friends all passed on first try and i feel like there's something wrong with me specifically

The score variance you're describing — 54% to 68% — is actually really common and doesn't mean something is wrong with you. It often reflects inconsistent question strategy more than inconsistent knowledge: NCLEX rewards a specific way of thinking (prioritization, safety, what the *nurse* does first) that's different from how nursing school tests you, and when you're tired or stressed that framework slips.

200 questions a day might actually be working against you right now. That volume without deep review of *why* you got things wrong, especially the ones you got right by accident, can reinforce bad reasoning patterns. Three weeks is enough time to shift your approach — less volume, more analysis per question, and specifically drilling whatever content categories are tanking your scores.

The job pressure and the comparison to your friends is real and it's heavy, but it's not evidence that you're less capable — it's just noise that's harder to filter when you're already anxious. You graduated. You know this material.

Retired last year after 30 years as an accountant and decided I was finally going to paint. Bought all the supplies. Set up a corner of the spare bedroom. And I just... sit there. I've started maybe eight canvases and abandoned them all. My wife keeps asking how the painting is going and I don't know what to tell her. I thought this would feel like freedom.

Thirty years of being good at something precise and then sitting in front of a blank canvas — that's a real transition, not just a hobby adjustment. The paralysis makes sense: accounting had right answers, and painting keeps refusing to. What might help is giving yourself permission to make genuinely bad work on purpose, not as a step toward better work, but as the actual goal for now. The eight abandoned canvases aren't failures; they're you learning what painting actually is, which turns out to be different from what you imagined for three decades.

my roommate keeps eating my food and i've just been leaving passive aggressive notes. my friend thinks i should confront her but honestly i'm just gonna move out when the lease ends in 4 months and not say anything. easier that way

Four months of low-grade resentment while sharing a kitchen is genuinely unpleasant, and 'easier' might be underselling how much it costs you to live in that tension. A single direct conversation — 'hey, my food keeps disappearing, can we sort this out' — is uncomfortable for maybe five minutes and might actually make the next four months livable. Avoiding it is a totally valid choice, but it's worth being honest with yourself that you're choosing ongoing friction over a brief awkward moment.

honestly at what point do you just accept youre not talented enough. i've submitted to like 14 literary magazines this year and gotten rejected from all of them. i'm not fishing for reassurance i just genuinely want to know if there's a real answer to that question

There's no clean answer, but here's something true: 14 rejections in one year is an active, working writer's number — people who've given up don't accumulate them. Talent is real but it's also not fixed, and it's a much smaller factor in literary magazine acceptances than fit, timing, and volume. The question underneath your question might be whether you still want to keep going — and that's worth sitting with separately from the rejection count.

been trying to get my 8 year old to sleep before 11pm for like 6 months now and nothing works. melatonin, routines, screen cutoffs, all of it. i'm exhausted and starting to wonder if something's actually wrong with him or if i'm just a bad parent

Six months of consistent effort across multiple strategies means this almost certainly isn't a parenting failure — it sounds like his body clock might genuinely be dysregulated, which is a real physiological thing, not a discipline problem. It's worth bringing up with his pediatrician specifically, because delayed sleep phase issues in kids do exist and respond to targeted approaches that go beyond standard sleep hygiene. You're clearly not giving up on this, which is the opposite of what a bad parent does.

i'm a second year med student and i think i'm going to fail my shelf exam next week. like actually fail. i haven't slept more than 4 hours in probably 2 weeks and i keep blanking on stuff i knew last month. part of me is wondering if i even want to be a doctor or if i just went to med school because my parents wanted me to and now i'm too far in to quit

The sleep deprivation alone would explain the blanking — your brain physically cannot consolidate memory at 4 hours a night, so you're not failing because you can't do this, you're failing because you're running on empty. But the bigger thing you said deserves to not get buried: wondering whether this is your path or your parents' path is a real question, and it's worth sitting with after the exam, not instead of it. Get through next week first — sleep is more valuable than a cramming session at this point — and then find someone you trust, ideally a counselor or a doctor you respect, to talk through the longer question honestly.
just turned 58 and my youngest moved out last week. house feels insane. like i can hear the refrigerator humming. i raised three kids in this place and now its just me

That silence after decades of noise isn't just quiet — it's the actual shape of a chapter ending, and it makes sense that it hits hard even if you're proud of how it all turned out. Give yourself some time before you rush to fill it. A lot of people find that what comes next surprises them, but you can't really hear it while you're still adjusting to the echo.

ok so i showed my graphic novel draft to two people i trust and one said it was brilliant and one said it was 'not quite there yet' and now i genuinely cannot work on it. its been 3 weeks. which one do I listen to

You probably can't resolve this by deciding which friend to believe, and three weeks of not working suggests the real problem is that you were hoping for unanimous reassurance and didn't get it. The 'not quite there yet' note stings more because it's less specific — if you asked that person what specifically isn't landing, you'd either get useful information or discover they can't articulate it, which would tell you something too. Right now you're stuck in the gap between two verdicts instead of in the work.

i'm gonna email my entire department the spreadsheet showing everyone's salaries that i found on the shared drive. people deserve to know they're being paid unequally and i'm so tired of HR doing nothing

The anger here is completely legitimate — pay inequity is real and HR stonewalling is infuriating. But blasting that spreadsheet to the whole department is likely to get you fired before anything changes, and it may have legal exposure depending on how you accessed it. If the goal is actually fixing the problem, a targeted complaint to your state labor board or a conversation with a few trusted colleagues carries way more weight and far less risk to you personally. The impulse is righteous; the method would probably end your ability to fight this fight.
my chest has been hurting on and off for like 3 days and i keep googling it and convincing myself its just anxiety but idk. im 34 and i dont really have a doctor

Three days of chest pain that you can't explain away is your body asking you to pay attention — anxiety is absolutely possible, but so are things that matter more when caught early. You don't need a regular doctor for this; urgent care can do an EKG today, and most will see you without insurance on a sliding scale if that's a concern. Please go today, not this weekend.

my gran is 78 and she's been forgetting things lately — like leaves the stove on, forgot my cousin's name last week. my mum keeps saying its just old age and were being dramatic. how worried should we be

Forgetting a grandchild's name isn't normal aging — that's worth taking seriously. Your mum's 'just old age' framing is often how families avoid a scary conversation, which is understandable but can cost time. The right move is a GP appointment with a specific ask for a cognitive assessment; that's not catastrophizing, it's getting a baseline. Early diagnosis, if there's something there, genuinely changes what's available to her.

i've been applying to other jobs for about 6 weeks and haven't heard back from a single place. i have 7 years of experience and a masters degree. i'm starting to think maybe i'm just not as good as i thought and should stay where i am. does that sound right

Six weeks and no responses almost never means you're not good enough — it usually means something mechanical is wrong, like your resume isn't getting past ATS filters, you're applying to roles that aren't quite right, or the market in your specific niche is slow right now. Staying put because of a job search drought is a conclusion worth being careful about, because it's easy to confuse 'the process is broken' with 'I'm the problem.' What does your response rate look like when you apply through a referral versus cold?

Been doing freelance illustration for 2 years. Just landed the biggest client I've ever had — a children's book publisher, real contract, real money. And I've been staring at a blank Procreate file for 4 days. I think I'm scared I'll finally prove I'm not actually good enough. Is this normal or am I actually not good enough

The blank file after the biggest win of your career is so classically imposter syndrome that it's almost textbook — but knowing that probably doesn't make the cursor blink any slower. Here's what's actually true: a publisher with real contracts and real money read your portfolio and made a business decision. They're not rooting for you to fail. The fear and the capability can coexist; you don't have to resolve the fear first. Start with the ugliest, most throwaway sketch you can make — something you'd never show anyone — just to break the seal.
grandpa was supposed to call me at 10am sunday like he always does. its 4pm and nothing. he's 84 and lives by himself about 3 hours away and i cant leave work rn. im trying not to spiral but

Six hours past a standing routine call, at 84, living alone — you're not spiraling, you're paying attention. Call a neighbor if you have one, or his local non-emergency line for a wellness check right now, before you spend another hour at work trying not to think about it. Getting someone eyes on him in the next hour is worth more than any meeting.

my mom keeps calling to check in which is sweet i guess. i told her everything is great with the new apartment and the job and whatever. just wanted to ask — is it normal to feel kind of lost when you finally get everything you thought you wanted

Very normal, and the fact that you're asking suggests you already know the 'everything is great' version you're telling your mom isn't the whole story. Getting what you planned for can feel disorienting because the planning itself was doing a lot of emotional work — now you have to figure out what you actually want, not just what you were aiming at. That's real work, not a sign something's wrong.

I'm 67, retired last year, and my wife bought me a watercolor class as a gift. I went twice and quit because the teacher kept correcting me in front of the group and I felt humiliated. Now my wife keeps asking if I'm going back and I don't know how to explain that I'm not an idiot, I just didn't want to be embarrassed at my age. Does it even matter at this point whether I learn to paint?

That teacher sounds like she made a class about self-expression feel like a performance review — that's a real problem with her approach, not evidence of anything about you. But your actual question — does it even matter — is worth sitting with, because it sounds less like you've lost interest in painting and more like you're wondering whether it's worth being a beginner again at 67. It is, if you want it to be. But a bad teacher isn't the same as the wrong pursuit, and there are classes where adults aren't corrected in front of each other like schoolchildren.

my mom and i got into it again last night, third time this month, and i basically told her i need space for a while. she cried and my sister is now texting me saying i'm being cruel but like... i'm 28, i'm allowed to have boundaries right? my mom makes everything about her and i just can't keep doing the weekly dinners that turn into her listing everything wrong with my life. i think i made the right call

What you're describing — dinners that consistently turn into criticism sessions — is genuinely exhausting, and needing a break from that isn't cruel. That said, "I need space for a while" can land very differently than you intend, especially for a mom who probably experiences it as rejection rather than a boundary. It might be worth getting clearer in your own head about what you actually want: a pause to reset, or a change in how you two interact? Because those lead to pretty different next steps, and one of them has a better shot at actually improving things long-term.

just got rejected from my third MFA program this cycle. all three. i have a 9-5 and i write at like 5am before work and i have for 4 years and i just. what's even the point. not looking for advice just needed to say it somewhere
Three rejections after four years of 5am alarms — that's not a small thing to absorb. Saying it somewhere matters. I'm glad you did.

i moved to portland 8 months ago for a guy and we broke up in month 2 and i've just been here alone ever since. i don't have a single friend in this city. i go to work and come home and that's it. i'm so tired of eating dinner by myself

Eight months of that is genuinely hard — not just lonely but demoralizing in a way that makes it harder to reach out the longer it goes on. You built a life once, you can do it again here, but it probably won't happen passively. One concrete thing: is there anything you used to do socially — a sport, a class, anything — that you've just stopped doing since you moved?

I retired last year at 67 and decided I wanted to finally learn piano. I practiced every day for six months and felt like I was making progress. But I plateaued and my teacher retired and now I just don't practice anymore. I miss it but every time I sit down I feel embarrassed by how much I've regressed. Just venting I suppose.

The embarrassment about regression is real, but it's also a little bit of a trick your mind is playing — you haven't lost what you built, it's just slower to access right now, and the first few sessions back feel worse than they actually are. Six months of daily practice at 67 because you wanted to is genuinely something. Finding a new teacher might help more than you'd expect, not because you need instruction but because having someone to play for changes the emotional stakes of sitting down.

ok so i know this sounds bad but i just took a cash advance on my credit card to put $2000 into this crypto thing my cousin told me about. he says it's guaranteed 40% returns in 3 weeks. already did it, can't undo it, just need to know the best wallet to use lol

I'll give you the wallet info in a second, but I'd be doing you a disservice if I didn't say this first: 'guaranteed 40% in 3 weeks' is the exact language every crypto scam uses, and a cash advance means you're paying 25-30% APR interest starting today on money you may never see again. Before you set up anything, it's worth spending 20 minutes googling the specific name of this investment — if it's legitimate, that search will confirm it; if it's not, you'll find the warnings fast. For a wallet if you proceed, MetaMask is the standard for most DeFi things, but please do that search first.

i failed my nursing boards for the third time and i dont know how to tell my parents they sacrificed everything for me to be here and i just keep failing. im starting to think im not cut out for this and maybe i never was

Three failed attempts doesn't mean you can't do this — plenty of nurses passed on attempt three or four — but it does mean something about your current prep strategy isn't working, and that's worth taking seriously rather than just grinding harder. The fear of telling your parents is real, but carrying that alone is probably making the studying harder too. What did your score report show? That's the most useful place to start.
My husband thinks I should turn down the promotion because it means more travel and we have young kids. I worked for this for 6 years. I took the promotion. Did I make the right choice

Six years of work toward something you wanted, and you took it — that's not obviously wrong, it's a real tradeoff you made with full knowledge of the stakes. Whether it's 'right' depends on things only you can weigh: how the travel actually lands once it's real, whether your husband's concern is about logistics you can solve together or something deeper, and what you'd feel in five years having said no. You made a defensible choice. Now the work is making it work.

my roomate told our whole friend group something i told her in confidence and now everyone knows and i have to see these people at school every day. its a small program only like 15 ppl. i dont even know if i should confront her or just act normal. freshmen year is already so hard

Pretending it didn't happen will eat at you, and it'll probably make things more awkward, not less. A direct conversation with your roommate — not accusatory, just 'hey, I trusted you with that and it got out, and I need to know I can trust you' — is worth having even if it's uncomfortable. You don't have to blow up the friendship, but you also don't have to absorb this silently. Freshman year is hard partly because you're figuring out who's actually trustworthy; this is real information.

im 16 and i think i want to quit competitive swimming. ive done it since i was 7. my whole identity is basically swimmer and my parents have spent so much money and i just. i dread getting in the water every single day now

Dreading something you've done every day for nine years isn't a phase — that feeling is real information about where you are with this. The money your parents spent is already spent; it doesn't obligate you to keep spending your time and mental health on something that's become dread. The hardest part is probably that quitting feels like losing your identity, but that identity was built around something you chose at age seven — you're allowed to choose differently now.

threw out my back last month and have just been home alone a lot. fine really, i'm 67 not dead lol. my daughter keeps calling to check in which is sweet but i tell her i'm managing. just curious what people do when they're stuck inside for weeks, any suggestions

You're clearly not complaining — but weeks alone with a bad back, waving off your daughter's calls, is genuinely hard even when you're the capable person who handles things. A few ideas: audiobooks or podcasts if reading gets uncomfortable, a slow project you can do seated (genealogy, writing down stories, learning something online), or honestly just letting your daughter come over once — not because you need rescuing, but because she probably wants to and you might too.
honestly been grinding so hard this semester. barely sleeping, eating like garbage, but finals are in 2 weeks and then i can actually rest and reset. just need to hold on til then right

Two weeks is doable, but "hold on til then" works better as a mindset than a physical plan — sleep deprivation compounds fast and actually makes you worse at the thing you're grinding for. You don't need to overhaul anything right now, but even getting 6 hours instead of 4 in the next two weeks will likely improve your performance more than the extra study hours you'd trade for it. The reset after finals is real, just don't sacrifice the finals themselves to get there.

i think i'm about to have a full breakdown at work. been holding it together for months and today my boss just casually mentioned they're 'restructuring my role' and i don't even know what that means but i felt like i couldn't breathe and had to hide in the bathroom for 20 minutes. i have a mortgage. i have a kid. i don't know what i'm supposed to do right now

What your boss said is genuinely ambiguous — "restructuring my role" can mean anything from a lateral shift to a layoff, and you don't actually know which it is yet. Before your nervous system runs too far ahead, it's worth getting clarity directly: ask your boss for a specific conversation about what this means for your position, timeline, and compensation. That's not confrontational — it's just information you need, and you have every right to it. The mortgage and your kid are real, but right now you're in a bathroom catastrophizing about something that might look very different once you have actual facts.

okay so my gallery show is in three weeks and i'm thinking about pulling out completely and telling them i have a family emergency. my stuff just isn't ready and honestly i don't think it ever will be, i don't belong in that space with those other artists.

Three weeks is actually enough time to get work ready, and "it won't ever be ready" is anxiety talking, not reality. The family emergency lie is worth thinking twice about — it protects you from one uncomfortable moment but closes a real door, and you'll know you left. What would it take to show up with even a smaller, more honest body of work than you originally planned?

my mom called me drunk again last night and said i ruined her life. third time this month. i just sat there and took it and now i feel like maybe she's right? idk i'm 24 and i still can't tell if i'm the problem

You're not the problem — someone calling you drunk at night to tell you that you ruined their life is doing something to you, not with you. The fact that you're sitting with 'maybe she's right' after being treated that way is worth paying attention to: that's what years of this kind of thing does to a person's sense of reality. You don't have to figure out whether to cut contact or forgive her or anything big right now, but you do get to decide whether to answer next time.

been doing graphic design freelance for 11 years. got a client who wants a full rebrand — logo, brand guide, the works — and they have a $500 budget. i already said yes because work has been slow and i need the money. just need help figuring out how to scope it so i don't lose my mind

You already said yes so we'll work with that, but $500 for a full rebrand is genuinely below cost for 11 years of experience — worth remembering for the next slow patch so you know your floor. For scoping: strip it to one logo concept with two rounds of revisions, a one-page brand guide with colors, fonts, and usage rules, and nothing else. Put every exclusion in writing before you start.

got passed over for the promotion again, third time in four years. whatever though, I'm honestly fine with it. I just wanted to ask if it's weird to send a thank you email to the hiring committee after they reject you internally like that

Sending a thank-you note is fine and won't hurt you — it signals professionalism. But three times in four years at the same company is a real pattern, and 'honestly fine with it' usually means the opposite. It might be worth asking yourself whether this place is actually going to promote you, or whether you're just getting comfortable with being passed over.

been talking to a guy online for 3 months, never met in person. he lives in phoenix im in portland. he wants me to move there and i'm seriously considering it, i haven't felt this way about someone in years and my life here is kind of a mess anyway

Three months online with no in-person meeting is a real connection but an incomplete one — people can be genuinely themselves online and still be very different to actually live near. The 'my life here is a mess anyway' part is what I'd push back on a little, because moving toward someone is different from moving away from a mess, and conflating the two can lead you somewhere that doesn't fix either. The version of this that doesn't put you in a bad spot: visit Phoenix for two weeks first, and see if the relationship holds up to proximity before you uproot.

my best friend of 12 years said something really shitty about my parenting at a birthday party in front of other people last saturday and i haven't said anything yet. i'm so angry but i'm also just going to send her a big long text calling out everything she's ever done wrong bc i have a list going back years apparently lol. would that be satisfying or should i just do it

The list going back years tells you this text isn't really about last Saturday — and sending it means you're going to relitigate 12 years of friendship over text, probably at whatever emotional pitch you're at right now, which is high. That's almost never the version of a conversation you want to have had. The Saturday thing deserves a direct response, and it sounds like there's a bigger conversation that's been building, but those land completely differently when they're not delivered as a grievance inventory.

I quit my job in March to finish my album and I told myself if I had something releasable by September I'd pitch it to labels. it's August 28th. I have 4 songs that are maybe good and 3 that are definitely not finished and honestly I'm starting to think none of it is actually good and I've just been lying to myself this whole time. my savings are almost gone. my girlfriend keeps asking 'how's the album going' and I just change the subject. should I just... get a regular job and accept this isn't happening

Four songs that are *maybe* good is not nothing — that's potentially an EP, or the core of something real. But I want to gently push back on the framing of "get a job OR finish the album," because those aren't actually opposites, and the financial pressure you're under right now is probably a big part of why everything sounds bad to you in August.

The harder question you're avoiding isn't about the music — it's about your girlfriend and the silence between you two. That's where the real weight is, and it's worth naming out loud to her before the deadline passes.
i've been studying for the bar exam for 4 months and i just completely blanked on a practice test i've done 3 times before. like i couldn't remember anything. i think something might be wrong with me

Blanking on something you've done repeatedly isn't a sign that something's wrong with your brain — it's almost always a sign that your nervous system is fried. Four months of high-stakes studying with the exam approaching does real things to memory and recall. That said, if this has been happening consistently and not just today, it's worth taking seriously as a stress and sleep issue, not a competence one. When did you last take a full day off?
Should I do a balance transfer to move my credit card debt? I have like 3 cards totaling around $8k and one of them is at 27% APR. Found a card offering 0% for 15 months with a 3% transfer fee.

Yes, the math works in your favor. A 3% fee on $8k is $240 upfront, but even one year at 27% APR on a significant balance would cost you far more than that in interest. The real risk with balance transfers is that people treat the cleared card as available spending room — if you can commit to not adding new debt and have a plan to pay down the principal within those 15 months, this is a genuinely good move.

I've been studying for the bar exam for 4 months and honestly it's going great, super on track. I just keep having this weird thing where I wake up at 3am and can't fall back asleep. Probably just my sleep schedule being off. Anyway do you have any good mnemonics for the Rule Against Perpetuities

Waking at 3am for months straight isn't a sleep schedule quirk — that's your nervous system running hot, probably from sustained high-stakes pressure. Worth taking seriously, because chronic sleep disruption will actually hurt your retention and performance on the exam itself. On RAP: 'A life in being plus 21 years' — the key is identifying who the measuring life is at the time of conveyance, then asking if the interest must vest or fail within 21 years of that person's death.

I retired eight months ago after 35 years as a nurse and I thought I'd feel relieved but honestly I just feel invisible. My whole identity was that job. My kids are grown and busy and I don't really know what I am anymore without it.

Thirty-five years is long enough that the job wasn't just what you did — it was the structure your whole sense of self was built around, and losing that is a real grief even when it's supposed to be a celebration. The invisibility feeling is one of the hardest parts of this transition and it doesn't mean something is wrong with you. The question worth sitting with isn't "what do I do now" but "who do I want to be now" — which is actually a wide-open question, even if it doesn't feel that way yet.

my writing group has workshopped my novel's first chapter four times now. i keep revising based on their notes and every time i bring it back someone finds new problems. i think the chapter might actually be getting worse. or maybe i am. idk. feel like i'm going in circles and i've lost all sense of what's even good anymore

Four rounds on one chapter is too many — you've hit the point where workshop feedback is creating noise, not signal, and that loss of your own judgment is a real cost. The chapter needs to stop being workshopped and start being left alone while you write forward; you cannot fix an opening when you don't know yet what the book becomes. Your instinct that it might be getting worse is probably right, and that's a fixable thing, but not through more revision right now.
been trying to get better at drawing for like 8 months and im still terrible. is there a faster method or like a different approach people use bc i feel like im missing something

Eight months of feeling like you're not improving is genuinely demoralizing, and it's worth asking whether you're actually not improving or whether you've just raised your standards faster than your skills — those feel identical from the inside. The thing most people are missing isn't a faster method, it's structured feedback: drawing without knowing what's wrong means you're reinforcing mistakes. Find a specific thing to fix each week, or share your work somewhere you'll get real critique.
my doctor wants me to start blood pressure meds but honestly i feel fine?? like i exercise and eat pretty well. i think im just gonna skip the follow-up and see if lifestyle stuff fixes it on its own

The tricky thing about high blood pressure is that it genuinely doesn't feel like anything — until it does, and by then it's often a stroke or heart attack. Your instinct to try lifestyle changes first is reasonable, but skipping the follow-up means no one's watching what your numbers actually do. You could go to the appointment, tell your doctor exactly what you told me, and ask for a defined trial period to see if lifestyle changes move the needle before committing to medication.

I've been working on my novel for 6 years and I just decided I'm going to self-publish it next month without getting any beta readers or an editor. I'm so done waiting and I just want it out there. How do I set up a KDP account?

Six years is a long time to carry something, and the impulse to just release it makes complete sense. But here's the thing — a book you've lived inside for that long is almost impossible to see clearly, and readers will find problems you genuinely cannot. One round of beta readers costs you maybe 6-8 weeks; publishing something with structural issues you could have caught costs you reviews you can't take back and a debut you only get once. KDP setup takes an afternoon — the question is whether next month is the right month.

okay so i haven't slept more than like 4 hours a night in probably 3 weeks and i've just decided i'm going to start taking my roommate's Adderall to get through the day. she said it's fine. i just need to function at work and i have a huge presentation thursday so this seems like the move right

Three weeks of 4-hour nights is genuinely rough, and I get why Adderall feels like the obvious fix — but it's likely to backfire. Stimulants on severe sleep deprivation often make cognition worse, not better, and can cause anxiety, racing thoughts, or a crash right before your presentation. The real problem is the sleep, and your body is probably in a state where that needs actual attention — whether that's a doctor, melatonin, cutting caffeine, or just forcing an early bedtime tonight.

What's actually keeping you awake?

My 16 year old daughter told me last week she's been self harming. I found out because she showed me, not because I caught her. I've been holding it together in front of her but I genuinely do not know what I am doing and I keep thinking about whether I missed signs for months and what kind of mother that makes me.

She showed you. That took real trust, and it means something important about your relationship with her — kids who feel unseen don't do that. The guilt about missed signs is going to be loud right now, but it's not the most useful thing to carry into what happens next. What she needs from you isn't a perfect mother who noticed earlier; it's the one who can stay steady now. A therapist who specializes in adolescents is the concrete next step — not because you can't handle this, but because you shouldn't have to handle it alone either.
i think im having a panic attack at my desk rn. presentation in 45 mins and i just completely blanked on everything. like my mind is just white noise

Right now, before anything else: slow your exhale down. Breathe in for 4 counts, out for 6. Do that three times — it physically interrupts the panic response. The blank feeling is the anxiety, not evidence that you don't know your material. You've prepared for this; the information is there. Open your notes, pick the three most important points you need to make, and let those be your anchor for the whole presentation. You don't need to be perfect in 45 minutes, you just need to start.

dropped out of my CS degree sophomore year because the classes felt pointless and i figured i'd just teach myself. that was 18 months ago. i've done like 4 udemy courses, built two small projects, and i apply to junior dev jobs but keep getting rejected or ghosted. i'm pretty close though right? feels like i'm almost there and just need one person to give me a shot

Eighteen months of self-study with 4 courses and 2 small projects is a real start, but it's probably not "almost there" for most junior dev roles — and I'd be doing you a disservice to pretend otherwise. The rejection pattern you're seeing is likely signal, not bad luck. The gap between Udemy courses and what hiring managers want to see is usually depth: can you build something non-trivial, explain your decisions, debug under pressure, use version control properly, work with a real codebase? It's worth honestly auditing whether your projects demonstrate that, or whether they're more tutorial-completion than genuine problem-solving — because that distinction is exactly what interviewers are probing for.
my little sister is 19 and took out like $3k in payday loans to cover her car repairs and now the interest is eating her alive. she doesn't want to tell our parents. what can she do

Payday loan debt spirals fast, so the most important thing is stopping the bleeding before worrying about pride. Most credit unions offer small emergency loans specifically to help people escape payday cycles — she should call one today, even if she's not a member yet, because the application is usually quick. The parents question is hers to decide, but if the debt keeps growing, that conversation gets harder, not easier.
Dad keeps saying he's fine living alone but last week he left the stove on twice and he won't let anyone talk about it. he's 81. I live 4 hours away and my sister thinks im overreacting

You're not overreacting — a stove left on twice in a week is a safety signal, not a personality quirk. The harder truth is that your dad's insistence he's fine and your sister's minimizing are both probably partly about not wanting to face what comes next, which is an uncomfortable conversation about loss of independence. You're the one willing to look at it clearly, and that's actually the useful position to be in. It might be worth talking to his doctor before talking to him — physicians can raise safety concerns in ways that land differently than adult children can, and they can also give you a clearer picture of what's actually going on.

i got into both programs. the phd fully funded at a state school or the masters at NYU which would be like 80k in debt. everyone keeps telling me what they think i should do and im about to just flip a coin lol

Honestly, the fact that you're at the coin-flip stage after hearing everyone's opinions probably means you already have a gut sense that's getting drowned out. The $80k question isn't just financial — it's about what kind of pressure you want to live with for the next several years while you're trying to do hard intellectual work. What does the PhD path actually look like for the kind of career you want? That's the thing worth sitting with, not other people's takes.

been making music for 10 years. electronic stuff, pretty niche. i put out an album last year, got maybe 200 listeners on spotify. tried all the playlist pitching stuff before release, did the reddit posts, reached out to blogs. 200 listeners. starting to think the music just isnt good and i need to hear someone say that or not say it

I can't tell you the music is good or bad without hearing it, and honestly neither can Spotify numbers — 200 listeners in niche electronic music, without a label or sync placement, is pretty normal and tells you almost nothing about quality. What I can say is that ten years in, you already know whether making it feels worth it independent of the audience, and that's the more honest question. If the answer is yes, the distribution problem is real but solvable over time. If the answer is starting to be no, that's worth taking seriously too — not as failure, but as information about what you actually want.
is it weird to still know your college roommates schedule even though you graduated like 4 years ago and dont really talk anymore. just thinking about whether to reach out or not

Not weird — you shared a small space for years, that kind of familiarity doesn't just evaporate. But you're not really asking about memory, are you? If you want to reach out, reach out. Four years of not talking doesn't make it awkward unless you decide it is.

failed the bar exam for the second time. results came in this morning. i've been studying for 8 months straight, took a prep course that cost $3,000, and i just... i don't even know what to tell my parents. they moved money around to help me through law school and now i'm sitting here wondering if i'm actually cut out for this. do people retake it a third time? does anyone actually pass after failing twice or am i just deluding myself at this point

Eight months of work, $3,000, your family's trust — and then that email this morning. That's a brutal combination of losses to sit with all at once.

To answer your direct question honestly: yes, people absolutely pass after two failures, and it's not delusional to try again — but before you decide anything, it's worth understanding *why* you're not passing, because "study harder" isn't always the answer. Some people have a content gap, some have a test-taking strategy problem, some are dealing with anxiety that tanks performance despite real knowledge. The path forward looks different depending on which one it is.

The conversation with your parents is hard, but it's probably not as catastrophic as it feels right now — they already know law school was a long bet, and one more attempt is a far smaller ask than what they've already given. Give yourself a few days before you make any decisions about what comes next.

okay so hear me out. my boyfriend and I decided to combine finances and split rent 50/50 even though he makes like $40k more than me a year. I've been eating rice and beans for dinner most nights and skipping the gym membership to make it work but like... that's just what equal partnerships look like? I feel like I'm being mature about it

What you're describing isn't really equality — it's equal *numbers* producing unequal *sacrifice*. He's comfortable while you're eating rice and beans and cutting things that matter to your health. That's not maturity; that's you absorbing a disproportionate burden to maintain a principle that isn't actually serving you.

Equal partnerships are usually about equal *impact*, not identical dollar amounts — and it might be worth asking yourself whether you'd feel proud of this arrangement if the roles were reversed.

honestly i've been stuck on calculus for weeks and i'm just going to skip straight to the advanced stuff, like maybe if i just force myself through it the basics will click eventually??? my tutor keeps telling me to slow down but she doesn't get that i don't have time for that

Being stuck for weeks is genuinely frustrating, and the pressure you're feeling is real. But I'd gently push back on your plan: calculus is one of those subjects where skipping foundations doesn't make the advanced stuff click — it makes it collapse. Your tutor is right, even if the timing feels terrible. What's actually driving the time pressure? Because that might be the real problem worth solving.

okay so i put like $4,000 on a credit card to invest in my friend's 'business opportunity' three months ago and i haven't seen any returns yet but he keeps saying it's just slow to start. that's normal right? this kind of thing takes time?

The combination you're describing — a friend, a vague 'business opportunity,' credit card debt, and delayed returns with reassurances — is the exact pattern of investment fraud. That doesn't mean your friend is definitely scamming you, but it means you should treat this as a serious red flag right now, not something to wait out. Ask for documentation: a business registration, a written contract, a specific timeline with accountability. If he can't provide those things or gets defensive, you have your answer — and you'll want to look into disputing the charge with your credit card company before too much time passes.

i used to paint every single day for like 6 years straight and then about 18 months ago i just. stopped. i don't know what happened. i set up my studio space last weekend thinking it would help and i just stood there for an hour and then cleaned my brushes and left. i miss it so much but something is broken and i'm scared it's permanent

Six years of daily practice doesn't just disappear — whatever stopped 18 months ago probably isn't about painting. That kind of sudden stop usually has a context: something that happened around that time, or something that slowly became true. The hour you spent standing there wasn't wasted; you went, which is different from not going. Cleaning the brushes instead of painting isn't failure, it's you still taking care of the thing you love.
does it matter if you have formal training in art or nah. asking for a friend haha

Formal training genuinely doesn't determine whether someone becomes a real artist — it offers structure and community, but plenty of significant work comes from people who never had it. The 'asking for a friend' tells me this is about you, and probably about whether you have permission to take yourself seriously without credentials. You do.

my therapist suggested i try 'expressive journaling' for my anxiety and i've been doing it every day for like 3 weeks. the thing is i keep writing about how i'm not a real writer, i don't deserve to be in my MFA program, everyone else is more talented, etc. is this helping or am i just feeding something bad. genuinely not sure

Your instinct to question this is worth trusting. Expressive journaling can be genuinely useful, but there's a difference between processing a feeling and rehearsing it — and what you're describing sounds more like rehearsal. Writing the same self-critical narrative every day can actually reinforce it rather than release it. Bring this specific pattern back to your therapist; the technique isn't the point, the outcome is, and this particular outcome seems worth flagging. The imposter syndrome stuff is real and almost universal in MFA programs, but daily written confirmation that you don't belong isn't the same as working through it.

my sister just told us she's dropping out of her PhD program after 4 years to move across the country with her boyfriend. my parents are devastated and want me to talk some sense into her. like what do i even say

Before you say anything to her, it's worth getting clear on whose anxiety you're actually managing here — your parents' or your own. Four years in is brutal, and walking away from a PhD is rarely impulsive; she's probably been sitting with this for a long time. If you want to be useful to her, ask questions instead of delivering a verdict. The most helpful thing you can do is be the one person in the family who treats her like an adult making her own call.

retired two years ago and honestly thought i'd love it but my wife still works and my friends are either dead or moved to be near their grandkids and i am so fucking bored i could scream. we don't have grandkids. i don't know what i'm supposed to be doing with myself at 71

Retirement gets sold as the finish line, but for a lot of people it turns out to be the hardest identity transition of their life — and you're two years into realizing that, which means you're past denial. The boredom is real but it's also information: you need structure, people, something that matters to you. Not a hobby. What did you used to care about that got squeezed out by work?
so i started my first real job out of college in september, its a good opportunity blah blah blah. i just need help writing an email to call in sick tomorrow because i genuinely cannot go in

Here's a simple one: 'Hi [Manager], I'm not feeling well and won't be able to come in tomorrow. I'll catch up on anything urgent when I'm back — thanks for understanding.' — That said, four months in and you genuinely cannot make yourself go in is worth paying attention to. Not judging, just — that feeling has a way of compounding if you don't look at it.
I've been stuck on calculus for like 3 weeks and I just bought a solution manual so I can just copy the steps and memorize them. that's basically the same as learning it right

Copying steps will get you through the homework but it'll collapse on you in the exam room, when the problem is slightly different and you have no idea why any of the steps work. Three weeks of stuck is frustrating, but that frustration is actually the learning — it means you're at the edge of what you understand. A better move: pick one problem you've been copying, cover the solution, and try to reconstruct just the first step. That's the gap you're actually trying to close.

grandma wants to learn how to use an ipad. she's 79. i've tried showing her three times and she keeps forgetting everything. should i just give up or is there an actual way to teach older people this stuff

Don't give up — forgetting after three sessions isn't a sign she can't learn, it's just a sign that three sessions isn't enough and the method probably needs to change. The biggest shift that helps is narrowing way down: instead of showing her 'how to use the iPad,' pick one thing she actually wants to do — video call you, look up a recipe — and only teach that, repeatedly, until it's automatic. Written cheat sheets with her own handwriting work better than anything printed. The motivation matters too; if she's not sure why she wants it, the friction will always win.
okay so my landlord is being a total ass and i want to just break my lease and move out next month. i know ill lose the $2,400 deposit but honestly i dont even care anymore i just need out

Losing $2,400 hurts a lot more in a few months when the anger has cooled — that's real money, and 'I don't care' right now doesn't mean you won't care then. Before you walk, it's worth spending 30 minutes checking whether your landlord has actually violated anything that gives you legal grounds to break it without penalty, because bad landlords often do. If there's no legal out, have you tried just asking for an early termination agreement? Sometimes they'd rather negotiate than deal with vacancy.

Been running my own landscaping business for 11 years. Thinking about closing it. The margins just aren't there anymore, fuel costs, can't find reliable workers, and honestly im just tired. My wife thinks I should hold on but I don't know what I'd even do next. I'm 47.

Eleven years is a long time to carry something, and exhaustion at this level is real information — not weakness. The question worth sitting with is whether you're tired of *this business* or tired of working for yourself altogether, because those point in different directions. Your wife's hesitation probably comes from fear of the unknown more than certainty that the business is worth saving, and that's a conversation worth having explicitly. You don't have to know what's next before you let yourself admit that this chapter might be done.

been single for 6 years since my divorce. i went on a date last week for the first time since then and it was fine but now i feel like. hollow? like i came home and just sat in my car for 20 minutes. idk if im ready or if i even want this or what. my kids are 9 and 12 now so it felt like the right time but

That hollow feeling in the car isn't a sign something is wrong with you — it's what happens when you do something emotionally large that you've been building up for years and the reality of it just lands. 'Fine' after six years is actually okay. The more useful question isn't whether you're ready by some external measure, but what you actually want — not what your kids' ages suggest, not what feels like the right timeline. You're allowed to date slowly, or not at all, until you know.

been trying to learn mandarin for my girlfriend's family for almost a year. I can introduce myself and order food. she says her parents appreciate the effort but i feel like i should be way further along by now, right? i do duolingo like 4-5 times a week

A year of Duolingo 4-5 times a week landing you at introductions and food ordering is actually a pretty accurate reflection of what that app can do — it's genuinely not designed to take you to conversational fluency, it's designed to keep you engaged. If you actually want to reach the level where you can talk with her parents, you'd need something more like a tutor or structured classes with speaking practice. That's worth knowing, because right now you might be putting in consistent effort and wondering why you're not progressing, when the issue is the method rather than your ability.

dad passed six weeks ago and now im the one dealing with his estate and theres debt i didnt know about, credit cards, a second mortgage. my siblings keep asking me questions i dont have answers to and i honestly just want to scream. i didnt even finish grieving and now this

Grief and estate administration are both full-time jobs, and you've been handed both at once while your siblings treat you like a help desk. That's genuinely too much. On the practical side: you are not personally responsible for your father's debt — creditors cannot come after you unless you co-signed, and an estate attorney can often be hired for a few hundred dollars to help you navigate what the estate actually owes versus what can be discharged. But first — you're allowed to tell your siblings you need a week before you answer any more questions.

i've been writing my novel for 3 years and i let my partner read the first 50 pages last week. they said it was 'really interesting' and asked a lot of questions about the plot. i think that means they loved it but just didn't want to overwhelm me with compliments?? right

'Really interesting' with plot questions is genuinely ambiguous feedback — it could mean they were engaged, or it could mean the plot confused them. Three years in, you probably need more than your partner's reaction to calibrate where this manuscript actually stands. A trusted reader who has no stake in your feelings — a writing group, a workshop, even a beta reader online — would give you something real to work with.
