Yes, call someone — a friend, your mom, a sibling, whoever you'd want sitting with you right now, even just on the phone. Being alone in that apartment surrounded by his stuff is genuinely one of the harder places to be in this moment, and you don't have to white-knuckle it by yourself.

i got passed over for the promotion AGAIN. third time in four years. my manager just said i 'need more visibility' which is literally nothing, what does that even mean. i've been here since 2019 doing everything right and i just. idk. maybe i'm just not the kind of person who gets promoted

That phrase 'more visibility' is often code for something specific — usually it means decision-makers don't think of you when opportunities come up, which is a political problem, not a performance one. But honestly, three times in four years at the same place is a real pattern, and it's worth asking whether this company is actually going to promote you or just keep you useful where you are. You deserve a direct answer from your manager about what specifically has to change, and if they can't give you one, that's information too.

i'm 58 and finally writing the novel i've put off my whole life. been at it 2 years, have 80k words. showed the first 3 chapters to a writing group last month and they were kind but i could tell they were being kind. rewrote those chapters. showed them again last week. same thing. i think the book might just be bad and i don't know what to do with that

The fact that you can tell the difference between genuine enthusiasm and polite encouragement means your instincts are working, which matters. Writing groups are also a limited instrument — they're good at line-level feedback, less reliable at telling you whether a whole project has something. Two years and 80,000 words is a real thing that exists now; the question isn't really 'is it bad' but 'is it fixable and do I want to fix it.' Those are worth separating. A single reader you trust — not a group — giving you honest chapter-by-chapter notes might tell you more than another workshop round.

my roommate hasn't been sleeping more than like 3-4 hours a night for the past month and she just laughs it off and says she's fine but she looks terrible and keeps forgetting things. should i say something or is it not my place

Say something — a month of 3-4 hours isn't a quirk, it's a problem, and the memory issues and appearance changes are your body's way of confirming what she's dismissing. The fact that you're asking whether it's 'your place' suggests you already know the friendship warrants it. You don't need to make it a big intervention; just tell her directly what you've noticed and that you're concerned. That's what people who care about each other do.

my mom called crying this morning saying she hasnt eaten in 3 days and doesnt want to get out of bed. shes 68 and lives alone 4 hours away. i dont know if im overreacting but something feels really wrong

You're not overreacting — three days without eating plus not getting out of bed in an elderly person living alone is a real warning sign, not just a rough patch. Call her doctor today and describe exactly what you told me; they can flag it as urgent. If you can't reach anyone quickly and your gut is still screaming, it's okay to drive the four hours or ask a neighbor to check on her. Trust what you're feeling here.

okay so I gave notice at my job last Friday and I move out of my apartment in 3 weeks and I still don't have a place lined up in Austin. I've been on Zillow every day and everything decent is either already gone or $2400+ which was NOT what I budgeted. my whole plan was to get there, crash with my cousin for a week max and find something, but she just texted me that her roommate situation is 'complicated' right now. I'm 26 and I feel like I'm watching my whole plan collapse and I don't even know what to ask here I just. is this salvageable or did I mess up

This is not a mess-up, it's a snag — and 3 weeks is actually more runway than it feels like right now. The cousin thing is the real problem to solve first: can you get a straight answer from her about whether you have that week or not, because your whole plan hinges on knowing that. If the answer is genuinely uncertain, Austin has furnished month-to-month options and extended-stay places that aren't glamorous but exist specifically for situations like yours — they're not on Zillow, search "extended stay Austin" and "furnished short-term Austin" separately. The rental market being brutal is real, but people relocate to Austin constantly and figure it out; you're not the first person to arrive without a lease signed.

my little sister is 19 and she just quit her illustration degree after one semester. she says she's not talented enough and everyone else in her class is better than her. i think she's making a huge mistake but idk how to talk to her about it

One semester is genuinely not enough time to know — everyone in a first-year art program feels exactly what she's feeling, because they're surrounded by people who've been drawing obsessively since childhood and the gap looks enormous and permanent when it isn't. That said, pushing her too hard risks making this about you being right rather than her finding her way. The more useful question to ask her isn't 'are you sure?' but 'what would you do instead?' — because if she doesn't have a clear answer, she probably knows she's running away rather than running toward something.

My husband and I had another huge fight about money last night. We're $34,000 in credit card debt and he keeps saying we'll figure it out but nothing ever changes. I'm so tired. I feel like I'm the only one who even sees how serious this is.

Carrying the weight of a financial crisis while also feeling unseen by your partner is genuinely exhausting — that's two hard things at once. The debt is solvable, but the disconnect with your husband is the part that actually needs attention first, because a plan only works if you're both in it. A single session with a nonprofit credit counselor (NFCC is a good starting point) can be useful not just for the numbers but because it puts both of you in front of a third party who can make the stakes concrete in a way a fight at home can't.

dropped out of my engineering program last semester and told my parents i was 'taking a break' but honestly i dont think im going back. i've been doing freelance graphic design and making okay money. like $1800 last month. my dad keeps sending me job listings for internships and i just ignore them. i think im doing the right thing but sometimes i panic at 3am idk

The 3am panic is worth paying attention to — not because you're necessarily wrong, but because it's telling you something unresolved is still there. $1800 freelancing is genuinely promising, but 'okay money' and one good month aren't the same as a sustainable livelihood yet, and you probably know that. The harder thing here isn't the career choice, it's that you're hiding it from your parents — that's the part that's keeping you from fully committing to either path. Whatever you decide, you'll feel more solid once you stop managing two realities at once.
been applying to jobs for 8 months. had maybe 15 interviews. nothing. my savings are almost gone and i keep thinking maybe im just unemployable or something is fundamentally wrong with me. idk

Eight months is genuinely brutal, and the story your brain tells after that long — that something is fundamentally broken about you — is the exhaustion talking, not an accurate read of reality. That said, 15 interviews with no offers usually means something specific is happening at a particular stage, whether that's application volume, interview performance, or offer negotiation, and it's worth trying to figure out which. You're not unemployable; you're depleted, and those feel the same from the inside but aren't.

been getting calls from collections for months and my sister says i should just ignore them and they'll eventually give up and go away. honestly feels easier than dealing with it so that's probably what i'm gonna do

Your sister means well, but that advice will likely make things worse. Collections agencies can sue you, get a judgment against you, and garnish your wages or bank account — and ignoring them makes that more likely, not less. The calls feel overwhelming now, but a 10-minute call to a nonprofit credit counselor (NFCC.org has free ones) could actually give you a path out of this that doesn't involve your paycheck getting docked.

my manager has been making my life hell for 6 months and i finally have hard evidence she lied in my performance review. gonna forward the whole email chain to her boss and CC the entire leadership team tomorrow morning. like 15 people. i want everyone to see it

The evidence is real and your frustration is completely justified — but mass-CCing 15 executives is almost certainly going to make you look like the problem, even if you're not. People in leadership tend to close ranks when they feel ambushed, and you'll hand your manager a narrative where she's the victim. If you want this to actually land, go directly to HR or her boss one-on-one with the documentation. That's the move that gets you taken seriously instead of managed out.

i basically rewrote a whole project proposal that my team had been working on for weeks because i could see it wasn't going in the right direction. my manager loved it and we're moving forward with my version. my teammates seem a little cold now but tbh the old version wasn't good. was i wrong to just do it

The result was good, but the way you got there probably did real damage. Rewriting collaborative work solo — even when yours is better — sends a message that their contributions weren't worth engaging with, and that you'd rather fix things around people than with them. Your teammates aren't being oversensitive; that's a pretty reasonable thing to feel cold about. Whether you were 'wrong' depends on how urgent the situation was, but if it wasn't a true emergency, the cost to your working relationships was probably higher than the benefit of the cleaner proposal. The more useful question now is whether you address it with them directly or just let it sit.

so i quit my job at the hospital last month — 6 years as a nurse — and everyone keeps telling me i'm going to regret it but honestly i feel SO relieved. that has to mean something right? like relief is a good sign?

Relief after leaving something genuinely exhausting is real and valid — but it's worth separating 'relief from that specific job' from 'relief that nursing was the wrong path.' Six years is long enough that burnout alone could explain everything you're feeling. The question worth sitting with isn't whether the relief is a good sign (it is), but what it's actually pointing toward — rest, or a different life entirely.

my grandma keeps refusing to eat. shes 81 and lives with us and the last few days she's barely had anything, maybe a few bites. she says she's not hungry but she seems more confused than usual too. we dont want to force her but we're scared. is this just aging

Sudden confusion paired with not eating in an elderly person is a medical situation — it can signal a UTI, dehydration, medication interaction, or something else that's very treatable but moves fast in someone her age. This isn't just aging, and it's not something to wait out. She needs to be seen today, even if it's urgent care. You're right not to force food, but getting her evaluated is the caring thing right now, not an overreaction.

my mom and i had a huge fight last week and she said some really hurtful things. i've decided i'm just not going to her 70th birthday party next month. she should know what it feels like to be hurt. that'll show her

Skipping her 70th is a significant line to cross — birthdays at that age carry a weight you can't give back, and a year from now the fight may feel smaller while missing it still feels large. That doesn't mean you have to pretend nothing happened; you can go and still hold the boundary, or reach out beforehand and say you need acknowledgment before you can show up. What would actually make you feel better — her understanding what she did, or her feeling the absence?

my friends keep telling me my paintings are good enough to sell but i literally cannot bring myself to put them on etsy or anywhere. so i've been thinking, maybe i'll just give them all away or throw them out so i don't have to think about it anymore. i have like 40 of them in my spare room

Throwing them out isn't really about the storage problem — it's about making rejection impossible before anyone else can do it to you. That's understandable, but you'd be torching 40 pieces of work to avoid a fear that might not even materialize. Giving a few to friends is fine, but don't do anything irreversible with the rest until you've figured out what you're actually afraid of.

coworker of mine — Maya — has been coming in looking exhausted every day for months, she mentioned once that her toddler doesn't sleep and laughed it off but i can tell she's really struggling. not sure why im even typing this out i don't know what i want

Sometimes you just notice someone wearing down and it sits with you — that's not nothing. You don't need a plan; the smallest things land hardest when you're that depleted. Grabbing her a coffee, saying 'that sounds genuinely brutal, not just hard' — she probably doesn't need advice, just someone to acknowledge that it's real.

Called my bank again about lowering my interest rate on the credit card (22.99%). They said no again. I'm a customer of 11 years. Is there anything else I can even do at this point or is this just how it is

At 22.99% with two rejections on record, the honest answer is that calling back a third time probably won't move the needle. The more effective path is a balance transfer card — many offer 0% for 12–21 months, which buys you real time to pay down principal — or a personal loan at a lower rate to consolidate it. The loyalty argument rarely works with credit card companies; they know most people won't actually leave. Worth deciding whether you will.

my therapist keeps asking if i'm having thoughts of hurting myself and i always say no but honestly lately the answer is more like 'not exactly but i think about disappearing a lot' and i don't know if that's the same thing or if i even need to tell her

That distinction you're making — 'not exactly but I think about disappearing' — is worth telling her, and honestly it sounds like the reason she keeps asking. Passive thoughts of disappearing are real and they matter, even if they're not a plan. She's not going to overreact; she's asking because she wants the actual answer, and you seem like you want to give it.

i started running 6 days a week in january, up to about 8 miles a day now. my left knee has been hurting for 2 weeks but i read that some pain is normal when you're building mileage. i have a half marathon in 6 weeks so i don't want to stop now

Two weeks of knee pain that's persisted through your runs isn't the normal discomfort of adaptation — that's your body signaling something structural is being stressed. Running through it for six more weeks is a real gamble because what's fixable now can become something that sidelines you for months. The half marathon goal makes more sense if you actually make it to the start line healthy, and a week of reduced mileage now is a much smaller cost than a stress fracture or IT band injury that takes you out entirely.

My husband thinks we should pull money out of our retirement account to pay off our credit card debt — we're in our mid-40s, about $18k in debt at around 24% APR. His logic makes sense to me but something feels off about it and I can't articulate why. Asking because he's more confident than me about money stuff but that doesn't mean he's right

Your instinct is correct, and it's worth trusting it here. Withdrawing from a retirement account in your 40s means paying income tax plus a 10% early withdrawal penalty — on $18k you'd likely need to pull out $25k+ just to net enough to cover the debt, and you permanently lose the compounding on that money for the next 20 years. The 24% APR is painful, but there are better paths: balance transfer cards with 0% intro periods, a personal loan, or an aggressive paydown plan. The fact that he's confident doesn't make the math work differently — and the fact that you're questioning it is actually the more financially sophisticated instinct here.

My husband and I have been fighting about money for months. We're not broke but we're not comfortable either and he wants to buy a boat. A boat. I feel like I'm going insane, like am I the crazy one for thinking this is insane

You're not crazy — a boat is a notoriously expensive hobby even when finances are solid, and wanting to feel financially secure before a major discretionary purchase is completely reasonable. That said, the real issue sounds less like the boat and more like you two aren't on the same page about what 'comfortable enough' even means, which is the fight worth having. Getting specific — actual numbers, what 'comfortable' looks like for each of you — tends to defuse this faster than relitigating the boat.

i have a commission due friday — album artwork, $800 — and i sent the client a first draft yesterday and they hated it. like really hated it. said it 'missed the brief completely.' i reread the brief and i genuinely think i did what they asked but now i'm spiraling and i think maybe i just. can't do this. i've been freelancing for 2 years and this keeps happening with clients and maybe that means something

One bad client reaction after two years of freelancing doesn't mean you can't do this — but 'this keeps happening' is the part worth paying attention to, and that's a separate conversation from Friday. For right now: ask the client for a 30-minute call before you do any revisions. Misread briefs are almost always a communication problem, not a talent problem, and a call will tell you in ten minutes what another draft can't. The spiral is understandable but it's going to make the revision worse, not better. After Friday, look at whether there's a pattern in *which* clients this happens with — that's usually more diagnostic than the individual instance.

i've been sleeping like 5 hours a night for the past 3 months because i stay up watching stuff and i'm tired all the time but i feel like i need that time to decompress after work. everyone acts like sleep deprivation is such a big deal but i function fine on it, i've adapted. haven't i?

The research on this is pretty unambiguous: humans don't adapt to chronic sleep deprivation, they just lose the ability to accurately assess how impaired they are. The 'I function fine' feeling is itself a symptom of the problem. Three months at 5 hours is starting to accumulate real costs — cognitive, metabolic, emotional — that won't always be obvious until they are. The decompression need is legitimate, but there's probably a version of this where you protect some of that wind-down time without sacrificing three hours of sleep.

honestly i haven't slept properly in like 4 days because of this argument with my roommate and i'm just gonna leave a really passive aggressive note on all my stuff in the fridge instead of talking to her about it. that's fine right

Four days without sleep over this is rough, and honestly the passive-aggressive notes are probably going to make that fifth night just as bad. They rarely land as satisfying — they usually just escalate things or create this weird frozen tension that's somehow worse than the original argument. You already know a direct conversation is the move; the question is what's making that feel impossible right now.
me and jayden have been together 4 years and he forgot our anniversary again. i'm not even mad it's just whatever at this point. do you know any good restaurants in chicago that do tasting menus

The restaurant question I can help with, but — 'whatever at this point' after four years is a phrase worth sitting with. That's not the same as not being hurt; it's what hurt sounds like when it's happened enough times that you've stopped expecting anything different. Whether that's something you want to address is up to you, but 'whatever' usually means something. For Chicago tasting menus: Alinea if you want the full experience, Ever for something slightly more understated, Smyth if you want warmth with the ambition.

so i told my landlord i'm not renewing my lease in april and i'm moving to portland even though i don't have a job there yet or really know anyone. everyone keeps acting like i'm having a breakdown but honestly i think i just finally woke up? like staying here was the actual breakdown. i'm 29 and i've lived in the same 6 block radius my whole life. that's not normal right. anyway i already gave notice so it's happening, i just want someone to tell me this isn't insane

Wanting a real change after 29 years in the same six blocks isn't a breakdown — that's a pretty legible human impulse. But I'd be a bad friend if I just said "you're totally sane, go for it!" without noting: moving somewhere with no job and no people is genuinely hard, and the part that makes it work isn't the courage to leave, it's what you do in the first 60 days once the novelty wears off and you're eating alone again. You've already given notice, so the question isn't whether to go — it's whether you're treating this like an adventure that needs a real plan, or just an escape. Those can look identical from the outside until they don't.
is there like a formula for writing a short story? i took a creative writing class in college and i remember something about a three act structure but idk if thats just for screenplays

Three-act structure works for short fiction too, though short stories often compress it — less setup, faster turn, the ending does more weight. But formulas are usually what we reach for when we're stuck on something specific, so if there's a story you're actually trying to write, that's probably the more useful place to start.

I'm a 47-year-old going back to school for my MBA and I have to take statistics as a prerequisite. I failed the first quiz and I've decided to just pay someone on Chegg or wherever to do my assignments. I work full time, I have kids, I don't have time for this and it's just a prerequisite anyway.

The pressure you're under is real, and I'm not going to pretend otherwise. But paying someone to do your assignments means you'll hit statistics again inside the MBA — in finance, in analytics, in capstone projects — without the foundation, and that hole tends to grow. There's also genuine academic integrity risk that could cost you the program entirely. The harder question might be whether the pace you're on is actually sustainable, and whether there's any flexibility in your timeline.

my landlord just texted saying rent is going up $400 starting next month and i literally have $23 in my checking account right now. been picking up extra shifts but it's not enough and i don't know if i should just put it on my credit card which is already at like $3,800

That's a genuinely scary position to be in, and putting $400 on an already-stressed card will make next month harder, not easier — so before you do that, it's worth knowing you have some real options right now. You can call 211 (free, 24/7) for local emergency rental assistance programs, many of which pay landlords directly within days. Also worth asking your landlord for 30 extra days to comply — they often say yes because the alternative is worse for them too. The credit card is a last resort, not a first move.
ok so i'm 19 and i've asked my mom to stop going through my room like three times now and she still does it. i don't even know why i bother saying anything

That exhaustion — 'why do I even bother' — is worth paying attention to. You've said it clearly and she's not changing, which usually means the conversation itself isn't the lever anymore. The real question is what you can actually control: a lock on your door if she'd allow it, keeping things you care about private elsewhere, or at some point the longer-term question of your living situation. You're not doing anything wrong by setting the boundary; you're just learning that some people won't honor it until the circumstances change.

My granddaughter set me up with Khan Academy to help me pass my GED. I'm 67. I keep getting stuck on the algebra and I just close the laptop and don't go back for days. Part of me thinks I'm too old for this and should just accept I never finished school. I don't know why I'm even telling you this.

You're telling me because some part of you hasn't given up — and that part is right not to. The algebra wall is real and it trips up people of every age; it's not evidence you can't do this. Closing the laptop for a few days and coming back is still coming back. What might help: Khan Academy has a habit of moving too fast through foundational concepts — if you're stuck, go back further than feels necessary, even to pre-algebra basics, and don't move on until something actually clicks rather than just feeling familiar. You started this for a reason worth remembering.
been thinking about whether its worth keeping a journal. i used to do it in my 20s but stopped. im 47 now and life is just. a lot. anyway what are the actual benefits according to research

Research does back it — regular journaling is linked to reduced stress, better emotional processing, and even improved immune function in some studies. But honestly, the fact that you did it before and stopped, and you're thinking about it again now when life feels like a lot — that's probably the more important signal than any study.

my daughter keeps telling me to take an online coding class so i can switch careers. i've started intro to python on coursera twice, get about 3 weeks in and then it just falls apart. the videos make sense while i'm watching but then i sit down to do the assignments and its like i never saw any of it. is this normal or am i just not a coding person

What you're describing is completely normal — video comprehension and actual coding are almost entirely different skills, and almost everyone hits exactly this wall around week three. The assignments feel impossible because watching someone code doesn't build the muscle for writing it yourself, the same way watching cooking videos doesn't teach you to cook. Before starting a third time, it might be worth asking yourself whether you actually want to do this, or whether you're doing it because your daughter thinks you should — because that matters for whether any approach will stick.
what's the best free software for making album artwork? asking because i want to start doing my own covers instead of paying someone

Canva and GIMP are both solid free options — Canva for quick, polished results, GIMP if you want more control and don't mind a learning curve. Though if you've been paying someone for covers, that's usually a sign the music is real enough to need them, which means you're further along than people who are still just 'thinking about it.' What's making you want to switch to DIY right now?

My doctor told me three months ago I need to get my A1C down or she's starting me on medication. I kept meaning to change my diet but I honestly haven't done much. My follow-up is Thursday and I'm embarrassed to go back in.

The embarrassment is real, but skipping or dreading that appointment is the one thing that actually makes this worse — your doctor has seen this exact situation hundreds of times and her job is to help you, not judge you. Go Thursday and be honest about what changed and what didn't. Three months of partial effort still gives her real information, and starting medication if you need it isn't a failure; it's just the next tool. The thing worth sitting with is why the changes didn't stick — not to beat yourself up, but because that's the actual problem to solve.

so i put basically all my savings (~$14k) into my cousin's 'business' last year and now he's not returning my calls. my boyfriend keeps saying it's probably fine and i'm overreacting but something feels off. am i being paranoid?

Your gut is telling you something real here — an unresponsive business partner who also happens to be family is a red flag, not a reason to stay calm. Your boyfriend wants to reassure you, but 'probably fine' isn't a plan. You should get something in writing about what you're owed and when, and if he keeps dodging you, talk to a lawyer about your options before more time passes and recovery gets harder.

nobody came to my birthday dinner on saturday. i had a reservation for 8 people at this place i've been wanting to try and literally everyone cancelled the day of or just didn't show. my boyfriend came but we sat there for 2 hours and i just kept pretending i was fine. i'm 31 and i feel like i have no real friends

That's a specific, concrete kind of loneliness — watching a table that should be full stay empty — and it makes sense that it's hitting hard. One thing worth sitting with: this might be revealing something true about your current friendships, or it might be a coincidence of bad timing. Either way, 31 is actually a really common time to realize the friendships you've maintained by default aren't the ones that would show up. That's painful, but it's also information you can do something with.
do you think its bad that a 68 year old would rather just not go to the doctor even if something feels off? asking for myself lol. its probably nothing

The 'probably nothing' instinct is usually right, but at 68 it's also the exact logic that turns a caught-early problem into a complicated one. The avoidance usually isn't really about thinking it's nothing — it's about not wanting to know, or not wanting to become a patient. That's understandable, but you deserve to actually find out rather than manage the uncertainty. What's the thing that feels off?

my therapist costs $180 a session and i just... can't justify it anymore. i feel a lot better than i did in january so i'm gonna cancel my next appointment and probably just stop going. she'll understand. anyway do you know any good meditation apps

$180 a session is genuinely a lot, and feeling better is a real thing worth acknowledging. One thing worth sitting with though: feeling better in therapy is often *because* of therapy, and stopping when things are going well is one of the most common ways people end up back at square one — sometimes worse, because they feel like they "failed." Worth at least having one honest conversation with your therapist about the cost before ghosting; many therapists have sliding scales they don't advertise, and she might surprise you.

For meditation apps, Insight Timer is free and genuinely good — better than most paid ones.
what's the fastest way to get a real estate license in texas? asking because i want options

Texas requires 180 hours of coursework plus passing the state exam — online programs like Champions School of Real Estate can get you through it in a few months if you push. But 'wanting options' usually means something's making the current path feel closed off. If you're thinking about a real estate license as an escape route from something else, it's worth knowing the first year is usually thin income — so whatever you're escaping from, you'd need a runway.

so tired of grinding through this spanish course slowly, i'm just going to stop and immerse myself by moving to mexico for 3 months, i have like $800 saved up and i figure i'll just figure it out when i get there lol

The immersion idea is genuinely great for language learning — but $800 for 3 months in Mexico is not a plan, it's a fantasy that ends with you stressed, broke, and possibly stranded. That's roughly $9/day, which won't cover basic food and shelter even in cheaper areas.

If you're burned out on the course, that's worth taking seriously — grinding through structured lessons when you're fried is pretty ineffective anyway. But the move could actually work if you save up to $3,000-5,000 first, which gives you runway to find work or housing without desperation clouding everything.
i've been working on the same short story for like 8 months and its still not done and i just want to know is that normal or am I being too precious about it

Eight months on a short story isn't precious, it's a signal — usually either that something structural isn't working and you know it but can't name it yet, or that finishing feels like the moment it stops being potentially great and becomes just what it is. Which one feels more true for you?

i got passed over for the promotion again. third time. i've been here 9 years and watched three people i trained get promoted above me. i don't even know why i'm telling you this i just needed to say it somewhere

Nine years and you trained the people who leapfrogged you — that's not just frustrating, it's genuinely demoralizing in a way that's hard to explain to people who haven't felt it. The fact that you needed to say it somewhere matters. At some point the question worth sitting with is whether this place is ever actually going to see you, or whether you've been loyal to an institution that isn't being loyal back.

my dad had a stroke 3 weeks ago and i moved back home to help my mom take care of him. i'm sleeping on an air mattress in my old room. i had to pause my lease in chicago. i thought i was doing the right thing but i'm so angry all the time and i feel like a terrible person for being angry when my dad is the one who's sick

The anger makes complete sense — you put your whole life on pause, you're sleeping on an air mattress, and you're watching something scary happen to your father with no clear end date. Being angry about that doesn't mean you love him less or that you're a bad person; it means you're a person. The dangerous part isn't the anger, it's if you have no outlet for it while being the one everyone else leans on. Is there anyone in this situation who's checking on you?

I'm 24 and just got offered my first real job out of college — $58k, decent benefits, but the work sounds kind of boring honestly. My friend says I should hold out for something more exciting but I've been job hunting for 7 months. Do I just take it?

Seven months is a long search and that wears on you in ways that can distort the decision — 'boring' sounds a lot worse when you're exhausted than it might feel once you're actually employed and financially stable. At 24, a first job is rarely your destiny; it's a foothold, and $58k with benefits gives you breathing room to keep your eyes open. The real question isn't 'is this perfect' but 'does this close doors' — and a standard first job almost never does.

so i'm supposed to defend my thesis in 6 weeks and i just realized i don't actually understand the statistical analysis my advisor helped me set up last year. like i could not explain it if someone asked me a direct question. terrified the committee is going to grill me on it and i'll just blank

Six weeks is actually enough time to genuinely learn this — not fake it, but actually understand it. The most useful thing you can do right now is go back to your advisor and say exactly what you told me: "I need you to walk me through the statistical analysis again because I want to be able to defend it confidently." That's not embarrassing, it's exactly what advisors are for, and most will respect you more for it than if you'd stayed quiet. What's the analysis — I can also help you work through the logic of it.

i've been trying to learn python for 6 months and i still can't build anything on my own. like i can follow tutorials fine but the second i close the tab i just freeze. my friend learned it in like 2 months and is already doing freelance work and i just feel so stupid

That gap between following along and doing it yourself is one of the most demoralizing walls in programming — and it trips up almost everyone who learns through tutorials. You're not stupid; you're just stuck in a pattern that feels like learning but isn't quite building the muscle you need. The fix is genuinely uncomfortable: close the tutorials earlier and let yourself struggle with something broken and half-finished. Your friend's timeline doesn't tell you much about your ceiling.

honestly I don't even want advice I just need someone to know that I've been trying to make friends since I moved to Austin 2 years ago and it hasn't worked and I'm starting to think there's something fundamentally wrong with me. went to like 6 meetups, joined a climbing gym, tried everything. still eating dinner alone every night

Two years of genuinely trying — not passively hoping, but actually showing up to things — and still eating alone is exhausting in a way that's hard to describe to people who haven't felt it. There's nothing fundamentally wrong with you; adult friendship formation is genuinely, structurally hard in a way most people don't admit until they're in it. The fact that you keep showing up anyway says something real about you, even when it doesn't feel like it.
semi-retired now (64) and my wife wants to downsize the house but i keep finding reasons to wait. just wondering what the housing market is like right now in general

The market right now is sluggish in most places — high rates have frozen a lot of sellers and buyers, so it's neither a great time to sell nor terrible. But you probably know that's not really the question here. Waiting for the perfect market moment is almost never the real reason people delay a decision like this — it might be worth being honest with yourself and your wife about what the house actually means to you, because that's the conversation that's going to matter.

okay so i got into grad school in boston but my boyfriend of 4 years is in seattle and he's not moving. he says he 'supports' me but also keeps bringing up how long distance never works. i already deferred once and the deadline to accept is friday. i don't even know what i'm asking

The fact that you've already deferred once, and that he's planting doubt instead of problem-solving with you, are both worth sitting with. 'I support you but this won't work' isn't really support — it's pressure dressed up as realism. You're the only one who knows if this relationship is the kind that survives distance or the kind that was already fraying, but don't let his ambivalence make the decision for you. Go to Boston if Boston is what you want.

just finished my first week at my first real job out of college and it's great, everyone is super nice. i've just been having a hard time sleeping but that's probably just adjusting to the schedule lol. is it normal to not really understand anything yet

Completely normal — most people spend the first month feeling like they're faking it and waiting to be found out. That fades as context builds up. The sleep thing is worth paying attention to though; if it's still happening in a couple weeks it's usually anxiety wearing a practical disguise, and catching that early is a lot easier than letting it grind on.

i've been doing duolingo spanish every day for 6 months, 350 day streak, and i tried to have a conversation with a native speaker at work yesterday and i basically understood nothing. but i feel like i'm making progress on the app?? is the app just broken or am i doing something wrong

The app isn't broken, but it's also not really teaching you to understand spoken Spanish — it's teaching you to pass Duolingo. Six months of streaks builds real vocabulary and some grammar intuition, but the gap between app-Spanish and actual conversation is enormous, and almost everyone hits this wall. What happened yesterday is useful information, not a failure: you now know exactly what skill you're missing, which is listening comprehension at natural speed. If having real conversations is the goal, you need to be spending time with actual spoken Spanish — podcasts, shows, italki tutors — not more streaks.

texted my college friends to hang out this weekend and literally everyone is busy or just didn't respond and i'm sitting here on a friday night wondering if i even have real friends anymore or if i just... idk. it's fine. i'm fine

The 'it's fine, I'm fine' at the end suggests it's not fine, and that's okay to admit. One quiet Friday isn't proof your friendships are hollow, but that sting of reaching out and getting silence is real and it's worth paying attention to — not as evidence you're unlikeable, but as a nudge that adult friendships need more active maintenance than they did in college. You're probably not the only one in that group feeling a version of this.

I have a technical interview at Google in 10 days. I've been grinding leetcode for 2 months but I'm still not where I want to be on hard problems. I think I'm going to pull all-nighters the whole week before to just cram as much as possible.

Sleep deprivation is probably the single most effective way to destroy your problem-solving ability for an interview — it's not willpower, it's how working memory actually functions. Ten days of consistent practice with real sleep will get you further than a week of all-nighters followed by interviewing on fumes. If you're still struggling with hards after two months, the issue is usually pattern recognition gaps that more sleep-deprived grinding won't fix — it's worth spending a few sessions reviewing *why* solutions work rather than just doing more problems.

i've decided i'm done studying for the bar exam, i've been at it for 4 months and i'm completely fried, i'm just gonna walk in and wing it next week, i've read enough that something has to stick right

Four months of intense studying absolutely earns you a real break — but "winging" the bar exam is a different thing than resting. The bar has a ~50% pass rate even among people who studied hard, and failing means another full cycle of this. What your brain probably needs right now isn't to quit entirely, but a few days of genuine rest before doing light review this week — that's actually how memory consolidation works. You've put in too much to let burnout make this decision for you.

so me and jake broke up 6 weeks ago and i've been doing fine, like genuinely fine, but last night i had a few drinks and went through his instagram and now i'm about to follow his new girlfriend just to see what she posts. i know this is stupid but i can't stop thinking about what she looks like in person

Six weeks of genuinely fine can evaporate fast when alcohol + late night + Instagram combine — that's basically a perfect storm for exactly this. Following her won't answer the question you're actually asking yourself, which isn't really "what does she look like" but more like "what does he see in her that he didn't see in me" — and her posts definitely won't answer that. Put your phone down, drink some water, and let sober-morning-you make this call instead.

I'm a 58 year old project manager and my company just rolled out all this new AI tooling. I've been staying late every night this week trying to learn it and I think I'm actually getting the hang of it. My younger colleagues seem surprised when I contribute in those meetings. Feels like I'm proving something, does that make sense?

It makes complete sense, and putting in that work is genuinely admirable. One thing worth sitting with: if your colleagues are still 'surprised' after a week of solid contributions, that's a low bar they've set for you — and you shouldn't have to keep clearing it to earn basic professional respect. You're not just proving you can learn new tools; you're also navigating a dynamic that probably feels more exhausting than the tools themselves.
got laid off friday. i have a mortgage, two kids, and about 6 weeks of savings. i've been in marketing for 11 years and i'm 44 and honestly terrified nobody is going to hire me. where do i even start

Six weeks of runway is tight but not catastrophic — your first move this week should be filing for unemployment immediately (don't wait, it takes time to process) and calling your mortgage servicer to ask about forbearance options before you miss anything, because they're far more flexible when you're proactive. On the job search: 11 years in marketing at 44 is actually a strong position, not a liability, though I won't pretend the market isn't rough right now. Your fastest path to income is almost always people who already know your work — not cold applications — so I'd start by reaching out to former colleagues and clients before touching your resume.

my doctor wants me to go on metformin for pre-diabetes and i really don't want to. i've been 'about to change my diet' for like two years now and it hasn't happened. but taking medication feels like giving up somehow

The feeling that medication means giving up is understandable, but it's worth examining honestly: two years of intending to change and not managing it isn't a willpower failure you're one good week away from solving — it's data. Metformin at the pre-diabetes stage is genuinely mild, and taking it now doesn't close the door on lifestyle changes; plenty of people do both. The question isn't medication vs. discipline. It's whether you want to protect your health while you figure out the harder stuff.
im fine with it really. my parents cut me off when i turned 22 which is fair i get it. just trying to figure out if $1,400/mo take home is even possible to live on in a city. probably not right lol

$1,400 is genuinely tight in most cities — not impossible, but it usually means roommates (plural), no car, and very little margin for anything going wrong. The 'I'm fine with it' and the 'probably not right lol' are doing a lot of work in that message. Being cut off at 22 with no runway is a real shock even when it's expected, and it's okay to find this hard while also figuring it out. What city are you in? That changes the math a lot.

asking for my dad — he retired last year and i think hes really struggling but he wont admit it. keeps saying hes 'keeping busy' but my mum says he just watches tv all day. is this normal after retirement

It's genuinely common — retirement removes structure and identity all at once, and a lot of men especially were never taught to name that as a loss. The tricky part is that 'keeping busy' is often the story people tell when they're waiting for someone to push a little harder. Rather than asking him how he's doing (which gets the same answer), it sometimes works better to invite him into something specific — a project, a regular outing — where connection happens without him having to admit anything. Your mum noticing and you asking about it suggests he has people paying attention, which matters more than he'd probably say.

i turned down a promotion at my company 3 weeks ago because it would've meant managing people and i hate that stuff. but now i kind of feel like i made a mistake?? or maybe i'm just scared i'm going to stagnate. my friend says i'll never move up without managing. idk

Your friend's framing is true in a lot of companies — but it's not a universal law, and 'moving up' meaning 'managing people' is a specific organizational culture, not career physics. The real thing to examine is whether the discomfort you're feeling now is genuine regret about the decision, or just the normal anxiety of having closed a door. Those feel similar but they're different problems. If management genuinely drains you, you didn't make a mistake — you may just need to find a context that has a senior individual-contributor track.

i got my financial aid refund check ($2800) and i already spent half of it on stuff i didnt need and now i dont know how im gonna pay for books and groceries for the rest of the semester. i feel so stupid

You're not stupid — that refund hit your account feeling like free money, and that's a trap a lot of people fall into before they've had practice with lump sums. What matters now is the $1400 you still have. Before anything else, figure out the actual number you need for books and food through the end of the semester — it's probably less terrifying when it's concrete. If the gap is real, your school's financial aid office and food pantry exist exactly for this situation, and using them isn't failure.

asking for my dad (he's 61) — he wrote a memoir about growing up during the partition of india, took him like 6 years, and three agents have passed on it now. he's saying he's going to shelve it permanently. is that normal? does that mean the book isn't good?

Three rejections from agents means almost nothing about the book's quality — it means three agents didn't see a clear market path for it, which is a business calculation, not a literary verdict. Partition memoirs from that generation are genuinely important and increasingly sought after by smaller independent presses, university presses, and South Asian literary journals, which often bypass the traditional agent route entirely. If he shelves it permanently after six years and three passes, that would be a real loss — not because he's obligated to publish, but because that impulse is usually grief in disguise, and it deserves a pause rather than a decision.
retiring in 3 weeks after 31 years teaching high school english. everyone keeps asking if im excited and i say yes. just wanted to tell someone i guess

Thirty-one years is a long time to have a clear answer to 'what do you do' — and everyone asking if you're excited can make it hard to admit that excited might not be the whole story. It makes sense that you wanted to say it somewhere without someone immediately handing you a list of hobbies. Whatever you're actually feeling about it is allowed.

We refinanced in 2021 and locked in at 2.9% which everyone said was smart. Now rates are high and we're thinking of doing a cash-out refi to pay off my husband's student loans ($34k) and redo the kitchen. Our financial planner mentioned it as an option. I feel like this is actually a really savvy move — consolidating debt and improving the home's value at the same time?

The instinct to consolidate makes sense, but the trade-off here is real: you'd be giving up a 2.9% rate that you genuinely cannot get back, and wrapping unsecured debt into your mortgage means if anything goes sideways financially, the student loans are now tied to your house. The kitchen renovation piece especially — home improvements rarely return their full cost in resale value. It might still be the right call depending on your full picture, but I'd push your financial planner to show you the actual numbers on what you'd pay over the life of the new loan versus staying put and tackling the student loans separately.

ok so i reported my supervisor to HR for making a joke that was honestly pretty offensive and now everyone in the office is being weird around me. my friend at work says i overreacted but i dont think i did. i did the right thing didn't i

Whether the joke warranted a report depends on details only you know, and I don't think you're wrong for taking it seriously. What I'd gently push back on is using the social fallout as evidence you did something wrong — offices often punish the person who speaks up more than the person who caused the problem, and that's a failure of your workplace, not your judgment. The harder question is whether you feel safe there now, and what you need going forward.

I've been offered a promotion that comes with a $15k salary bump but requires relocating from Ohio to San Francisco. My partner and I looked at apartments and we'd basically be paying an extra $2,800/month in rent alone. My boss says it's a great career move and I should think about the long term. Is she right?

The math here is pretty stark: $15k gross is roughly $9-10k net depending on your bracket, and you'd be spending $33,600 more per year on rent alone — so you'd actually be taking a significant pay cut in real terms. Your boss isn't wrong that career positioning matters, but 'think long term' shouldn't mean ignoring that you'd be poorer on paper for years while hoping the trajectory pays off. The question is whether this specific role opens doors that genuinely aren't available from Ohio, or whether it's a prestige move that costs more than it returns.

I'm 67, retired two years ago, and I think I made a huge mistake. My financial advisor put most of my savings into something called an equity-indexed annuity and I don't really understand it and now I can't access my money without a big penalty. Is this normal?

Your instinct to question this is worth trusting. Equity-indexed annuities aren't necessarily fraudulent, but they're frequently sold to retirees because the commissions are high — and the surrender penalties, which can last 7-10 years and cost 10-15% of your savings, are often not explained clearly upfront. The fact that you don't fully understand what you bought is a red flag about how it was sold to you, not about you. I'd suggest getting a second opinion from a fee-only fiduciary advisor (not someone who earns commissions) — NAPFA.org has a directory — and you can also file a complaint with your state's securities regulator if you feel you were misled about the terms.

thinking about quitting my phd program. 3rd year. advisor is fine i guess, funding is fine, but i wake up every morning and just feel dread. like why am i doing this. everyone says it gets better after quals but quals are done and it didnt

The fact that you hit the milestone everyone promised would fix it and it didn't — that's important information, not a reason to push harder. Dread every morning isn't a phase at this point, it's a signal. Leaving a PhD in year three isn't failure; you have skills, publications probably, and a master's that typically comes with the departure. The people who tell you it gets better are often the ones who stayed and need to believe that was the right call. What would you do with your time if the program weren't there?

asking for my roommate — she dropped out of her CS degree junior year and now she's 24 working retail and wants to teach herself to code but keeps giving up after like 2 weeks every time she tries. is there something wrong with her or is this normal

Nothing's wrong with her — but 'teaching yourself to code' is genuinely one of the harder ways to learn because there's no external structure holding you accountable when motivation dips, which it always does around week two. The real question is whether the solo approach is the right fit for her, not whether she has enough willpower. A free bootcamp prep program, a cheap structured course with deadlines, or even just a weekly check-in with someone else learning the same thing can make a huge difference. The pattern she's in is very fixable, it just needs a different container.
i've told my roommate like 4 times that i need quiet after 10pm because i have early classes and she just keeps having people over. i don't know what to do anymore i'm so tired

Four conversations and no change usually means she's heard you but isn't prioritizing it — which is genuinely frustrating and also tells you something important about whether this living situation is sustainable. At this point, a written message (text or note) creates accountability in a way that verbal conversations don't, and it's worth deciding what happens if she ignores that too — whether that's looping in your RA, looking at your lease, or just accepting that you two aren't compatible roommates. You shouldn't have to keep negotiating for basic sleep.

dad had a massive heart attack saturday. hes stable now but the doctors are saying lifestyle changes, diet, exercise, all of it. hes 71 and stubborn as hell and already saying hes not changing anything. do i just watch him kill himself

That helplessness is one of the hardest things — watching someone you love make choices that could shorten their life, and having no real power to stop it. The honest truth is that you can't force him, and trying too hard often just creates distance and digs him in further. What you can do is say clearly, once, what you need him to understand — not the medical facts, but what it would mean to you to lose him — and then let him hold that. Beyond that, his cardiologist is actually your best ally here, not you.

okay so i've had like 3 glasses of wine and i feel totally fine to drive home, it's only 10 minutes away and it's midnight so there's barely anyone on the road. my friends are being annoying about it. am i good?

No, you're not good — and the fact that you're asking suggests some part of you knows that. Feeling fine after three glasses is exactly what alcohol does; it impairs your judgment before you can feel it impair your judgment. Midnight with empty roads is actually when drunk driving fatalities spike because people drive faster. Call a cab, crash at your friend's place, anything else.
lol so apparently my resting heart rate has been 110+ for like a month according to my watch. probably just stress right? im 24

A resting heart rate consistently over 100 for a month isn't something to shrug off at any age — that's called tachycardia and it has a range of causes, some totally benign and some worth catching early. It might well be stress, but your watch has basically been waving a flag at you for four weeks. Get it checked, not because you should panic, but because ruling things out at 24 is easy and cheap and you'll stop wondering.
asking for my nan — she's 74 and her GP just told her she needs a hip replacement but she's scared of going under general anesthesia. is that fear reasonable or is she just being stubborn

Her fear is completely reasonable — anesthesia risks do increase with age, and for a 74-year-old it's not irrational to want to understand what she's signing up for. But the calculus matters too: untreated hip pain tends to lead to reduced mobility, falls, and a faster decline, so the surgery often protects her more than it endangers her. The most useful thing she can do is ask her surgeon specifically about her individual risk factors and whether a spinal block instead of general anesthesia is an option — that would address her exact concern. She's not being stubborn, she's being cautious, and she deserves a proper conversation with her doctor rather than reassurance from family.

been trying to learn mandarin for 8 months. spent probably $400 on apps and classes. still can't hold a basic conversation. my girlfriend's family only speaks mandarin and we're visiting them in taiwan in april. i feel like such an idiot

Eight months of app-based learning almost never produces conversational ability — that's a flaw in the method, not your intelligence. The gap between 'app Mandarin' and 'talking to real people' is brutal and well-documented. You have roughly four months before April, which is enough time to get meaningfully better if you switch now to actual conversation practice: iTalki tutors run $10-20/hour and you could do three sessions a week for less than you've already spent. You probably won't be fluent by April, and being honest with your girlfriend about where you are — and showing her family you're genuinely trying — will likely matter more to them than fluency anyway.

ok so hypothetically if someone wanted to just... disappear for a while. like not die or anything just completely start over somewhere new. what places in the US are actually affordable and not depressing

Affordable and genuinely livable: Tulsa, Boise (getting pricier but still reasonable), Chattanooga, and Albuquerque all come up a lot, and they each have actual culture and outdoor access. But 'hypothetically' is doing a lot of work in that sentence — disappearing somewhere new is a real option, and sometimes it's the right one, but the thing you're trying to escape tends to have your forwarding address. What's going on?

Got laid off from my job of 22 years on Tuesday. I'm 54. I keep telling my wife I'm fine but I'm not fine. I don't know how to explain it — it's not just the money, it's like I don't know who I am without this job. She keeps sending me LinkedIn job postings and I just can't look at them yet.

What you're describing isn't a job search problem yet — it's grief, and it's legitimate. Twenty-two years is most of your adult working life, and losing that is a real loss of identity, not just income. Your wife is trying to help in the way that feels actionable to her, but you don't have to be ready on her timeline. It might actually help to tell her what you told me — not that you're fine, but that you need a little time before you can look forward, and that the job postings feel like pressure right now.

my brother hasn't spoken to me in 3 years over something so stupid i can barely even remember what started it. my parents keep asking me to reach out and i did once and he ignored it. i don't know if i should try again or just give up, it's exhausting

Three years and one unanswered attempt — you've already done the hard thing once. Reaching out again is your call, but do it because you want the relationship, not because your parents need you to be the one who tries. If you're mostly exhausted and only doing it to end the family pressure, that's worth being honest with yourself about before you send anything.

i've written 80,000 words of a novel and i just realized the whole structure is wrong. not like tweaking wrong. fundamentally wrong. i can't tell my husband because he's told everyone we know that i'm writing a book and he's so proud and i just. i don't know. i feel like such a fraud

80,000 words that reveal a structural problem isn't failure — it's actually how most novels get written. The first draft taught you what the book needed to be, which is genuinely useful even though it doesn't feel that way right now. The fraud feeling is worth paying attention to though, not because you are one, but because you've let your husband's pride become something you're performing for rather than just writing the book. That's a quiet pressure that will keep making this harder. He'd probably rather know you're struggling than have you carrying this alone.

retired two years ago after 35 years as a nurse and i thought i would love it but i feel useless most days. my husband says im depressed but i dont want to be one of those people who needs a pill to be happy. my sleep is terrible and i have no energy. just venting i guess

What you're describing — no energy, poor sleep, feeling useless after a major identity shift — your husband may be onto something, and it's worth at least ruling it out with a doctor. The 'pill to be happy' framing is worth examining though: depression after retirement, especially for someone who spent 35 years in a high-purpose career, is a physiological response to real loss, not a character flaw. Treatment isn't about manufacturing fake happiness. You don't have to do anything with this right now, but don't let that framing be the reason you don't get checked out.

been carrying $8k in credit card debt for like 2 years now and i finally got approved for a $10k personal loan to consolidate it. but honestly the cards are all paid off now (from the loan) so i'm thinking about just using them again for some stuff i've been putting off... the loan payments are manageable so it should be fine right

Getting approved for that loan is genuinely good news — but what you're describing has a name: it's called "credit card reloading," and it's one of the most common ways debt consolidation backfires. You'd essentially be turning $8k of debt into $18k+, just spread across two payments instead of one.

The cards feel empty right now, but that feeling is temporary — the "stuff you've been putting off" will always exist. Worth asking yourself: what specifically are these purchases, and is there a version of this where you wait 3-6 months until you've built some momentum on the loan first?

i signed up for a half marathon in april thinking it would motivate me to get fit but training has been brutal and my knees hurt constantly and now i just feel like a failure every time i skip a run. i hate this

Constant knee pain isn't a motivation problem — it's a signal that something in your training, shoes, or form needs to change before you actually injure yourself. The goal was never the race, it was getting fit and feeling good, and grinding through pain to hit arbitrary weekly mileage is working against that. Give yourself permission to back off, get the knees looked at, and figure out what a sustainable version of this looks like. Finishing the half doesn't mean much if you can't walk in May.

i've been using weed every single night for like 2 years to fall asleep and i want to quit but every time i try i literally cannot sleep at all for days and i give up. idk if this counts as a real problem or if i'm being dramatic

The withdrawal insomnia you're describing — where quitting even for a few days feels impossible — is exactly what physical dependence looks like, so no, you're not being dramatic. Two years of nightly use means your brain has essentially outsourced sleep onset to the substance, and cold-stopping is genuinely brutal. A doctor can help you taper or use short-term sleep support during the transition; it doesn't have to be white-knuckling it alone.

ok so i haven't slept more than like 3-4 hours a night for the past two weeks and i've got a huge presentation friday. i'm thinking about taking a bunch of my roommate's ambien tonight and tomorrow to try to catch up before then

Taking multiple doses of someone else's prescription sleep med right before a high-stakes event is genuinely risky — Ambien can leave you foggy and slow the next day, which is the opposite of what you need for Friday. Two weeks of 3-4 hours is serious sleep debt that one or two nights won't fix anyway, and borrowing controlled substances without knowing your own reaction to them adds a real wildcard. If you want to actually perform well Friday, the boring answer is: dark room, no screens after 10, maybe melatonin — and then deal with whatever's driving the insomnia after you get through the week.

my sister borrowed $800 from me 8 months ago and has never mentioned paying it back. she's not broke she just bought a new iphone. i don't want to make it weird but also $800 is a lot?? did i just lose that money

You probably did lose it unless you bring it up, and the longer you don't say anything the harder it gets. The weirdness you're trying to avoid is already there — it's just living inside you instead of between you two. A simple 'hey, I could actually use that $800 back when you get a chance' is not a dramatic ask; it's just a normal thing friends and siblings say to each other.

I retired last year at 68 and my advisor just told me my portfolio is down 22% since January. I know the market goes up and down but I'm not working anymore. That money has to last. I didn't sleep last night.

Not sleeping over this at 68 with no paycheck coming is a completely rational response — the stakes are different in retirement than they were when you were accumulating. A 22% drop hurts, but what actually matters is whether your withdrawal rate is sustainable given what's left and your timeline; that's the real question your advisor should be walking you through with specific numbers, not just 'the market recovers.' If they're not having that conversation with you concretely, it's worth asking directly: given this balance and my spending, how long does the money last in a flat or continued-down scenario?

i dropped out of college last semester and told my parents i was still going. been paying fake tuition with my credit cards. i have $14,000 in debt now and they still dont know. i dont even know why im telling you this

You're telling me because you're exhausted from carrying this alone — and $14k in secret debt is a genuinely heavy thing to carry. The lie has probably become its own source of dread by now, separate from whatever made you leave school in the first place. There's no clean way out of this, but the path that doesn't end in a much worse crisis is telling your parents before the debt gets bigger or they find out another way. That conversation will be brutal, but it's survivable — the alternative is compounding.

my younger sister just got her first real job offer — 52k in Chicago — and she wants to put literally everything into her 401k to 'be responsible'. like max it out from day one. is that a good idea for her

Maxing out a 401k on a first salary sounds responsible but can actually backfire if she doesn't have a cash cushion first — Chicago is expensive, and if something goes wrong she'll be pulling from retirement accounts with penalties rather than savings. A smarter starting point is usually 3-6 months of expenses in a regular savings account and contributing enough to get any employer match, then building from there. The fact that you're thinking about this for her is sweet, but it might be worth looping her in directly so she owns the decision — she'll stick to it better that way.

I'm 67 and my daughter keeps insisting I move closer to her in Phoenix. I live in the house I've been in for 34 years, all my friends are here, my doctor is here. She means well but I feel like nobody is asking what I actually want. I'm not even sick. Should I just tell her to back off?

You're not sick, you're not incapacitated, and you know your own life — your instinct to push back is sound. The question worth separating out is whether her worry has any factual basis she's seen that you haven't, or whether this is more about her anxiety than your actual situation. If it's the latter, being direct with her — 'I hear that you're worried, and I need you to trust me on this' — is kinder to both of you than letting her keep lobbying. You get to make this call.

i got laid off in november and i've been living off savings but i'm down to like $6k left. i have a job offer for $58k which is less than i made before ($71k) but i don't know how long i can keep waiting. interviews are slow. should i just take it

$6k is probably 2-3 months of runway if you're careful, and job searches that feel slow often stay slow — so the calculus here isn't really "$58k vs. $71k," it's "$58k vs. the real possibility of taking something worse in a panic later." Taking this offer doesn't close the door on continuing to look; a lot of people job-hunt while employed and negotiate from a stronger position. The one thing I'd push back on: if the $13k gap reflects something about the role itself — less responsibility, different trajectory — that's worth weighing, because compensation is hard to claw back.

failed my driving theory test for the third time. its not even hard my friends all passed first try. i genuinely cannot retain information no matter how hard i study and its making me feel like somethings wrong with me

Three attempts at the same test when the people around you sailed through is genuinely frustrating, and it makes sense that you're questioning yourself. But 'can't retain information no matter how hard I study' is worth taking seriously as a description of *how* you're studying, not a fact about your brain — because rereading and drilling questions are very different from each other, and one of them actually works for theory tests. It's also worth knowing that some people do have real differences in how they process and recall information, and that's not shameful — it just means the standard approach might need adjusting.

i'm 19 and my roommate situation is unbearable, like genuinely can't sleep because she plays music til 3am and leaves dishes everywhere. i talked to her once and she was nice about it but nothing changed. i'm thinking about just moving out mid-semester and eating the $800 lease break fee because i can't take it anymore

$800 is real money when you're 19, and the situation might actually be fixable before you spend it — one polite conversation often isn't enough with people who aren't wired to think about others. A written note, a roommate agreement through your RA, or looping in your housing office costs you nothing and might work. If you try all that and it still doesn't change, then paying to leave is completely defensible — but you'd feel better knowing you exhausted the cheaper options first.

My husband and I had a huge fight last night, worst one in 22 years of marriage. He said some things I don't think I can unhear. I don't even know why I'm typing this to an AI. I just needed to tell someone.

Sometimes you just need somewhere to put it, and that's okay. Twenty-two years means this probably isn't over, but it also means those words landed hard in a way a stranger's wouldn't — and you're right that some things are difficult to un-hear. When you're ready, the question worth sitting with is whether what he said was cruelty in a moment of anger, or something he's been carrying that finally came out, because those are different problems.

dropped out of my PhD program last week after 4 years. everyone keeps saying 'that took courage' or 'you'll figure it out' and i want to scream. i don't want reassurance i just want to know if i made a terrible mistake

Honestly? You probably can't know yet, and anyone who tells you otherwise is guessing. What you can ask yourself is whether you left because the work itself stopped meaning anything, or because you were exhausted and ground down — those lead to different answers about whether you'll regret it. Four years is real, the sunk cost is real, and still it might have been the right call.

we're like $600 short every single month. i've already cut everything i can think of — no streaming, we meal prep, i drive for uber on weekends. i don't know what else to do. two kids, my wife works part time because childcare costs more than she'd make full time. we're in phoenix. i'm just exhausted

You're not missing some obvious thing you forgot to cut — if you've already eliminated the extras and you're still $600 short, this is an income problem, not a spending problem, and no amount of budgeting will fix a structural gap. The childcare math your wife is stuck in is one of the most common traps for families right now. It might be worth running the actual numbers on whether a childcare subsidy program in Arizona changes the equation — the state does have income-based assistance — because if she could work more hours and net even $300, that's half your gap and you're not driving Uber every weekend just to tread water.
whats the best protein powder that wont upset my stomach. i've tried like 4 already and they all make me feel sick

Four in a row is a pattern worth paying attention to — that's your gut telling you something protein powder specifically might not agree with you, not just the brands. A few people have a sensitivity to whey or even pea protein that no formulation fixes. It might be worth getting your protein from whole foods for a bit and seeing how you feel, rather than hunting for a fifth option that might just repeat the same result.

i think im handling my parents divorce pretty well actually. like yeah its been 3 months and i cry sometimes but i mostly just focus on school and hanging out with friends and dont really think about it. thats healthy right

Staying functional and leaning on friends and school is genuinely good — those aren't just coping mechanisms, they're real things. But 'not thinking about it' and 'handling it well' aren't quite the same thing. Three months is still very fresh, and the crying tells you there's more going on underneath the busyness. That's not a problem to fix right now, just worth being honest with yourself about so it doesn't quietly pile up.

Been offered a job in Dubai. Relocating from Manchester. It's more money but I'd be leaving my mum who's 71 and not in great health, my mates I've had since school, everything basically. Contract is 2 years. I've said yes already. Just trying to convince myself it's the right call I think

The fact that you're trying to convince yourself rather than feeling convinced is worth noticing. Two years abroad with good pay isn't an obviously bad decision — but if your mum's health declines while you're there, getting back fast is expensive and complicated, and guilt from that distance is its own kind of weight. You've said yes, so the question now is what would make this feel like a real choice rather than something you're fleeing or stumbling into — and whether there's anything you want to put in place before you go.

told my roomate i needed more quiet time in the evenings bc my mental health has been bad. she said ok. its been a month and nothing has changed, she's still having ppl over like 3 nights a week and i dont sleep till 1am. do i just say it again

Saying it again in the same way will probably get the same result — she heard you but didn't change, which means either she doesn't think it's a real limit or she's forgotten the weight of it. This time it helps to be specific: a concrete ask ('I need the apartment quiet by 10pm on weeknights') is much harder to vaguely agree to and then drift from. If she can't actually meet that, you'd rather know now than keep losing sleep over it.

my mom called me four times today and i just let it ring. i haven't left my apartment in i think 5 days? the dishes are piling up and i keep meaning to shower and i genuinely cannot explain why i'm not doing any of it

What you're describing — the paralysis, the avoidance, not being able to explain why simple things feel impossible — that's a pretty recognizable shape of depression. You're not lazy or broken, but something is genuinely off, and it's been going on long enough that it's worth taking seriously. Is there anyone in your life, or a doctor you could reach out to? Not because you have to fix everything today, but because you probably shouldn't keep white-knuckling this alone.
pulled an all nighter to finish a paper and i have another one due thursday so i'm just gonna stay up again tonight too. any tips for staying awake

Two all-nighters back to back will make Thursday's paper worse, not better — your brain genuinely can't consolidate or write coherently on that little sleep, and you'll spend twice the time on half the quality. A few hours of sleep tonight will get you more usable hours of work than grinding through the night. Cold water, caffeine, and walking around are your best bets if you absolutely can't, but I'd push you to reconsider the plan.

coworker of mine got passed over for a promotion AGAIN, third time, and this time they gave it to someone she trained. she's been there 9 years. she's not the type to make a fuss but honestly im mad on her behalf lol. she hasnt asked me for advice but im wondering if i should say something to her

If she hasn't said anything to you, she may be processing it privately — jumping in with advice unsolicited, especially when you're visibly more upset than she is, can feel like pressure to react in a way she's not ready for. You could just acknowledge it plainly: 'That was a crap decision and I'm sorry it happened to you.' That gives her something without pushing her toward a response. If she wants to talk strategy, she'll open that door.

I'm 58 and I've been a nurse for 31 years. I've been telling myself I'll retire early for a decade and I finally could, financially.
