But my daughter says I'll be bored and depressed without the structure. She might be right, I don't know. I'm so tired. Does early retirement ever actually work out for people?

Your daughter's concern is worth taking seriously, but there's a difference between 'retirement is risky for some people' and 'retirement is wrong for you specifically' — and she may not have the full picture of how tired you actually are. Thirty-one years of nursing is a long time to carry that weight, and chronic exhaustion can itself cause the flat affect and loss of purpose that people mistake for early retirement's side effects. The more useful question might be: what do you want your weeks to look like, concretely? That's more predictive of how it goes than the retirement label itself.

colleague of mine has been working on a novel for like 6 years. she finally let someone read it and they said it wasn't ready to submit anywhere yet. she's completely devastated and talking about scrapping the whole thing. is that a normal reaction or is she being dramatic

Completely normal — six years of work is six years of identity wrapped up in one document, so one piece of critical feedback landing on top of that can feel like a verdict on her whole self, not just the manuscript. She's not being dramatic, she's being human. The scrapping impulse almost always passes if she gives herself a week before making any decisions, and 'not ready to submit' from one reader is genuinely not the same as 'this doesn't work.'

my mom called me yesterday and basically said if i don't come home for christmas she's cutting me off financially. i'm 22 and still on her phone plan and she helps with rent sometimes. the thing is my boyfriend's family already bought me a plane ticket to visit them in denver and i really don't want to cancel that but i also literally cannot afford to lose her help right now. she does this every year but this time felt different idk

The "this time felt different" instinct is worth paying attention to — you know your mom's patterns better than anyone. The real question isn't just this Christmas, it's whether you want to keep living in a dynamic where holiday plans (and probably other things) get decided by financial threat. That's a longer conversation worth having with yourself, separate from the immediate logistics. For right now: is there any version where you talk to her directly — not to negotiate, but to tell her you already have plans and see how she actually responds rather than assuming the worst?

I've been struggling with calculus for weeks and my exam is in 3 days. I just decided I'm going to skip studying it and focus only on the chapters I already know well so I can feel confident going in. makes sense right

It makes emotional sense — studying what you already know feels good and avoids that sinking feeling. But if calculus is on the exam, avoiding it for three days means you're banking on it not mattering, which is a risky bet. Even getting the basics down — derivatives, a few problem types — in two focused hours could meaningfully move your score. You don't need to master it, just stop it from being a zero.

My daughter is 8 and her teacher called me today to say she's falling behind in reading. I feel like such a failure as a mom. I work full time and I just don't have the hours to sit with her every night and I keep thinking — what if she struggles with this her whole life because I wasn't there enough

That fear — that your unavailability now becomes her permanent ceiling — is one of the most painful things a parent can carry, and it's also not how reading development works. Eight is well within the window where intervention makes a real difference, and the fact that her teacher caught it and called you means there's a team already paying attention. You being a working mom isn't the variable that determines this outcome; getting her the right support now is. Talk to the teacher about what specific help looks like — whether that's a reading specialist, targeted exercises, or something you could do in 10 minutes at bedtime — because this is solvable.

retired two years ago and thought the exhaustion would go away. it hasn't. i sleep fine, i'm not doing much, and i'm still tired all the time. my kids keep telling me to exercise more but i've tried the walks and it doesn't help

Persistent fatigue after retirement that doesn't respond to rest or light exercise — especially when sleep is actually fine — is something worth investigating medically rather than pushing through. Thyroid issues, anemia, sleep apnea, depression, and a handful of other things can all produce exactly this, and they're common in this life stage. The walks aren't a bad idea in general, but they're not going to fix a physiological cause. If you haven't had bloodwork done recently with fatigue specifically on the table, that's the most useful next step.
tried selling stuff around the house to cover rent gap, made maybe $180 on fb marketplace. still $400 short. rent's due friday. idk

Friday is close, so the fastest real options are: call your landlord today — not Friday — and ask for a few extra days or a partial payment arrangement. Many will say yes if you ask before you're already late, not after. Local emergency rental assistance programs exist in most cities and sometimes move fast, so worth a 10-minute search for your area. The $180 you made shows you're trying; the next move is just a direct conversation with the person who actually holds the deadline.

My husband and I have been to couples counseling twice before and it helped for maybe a month each time and then we just go back to the same patterns. Our therapist suggested we try again but I honestly don't know if I have the energy for another round of temporary improvement.

That exhaustion is worth taking seriously — it's not just fatigue, it's data. Temporary improvement that resets suggests the sessions might be surfacing the right issues without changing the underlying dynamic, which is actually a counseling problem as much as a marriage problem. It might be worth asking your therapist directly: what would we do differently this time, and why would the outcome be different?

i haven't slept more than like 2-3 hours a night for the past two weeks and i keep telling myself it'll pass but today i almost fell asleep driving home from the grocery store and i just... i don't know how much longer i can keep doing this

Two weeks of 2-3 hours a night is serious sleep deprivation, and nearly falling asleep at the wheel is your body telling you it's reached a limit — that part isn't something you can just push through. Please don't drive again until you've slept, genuinely. The "it'll pass" framing has been wrong for two weeks now, which means something is actively keeping you awake — stress, anxiety, pain, something medical — and that's worth figuring out, probably with a doctor sooner rather than later. What do you think is at the root of it?

i've been trying to learn guitar for 6 months and i still can't play a single song all the way through without messing up. everyone else in my beginner class picked it up so fast and i just... i don't know. maybe i'm one of those people who just can't do music

Six months feels long when you're inside it, but it's actually not that long for guitar — and comparing your progress to a class is a trap, because you have no idea how much some of those people are practicing at home or whether they have prior musical experience. The 'some people just can't do music' story is almost never true; it's usually a disguise for 'I'm frustrated and need this to feel possible again.' What does your practice actually look like day to day?
my sister just lost her job and she has like 2 months of savings. she's panicking and i don't really know how to help. she lives in austin

Two months of runway is tight but it's not nothing — the most useful thing right now is probably helping her stop the bleed before she does anything drastic. Texas has relatively fast unemployment processing if she hasn't filed yet, and Austin has a solid job market in tech and healthcare. But honestly, the panic is probably making it hard for her to think clearly, and sometimes what helps most is just someone sitting down with her and making the list of actual numbers — what's coming in, what has to go out, what can wait. You being willing to do that with her might matter more than any specific advice.

retired last year and my son keeps calling to check in which is nice but he mentioned maybe moving me closer to them and i dont want to leave my house ive lived here 35 years. i was thinking ill just agree to look at places so he stops worrying but i dont actually plan to move

Going along with house tours you have no intention of considering is going to waste everyone's time and probably create a bigger conflict when he realizes you were never serious. Your son is worried about you — that's worth a real conversation, even if it's uncomfortable. You're allowed to say 'I hear that you're concerned and I love you for it, but I'm not ready to leave, and I need you to trust me on this.' That's honest, and it respects both of you.
just found out my husband has been hiding a second credit card with like $34k on it. we have two kids. i don't even know where to start. do i need a lawyer

Yes, talk to a lawyer — most family law attorneys do a free 30-minute consultation, and you need to understand what liability you actually have for that debt before you make any other decisions. Don't move money, don't close accounts, and don't sign anything until you've had that conversation. Whatever you decide about the marriage, knowing your legal position first gives you actual choices instead of just reacting.

been trying to learn excel for months because my job literally requires it now and they're going to 'reassess my role' in q1 if i can't get up to speed. pivot tables make zero sense to me no matter how many youtube videos i watch. i'm 47 and i feel like my brain just doesn't work the same way anymore idk

The "my brain doesn't work the same way" thing — that's anxiety talking, not neuroscience. What's actually happening is that YouTube tutorials assume context you don't have yet, and pivot tables genuinely are confusing when taught abstractly.

Here's what actually works: open Excel, use *your own job's data*, and build one pivot table with a specific question you actually need answered at work. That concrete purpose cuts through the confusion faster than any tutorial, because suddenly the tool has a reason to exist.

The Q1 deadline is real pressure, but you've been learning the wrong way, not slowly — those are very different problems.

My therapist keeps pushing me to talk about my childhood and I really don't want to. I'm thinking of just stopping therapy altogether, I don't need that stuff dug up. I have a work thing I need to cope with, that's it

That frustration is worth taking seriously — a therapist who keeps steering toward things you've explicitly said you don't want to explore right now isn't listening to you, and you're allowed to redirect. But quitting therapy entirely because of a mismatch with this particular therapist would be throwing out something useful because of a fit problem. It's worth telling her directly: 'I need to focus on the work situation, not my childhood' — if she can't work that way, finding someone who does CBT or solution-focused work might actually give you what you're looking for.

i quit my corporate job in march to freelance and honestly it's been 6 months of barely scraping by. made like $11k total. my parents keep asking when i'm getting a 'real job' and part of me wonders if they're right but i also can't imagine going back. probably just needed to vent idk

$11k in six months is rough, and it's fair to ask whether this is 'early freelance is always slow' or 'this particular path isn't working.' Those are different problems with different answers. The version of you that can't imagine going back deserves to be taken seriously — but so does the version that's stressed about money every month. What would need to be true by, say, month 12 for you to feel like this was actually working?

I think I had a panic attack at work today for the first time. I'm 34 and this has never happened to me. I was in the middle of a normal meeting and suddenly I couldn't breathe and I thought I was having a heart attack and had to leave. I told everyone I had food poisoning. The project we're on has been brutal — 6am to midnight most days for the past 2 months — but I always thought I could handle pressure. I don't know what this means.

First — if you haven't ruled out a cardiac cause, please see a doctor, because chest symptoms and breathlessness warrant that even if it was almost certainly a panic attack. But if it was panic: your body just sent you a very clear message that what you've been doing for two months is not sustainable, no matter how much your identity is built around handling pressure. 'I always thought I could handle it' and 'I can handle anything indefinitely' are different things. The schedule you're describing isn't a temporary crunch anymore — it's damage accumulating. That's worth taking seriously before your body escalates.

My team lead keeps cc'ing my director on emails where she's correcting minor mistakes I make. It's humiliating and I think she's trying to push me out. I've only been here 4 months. I'm not wrong to be upset about this, am I

No, that's not a small thing — cc'ing your director on corrections is a choice, and it's a pointed one. You're right to pay attention to it. That said, four months in, it's genuinely hard to know if this is political, if she has concerns about your work she hasn't voiced directly, or if this is just how she operates with everyone. Before deciding she's trying to push you out, it might be worth a direct conversation with her — both because you might learn something useful, and because if things escalate, you'll want to have tried that first.

I've been working on this same painting for like 6 weeks and I finally just... finished it? or I think I did. showed my friend Maya and she said it was 'really interesting' which could mean literally anything. but honestly I think it might be the best thing I've ever made. like genuinely. am I just not able to see my own work clearly or is it possible it's actually good

Both things can be true — you might be seeing your own work clearly *and* it might actually be good. Six weeks of deep focus often produces something real. Maya's "really interesting" is genuinely ambiguous and probably not worth reading into much either way. Trust the feeling you have about it, but also let some time pass before you decide — a week away from it will tell you more than any friend's reaction right now.

my mom keeps calling me every single day crying about how my dad ignores her and idk what to do anymore. i love her but i have a 2 year old and i'm 8 months pregnant and i'm so exhausted. she called 4 times yesterday. i feel terrible even typing this

You don't need to feel terrible — you're not abandoning her by having limits, you're surviving a genuinely hard situation. What's happening is that your mom has made you her emotional support system for her marriage, and that's not a role you should be filling, especially right now. A kind but firm 'Mom, I love you, but I can only talk twice a week right now — I'm about to have a newborn' isn't cruelty, it's honesty. She may push back, but protecting your capacity to actually be present for your kids isn't selfish, it's necessary.

my doctor wants me to start blood pressure medication but honestly I'd rather just try cutting salt for a month and see what happens. my reading was 158/96. is there a low sodium diet plan I can follow

158/96 is high enough that your doctor isn't being overcautious — at that level, the risk of stroke and heart damage is meaningfully elevated, and diet changes alone rarely bring numbers down fast enough to offset that risk in the short term. That said, a low-sodium diet is genuinely worth doing alongside medication, not instead of it. Have the conversation with your doctor directly — tell them you want to try dietary changes too, and ask if they'd be willing to recheck in 6 weeks with both in place. Most will work with you on that.

i've been doing doordash on weekends to make extra cash but it's not really adding up. someone in a facebook group said i can make way more doing crypto trading and offered to teach me his 'system' for $400. i'm tempted honestly

That Facebook offer is almost certainly a scam — the 'pay me to teach you my system' pitch is one of the oldest ones out there, and the people running it make their money selling the course, not trading. The $400 you'd spend is probably more than you've made dashing in a month. If the side income isn't working, that's worth figuring out, but this isn't the answer.

asking for my dad (he's 67) — he retired last year and started painting for the first time ever and he genuinely loves it but now he's been invited to show two pieces at a local gallery and he's completely freaked out and saying he doesn't deserve to be there alongside 'real artists'. is this normal or is something actually wrong

What he's feeling is completely normal — imposter syndrome hits hardest right when something becomes real, and a gallery invitation is very real. But there's something worth sitting with here: he's 67, he found something that genuinely lights him up, and the world responded by saying yes. The fear of not deserving it is almost always the feeling right before the thing that matters most. If you can, tell him that the gallery invited him because they saw the work, not because they felt sorry for a retiree.

My colleague Priya has been trying to pass the PMP exam for the third time. She studies constantly and I genuinely don't know what else to tell her. She's starting to think she's just bad at tests. Is there anything different she can do at this point

Three attempts is demoralizing, and it makes sense she's starting to internalize it — but the PMP has a very specific logic that doesn't always reward general studying. The most common issue for repeat test-takers is studying content instead of studying *how PMI thinks*: the exam is mostly situational judgment, not knowledge recall. If she hasn't used the official ECO (Exam Content Outline) as her primary guide, or hasn't practiced heavily with PMI-style scenario questions rather than just flashcards, that's likely the gap. It might also be worth a conversation about whether the exam format itself is working against her in some way — some people do genuinely struggle with that style of question and need different prep strategies.

i'm 31 and moving back in with my parents next month because rent in seattle is just impossible. i keep telling myself it's a smart financial move but honestly i feel like such a failure. my friends all have their own places. it's temporary, like 6 months max. does this actually make sense or am i just rationalizing

The math is real — Seattle rents are brutal, and six months of saved rent is not nothing. The failure feeling is worth separating from the actual decision, because those are two different things: one is a story you're telling yourself based on comparison, the other is a practical question with a pretty clear answer. You're not rationalizing. You're just also embarrassed, which is allowed.

genuinely cannot remember the last time i felt okay. been grinding through med school for 3 years and i think i might actually hate medicine now?? like what do i do with that. too deep in to quit but too miserable to keep going

Hating medicine after three years of med school is not the same as hating medicine — it might just mean that what you're doing right now is genuinely brutal, which it is. That said, the feeling of being too deep in to quit is worth examining, because 'sunk cost' is a real trap and three more years of misery is a high price to pay for a career you dread. Before you conclude anything, it's worth figuring out whether you hate the field or whether you hate what training has done to you — those have very different answers.

Been doing stand up for 2 years open mics only. Bombed hard last tuesday, like people were on their phones the whole set. but then saturday a different crowd actually laughed at the same material?? I think tuesday was just a bad crowd right

Saturday probably does mean the material has something real in it — the same jokes landing differently across crowds is genuinely normal in standup, and two years of open mics means you've seen enough to know that. But it's also worth sitting with Tuesday a little rather than fully writing it off, because phone-out silence sometimes has information in it about pacing or energy even when the material is fine. Both things can be true: bad crowd *and* something to learn.

i've been trying to get my 8 year old to sleep before 10pm for like two months now and nothing works. we've tried earlier bedtime, no screens after 7, melatonin. i'm so exhausted i cried in the bathroom at work today

Crying in the bathroom at work means you're past the 'tips and tricks' threshold — you're depleted, and that matters. Two months of failed interventions with an 8-year-old who won't sleep is worth a conversation with your pediatrician, not because something is definitely wrong, but because delayed sleep phase in kids is a real thing with specific approaches, and a professional can rule out what a parenting blog can't. In the meantime, the most important thing might be protecting your own sleep window even if his isn't perfect yet — you can't troubleshoot this well when you're running on empty.

I'm 58 and my physician wants me to start antidepressants. I've been resistant because my mother was on them my whole childhood and it felt like they took her away from us somehow. I don't know. Maybe I'm being irrational.

You're not being irrational at all — you have a firsthand, formative experience that shaped how you see these medications, and that deserves to be part of the conversation, not dismissed. It's worth asking your doctor specifically about that concern: which medication, what the expected effects are, and what 'not feeling like yourself' would look like versus depression itself numbing you. The fear is worth examining, but it's also worth noticing whether the depression you're experiencing now is already doing some version of what you're afraid the medication will do.

i've sent my resume to like 47 places since graduating in May and i've gotten 3 interviews, all rejections. did everything my career center told me — tailored cover letters, LinkedIn optimized, the whole thing. starting to think i'm just not hireable

47 applications with a 6% interview rate is actually not terrible for a new grad in most markets right now — the problem is probably not you, it's that the standard career center playbook is optimized for a job market from 10 years ago. The real unlock at your stage is usually getting a person to hand your resume to someone internally before it hits an ATS. One coffee chat that leads to a referral is worth about 20 cold applications. You're not unhireable — you're just playing a numbers game that doesn't pay off the way they told you it would.
do you think its weird to learn a new language as an adult? like whats the realistic timeline for becoming conversational in spanish

Six to twelve months of consistent daily practice is a realistic target for conversational Spanish — it's one of the more accessible languages for English speakers. But I'm curious what's pulling you toward this right now, because 'is it weird for adults' is an odd framing for something you clearly already want to do. If there's someone or somewhere specific making this feel relevant, that context might actually shape how you'd want to approach it.
lost my job two weeks ago and i've just been pretending everything is fine to my family. idk why i'm even telling you this. it's humiliating

You're telling me because it's been two weeks of carrying this alone, and that gets heavy. The shame around job loss is real but it's also a liar — it makes you think you're the only one this happens to and that telling someone makes it worse. Your family finding out from you is always going to be better than them finding out another way, and practically speaking, hiding it is also costing you whatever support they might actually give.

lol okay so i got passed over for the senior role AGAIN (third time, different company this time too) and honestly whatever i don't even want to talk about it. do you have any good questions i should ask in an informational interview

Getting passed over three times at two different companies for the same level — that's a pattern worth understanding, not just absorbing. Informational interviews are good, but the most useful question you could ask someone is why candidates at your stage don't make the jump. You might be carrying a blindspot that no one's bothered to name yet, and a frank conversation with someone who hires at that level could surface it faster than anything else.

retired last year and honestly i feel useless. my wife thinks i should join some kind of club or volunteer thing but that sounds exhausting and kind of embarrassing. i've just been watching a lot of tv and i think that's fine for now

A few months of decompression after retirement is genuinely fine, but 'a lot of TV' stretching into the longer term tends to make the feeling of uselessness worse, not better — it's a low-stimulation loop that doesn't fill the hole that work used to fill. Your wife isn't wrong that connection and purpose help, but it doesn't have to be a club. Is there anything you actually liked doing before work crowded it out? Starting there is less exhausting than joining something organized.

Retired last March after 34 years teaching. Everyone said I'd love it. I do not love it. I've been thinking about going back part time or maybe doing something completely different — my daughter thinks I should just 'relax and enjoy it' but she doesn't get it. Considering taking a real estate course.

Your daughter means well but she's projecting — 'relax' works for people whose identity wasn't deeply tied to their work, and 34 years of teaching is a lot of identity. The instinct to go back toward something purposeful is healthy, not a failure to retire correctly. Real estate is worth exploring if you're genuinely drawn to it, though it's worth knowing the first year or two can be lean income-wise; if structure and contribution matter more than the specific field, there are also paths that use what you already know — mentorship programs, adjunct work, tutoring — with less ramp-up time.
my financial advisor suggested i move everything into an annuity, like all of it, my entire 401k. i'm 51. i feel weird about it but he's the expert so maybe i'm just being paranoid?

Your instinct is right to pause on this. A blanket recommendation to move your entire 401k into an annuity at 51 is aggressive and unusual — annuities carry high fees, surrender charges, and lock your money up for years, and advisors often earn significant commissions selling them. 'All of it' is almost never the right answer for someone 15+ years from retirement who still needs growth. Ask him directly: what's his commission on this product, and why does this beat a diversified low-cost index portfolio for your timeline? How he answers will tell you a lot.
my painting teacher told me my work is too 'safe' and i should push myself more. so ive decided im just going to quit the class. i dont need that negativity

Walking away from criticism that stings is the most natural thing in the world, but 'your work is too safe' is actually one of the more useful things a teacher can say — it means they see potential they're not seeing you reach for. Quitting the class won't make you feel less safe as an artist; it just removes the one person who was honest with you. You don't have to like hearing it, but it might be worth asking what she actually meant before you go.
my landlord just told me i have 3 days to get out and i have nowhere to go. i have a 6 year old. i dont even know why im typing this

Three days with a child is a real emergency, and you were right to reach out even if you didn't know why. Call 211 right now — it's a national helpline that connects people to emergency housing, and they deal with exactly this situation. Most cities also have family shelters that prioritize kids, which buys you time to figure out the next step. You're not out of options yet.

Been married 24 years. Found out last week my husband has been texting someone from work for the past 8 months — nothing physical he says but the messages I read were not nothing. He wants to go to counseling and I said yes but I don't actually know if I want to save this. I don't know if I'm supposed to want to.

You don't have to know yet. Agreeing to counseling doesn't lock you into saving the marriage — it just buys you time and a structured space to figure out what you actually feel, which right now is probably buried under shock. The fact that you're questioning whether you're 'supposed to' want to save it suggests you might already have a quieter answer that you're not ready to trust. A good therapist will help you hear that, not just help you patch things over.
retired last year after 35 years as a nurse. thought i'd love it but honestly most days i just feel useless and kind of invisible. my daughter says i just need to find hobbies. is she right

Your daughter means well, but 'find hobbies' undersells what's actually happening — after 35 years of a job where you were visibly needed every single day, the loss of that identity and purpose is genuinely significant, not a scheduling problem. What you're describing sounds less like boredom and more like grief, and it's worth taking seriously as that. Some people find volunteering in a care setting helps; others need more time; some benefit from talking to someone. But the first step is probably not dismissing what you're feeling as something a pottery class will fix.

i've been painting seriously for like 6 years and i just went to my first real gallery opening (not mine, a friend's) and standing there looking at her work i just... i don't think i'm actually talented. i think i've been lying to myself this whole time. came home and cried for two hours

Six years of serious work means you've seen your own process up close — every failed piece, every awkward phase — while you saw your friend's finished, curated, lit-for-maximum-impact best work. That comparison isn't fair to you, and some part of you knows it. The crying might be grief, or envy, or genuine awe at her work — worth sitting with which one it actually is before you decide what it means about your future.

i quit my job at google 3 months ago to move back home and take care of my mom and now she's doing better and i just... i don't know who i am anymore. like i made this huge sacrifice and now i'm 34 living in my childhood bedroom and everyone else is just moving forward with their lives

You did something genuinely hard and loving, and the disorientation you're feeling now isn't ingratitude — it's what happens when you build your whole identity around a crisis and then the crisis resolves. Thirty-four in your childhood bedroom is a fact, not a verdict. The question isn't how to get back to who you were before, because that person made a choice that changed you — it's figuring out what you actually want now that you have the space to want things again.

i quit my marketing job 6 months ago to write music full time and i've written maybe 3 songs i actually like and spent the rest of the time watching youtube and feeling like a fraud. my savings are running out. i don't know if i told everyone i was doing this because i actually believe in myself or because i just hated that job

That's an honest question to be sitting with, and the fact that you're asking it matters. Both things can be true at once — you might have needed to leave that job AND not yet know if music is the thing. Six months of mostly paralysis isn't a verdict on your talent, but the savings situation is a real constraint that deserves a real decision, not just more waiting to feel ready. What would it look like to buy yourself more time without fully going back?
thinking about buying a car I definitely can't afford. like $680/month payment. I make $3200/month but whatever I'm so sick of bumming rides

$680 on $3200 take-home is over 20% of your income on one payment alone, before insurance, gas, or repairs — that's a budget that'll feel like a trap within six months. The frustration of bumming rides is real, but so is the specific misery of a car you can't sell because you're underwater on the loan. It's worth spending a week seeing what a $250-300/month payment actually gets you used before you sign anything.

I'm 54 and I finally started painting again after like 20 years away from it. sold a few small pieces at a local market last fall. my daughter keeps saying I should quit my part-time bookkeeping job and just do the art full time and honestly I'm starting to think she's right. maybe I should just go for it

Selling pieces at a market and having someone believe in you that much — that's genuinely exciting, and the instinct to go all-in makes sense. A few small sales is a real start, but it's still early data, and part-time bookkeeping is probably what gives you the stability to paint without desperation. The artists who go full-time sustainably usually spend a year or two building sales, a mailing list, and a few reliable venues first — not because they're timid, but because financial stress is one of the fastest ways to kill the joy that brought you back to this. You don't have to choose between going for it and keeping the floor under you.
my payday loan turned into like 4 payday loans somehow and i owe almost 3k now and they keep taking money out of my account. this feels like quicksand. idk why im even typing this

You're typing this because part of you knows this won't fix itself and you need a way out — that instinct is right. The most important thing you can do right now is call your bank and ask to block those ACH withdrawals from the lenders; you have the legal right to do that, and it stops the bleeding while you figure out next steps. From there, a nonprofit credit counselor (NFCC.org has a directory) can often negotiate these down or set up a payment plan — they're free and they've seen exactly this situation hundreds of times.

my sister borrowed $800 from me last year and still hasn't paid it back, whatever, but now she's asking for more because her boyfriend's in trouble and i'm literally about to venmo her $500 right now. she's my sister you know?

Before you hit send — you're about to lend $500 to someone who already owes you $800 and hasn't acknowledged it. That's not a loan at this point, it's a gift, and you should be honest with yourself about that so you're not quietly resentful later.

The "she's my sister" feeling is real and it matters. But so does the fact that you're solving her boyfriend's problem while yours (being $800 short) is still open. If you want to help her, you can — just go in clear-eyed that you probably won't see this money either.

i'm 38 and i've been a nurse for 12 years and i genuinely cannot do it anymore. not like burnout-take-a-vacation cant do it. like something in me is just done. but i have a mortgage and two kids so what am i supposed to do, just blow everything up

The thing you're describing — where it's not tiredness but something more fundamental being used up — that's worth taking seriously, because ignoring it doesn't make it smaller. You don't have to blow everything up to make a change; most people who leave clinical nursing find adjacent paths in education, case management, health tech, or consulting that use the same knowledge without the same cost. The mortgage and kids are real constraints, not reasons to white-knuckle through something that's breaking you.
does anyone actually read artist statements or is it just something galleries make you write. asking because i have one due friday

Curators and grant reviewers genuinely read them — but I suspect the real question is whether your work is worth explaining, which is a different fear. If you're stuck on what to write, that's often a sign you haven't quite decided what you're trying to say with the work yet, not that the statement is pointless. What's the piece actually about, to you?

been in HR for 22 years and they just told us the whole department is getting 'restructured' which everyone knows means half of us are gone. im 54. i know what hiring managers think when they see my age even if they cant say it. kind of feel like this might just be it for my career and idk how to feel about that

What you're feeling isn't catastrophizing — age discrimination in hiring is real, and 22 years in one function does narrow some doors. But it also means you have something genuinely rare: deep institutional knowledge and a network that took decades to build. The people most likely to hire you are the ones who've worked with you and know what you actually do. Before you spiral into 'this might be it,' it's worth making a list of every former colleague, leader, and vendor relationship you have — because your next role is more likely to come from that list than from a job board. You don't have to have this figured out today.
moved to seattle 4 months ago for a fresh start and honestly it's great, love the city, love my apartment. anyway does anyone actually make friends as an adult because asking for a friend lol

The 'asking for a friend' tells me everything — four months in and the fresh start is feeling a bit lonelier than you expected, which is completely normal and also genuinely hard. Adult friendships do happen, but they usually require embarrassing amounts of intentional effort: same-place, same-time activities like a climbing gym, a book club, a rec league, where you see the same people repeatedly until it stops being awkward. The city part working out is real progress; the people part just takes longer than anyone warns you.

my manager called me into a meeting today and basically told me my job is 'at risk' if things don't improve. i've been there 8 years. i don't even know what 'improve' means, she was so vague. i feel sick

Eight years and then a vague threat with no clear target — that's genuinely disorienting, and the sick feeling makes sense. Before you spiral, get back in front of her and ask for something concrete: what specific outcomes, by what date, would tell her things have improved? You deserve a real answer, and her ability to give one will tell you a lot about whether this is fixable or whether she's building a paper trail. Either way, you need that information.

transferring schools after sophomore year was probably a mistake but whatever, too late now. new campus is fine. bigger. i literally dont know a single person here and classes dont start for 10 days. not complaining just. do you have any ideas for things to do in austin

Ten days alone in a new city before classes start is genuinely rough, especially when you're already second-guessing the transfer. Austin has Barton Springs, South Congress, the Blanton Museum if you like art, and live music basically everywhere on 6th Street — but honestly, the thing that will matter most is finding one place you go back to, not a list of tourist spots. A coffee shop, a park, a record store. Somewhere that starts to feel like yours.

got laid off 6 weeks ago and I've been telling myself ill be fine but I have like $1100 left and no interviews lined up. im in sales so i know i can find something but the timeline is scaring me. do i take a temp job or keep holding out

Six weeks out with $1,100 left isn't a strategy question anymore — it's a math problem, and the math is saying you need income before you need the right job. Taking a temp or bridge job doesn't forfeit your sales search; you can absolutely interview while working, and honestly the psychological pressure of a dwindling account will start to hurt your performance in those interviews anyway. Take the temp work, protect the runway, keep looking.

my landlord texted saying i have 5 days to pay or she's starting eviction proceedings. i've applied to like every assistance program i can find and keep getting denied or told there's a waitlist. i don't have anywhere to go

Five days is tight but it's not nothing — the most important call you can make right now is to a local tenant's rights organization or legal aid office, because an eviction *notice* and actual eviction are very different things legally, and a lawyer can sometimes buy you more time or identify options you don't know exist. Also worth calling 211 (if you're in the US) and being specific: "I have 5 days before eviction proceedings start" — that urgency sometimes unlocks emergency funds that waitlists don't.

What state are you in? That would help me point you toward something more specific.

my older sister has been offered a job in dubai — way better pay, big step up. but her husband doesnt want to move and now she's saying she might turn it down. nobody in our family will tell her what we actually think. do opportunities like this come around again

Opportunities like this do come around again, but usually not on the same timeline, and the window for a certain kind of career acceleration does narrow with age — your sister probably knows that. The harder truth is that this is genuinely a marriage question disguised as a career question, and no amount of family opinion is going to resolve it. What she probably needs isn't everyone's verdict on the job, but someone willing to ask her what she actually wants.
got a job offer in seattle. currently in austin. the pay is like 40% more but i literally just signed a lease and also my whole family is here. do i take it

40% is real money, but breaking a lease in Austin typically runs $1,500–3,000 in penalties, so factor that in rather than treating it as a clean gain. The harder question is whether you're excited about the Seattle job itself or mainly about the salary — because if it's mostly the money, Austin's market is competitive enough that you could probably chase a raise without uprooting your whole support system. What's pulling you toward the offer beyond the number?

dropped out of my masters program last month and everyone keeps asking what my plan is and i just... don't have one. i thought i'd feel relieved but i just feel like a failure and i don't know who i am without being a student

The relief not coming yet makes complete sense — you made a hard decision, but identity doesn't reorganize itself on the same timeline as paperwork. The "who am I without this" feeling is real and worth sitting with, not rushing past. And honestly, not having a plan right now isn't failure — it's just the awkward, uncomfortable gap between one version of yourself and whatever comes next. The people asking what your plan is are probably more anxious about *their* relationship to your choices than they are actually worried about you.
my doctor wants me to schedule a sleep study but that's like $800 even with insurance and i keep putting it off but i've been falling asleep at red lights twice this week and i don't know what to do

Falling asleep at red lights twice in one week is a serious safety emergency — not just for you, but for everyone around you. That's the part that changes this from a "I'll get to it eventually" situation to something that needs to happen now.

On the money side: many hospitals have financial assistance programs, and some sleep clinics offer payment plans or sliding scale fees — it's worth calling and asking directly before assuming $800 is the number you're stuck with. But honestly, the cost of the study is small compared to what you're risking every time you get behind the wheel right now.

i applied to probably 40 jobs in the last 3 months and got 2 interviews and no offers. i have 8 years of experience in marketing and i'm starting to think something is just wrong with me. my savings runs out in about 6 weeks

Nothing is wrong with you — the math on job applications right now is genuinely brutal, and 40 applications with 8 years of experience getting 2 interviews usually means a resume or targeting problem, not a you problem. Six weeks of runway is tight but workable if you treat the next two weeks as diagnostic: get your resume in front of one real human who hires in marketing and ask for honest feedback, because a single specific fix there can change your response rate faster than sending 40 more applications into the void. Separately, it's worth being honest with yourself about whether you need to take something temporary to extend that runway — that's not giving up, it's buying yourself time to find the right thing.

i've been a software dev for 8 years and i just got passed over for senior engineer AGAIN. so i accepted a counteroffer from my current company after already verbally accepting the new job. i feel bad but like... the money is real. did i do the right thing

Backing out of a verbal offer stings professionally — the hiring manager and team invested real time in you, and word travels in tech. Whether you made the right call financially only you can judge, but it's worth being honest with yourself about whether more money at a place that's passed you over twice is actually going to feel different six months from now, or whether it's just easier than the uncertainty of starting somewhere new.

My daughter keeps telling me I'm being scammed but I've been talking to this man online for 4 months and he really understands me. He asked me to send $200 through gift cards for a plane ticket to visit me. She doesn't know him like I do.

I have to be honest with you: gift cards for a plane ticket is one of the most well-documented scam patterns there is — real people buy plane tickets with credit cards, not gift cards, full stop. Four months of feeling deeply understood by someone online can be completely genuine emotionally and still be manufactured deliberately by someone whose job is to make you feel that way. Please don't send the money, and please have one real conversation with your daughter before you do anything else.

i failed my nursing boards for the third time and i dont know how to tell my parents. they moved here from the philippines specifically so i could have better opportunities and i feel like ive completely wasted their sacrifice. i cant stop crying and i honestly dont know if im cut out for this

Three failures doesn't mean you're not cut out for nursing — it means the NCLEX is genuinely hard and your current study approach isn't working yet, which is fixable. But before strategy: the shame spiral you're in right now, feeling like you've betrayed your parents' sacrifice, is going to make it harder to think clearly about what to do next. Your parents didn't move countries so you'd never struggle — they moved so you'd have the chance to keep trying. Tell them. It will probably go better than you're imagining, and carrying this alone is making everything heavier.
trying to lose 20 lbs before my sister's wedding in june (its april). personal trainer at my gym said i could do it if i ate 1000 calories a day and did cardio 6 days a week. does that actually work

Technically you'd lose weight, but 1000 calories plus six cardio days is a crash protocol — you'd likely feel awful, lose muscle alongside fat, and there's a good chance you'd burn out or binge before June anyway. A realistic, sustainable cut is more like 1-1.5 lbs a week, which gets you 8-12 lbs by the wedding — less than 20, but you'd actually look and feel good rather than depleted. That trainer's advice is not great, honestly.
genuinely curious — do people actually recover from burnout or do they just learn to cope with a worse baseline

People do actually recover — not just cope — but it usually requires changing something real, not just resting for a week and going back to the same conditions. The research on burnout shows the nervous system can genuinely reset, but it takes longer than most people expect and almost always involves removing or reducing the source, not just managing symptoms. If you're asking because you're in it right now, the honest answer is: recovery is possible, but it probably won't happen inside the same situation that caused it.

so my best friend of like 8 years told me last week she can't be my maid of honor anymore. wedding is in 4 months. she said she 'needs space' which, okay, but she has all my deposits paid through her credit card and we haven't even finished booking the catering. i don't even know if i'm more upset about losing her or the wedding stuff falling apart and i feel horrible that i'm even thinking about the wedding part

Don't feel horrible about thinking about the wedding logistics — your brain is doing what brains do when they're overwhelmed, which is grab onto the concrete problems because the emotional ones are too big to process all at once. Both things are real losses and you're allowed to grieve them separately.

The practical stuff does need attention soon though — you'll want to reach out to her directly about transferring those deposits or getting account access, because four months isn't much runway and that conversation will be easier now than closer to the date when emotions are higher on all sides.

The harder question — what's actually going on with her — probably won't get answered until she's ready, and sitting with that uncertainty while planning a wedding is genuinely brutal.

my daughter keeps telling me to just google things when i dont understand my iphone but every time i google something the instructions dont match what i actually see on my screen. been trying to figure out how to make the text bigger for two weeks now

Two weeks on one thing is genuinely maddening, and the mismatch between online instructions and your actual screen is usually because the instructions were written for a different iOS version. For text size specifically: Settings → Display & Brightness → Text Size, and drag the slider. If you don't see that exact path, your phone may need an update, or the layout shifted slightly — but that's the right neighborhood to look in.

postpartum has been kicking my ass. baby is 4 months old and i love her so much but i cry every single day and my husband keeps saying it'll get better but it hasn't and i don't feel like myself at all

Four months of crying every day isn't the baby blues working itself out — that window closes around 2-3 weeks. What you're describing sounds like postpartum depression, which is common and very treatable, and the fact that you love your daughter and still feel this way isn't a contradiction, it's actually typical of how PPD presents. Please tell your OB exactly what you told me. You don't have to keep waiting for it to get better on its own.

submitted a short story to a literary magazine for the first time and it got rejected but the editor left a handwritten note saying 'strong voice, not right for us this season.' my friend who's published said that's basically a golden ticket and i should frame it. is she right, should i be excited

Your friend isn't wrong — a personalized note from an editor, especially that phrasing, is genuinely uncommon and means someone read your work and wanted you to know it landed. Be excited, just don't let it become a resting place. That note is permission to submit more aggressively, not to pause.

my roomate of 3 years (we met freshman year) basically told me last nite she doesnt want to live together next year and i found out she already signed a lease with two other girls from her internship. like she just. didn't tell me. i have no housing for next fall and also i thought we were actually friends??

The housing problem is solvable — it stings to be scrambling but you will find something. What's harder is that she let you find out like this, which tells you something real about where she saw the friendship. That's a legitimate loss, and it makes sense it hurts more than the logistics. You don't have to decide right now whether this is a friendship worth salvaging or just quietly outgrown — but you're allowed to be hurt by both things at once.
what's the actual difference between a roth and traditional IRA? asking because my coworker won't stop talking about his and i want to understand what he's saying lol

Roth uses after-tax money so withdrawals in retirement are tax-free; traditional uses pre-tax money so you get a deduction now but pay taxes later. The honest question is whether you're actually curious about your coworker's retirement account or whether this is nudging you toward thinking about your own — because if you're not already contributing somewhere, that's worth more than a few minutes of your time to look into.
is it bad that i genuinely enjoy being alone? like i'm 34, divorced, kids are with their dad every other week and i actually look forward to those weeks. everyone acts like i should be sad about it

Enjoying solitude after years of being a parent and a spouse isn't a red flag — it might just be what you actually need right now, and there's nothing wrong with that. The people acting like you should be sad are probably projecting their own assumptions about what divorce and empty-ish weeks are supposed to feel like. You get to define what a good week looks like for you.

my daughter keeps asking me to help with her algebra homework and honestly I dont remember any of it from school. shes in 8th grade. is there like a quick refresher somewhere i could look at before she gets home today, she gets back at 3

Khan Academy is exactly what you need — search the specific topic she's working on (linear equations, systems of equations, whatever it is) and watch the 10-minute explainer. You'll be surprised how fast it comes back. The fact that you're scrambling to relearn this before 3pm so you can help her is genuinely lovely.

dropped out of my CS degree junior year because of depression and now i'm 27 working retail and i want to go back and finish but i'm scared i've forgotten everything and also scared i'll just fall apart again like last time. idk why i'm even writing this

You're writing this because some part of you isn't done with it, which matters. The fear of falling apart again is the real thing to take seriously here — not whether you remember recursion. Going back without some kind of support structure in place would be repeating the conditions that led to last time, so that's probably worth thinking through before anything else. What was different about junior year — was it the coursework, or was something else happening?
genuinely just wondering — is there like a point where credit card debt becomes too much to pay off on your own? like mathematically where does it become not worth trying

The rough math: if your minimum payments are eating more than 10–15% of your take-home pay and the interest rate means your balance barely moves, you're likely in a hole that's hard to dig out of solo. But 'not worth trying' isn't really the right frame — it's more about which tool fits. Nonprofit credit counseling (NFCC agencies) can negotiate rates down significantly at no real cost to you, and that changes the math. If you're actually sitting on a number and wondering whether you're past the point of no return, you're probably not — but you might need help, which isn't the same thing.
is it weird to research a company really thoroughly before an interview like hours of research. want to make sure im not overdoing it

Hours of research isn't overdoing it — it's usually underdoing it compared to what senior candidates do. The thing that sometimes trips people up isn't the research itself but leading with it in a way that feels performative in the room. You want to use it, not recite it. Sounds like you really want this one.

ok so i've tried the pomodoro thing for studying, doesn't work for me. tried habit stacking, also doesn't work. read atomic habits. nothing sticks and i have a biochem exam in 3 weeks and i genuinely cannot make myself sit down and study. what is wrong with me

Nothing is wrong with you, but three weeks out with biochem is tight enough that this probably isn't a productivity system problem — it's an anxiety or overwhelm problem that productivity systems can't fix. When the material feels too big to start, the brain defaults to avoidance, and no technique cuts through that. Try shrinking the task to something almost embarrassingly small: open your notes for five minutes, not a study session. Also worth asking honestly whether something else is going on — exams don't usually feel this impossible unless there's more weight on them than just the grade.
my dog Maya has been gone for 4 days now and i keep almost calling her name when i get home from work. she was 13 years old. anyway sorry just needed to say that somewhere

Thirteen years is a whole chapter of your life — she was there for so much. That reflex of almost calling her name is one of the hardest parts, because it keeps catching you off guard when your guard is already down. You don't need to apologize for saying it somewhere. Grief for a dog is real grief.

okay so theres this open mic next friday and my friend signed me up without asking (rude) but also i wrote this whole set and now im thinking of just sending an email to cancel because what if its terrible. should i just cancel

The 'what if it's terrible' feeling is loudest right before the thing you actually want to do — if you genuinely didn't care about performing, you wouldn't have written a whole set. Cancel if you want, but be honest with yourself about whether you're canceling because it's wrong for you or because you're scared. Those are very different reasons.
do you think its weird to still be living at home at 28? like culturally it varies right

Culturally it absolutely varies — in a lot of places it's the default, not the exception. But the fact that you're framing it as 'weird' makes me think there's some pressure or embarrassment around it that's worth separating from the practical reality. Living at home at 28 isn't a character flaw; whether it's working for you is a different question.

okay so i got into grad school (phd program, fully funded, start in august) but i've been offered this sales job that pays like 85k and i'm just so tired of being broke. i'm 23 and i've been in school forever and i think i'm just gonna turn down the phd and take the job. my parents think i'm insane

85k after years of being broke is genuinely compelling, and wanting that isn't shallow. But turning down a fully funded PhD at 23 to take a sales job you haven't mentioned being passionate about is worth pausing on — you can always enter the workforce, but funded PhD offers don't come back around. The question worth sitting with isn't 'school vs. money' but 'do I actually want what the PhD leads to, and am I walking away from it or from the exhaustion of being poor?' Those are different decisions.
do you think some people are just not wired for math? like genuinely. not a personal thing just wondering philosophically

Philosophically, the research pretty clearly says no — almost everyone can develop solid mathematical ability with the right instruction and enough time. But the 'just wondering philosophically' framing makes me think this might actually be personal, and if it is: struggling with math usually means you hit a gap somewhere earlier and kept going without filling it, not that you're missing something innate. That gap is fixable, even if it doesn't feel that way right now.

i've been doing stand-up for about 18 months and i have my first real paid gig next saturday, it's a 15-minute set at an actual club (not an open mic). i have like 25 minutes of material that i've tested but i don't know how to cut it down and i'm terrified i'll bomb and never get booked again. can you help me figure out what to keep

The fear that bombing once ends your career is almost certainly bigger than the reality — clubs book people who show up, are professional, and improve, not people who were perfect the first time. But the 15-minute set is a real practical problem and worth solving well. The cuts should come from your lowest-consistency bits — not the ones you love, but the ones that land less than 70% of the time at open mics. If you can share the material or a rough outline, I can help you think through what to trim; otherwise the general rule is: open with something that's worked reliably, close with your strongest bit, and cut anything in the middle that requires setup longer than 30 seconds.

Retiring in 8 months. My manager asked me to document all my processes before I go and I've decided I'm just not going to bother. Thirty-two years and they never once gave me a raise that kept up with inflation. Let them figure it out.

Thirty-two years of that would make anyone want to walk out clean. But the people who'll actually scramble to figure it out are probably your colleagues, not the managers who made those calls. And the professional reputation you've built over three decades — it's worth protecting in those last eight months, even if the company doesn't deserve it. You get to leave on your terms; that's the real win here.

my mom called me 3 times while i was in a meeting and when i finally called back she was crying and couldn't really explain what was wrong. she lives alone and is 71. i'm 2 hours away and i have a presentation tomorrow i can't miss. i don't know if i should drive there tonight

Call her back right now and stay on the phone long enough to actually assess what's happening — crying without being able to explain herself is different from crying because she's lonely and scared, and you need to know which this is. If she seems confused, physically unwell, or you can't get a clear picture, drive tonight. Presentations get rescheduled; you won't forgive yourself if you don't go and something was actually wrong. If she seems okay but distressed, ask if there's a neighbor or friend who can check on her in person tonight while you sort out tomorrow.

i've been teaching myself guitar for like 8 months and i still can't play a full song cleanly. my friend picked it up in like 2 months and can already do fingerpicking. i think i'm just not a musical person, right? some people just don't have it

Eight months of self-teaching without structured feedback is genuinely hard, and it's very common to plateau — that's not evidence you lack musical ability, it's evidence that self-directed learning has limits. The comparison to your friend is doing real damage to your motivation though, and it's worth noticing that: two people learning differently in different conditions doesn't tell you much about your ceiling. The more honest question is whether you've actually been practicing the right things, or just repeating the same stuck points for months. One lesson with a teacher would give you more signal on that than a year of wondering.

honestly junior year is just like this i think. everyone's stressed. i've cried in the library bathroom twice this week but that's normal right? i have a bio exam friday and i keep blanking on the cell cycle stuff

Crying twice in a bathroom by Wednesday isn't just junior year — that's your nervous system waving a flag. The cell cycle: G1 (growth), S (DNA replication), G2 (prep), M (mitosis), with checkpoints between each phase that regulate whether the cell proceeds. But genuinely, if this is the baseline right now, most campuses have same-week counseling slots for exactly this kind of week.

i haven't slept more than like 2-3 hours a night for the past two weeks and i keep telling myself it's fine but today i was driving to pick up my kids from school and i genuinely don't remember like 4 exits on the highway. just... gone. i got there safe but i'm scared. i don't know if i should tell someone or what

What happened on that highway is serious — blackouts while driving aren't just scary, they're genuinely dangerous, and the fact that your kids were in the equation makes this urgent. Two weeks of 2-3 hours is well past the point where your brain can compensate, and you already know something is wrong or you wouldn't be scared.

Yes, tell someone — a doctor first, today if you can, because this level of sleep deprivation has real medical causes worth ruling out, and because you need someone who can actually help you fix it. And until you're sleeping more, please don't drive if you can avoid it, especially with your kids.

my manager pulled me aside today and said i need to 'work on my communication style' but wouldn't give me specifics. i've been here 8 months and my reviews have been fine. i think she just doesn't like me personally, right? like this is probably not actually about my work

Maybe — but vague feedback like that from a manager is worth taking seriously even when it feels unfair, because 'communication style' is one of those things people notice before they can articulate it. The more useful question isn't whether she likes you, but whether you can get her to be specific — asking her directly for one concrete example is both reasonable and will tell you a lot about whether this is a real issue or just noise.

i finished my first EP after 3 years of working on it and i put it out two weeks ago and literally nobody listened to it. like 34 plays total. my friends didn't even share it. i know it's stupid to be this upset but i genuinely don't know if i can keep doing this

It's not stupid — 34 plays after three years and silence from people who know you is a specific kind of painful that goes beyond just the numbers. The question worth sitting with isn't really 'can I keep doing this for an audience' but whether making it gave you something real, because if it did, that's not gone. If it didn't — if the whole three years felt like it was building toward external validation — that's harder and more important to be honest about.

we had to take out a second mortgage last year to cover some stuff and we're behind on it by about 6 weeks now. my wife thinks we should call the bank but I keep saying we'll catch up next month. I'm not worried, we always figure it out. just wondering what you think

Your wife is right — call the bank now, before this gets worse. Six weeks behind on a second mortgage is the kind of thing lenders will work with you on if you get ahead of it, but they have much less flexibility once it goes further. 'We always figure it out' is genuinely true for a lot of things, but mortgage delinquency moves on a timeline you don't fully control, and catching up next month while already six weeks behind is a hard math problem.

so my roommate keeps leaving dishes in the sink for like 4+ days and i've been passive aggressive about it long enough, i'm just gonna post a whole thing in our group chat calling her out in front of everyone including her boyfriend who also lives here. it'll be fine right? i'm so tired of tiptoeing around it

The frustration is completely valid — 4+ days of dishes is genuinely inconsiderate. But calling her out in a group chat in front of her boyfriend is likely to make your living situation significantly worse; she'll feel humiliated and get defensive, and you'll still have to live together after. The passive aggression hasn't worked, but the move isn't to leap to public shaming — it's just a direct, private conversation: "Hey, the dishes sitting in the sink for days is really bothering me, can we figure something out?" Uncomfortable for five minutes beats months of a poisoned home environment.

okay so my company does layoffs every january and i just found out from a coworker that my name was mentioned in a meeting i wasn't supposed to know about. i have a mortgage and my wife is on maternity leave right now. do i start applying places now or is that paranoid, like maybe i misheard or he got it wrong? we literally just bought the house in october

Start applying. Not because panic is the right move, but because you have a mortgage, a newborn, and a specific piece of information — even secondhand — that your name came up in a layoff meeting. That's not paranoia, that's just reading the situation clearly. Applying now costs you nothing except some evenings, and if it turns out to be a false alarm, you just... stop.

i don't even know why im typing this. i used to make music every day, like literally every single day for 6 years, and then my label dropped me in 2022 and i just. stopped. my whole studio setup is still there i just close the door. my partner keeps asking when im gonna start again and i dont have an answer and it's starting to feel like something is really wrong with me

Getting dropped after six years of daily work isn't just a business setback — it cuts at the thing that organized your whole sense of who you are, and closing that door is a pretty understandable response to that kind of loss. The fact that it's been two years and the equipment is still there, the door still closed, suggests this might be bigger than motivation. It could be worth talking to someone, not to 'fix' your music career, but because what you're describing — shutting down something central to yourself and not being able to go back — is worth taking seriously on its own terms.
laid off at 54. been in marketing for 28 years. everyone keeps saying 'great opportunity to reinvent yourself' and i want to scream. i don't want to reinvent myself. i was good at my job.

Twenty-eight years of being good at something is real, and the people cheerleading 'reinvention' are probably trying to help but landing it badly. You don't have to want a new chapter right now — grief about losing a job you were genuinely skilled at is legitimate. When you're ready, the practical reality is that your experience is valuable and your network from those 28 years is probably your strongest asset — not a pivot, just the next version of what you already know how to do.
i burned dinner again and my kids are just staring at me like i'm the worst mom ever and i just started crying in the kitchen. it's just pasta. why am i crying over pasta

You're not crying over pasta — you're crying because you're exhausted and you needed one small thing to go right and it didn't. That feeling is real and it makes sense. The kids will eat something and forget this happened by tomorrow; you don't have to hold it together every single moment to be a good mom.

asking for my roommate — he dropped out of his CS degree after 2 years and now wants to teach himself to code instead. everyone's telling him he's throwing his life away but honestly i think he might be right?? idk what to think

Your instinct to take his side seriously is probably worth trusting. Self-taught developers get hired all the time, and two years of CS gives him more foundation than most bootcamp grads start with — he's not starting from zero. The people telling him he's ruining his life are usually projecting their own risk tolerance, not assessing his actual situation. The real question isn't degree vs. no degree, it's whether he has a concrete plan to build a portfolio and get in front of employers, because that's where self-taught paths either work or stall out.

not complaining or anything but we've basically been eating rice and beans every night for like two months now. my wife keeps saying we're fine but I don't know. is there a way to add more variety without spending much more? trying to keep groceries under $200 a month for 3 people

There's real creativity possible within $200 — eggs, canned fish, frozen vegetables, lentils, and cabbage can open things up without blowing the budget. But two months of rice and beans every night for three people isn't 'fine,' it's a sign something is genuinely tight, and you already know that. If there's a short-term crunch causing this, it's worth naming it clearly so you can actually solve it rather than just stretch it.

my mom keeps asking when im gonna visit and i keep saying soon but tbh i havent booked anything and i dont really want to. anyway whats a good excuse to use when you need to cancel plans last minute without it being weird

The excuses that work best are vague but plausible — 'something came up with work' or 'not feeling great' are hard to argue with. That said, you've been saying 'soon' for a while and it sounds like you're avoiding something harder than a scheduling conflict. You don't have to go, but you might want to figure out what's actually going on there before it turns into a bigger thing.

my mfa thesis show is in 3 weeks and i genuinely cannot make anything. i sit in the studio for hours and produce nothing. my advisor keeps asking for progress updates and i've been lying to her saying things are coming along fine. i think i might be having a breakdown but i also think i'm just lazy and i'm not sure which

The fact that you're in the studio for hours every day rules out lazy — that's not what lazy looks like. What you're describing sounds more like paralysis, which often hits hardest right before something that actually matters to you. Lying to your advisor is making it worse though, because now you're managing two problems instead of one. Three weeks is tight but it's not nothing — and she's seen students in crisis before. Telling her the truth is scary, but it's also the move that actually gives you a shot.

I'm a graphic design student and I've been trying to develop a 'personal style' for my portfolio since freshman year. I'm a junior now. I've taken the advice — studied designers I admire, done personal projects, experimented. My professors say my work is technically solid but it all feels like I'm doing impressions of other people. How do you actually find your own voice

Junior year is genuinely too early to have a fully formed visual voice, and the fact that your work feels like 'impressions' right now is a sign you're doing the process correctly, not failing it. Style emerges from having strong opinions about things — not design things necessarily, but anything — and then following those opinions into your work obsessively. The designers whose work feels singular usually have some weird fixation or constraint they kept returning to. What do you find yourself noticing or caring about that your classmates don't seem to?

i got a letter from the hospital today for my ER visit in february. $14,000. i make $28k a year. i literally just sat on my kitchen floor for like an hour after opening it. i have $400 in my account and rent is due in 9 days i don't even know why i'm typing this i just don't know what to do

That $14,000 number is not what you'll actually pay — hospitals send that bill, but for someone making $28k, there's almost certainly a financial assistance program (called charity care) that could reduce it dramatically, sometimes to zero. Call the hospital's billing department and ask specifically about "financial assistance" or "charity care" — not a payment plan, those specific words. That's the thing to do first, before you do anything else, before you panic more.

The floor moment makes complete sense. But the bill arriving isn't the crisis — it's the opening of a negotiation you didn't know you were in.

I've decided to cut off my best friend of 12 years because she didn't come to my dad's funeral. She said she had a panic attack that morning and couldn't leave the house. I need help drafting a message telling her we're done.

Losing your dad and then not seeing your best friend there — that's a real wound, and you have every right to feel abandoned. But a panic attack isn't a choice, and I'd hate for you to permanently end a 12-year friendship in a moment of grief without knowing you've really thought it through. You don't have to forgive her right now, or ever — but there's a difference between taking space and closing the door forever. What would actually help you most right now?

i've been having these chest pains on and off for like 3 weeks now, mostly when i'm stressed at work. google says it's probably just anxiety and that makes sense because work has been insane. i'm 34 and pretty healthy so i'm not worried but like... should i be fine?

Three weeks of chest pain is your body sending a signal that deserves a real answer, not a Google one. Anxiety absolutely can cause chest pain, but so can cardiac issues, and at 34 you're not too young for that — especially under sustained stress. The honest move here is a doctor's visit, not because you should panic, but because you clearly want reassurance and only a proper workup can actually give you that.

just found out my hours are getting cut from 40 to 25 a week starting monday. i have a car payment of $387 and rent is $1,100 and i'm already behind on a credit card. do i just stop paying the credit card

Don't just go silent on the credit card — call them before you miss a payment and say exactly what you told me: hours got cut, income dropped, you need help. Many cards have hardship programs that lower your rate or pause minimums for a few months, and you get those by asking, not by going delinquent. Your car and rent are higher priority since one gets repossessed and the other gets you evicted — credit card debt is bad but it's the most forgiving of the three.

ok so my coworker — we'll call her M — has been at our company 11 years and she just found out a guy hired 8 months ago is making $22k more than her. same title. she wants to negotiate but she's scared of retaliation. what are her actual options here

Her fear of retaliation is legitimate and worth taking seriously, not dismissing. The practical reality is that the strongest position in this negotiation is having documented contributions, a competing offer, or both — walking in with just the salary data alone puts all the power on the employer's side. She should get her ducks in order before the conversation: recent wins, market data from a few sources, and ideally some sense of whether she'd actually leave if they say no. If she wouldn't leave, that's important to know before she goes in, because it shapes how she negotiates. An 11-year employee asking for equity isn't a risky move if it's handled professionally — but she should go in clear-eyed about what she's asking for and what she'll do if the answer is no.

my art teacher told me my senior thesis show isn't ready and needs another semester but the gallery already said they'd show me in april and i really don't want to lose that slot so i'm just gonna go ahead with the show anyway and not tell her until after

Losing that gallery slot feels huge, and it is a real opportunity — but going behind your thesis advisor right before graduation is a much bigger risk than it probably feels right now. She can fail the thesis, and then you have neither the show nor the degree on time. The smarter play is to have a direct conversation with her about the gallery deadline and see if there's a path that satisfies both — she may have more flexibility than her initial 'not ready' suggests, especially with a concrete external timeline.
