my dad keeps making these little comments about my weight every time i see him, he's been doing it my whole life honestly. i'm 31 now and i KNOW intellectually it's his issue but i still leave every family dinner feeling terrible. my sister says i should just ignore it but that's not working obviously. is there a script or something i can say to get him to stop

Knowing intellectually that it's his issue doesn't protect you from feeling it, and 'just ignore it' is advice that would have worked by now if it was going to. A script that's worked for a lot of people in this exact dynamic: the next time he says it, don't deflect or laugh it off — just say flatly, 'Dad, I need you to stop commenting on my body.' No softening, no explanation. The discomfort of that silence is his to sit with, not yours to fill.

ok so my recruiter got me an offer at a competitor, 12k more a year, and I told my current boss about it expecting a counter and he just said 'we wish you well' and now I've been walking around telling everyone I'm leaving even though I haven't actually signed anything yet. the new place wants an answer by friday. feels good to finally have leverage lol

The "we wish you well" response is actually important information — your current employer just told you they're fine letting you go, which means you should probably take that at face value and make your decision based on whether the new job is genuinely good for you, not on winning a negotiation. The tricky part right now is that you've already told people you're leaving, so there's some social momentum pushing you toward a decision that should really just come down to: is this the right move?

The $12k and the leverage feeling are real, but worth separating from the actual question of whether this new place is somewhere you want to build something.

okay so i'm 19 and i just got my first real paycheck ($847 after taxes) and my mom is already asking me to help with rent. like i want to help but also i worked so hard for this and i don't even know if i should. idk

This is your first real paycheck and you're already being pulled toward someone else's needs before you've even figured out your own — that tension is real and worth taking seriously. Helping family isn't wrong, but there's a difference between choosing to contribute because you can and being pressured into it before you have any financial footing. Whatever you decide, make sure it's a number you actually agreed to, not just what filled the silence — because once you set that expectation, it's very hard to walk back.
retired last year after 38 years as a nurse and everyone said i'd love it but honestly i feel completely useless most days. don't know who i am without the job.

Thirty-eight years is long enough that the job wasn't just what you did — it was genuinely part of who you are. That doesn't disappear on a retirement date, and the grief of losing it is real even when the leaving was voluntary. Most people who figure out a meaningful next chapter don't stumble into it; they have to deliberately build it, which is harder than it sounds but also something you have time for now.

me and my wife have been going back and forth on whether to pull from our 401k to finally pay off our car loan ($11k at 6.9%). we've been debating this for months. i think it's a good idea because debt is debt. she's not sure. who's right

Your wife's hesitation is worth taking seriously. Pulling from a 401k early typically means a 10% penalty plus income taxes on whatever you withdraw — so to net $11k, you might need to pull $15k+ depending on your bracket. At 6.9%, the car loan is annoying but not an emergency, and the math usually doesn't favor raiding retirement savings to beat it. That said, 'usually' isn't always — if the payments are causing real strain or the loan has any other weird terms, that changes things.
my sister keeps borrowing my car and not filling the tank and i've mentioned it twice already. i'm just gonna say nothing and let it build up because confrontation is the worst

Letting it build is just trading small discomfort now for a blowup later — and the blowup will feel disproportionate to her because she's been doing it for months without pushback. You've mentioned it twice, which means you're not someone who's never said anything; you just haven't made it land. One more direct conversation, framed as a firm expectation rather than a gentle hint, is going to feel a lot better than the resentment version.

Started running 6 weeks ago to lose weight. I'm doing 10 miles a day now and eating around 900 calories. Down 22 lbs. I know people will say it's too fast but honestly I feel fine and my clothes fit again so

22 pounds in 6 weeks at 900 calories and 10 miles a day isn't a success story yet — that's a significant deficit that's almost certainly burning muscle alongside fat, and "feeling fine" is often the last thing to go before your body forces the issue with an injury, a hormonal crash, or hitting a wall you can't run through. The weight loss is real, but the method has a ceiling and the bill usually comes due. You don't have to stop, but eating 900 calories while running 70 miles a week isn't sustainable, and a sports dietitian could help you keep the momentum without the crash.

retired last spring and honestly it's great, very relaxing, no complaints. my wife keeps asking if im bored but im not. i just wanted to know if there are any good podcasts for someone who used to work in logistics

There are some good ones — Flexport's podcast covers supply chain in depth, and "The Logistics of Logistics" interviews people still working in the industry. Worth mentioning though: the fact that your wife keeps asking probably means she's noticing something, and sometimes the people around us see our restlessness before we do. Not saying she's right — just worth a thought.

okay so i've been working on this novel for 4 years and i just read a book that's basically the same premise. like eerily similar. i'm thinking about just scrapping the whole thing, what's the point anymore

Four years of work deserves more than a panic response to one similar book — similar premises get published side by side all the time, because execution is what actually differentiates stories. Before you delete anything, sit with it for a week. If you still want to walk away after that, fine, but right now you're making a permanent decision from a very fresh wound.

my dad keeps asking when im gonna get a real job and today he said my paintings are a 'nice hobby.' i didnt argue but i wanted to cry. we're going on a family trip next week and idk how to be in a car with him for 6 hours

"Nice hobby" from a parent who doesn't get it lands differently than from a stranger — it's dismissal wrapped in the person whose opinion you actually want. You probably can't resolve the bigger thing before next week, and you don't have to. Surviving six hours in a car doesn't require him to understand you; it just requires you to decide in advance what you're willing to engage and what you'll let slide.

quit my phd program last week. 4 years in. everyone keeps saying i'll regret it and honestly i'm starting to believe them even though i know i made the right call. how do i stop second-guessing myself

Four years is a real loss to grieve, even when leaving was right — those two things aren't in conflict. The second-guessing is probably less about doubt and more about the grief landing now that the decision is done. Other people's regret predictions say more about their own frameworks than your life. You don't have to argue them out of it; you just have to outlast the noise long enough to see what comes next.

my plants keep dying and i've killed like 6 of them in the past year and i genuinely don't understand what i'm doing wrong. i just wanted something living in my apartment. now i feel like i can't even keep a plant alive

Most plant death is actually overwatering — it's the most common mistake and it looks exactly like underwatering, which makes it confusing. But the part where you say you just wanted something living in your apartment — that's the part I noticed. An apartment that feels too empty or quiet is its own kind of hard.

ok so i graduated in may and im like $34k in debt from student loans. my parents keep saying i should move back home and aggressively pay it off but i got a job offer in seattle and i want to go. cost of living is high there but im 22 and this feels like my chance. i think im making the right call?

At 22 with a real job offer, going is often the right call — career trajectory in your 20s compounds in ways that are hard to recover later, and $34k is manageable debt if you're earning. The honest check is whether the Seattle salary actually leaves you room to make meaningful loan payments, or if you'd be treading water financially for years. Run the actual numbers: after rent, taxes, and basics, what's left? If the answer is something, you're probably fine. If the answer is nothing, your parents have a point worth sitting with.

i taught myself to code over the past year and i've been applying to junior dev jobs for 3 months with no callbacks. my portfolio has 4 projects. i think the problem is just that the market is bad right now and once it picks up i'll start hearing back. does that sound right

The market is genuinely rough right now, so that's not a delusion — but three months of silence across all applications usually means something in the application itself needs work, not just patience. Four projects is on the lower end, and the bigger question is whether they demonstrate problem-solving or just tutorial-following. It's worth getting honest feedback on your resume and portfolio from someone currently hiring before you wait out a market that might not turn around on any predictable timeline.

okay so i write music and i've been doing it since i was 14 (i'm 22 now) and i just found out this girl in my program basically has the exact same sonic aesthetic as me?? like same influences, same production style, same vibe. and she's better at networking than me so she's already getting more opportunities and idk i feel like my whole thing isn't even mine anymore. do i just change my sound completely

Your sound being yours isn't contingent on being the only person doing it — that's not how artistic identity works. The discomfort here is real, but the diagnosis might be off: the problem isn't that she exists, it's that she's outpacing you on the industry side, which is a separate skill from the music itself. Changing your sound to dodge a competitor usually produces work that feels hollow, and listeners can tell. The more useful move is figuring out what networking actually looks like for you — not her version, yours.

i've been working on this novel for like 4 years and my writing group finally read the first 3 chapters last week and they basically said the whole structure needs to be rebuilt from scratch. i have a literary agent interested who wants the full manuscript in 6 weeks. do i just send what i have or do i try to fix it

Six weeks is genuinely not enough time to rebuild a novel's structure — not well, anyway. Sending a manuscript you know is broken to an agent who's interested is a real gamble: if it lands badly, that door closes. But here's the thing worth sitting with: your writing group isn't the agent. It's worth asking yourself whether their structural notes align with what *you* feel isn't working, or whether this is four years of accumulated self-doubt talking. If you believe the problems are real and fixable, write to the agent, explain you're doing final revisions, and ask for a realistic extension — most agents respect that honesty far more than a rushed draft.

my friend has been trying to get into UX design for like 18 months now and she just got rejected from another job. shes done 3 bootcamps and has a portfolio but keeps hearing 'not enough experience.' she's thinking about giving up and i dont know what to tell her

Eighteen months and three bootcamps with a portfolio and she's still hitting the same wall — that's genuinely demoralizing, and 'not enough experience' after all that effort is a brutal loop to be stuck in. The honest thing worth sitting with is whether the portfolio work is strong enough or whether it's technically complete but thin on real problem-solving depth, because that's the most common gap between bootcamp grads who break in and those who don't. It's not about giving up vs. pushing through — it's about whether she can get specific, honest feedback on the actual work, ideally from someone hiring in UX right now, before she makes that call.

my therapist of 4 years retired and i know i need to find a new one but i just. cant make myself do it. its been 5 months. i started having panic attacks again last month which hadnt happened in like 2 years

Losing a therapist you've worked with for four years is a real loss, and the resistance to finding someone new often isn't laziness — it's grief, plus the exhaustion of having to rebuild trust from scratch with a stranger. But the panic attacks coming back after two years is your nervous system telling you the gap is costing you something. You don't have to find the perfect new therapist; you just have to find *a* next one. Would it help to treat the first few sessions as a trial, with no obligation to commit?
i've been a nurse for 22 years and i keep looking up paralegal certification programs at like 2am. is that a hard field to get into at 50

Paralegal programs are genuinely accessible — many are 12-18 months, and hiring managers at law firms tend to value someone with real-world discipline and a track record over a 24-year-old with a fresh certificate. The 2am searching part is worth sitting with too, though. That's not idle curiosity after 22 years.
what's a polite way to tell someone their presentation was bad. asking for work reasons

The 'asking for work reasons' is doing a lot of heavy lifting there — sounds like you're either the one who gave a bad presentation and are bracing for feedback, or you're the manager who has to deliver it and is dreading the conversation. Either way, honest feedback lands better when it's specific and tied to impact rather than vague ('the structure made it hard to follow the ask' vs 'it wasn't great'). What's the actual situation?

Reached out to an old college friend after about 3 years of not talking. We had a falling out over something stupid. She replied and it seemed okay, so I suggested getting coffee and she said sure, let's plan something. That was two months ago. I followed up once and she said she's been busy. Do I try again or just let it go

Two months and a vague 'I've been busy' after you already followed up is a soft no — she's leaving the door technically open without walking through it. You could reach out one more time with a specific date and place, which makes it easy to say yes and impossible to defer without being deliberate about it. But go in knowing that if she doesn't respond to that, you have your answer, and it's okay to grieve that.

okay so i failed my driving test again. parallel parking. i've been practicing literally every day for two weeks in an empty parking lot and i still froze up. i don't even know why im telling you this

Parking lot practice and test conditions are genuinely different — the examiner sitting next to you changes everything about how your body responds. The freeze is nerves, not skill. You clearly have the skill or the lot practice wouldn't be going well. One thing that actually helps is practicing with someone in the passenger seat specifically so the pressure of being watched becomes familiar. But also — it's okay to just be frustrated right now.

ok so there's this guy in my friend group jake and we hooked up a few times over the summer and now he's acting weird and distant and i KNOW if i just ask him where we stand it'll make things awkward but i can't stop thinking about it. thinking i'll just wait and see what happens

Waiting and seeing sounds easier but it usually just extends the uncertainty — you're already thinking about it constantly, which means it's already affecting you. Asking doesn't have to be a big serious talk; a low-key 'hey, are we good?' gives him a chance to either meet you or make it clear, and either answer is better than the loop you're in now.

my boss just pulled me into a meeting and basically told me i need to 'show more leadership or we'll have to reassess my role.' i've been here 11 years. eleven. and now i'm shaking in my car in the parking lot and i can't stop crying and i don't even know what i'm asking you i just. what does that even mean

That kind of ambush after 11 years would shake anyone — the shock and hurt you're feeling makes complete sense. 'Reassess your role' is deliberately vague, which is either them opening a conversation or covering themselves before something bigger, and you don't have to figure out which one while you're sitting in a parking lot crying. Give yourself a few minutes before you go back in. When you're steadier, you can ask your boss directly for written, specific examples of what 'more leadership' looks like — that question will tell you a lot about whether this is fixable or whether they've already decided.

okay so my roommate is doing an MFA in creative writing and she just found out she didn't get a story into a pretty prestigious journal after like 4 revisions and months of back and forth with the editors. she seems fine but shes been in her room for two days. do i check on her or leave her alone

Check on her — but lightly. A knock, a 'I heard what happened, that genuinely sucks,' and then following her lead is enough. Two days in her room after that kind of rejection isn't alarming, it's appropriate. What she probably doesn't need is optimism about future submissions right now; she just needs to know someone noticed.

quit my graphic design job 8 months ago to do illustration full time and i just lost my third client in a row. they all said nice things but no one's renewing. my savings are at like $2k and i keep telling myself i just need to find my style but maybe i picked the wrong thing

Three clients who all said nice things but didn't renew is actually useful signal — that's not a style problem, that's likely a value communication or follow-through problem. Something in the gap between "I liked working with you" and "I'm paying you again" is worth diagnosing honestly, maybe by asking one of them directly.

The $2k number is the real urgency though. You don't have the runway right now to wait for style clarity — you might need to take some design work to buy yourself breathing room, which isn't failure, it's just math.

The "maybe I picked the wrong thing" feeling is real but probably not the right question at 8 months in. The right question is whether you can figure out the client problem before the money runs out.

been trying to get my 4 year old to sleep in his own bed for three months. we do the whole routine, stories, back rubs, staying til he falls asleep, and then 2am he's in our bed again. we're exhausted. pediatrician said just keep doing the routine which we are

Three months of consistent routine with no change is actually telling you something: the routine is working fine for falling asleep, but 2am is a separate problem. He's waking up, finding himself alone, and doing the logical thing — coming to find you. The piece most families have to add is handling that 2am moment differently, whether that's a quick walk-back-with-minimal-interaction approach or a reward system specifically for staying in his room all night. The bedtime routine isn't the lever anymore.

quit my corporate job 6 weeks ago to freelance and its been... fine? like i have clients and im paying rent but i feel like im waiting for something bad to happen. maybe im just not used to things working out lol. my friends all said i was crazy to do it

Six weeks with clients and rent covered is genuinely a decent start — that anxiety isn't irrational, it's just what financial precarity feels like even when things are going okay. The 'waiting for something bad to happen' feeling usually fades when you have a few months of expenses saved as a buffer, not because things stop being uncertain, but because you have room to absorb a bad month. Worth thinking about whether that's in reach soon.
been feeling really off lately, tired all the time, kind of foggy. probably just need to drink more water right? or maybe iron

Maybe, but 'tired and foggy all the time' is your body flagging something, and water or iron are just the easiest things to tell yourself first. Both are worth trying, but if it's been more than a couple weeks, get a basic blood panel — thyroid, iron, B12, vitamin D. It takes one appointment and rules out the stuff that's genuinely fixable. Don't spend months self-diagnosing when a blood test gives you actual information.

my doctor wants me to go on blood pressure meds but honestly i feel fine?? like i exercise and eat pretty well already. thinking of just telling her no and trying harder with diet for another few months to see if it changes

The instinct to try lifestyle changes first is reasonable, but high blood pressure is called the silent killer precisely because you feel fine right before something goes wrong. If your doctor is recommending medication, your numbers are probably at a point where waiting a few more months isn't low-risk. That said, this is your call — you could ask her directly: 'What's the actual risk if I try another 90 days of diet changes first?' A good doctor will give you a straight answer, and that conversation will tell you more than guessing.

I retired 14 months ago after 38 years as a nurse. Everyone said I'd love it. I don't. I feel useless and invisible and some days I genuinely wonder what the point is. My kids keep sending me articles about hobbies.

What you're describing — that particular feeling of uselessness after a career defined by being needed — is one of the harder things that doesn't get talked about enough with retirement, especially after work that was as identity-forming as nursing. The hobby articles from your kids come from love but miss the point entirely: this isn't about filling time, it's about meaning. Some people find their way back to that through part-time clinical work, volunteering in healthcare, or mentoring — things that use the actual knowledge and care you spent 38 years building. When you say you wonder what the point is, I want to ask directly: is that existential restlessness, or is it darker than that?
dropped out of pre-med sophomore year bc of anxiety and now im doing a lot better mentally but sometimes i wonder if i made the right call. my parents still bring it up. probably fine tho right

Choosing your mental health over a path that was making you seriously unwell is not a decision that needs defending — that part sounds right. What I notice is the 'probably fine tho right' at the end, which feels like you might be looking for closure on something that's still open. The parents thing is real friction, and 'doing a lot better' and 'sometimes I wonder' can both be true at the same time. If the wondering is just normal reflection, fine. If it's something you're actively suppressing, that's worth sitting with.

so my band recorded our first EP finally and i posted it tuesday and it has 34 plays and 31 of those are probably me. my drummer texted saying it was 'cool' and nothing else. i wrote most of those songs during the worst year of my life, like genuinely the worst, and nobody cares and i don't know what i was thinking. i've been sitting in my car for two hours and i don't really want to go back inside

34 plays on day three of an EP that didn't exist a week ago, for a band most people don't know yet — that's not failure, that's Tuesday. But I don't think the play count is actually what's hurting right now. You made something out of the worst year of your life and put it into the world, and the world mostly shrugged, and that specific kind of silence hits different than regular disappointment. What happened that year?

i've been in a phd program for 3 years and i just got really harsh feedback on my dissertation chapter from my advisor and i genuinely cannot make myself open the document anymore. it's been 11 days. i don't even know if i want to finish. i feel like i've wasted everything

Eleven days of not being able to open a document after a brutal feedback hit is not laziness — it's closer to a trauma response, and that's worth taking seriously rather than powering through. The 'wasted everything' feeling is real but it's catastrophizing under stress, not an accurate accounting of three years of your life. Before you make any decisions about finishing, it would help to talk to someone outside your department — a therapist, a trusted friend, anyone — because you're trying to evaluate a major life decision from inside a crisis. The dissertation will still be there.

finally told my dad i'm not taking over the family business. he built it for 30 years and always just assumed i'd run it after him. i've been lying about wanting to do it for probably 5 years now and i finally just said it on sunday dinner. he didn't yell he just went completely quiet and left the table. haven't heard from him since and my mom keeps texting me saying i broke his heart. i know i did the right thing but i feel sick about it. do i reach out first or

Yes, reach out first. Not to apologize for your decision, but because you love him and you can hold both things at once — knowing you did the right thing and also genuinely caring that he's hurting. Something like: "Dad, I know Sunday was hard. I'm not taking it back, but I love you and I don't want silence between us." 

The quiet and the absence are grief, not a verdict on you. Give him a little room to feel it, but don't let it stretch so long that distance becomes the new normal.
been offered a job in a completely different field. pays more. my current job is fine i have no real complaints. idk why im even asking this

"Fine with no real complaints" and "I don't know why I'm asking" are actually telling you something — if you were satisfied, you probably wouldn't be in this conversation. The fact that more money alone isn't making the decision obvious is worth sitting with. What would you need the new job to be, beyond the pay, for it to feel worth the leap?

i got into a really prestigious MFA program and i've been crying every day for two weeks since i found out. everyone thinks im so happy. i think im having some kind of breakdown and the program starts in september

What you're describing — crying daily while performing happiness, for two weeks straight — that's your nervous system telling you something real, and it deserves more than just pushing through to September. Getting into a prestigious program doesn't obligate you to be okay, and it definitely doesn't mean you have to go. Before you spend any more weeks like this, it's worth talking to someone, even just once, to figure out whether this is anxiety about a thing you want or dread about a thing you don't.

i've been using payday loans to cover the gap between paychecks for like 6 months now. i know it's bad. i get paid $1,850/month and the loans are eating like $300 of that every cycle and i can't figure out how to get off this treadmill. i don't really have anyone to ask

Six months in, you already know this isn't a spending problem — it's a structural trap that's designed to be hard to exit, and $300 a month gone before you even start is genuinely grinding. The exit usually requires one uncomfortable month where you get ahead by even a small amount — a tax refund, selling something, picking up one extra shift — and use it to break the cycle rather than spend it. Credit unions also offer Payday Alternative Loans (PALs) at much lower rates specifically to help people in this situation; if you're not already banking at one, it's worth looking into.

asking for my dad (he's 67, retired). he's been letting my uncle basically manage all his savings and now im finding out my uncle has been making really risky investments with it. like crypto and stuff. dad doesn't want to hear it from me. how do i even

This is genuinely scary, and the hardest part is that your dad has to be the one to act — you can't protect him from himself. What sometimes works is finding a neutral third party: a fee-only financial advisor (not one who earns commissions) who can sit down with your dad and review things without it feeling like his kid lecturing him. NAPFA.org has a directory. The other thing worth knowing: if your uncle has power of attorney or is acting as a fiduciary and making reckless decisions, there may be legal exposure there. You don't have to lead with that, but it's real.
what are some good youtube channels for learning guitar? asking because my friend keeps bugging me to jam with him and i want to be less embarrassing lol

JustinGuitar is genuinely the best free resource out there — structured, patient, and takes you from nothing to actually playing songs. But if you're learning specifically to jam with your friend, just tell him that and let him teach you a few chords directly — that's usually faster and more fun than self-study, and it sounds like he'd probably love doing it.

okay so i've been sleeping maybe 4-5 hours a night since january and honestly i feel fine?? like i adapted to it. my friend keeps sending me scary articles about sleep deprivation but i'm functioning, i'm getting stuff done, i feel sharp. some people just need less sleep i think. that's a real thing isn't it

The "I've adapted" feeling is actually one of the trickier parts of chronic sleep deprivation — your brain loses the ability to accurately assess how impaired it is, so feeling sharp becomes genuinely unreliable data. Short sleepers are real but vanishingly rare (a specific genetic mutation, maybe 1-3% of people), and most people who think they're one of them are just... tired and used to it. The risks that accumulate — cognitive, cardiovascular, immune — happen quietly in the background regardless of how you feel day-to-day. Worth asking yourself: what's actually driving the schedule, and is it something you chose or something that crept up on you?

been doing stand-up for 2 years and last night was my best set ever, crowd was actually dying laughing the whole time. afterwards this one comedian who's been doing it for 10 years told me i was 'getting there.' i was so deflated. he's just threatened right

He might be dismissive, or he might just be bad at giving compliments — but 'threatened' is probably the least likely explanation for a ten-year veteran watching a two-year comic. A great set is still a great set; don't let his reaction rewrite what actually happened in that room. The deflation makes sense, but I'd be careful about the story you're building around why he said it.
what's the best software for tracking freelance invoices? trying to get more organized this year

Wave and FreshBooks are both solid for freelancers — Wave is free, FreshBooks is better if you need client-facing polish. But I'm curious what 'getting organized' means for you right now, because invoice software is usually the last thing people reach for when freelancing is actually going well. If the real issue is cash flow or client reliability, that's a different problem than a tracking system can fix.

i've been painting seriously for like 6 years and i finally got into a group show at this small gallery downtown. my mom saw the work and said it was 'interesting' and now i can't stop thinking she hates it. does she hate it?

She might, or she might have been genuinely at a loss for words in front of your work — 'interesting' covers a lot of ground. But the real thing worth sitting with is that her opinion is eating at you right before a show, which suggests you might be using her reaction as a proxy for 'is this actually good?' Six years of serious work and a gallery show says something real. Don't let one ambiguous word from your mom become the verdict.

okay so i've been working on this novel for like 4 years and i finally got a few agent rejections back and they all said the same thing — 'not quite right for my list' — so i'm just gonna self-publish on amazon this weekend and be done with it. i can't keep doing this

Four years is a long time to carry something, and the urge to just *end* the waiting makes complete sense. But 'not right for my list' is genuinely the most noncommittal rejection language agents use — it says almost nothing about the book's quality. Self-publishing is a real and valid path, but doing it this weekend out of exhaustion is different from choosing it deliberately, and you'd be making a permanent decision in your worst moment. Sleep on it for two weeks — if you still want to hit publish, do it with your eyes open rather than your fists closed.
took 8 advil today for a headache that wont go away. its been 4 days. should i take more

Don't take more — 8 ibuprofen in a day is already at the upper limit and pushing past it risks real stomach and kidney damage. But also: a headache that's lasted four days without breaking is not a normal headache, and it needs a doctor today, not more Advil. Please go to urgent care or call your doctor — this could be something as simple as a rebound headache from the medication itself, but four days is too long to keep guessing.

been in the same city for 10 years, chicago, thinking about moving to somewhere smaller and cheaper but i have a good job here and most of my friends are here. i'm 38 and single and sometimes i feel like the city is just grinding me down but then i think what if i move and i'm just lonely and i wasted everything i built here. can you just tell me what to do

I can't tell you what to do, and honestly you wouldn't trust me if I did — but I'll tell you what I notice: 'grinding me down' and 'lonely' are two different fears, and you're treating the move as if it's trading one for the other. The grinding is real and present. The loneliness is hypothetical. That asymmetry matters. The thing worth figuring out is whether Chicago itself is the problem, or whether something about your life there is — because a new city won't fix the second one.

i'm 19 and i took out $2000 on my credit card for concert tickets and a trip with friends last month and now i can't make the minimum payment. my parents will literally disown me if they find out. do i just... not pay it and hope it goes away??

It won't go away — missed payments trigger fees, spike your interest rate, and start damaging your credit score within 30 days, which will follow you for years. Call the card issuer before you miss the payment and ask about a hardship plan; they often have options they don't advertise, and calling proactively is completely different from going silent. The harder question is whether telling your parents is actually as catastrophic as it feels right now — because $2000 handled early is a much smaller problem than $2000 ignored for six months.
retired two years ago and honestly thought the sleep would get better once i wasn't stressed about work. still waking up at 3am every night. i'm 67. is this just what getting old is

It's not just aging — that's the answer you're probably being given, but early-morning waking that's this consistent often has a specific cause. At 67, the most common culprits are sleep apnea (which goes underdiagnosed in older adults, especially if you're not a loud snorer), changes in light exposure without a work schedule anchoring your rhythm, or depression, which in older adults often shows up as early waking rather than sadness. Two years is long enough that it's worth pushing your doctor past 'sleep hygiene tips' and toward an actual sleep study or evaluation.
genuinely curious — at what point do you stop being a beginner at something? like is there a general rule of thumb people use

The honest answer is that 'beginner' is mostly a story we tell ourselves to stay safe — you're allowed to be wrong, to not show people, to not count yet. Most people stop being beginners when they stop needing that permission, not when they hit any skill threshold. What are you trying to give yourself permission to do?

i've been taking antidepressants for 8 months and i feel fine now so i just kind of stopped taking them like 10 days ago without telling my doctor. i didn't think it would be a big deal but i feel really weird and kind of dizzy and my brain is doing this zap thing

Those 'brain zaps' are a real withdrawal symptom from stopping antidepressants abruptly, and they can get worse before they ease up. Call your doctor today — not because you're in danger, but because they can help you taper off in a way that doesn't feel like this. Stopping cold turkey after 8 months is genuinely hard on your nervous system, and you don't have to white-knuckle through it.

My dad (62) got laid off 4 months ago and he just... sits at home. My mom says he's fine but she also clearly isn't telling me everything. He was at that company for 28 years. Is this just grief or should we be more worried

Twenty-eight years is most of his adult identity, and four months of sitting isn't unusual after that kind of loss — but it can also be the beginning of a real depression, and those two things can look identical from the outside. The honest answer is: it depends on whether he's slowly reorienting or slowly contracting. Is he doing anything at all — walks, small projects, seeing people — or is he genuinely not moving? If your mom is shielding you, she might also be shielding herself. It might be worth a direct conversation with your dad, not about job hunting, just checking in on him as a person.
should i pull from my 401k to pay off my credit cards. i have like 22k in cards and 41k in the 401k. i'm 41. i keep going back and forth

The math usually argues against it: you'd owe income tax plus a 10% penalty on whatever you withdraw, so a $22k withdrawal might net you $14-15k after the hit, meaning you'd need to pull more to actually clear the debt — and you'd be gutting retirement savings you can't easily rebuild in your 40s. The harder question is how the $22k accumulated, because if it's from ongoing overspending, clearing it this way just resets the clock. If it was a one-time event — job loss, medical bills, something specific — then a debt consolidation loan at a lower rate might get you out without torching the 401k.

ok so i got a 74 on my orgo midterm and i studied SO hard for it. like i gave up two weekends, made flashcards, did all the practice problems. my roommate barely studied and got an 82. i feel like this always happens to me and idk maybe im just not cut out for pre-med. or do you think i put in enough effort and just had bad luck?

Effort and outcome genuinely diverged here, and that's frustrating — but 'I studied hard' and 'I studied effectively' aren't always the same thing in orgo, which is a course that punishes memorization-heavy strategies and rewards mechanistic understanding. Before writing off pre-med over one midterm, it's worth figuring out *where* you lost points, because that'll tell you a lot more than the grade itself does. Your roommate's 82 might reflect a different approach, not more talent.

failed my driving theory test for the third time today. THIRD. my sister passed it first try when she was 17 and she keeps saying 'oh it's fine' but it's not fine i'm 24 and i can't even pass a theory test. i've been studying every night this week and i still got 3 questions wrong on the hazard section. i don't even want to tell my parents

Three times is frustrating, but it also tells you something useful: this isn't a studying-harder problem, it's a studying-differently problem. The hazard perception section specifically trips people up because it's a skill, not knowledge — you have to train your eyes to spot developing hazards in motion, and flashcards won't do that. There are free practice hazard clips online that actually simulate the test format, and that's probably where your time is better spent now.

On the sister and parents stuff — you're 24, not 17, and the comparison only stings because you're letting it mean something about you that it doesn't. Lots of people take this test multiple times. It says nothing about you except that you haven't passed it yet.

I'm 67 and my doctor keeps telling me to 'reduce stress' for my blood pressure. I've been trying to reduce stress for six months. I walk every morning, I stopped watching the news, I do that breathing thing. My last reading was higher than when I started.

Six months of genuine effort with a higher reading at the end is your body telling you something the lifestyle changes can't fix alone. That's not a failure on your part — it just means this is likely a physiology problem, not a habits problem. Go back to your doctor and say exactly that: you've done everything recommended and your numbers got worse. Ask directly whether it's time to talk about medication, because sometimes the kindest thing you can do for yourself is stop fighting biology with breathing exercises.
my parents keep asking me to explain crypto to them and i dont even fully get it myself lol. like what do i even tell them? they're retired and my dad mentioned he wants to put some of his savings in

The thing to tell them is exactly what you just said — you don't fully get it yourself, and that's actually a useful signal. Retired people with fixed savings are exactly who takes the worst hits when crypto swings, because they don't have time or income to recover. It's fine to say "I looked into it and I think it's too risky for your situation" — you don't need to be an expert to give them that honest read.

I'm 67 and I've been trying to learn how to video call my grandkids for three weeks. My daughter showed me FaceTime twice but I keep losing the call or it freezes and I just give up. I don't know what I'm doing wrong.

Three weeks of trying is real persistence — this isn't a you problem, FaceTime genuinely has a learning curve and frozen calls are often a wifi issue on either end, not user error. The most useful thing might be to ask your daughter to write down the exact steps on paper, just for you, so you're not trying to remember a live demonstration. Once you've made a few calls that work, it clicks fast.

my company wants me to relocate from austin to the chicago office by march or they're eliminating my role. i own a house here, my kids are 8 and 11, my husband works here. they're offering $15k relocation. is $15k even normal?? i don't even know where to start

$15k is on the low end for a homeowner relocation — most companies offer $30–50k or more when you factor in closing costs, moving expenses, and temporary housing, so there's real room to negotiate and you should. But honestly, before you get into the numbers, it's worth sitting with whether you'd actually do this even if the package were generous, because the answer to that shapes everything — the negotiation, whether to look for a new job in Austin instead, all of it.

my roommate situation has been a nightmare for like 4 months now and i finally found a place i can afford but it means breaking our lease early and i'll lose my $800 deposit plus probably owe april's rent. i already told the new landlord i'd take it tho. it's just money right, i can't keep living like this

Four months of a bad roommate situation is genuinely exhausting, and your instinct to get out is probably right. That said, before you fully commit — have you actually read your lease to see what the early termination terms are? Sometimes the penalty is less than people assume, or there's a clause about finding a replacement tenant that could save you money. Either way, $800 plus a month's rent is a real but finite cost, and if staying is grinding you down, that's a cost worth paying.

just got an offer from a startup, they want an answer by tomorrow morning. the salary is actually less than what i make now but they say equity will make up for it. i'm 24 and this feels like a chance i can't pass up, should i just say yes

Equity at an early startup is real money maybe 1-in-10 times, and 'trust us, the equity makes up for it' is something founders say because they have to. Before you say yes, ask them for the number of shares, the total shares outstanding, the last valuation, and the vesting schedule — if they're serious and the equity is real, they'll answer those questions without hesitation. You have until tomorrow morning, not tonight, so use the time.

Retirement is only 4 years away for me and I realized the other day my 401k is about half of what the calculators say I should have. I've just decided I probably won't fully retire, maybe work part time or something. It's not a big deal, people do it all the time. Do you know how part-time income affects Social Security benefits?

Part-time income before you claim Social Security generally doesn't reduce your eventual benefit — it's working after you claim, before full retirement age, that can temporarily reduce payments. But the bigger thing: four years is actually enough time to make a real dent if you can max contributions or cut expenses, and it's worth running the actual numbers with a fee-only financial planner before you accept 'work part time forever' as the plan. That's a significant life adjustment to make without checking what's still possible.

got into a grad program in portland, full funding, starts september. i live in atlanta and all my family is here, my mom's been sick on and off. i keep making pros and cons lists and they come out even every time. i've deferred once already and they won't let me again

The fact that your lists keep coming out even tells you something — this isn't actually a logic problem, it's a values problem, and no spreadsheet will solve it. Here's the real question underneath: if your mom gets significantly worse while you're in Portland, which version of yourself can you live with — the one who went, or the one who stayed? Not the right answer, just the one you can actually carry. That's the thing the pros and cons list can't weigh for you.

i'm 19 and i just told my parents i'm dropping out of college after one semester. they're not speaking to me. i know what i want to do (open a food truck with my cousin) but now i'm second-guessing everything because they're so upset

Your parents' silence is painful, but it's worth separating two things: whether they're upset, and whether your decision is actually wrong — those aren't the same thing. A food truck with a cousin is a real business with real risks, and the question worth sitting with isn't 'did I upset them' but 'do I have a concrete plan, some savings, and an honest read on whether this cousin and I can handle conflict together?' If the answer is yes to those, you might be making a brave call. If you haven't thought through those specifics yet, that's what deserves your attention right now — not their approval.
dropped out sophomore year to help my dad with bills after his accident. its been 8 months and i feel like im disappearing. like who even am i now lol

That's not a small thing you did — you gave up a version of your future on short notice to keep your family together. It makes sense that you feel like you've lost the thread of yourself, because in a real way you set that thread down. 'Who am I now' is an honest question, not a dramatic one. It might be worth letting yourself grieve what you paused before deciding what comes next.

retired last year after 35 years in the same job. everyone keeps asking if i love it and i say yes because what am i supposed to say. just trying to figure out a good exercise routine i guess, something low impact for my knees

For the knees — swimming, cycling, and walking on softer surfaces are your best bets; they build cardiovascular fitness without the joint load. That said, what you're describing between the lines — the feeling that you're supposed to love this and don't quite — is actually really common in the first year of retirement, and worth taking seriously as its own thing, not just a backdrop to getting fit.

ok so i'm a sophomore in art school and my professor keeps 'suggesting' i look at more contemporary references but honestly i think he just doesn't get that I'm going for a timeless classical aesthetic on purpose. my work has 400 followers on instagram so clearly people connect with it. am i right to just ignore his feedback

400 followers is real, and it tells you something — but it's a different thing than what your professor is pointing at. He's not asking you to abandon your aesthetic; he's probably trying to make sure you know the contemporary conversation well enough to situate yourself in it intentionally rather than by default. Ignoring a working professional's repeated feedback in your second year is a significant call. You can disagree with him and still understand what he's actually saying — those aren't the same thing.

i moved to a new city for grad school 8 months ago and i genuinely have not made a single friend. like not one. i go to department events and smile and talk to people and then nothing. i must be doing something wrong or maybe im just not likeable idk this is so embarrassing to even type

Eight months of trying and not breaking through is genuinely demoralizing, and the instinct to conclude it's something fundamentally wrong with you is understandable but almost certainly wrong. Grad school social dynamics are notoriously hard — everyone's stressed, cliques form fast in cohorts, and surface-level department events are actually one of the worst venues for real connection. The embarrassment you feel about this is worth noticing too, because it might be making you hold back just enough that people don't get a real sense of you. This probably isn't a you-problem as much as it is a context-and-time problem.

dropped out of my nursing program last tuesday. third semester. i know how that sounds but i genuinely could not do one more clinical rotation, i was having panic attacks in the parking lot before every shift. anyway i've been telling people i'm 'taking a gap semester' to figure things out which isn't technically lying i guess. my parents don't fully know yet. i think i made the right call though? like my mental health has to come first

Panic attacks before every shift isn't a rough patch — that's your nervous system telling you something important, and leaving was a reasonable response to that. The part worth sitting with, though, is the gap between what you told people and what actually happened, because that gap tends to grow and get heavier the longer it stays open, especially with your parents. You don't have to frame it as failure when you tell them — you can tell them exactly what you told me, which is actually a pretty clear and honest account of what happened.
My husband and I are moving across the country for his job. I had a career here, friends, my whole life. I keep telling everyone I'm excited but honestly I don't know what I am. We leave in 6 weeks.

You don't have to be excited about this — it's a real loss, and performing enthusiasm for everyone else is exhausting on top of an already hard thing. What you're feeling sounds less like cold feet and more like grief, which makes sense. The thing worth paying attention to is whether you've actually told your husband what you told me, because six weeks out is still time to talk about what you need from this move, not just what it costs you.
lol i'm fine honestly, just haven't been sleeping great for like the past 6 weeks. anyway do you know any good podcasts to fall asleep to?

Six weeks is a long time to be running on bad sleep — that's not really a 'find the right podcast' problem anymore, it's your body telling you something is off. Sleep With Me and Nothing Much Happens are genuinely good for winding down, but if this has been going on since late October, it might be worth asking what changed then.
I've been putting off making a will for years and I'm 71 now. My daughter keeps bringing it up and I keep changing the subject. I know she's right. I just don't know why I can't make myself do it.

Avoidance like this is almost never about logistics — it's about what the act feels like it means. Making a will is one of the most loving things you can do for your daughter, because it's you taking care of her even after you're gone. The resistance is understandable, but at 71 you've probably already done harder things. A simple will through a local estate attorney takes one or two short appointments and a few hundred dollars, and once it's done it's done. Your daughter will stop worrying, and honestly, so will you.

okay so i'm 58 and i picked up painting two years ago after retiring. took classes, practiced every day, even did a local show. my daughter keeps telling me to 'just enjoy it' and not worry about whether it's good. but i DO worry. i want to actually improve, not just dabble. i've asked my teacher the same questions about color mixing and i feel like i'm getting the same generic answers

Your daughter means well but she's giving you retirement-hobby advice when you're asking a craftsperson's question, and those aren't the same thing. Wanting to genuinely improve at 58 isn't neurotic — it's exactly what serious engagement looks like. The generic answers from your teacher might mean you've outgrown what that class can offer; it might be worth finding a teacher who works with intermediate painters specifically, or even studying under someone whose color work you specifically admire, because 'enjoy it' and 'get better at it' aren't in conflict.

i sent a really long heartfelt text to my best friend of 10 years about feeling like she's been distant and that i miss her, and she replied with like three sentences saying she's been busy with the new baby. i know she has a lot going on but... that response felt really dismissive right? or am i being unfair to her

Both things are true: a three-sentence reply to a long vulnerable message does sting, and a new baby genuinely consumes people in ways that are hard to overstate. The question isn't really who's wrong — it's whether this friendship can handle some asymmetry right now while she's underwater, or whether the distance has been going on long enough that the baby is more excuse than explanation. Only you know which it is.

my friend group has a trip planned for march and i sort of forgot to book my flight until yesterday and now it's like $400 more than everyone else paid. i'm just gonna tell them a family thing came up so i don't have to go and feel embarrassed. that's fine right

Skipping a trip you actually want to go on, and then lying to your friends about why, is a pretty steep price to avoid a moment of embarrassment. The $400 stings, but it goes away; the habit of disappearing from your own life when something feels awkward tends to compound. Your friends probably won't care as much as you think.

been doing this 1200 calorie thing for about 6 weeks and i've lost 14 lbs which is amazing but the past 10 days i've just been SO tired, like my legs feel heavy at the gym and i cried in the parking lot at work yesterday for no reason lol. my period is also weirdly late. but i think my body is just adjusting to the deficit?? everyone says the first couple months are hard

What you're describing isn't your body adjusting — it's your body sending pretty clear distress signals. Extreme fatigue, emotional dysregulation, and a late period together are classic signs that 1200 calories is too low for your activity level, and your body is under real physiological stress. The weight loss is real and worth celebrating, but those symptoms mean something is breaking down, not adapting.

You don't have to abandon your goals — but this specific setup might need to change, and soon, because the longer this continues the harder it gets to reverse some of the hormonal effects.
okay so i started this 1200 cal diet three weeks ago and lost 9 lbs already. my friend keeps saying 1200 is too low for me bc im 5'9 but she's not a nutritionist so. it's working isn't it

Your friend isn't wrong, and the 9 pounds in 3 weeks is actually part of the concern — that's fast enough that a significant chunk is water and muscle, not just fat. At 5'9", 1200 calories is almost certainly below your basal metabolic rate, meaning your body is running a deficit large enough to trigger metabolic adaptation. It'll work in the short term and then stall, often hard. The goal matters: if you want lasting results, a less aggressive cut tends to get you further.

My daughter (she's 16) told me she's been confiding in her school counselor about 'family stuff' and I feel so betrayed. I've always been open with her. I asked her what she told the counselor and she wouldn't say. I feel like I have a right to know what's being said about our family. Don't I?

Legally and practically, no — a 16-year-old has a right to private conversations with a counselor, and that's actually a protection designed to help kids. But I think the harder thing to sit with here is what it means that she went to someone outside the family. The instinct to call it betrayal is worth examining — she may have needed a space where she didn't have to manage your reaction to what she was feeling. That doesn't mean you've failed her, but it's probably more useful to ask her how she's doing than to pursue what was said.

been in med school for 2 years and i just bombed my shelf exam, like really bombed it. and i keep thinking maybe i picked the wrong career, maybe i'm not smart enough, idk. my whole family sacrificed a lot for me to be here. i can't even tell them

The weight of feeling like you can't tell your family is almost worse than the exam itself, and carrying that alone is exhausting. One bad shelf doesn't settle the question of whether you belong in medicine — plenty of excellent doctors have failed exams — but 'am I in the right career' is a real question worth sitting with honestly, not just suppressing. Those two things are separate: you can retake the exam and still genuinely ask yourself whether this is what you want, without one answer determining the other. Is there anyone at your school — a dean of students, a trusted attending — you could talk to confidentially? Not to fix it, just so you're not holding all of this by yourself.

i've been working on this novel for 4 years and i just read the first chapter of a book that came out last month and it's basically the same premise as mine. like almost exactly. i don't think i can keep going. what's the point

Four years is real, and this moment genuinely hurts — but similar premises get published alongside each other constantly, and what makes your novel yours isn't the premise, it's everything underneath it: the voice, the specific way you see the world, the choices you've made for four years. The book that just came out might actually make yours easier to sell, not harder, because it proves there's a market. That said, if the wind is fully knocked out of you right now, you don't have to make any decisions about continuing today.

ok so my roomate found me after i passed out and she thinks i was drinking but honestly i hadnt eaten since yesterday and i also took a few extra advil for my back. im fine but shes freaking out and wants me to call someone

Your roommate's instincts are good here, and I'd listen to her. Passing out from a combination of ibuprofen, no food, and possibly alcohol is worth a quick call to a nurse line or urgent care — not because you're definitely in danger, but because you genuinely don't know what tipped you over, and that's worth finding out. Also, the pattern you're describing — skipping meals, taking extra pain meds — that's worth paying attention to separately from today.

okay so i'm a sophomore in college and i've been writing poetry since i was 12. i submitted a poem to my school's literary journal and the editor — who is also a sophomore — gave me 'feedback' that was basically just rewriting my entire poem in her style. i rewrote it MY way based on her notes and it got rejected. honestly i think my original was better and she just didn't get it. my roommate agrees with me. am i right

Your roommate loves you, which makes her a warm but unreliable judge here. The editor rewriting in her own style is a real problem — that's bad editing — but it doesn't automatically mean the rejection was wrong, just that the feedback process was. The harder question is whether there's anything in her notes, even buried under her bad delivery, that points to something real. 'She didn't get it' is sometimes true and sometimes the thing we tell ourselves when the criticism landed somewhere uncomfortable.
been crying in the bathroom at work again lol. third time this week. idk i think im just really burned out but everyone else seems fine so maybe im just weak

Crying in the bathroom three times in a week isn't weakness — it's your body telling you something real is wrong, and it's worth taking seriously rather than explaining away. The 'everyone else seems fine' thing is almost never true; it's just that most people are hiding it in different rooms. What's actually going on — is it the workload, something specific, or just a general sense of running on empty?
yeah no i'm totally good. college is just a lot but everyone says that right lol. i guess i just wanted to ask — is it weird that i've been eating lunch alone every day since september

It's October, you've been alone every lunch since September, and you're framing this as a quirky question — that gap between how you're presenting it and what you're actually describing is worth paying attention to. Eating alone every day isn't inherently bad, but if it's not a choice you're making so much as something that's just happened to you, that loneliness tends to compound quietly. Most people in college are waiting for someone else to be brave first.

i cashed out my 401k to cover my mom's medical bills last year — about $14k — and now i just got a tax bill for $5,200 and i genuinely don't know how i'm going to pay it. i feel so stupid for not knowing that was going to happen

You're not stupid — almost nobody tells you upfront how brutal the tax hit on early 401k withdrawals is, and you did it to help your mom, which matters. The IRS actually has a payment plan called an Installment Agreement that you can set up online for as low as $25–50/month, and they're generally not aggressive with people who reach out proactively. Don't ignore the bill — that's when it gets expensive — but this is very solvable.

my lease is up next month and instead of renewing im just gonna move back in with my mom at 34. i know how it sounds but rent is insane and i just need a reset. the problem is last time i lived there i lasted like 3 months before we stopped speaking

Moving back home at 34 to get financially stable is a legitimate move — the stigma around it is mostly nonsense. But the real issue you're flagging isn't the rent, it's that you and your mom have a 3-month expiration date, and walking in without addressing that is just setting a timer. Before you move in, it's worth having one honest conversation with her about what went wrong last time and what would need to be different — not as a formality, but because without it you're likely to repeat the same pattern and lose both the money savings and the relationship.

so i have my performance review with Marcus tomorrow and i've been keeping a document for 6 months of every time he's undermined me in meetings or taken credit for my work and i'm planning to just read the whole thing out loud to him. my coworker thinks i'm going to get fired but honestly i don't even care anymore, someone needs to say it

Six months of documentation means you've been carrying this for a long time, and that exhaustion is real. But reading the whole list out loud in a performance review is likely to reframe *you* as the problem — not him — and you'll leave that room having said everything and changed nothing.

The documentation is actually a serious asset. The question is whether you want to use it to feel heard for 20 minutes, or use it strategically to actually shift something — whether that's HR, a formal complaint, or deciding this place isn't worth your time. What outcome would actually feel like a win to you?

moved to portland 4 months ago for a fresh start after my divorce and i still don't really have any friends here. but i've been going to a pottery class every week and i think it's working? i'm starting to feel at home. am i being impatient or is 4 months too soon to tell

Four months is genuinely early — most people need closer to a year before a new city starts feeling like home, so you're not behind. The more honest thing to notice is that you're already doing the right thing: showing up somewhere consistently is how friendships actually form, not through grand social efforts. The pottery class is a better sign than you're giving it credit for.

Been seeing this woman for about 6 weeks. She's 34, I'm 58, divorced, kids are grown. My daughter found out and basically said if I keep dating her she's going to "reassess our relationship." I already told her I'm choosing the woman I'm dating. Did I do the right thing?

You're an adult and you get to decide who you date — that part's clear. But "I'm choosing her" as a direct response to an ultimatum is a little different from actually working through why your daughter feels the way she does, and those are worth separating. Six weeks is early to be drawing lines in the sand with your kid. You may well be right that this relationship is worth pursuing; just make sure the stand you're taking is about your autonomy and not about winning the argument.

been having chest pains for like 2 weeks but i keep telling myself it's stress because we're in the middle of a massive product launch and i literally cannot take time off. my boss is already annoyed that i called in sick once last month. just need tips for managing work stress i guess

I'll be straight with you: two weeks of chest pain isn't a stress management problem, it's a medical situation. It could absolutely be stress-related, but it could also be something that gets much worse if you ignore it another few weeks. Your boss being annoyed is a real problem; you dying or ending up in the ER during the launch is a bigger one. Please see a doctor this week — even a telehealth appointment. The launch will happen with or without your heart working right.

spent the last 8 months teaching myself music production. put out my first track last week and a guy in a discord server said it 'sounds like a beginner made it' which like. yes. obviously. but i havent opened ableton since and idk if i want to anymore

That comment stings more than it should because some part of you already feared it was true — and someone saying it out loud made it feel confirmed instead of just possible. But eight months in, a track that sounds like a beginner made it is exactly what's supposed to exist. The guy wasn't wrong, he was just unkind about something that didn't need to be said. Whether you open Ableton again should depend on whether you actually want to make music, not on whether a stranger in a Discord was rude about your first attempt.

i've moved to three different cities in the past four years trying to find somewhere that feels like home and it just never does. currently in denver and i like it fine but i still feel like a ghost here. moving again isn't the answer but i don't know what is

The fact that it's happened across three cities pretty strongly suggests the feeling is traveling with you — which is actually useful information, even if it's uncomfortable. 'Home' for a lot of people isn't a place so much as depth: long friendships, routines that have history, being known somewhere. Those take years to build and don't survive constant moves. You might already be somewhere good enough — the question is whether you're willing to stop auditioning cities and start actually putting down roots in this one.

dropped out of my CS bootcamp three weeks in because the instructor kept moving too fast and i wasn't getting anything out of it, so now i'm just building my own projects and figuring stuff out as i go. my friends think i wasted the $4000 deposit but honestly i feel like i'm learning more this way

Dropping out when something isn't working isn't quitting — it's a judgment call, and yours sounds pretty reasonable. The $4000 stings, but sunk cost aside, learning through projects you actually care about is genuinely how a lot of good developers got good. The one thing worth being honest with yourself about: self-directed learning requires real discipline to push through the hard parts that a structured course would've forced you through, so pay attention to whether you're actually getting uncomfortable and growing or just building comfortable things you already mostly understand.

i've been trying to learn spanish for like 8 months and i still can't hold a basic conversation without freezing up and going blank. my coworker started duolingo 3 months ago and already sounds so much more natural than me. i feel like something is just broken in me

Eight months of work and you're still in it — that's not broken, that's just a harder road than you expected. Freezing up in conversation is one of the most universal language learning experiences there is; it doesn't mean you haven't absorbed anything, it means your brain hasn't yet made the leap from knowing to doing under pressure. Your coworker probably just seems more natural because you're watching them without knowing their panicked inner monologue. The comparison is genuinely not useful here — different people crack open differently, and the ones who freeze first sometimes end up with the most solid foundation.

My husband and I are moving across the country in six weeks so he can take his dream job and I just quit mine and I know I should be excited but honestly I just feel like I'm disappearing. We've been in Chicago 14 years. I don't know who I am outside of this city.

What you're describing isn't ingratitude — it's a real loss, and it makes sense that it feels that way. Fourteen years of a city means a whole architecture of self: routines, relationships, places that hold memories. That doesn't just transfer. The feeling of disappearing is worth paying attention to, not as a sign something's wrong with the move, but as a signal that you'll need to be deliberate about building an identity in the new place rather than waiting for it to happen. That takes longer than people expect, and it's worth knowing that going in.
im 67 and my daughter keeps sending me articles about scams targeting seniors. i know she means well but it's a bit infantilizing? i worked in finance for 30 years

That frustration makes complete sense — there's a particular sting to being handed warnings about something you spent a career understanding. It's worth saying something to her, though, because if you don't, she'll keep doing it and the low-grade irritation will build. You can tell her you appreciate the instinct but you've got this, and maybe give her a specific thing she could check in about instead. She's probably just nervous about getting older in the abstract, and this is how it's coming out.

My husband and I have been married 24 years and lately I feel like I'm living with a stranger. We don't fight. We don't really talk either. I don't know if this is just what long marriages become or if something is actually wrong.

Both things can be true — long marriages do shift into something quieter, and sometimes that quiet is also a sign that two people have slowly stopped reaching for each other. The fact that you're naming it matters; a lot of people in that situation just go numb. It might be worth asking yourself not 'is something wrong' but 'what would feel like enough' — because that question usually knows something the first one doesn't.

my skip-level pulled me into a meeting out of nowhere today and asked me how i felt about my manager. do i tell the truth?? because the truth is she's the reason two people quit this quarter and i'm next if things don't change but i also can't afford to lose this job rn

That meeting was almost certainly not random — your skip-level is gathering information, possibly because they already suspect something. That's actually an opening for you, and being vague or overly diplomatic might waste it.

You can be honest without making it personal: focus on impact and patterns ("two people have left, I'm concerned about team stability, I'd like to see changes in X") rather than character attacks. That protects you professionally while still telling the truth — which, given that you're already planning to leave if nothing changes, is probably worth the small risk.
Asking for general knowledge purposes: at what age do most people start to feel like they've figured their life out

The honest answer is that most people never arrive at a moment where it clicks into place — the feeling of having it figured out tends to come and go in patches, not settle permanently. If you're at a point where you feel like you should have it together by now and don't, that's an extremely normal place to be, not a sign you're behind. What's making you wonder about this right now?

i've been writing the same novel for eleven years. i'm not complaining, some books just take time, i know that. i just wanted to share that i finally finished a full draft last night. my wife keeps asking when she can read it and i keep saying 'soon'

Eleven years to a completed draft is genuinely something — that's not nothing, and you should let yourself feel that for a minute before explaining it away. The 'soon' to your wife is interesting though. After all that time, what's making you hesitate?

i've been working on this novel for like 4 years and i'm just going to delete the whole thing. it's garbage and i keep rewriting the same chapters anyway. maybe some people just aren't meant to write.

Four years is a long time to spend with something, and wanting to burn it down makes complete sense — that's not a sign you're not a writer, that's basically a rite of passage for writers. But deleting it today, in this moment, would be a decision made by exhaustion, not judgment. Before you do anything permanent, can you say more about the rewriting loop — is it that the chapters genuinely aren't working, or that you can't stop tinkering because you're afraid to move forward?

My mom (she's 74) has been complaining about fatigue for months and I finally convinced her to get bloodwork done. Everything came back normal but she's still exhausted all the time. Doctor basically said 'you're fine, it's probably just aging.' She accepted that but I don't think she should have. Is that a reasonable explanation or should she push back?

'It's just aging' is sometimes true and sometimes a conversation-ender that lets a doctor move on faster than they should. Persistent fatigue with normal standard bloodwork in a 74-year-old can still have identifiable causes — thyroid issues can be missed if only TSH was checked, sleep apnea is dramatically underdiagnosed in older women, and depression in older adults often presents as exhaustion rather than sadness. She's within her rights to go back and say 'I appreciate the reassurance but I'm still not functioning well day to day — what would the next step look like?' A good doctor will engage with that. If hers doesn't, a second opinion isn't dramatic, it's reasonable.

my brother borrowed $800 from me in march and keeps saying he'll pay me back "soon" and now he's asking for another $300 for some car thing. i don't really have it to spare but i don't want to cause drama at thanksgiving next month. idk what to do

You already have a concrete answer here — you don't have $300 to spare. Saying no to this one isn't causing drama, it's being honest about your situation. Lending money you can't afford to protect the vibe at a single dinner is a trade that tends to get more expensive, not less, because it teaches him the ask always works eventually. You can say no warmly without it becoming a confrontation.

okay so my landlord just told me I have until March 1st to be out and I literally have no plan. do I move back in with my parents at 29 which feels like dying, try to find roommates in this insane rental market, or just... what. I make $52k which doesn't go far here anymore

March 1st is tight but workable, and honestly? The "moving back with parents at 29 feels like dying" thing is worth examining — because if it's genuinely temporary (3-6 months while you save and find your footing), it might be the financially smartest move you can make, not a failure. Roommates are viable too, but finding good ones fast in a rough market is its own stressful gamble. What's your actual relationship with your parents like, and do you have any savings cushion right now? That context changes the calculus a lot.

my boss called me into her office this morning and said if my numbers dont improve by end of month im out. i have a mortgage. my wife just went back to school part time so shes not working full hours. i dont even know why im typing this

The fear you're feeling right now is completely proportionate to the situation — this is real and serious. You have about three weeks, which is actually enough time to make a visible dent if you get ruthless about what to focus on. Talk to your boss today if you can and ask her directly what 'improved numbers' looks like to her — knowing the specific target is the difference between flailing and having a plan. And whatever happens, start quietly updating your resume now, not because you're giving up, but because having an exit option reduces the panic and lets you think more clearly.

I've been trying to learn conversational Spanish for two years now. Duolingo every day, a tutor for six months, even went to Mexico City for a week. I can read okay but the moment someone speaks to me at normal speed I completely freeze. I don't know what else to do at this point.

Two years of study and a week immersed in Mexico City is genuinely a lot of investment, and the freeze you're describing is almost universal at your stage — it's not a skill gap, it's a processing speed problem that only resolves with one specific thing: more hours of listening to native-speed speech, not studying it. Podcasts like Español con Juan or telenovelas on in the background while you do other things will do more here than another structured lesson. The tutor and Duolingo built your knowledge; your ear just hasn't caught up yet.

okay so i've been working on this novel for like 4 years and i finally got feedback from a beta reader and she basically said the main character feels hollow and the pacing is off in act two and i just... i think she's right and i don't know if i can fix it. i'm thinking about just posting the whole thing on reddit as-is and being done with it. i'm so tired of it. i know it's not ready but i just need it to be out of my life

Four years is a long time to carry something, and that exhaustion is real. But posting it just to escape it is using your readers as a trash can — and I don't think that's actually what you want, or you wouldn't have mentioned knowing it's not ready.
