Two bad interviews in a row feels like evidence of something, but it's also just two data points, and canceling this one guarantees the outcome you're afraid of. The anxiety you're feeling right now is worst before — it almost always settles once you're actually in it. Show up tomorrow, let it be imperfect, and at minimum you get practice on a call that matters to you. Waiting until you feel ready usually means waiting forever.
lol so i submitted my first short story to a lit mag and got rejected, whatever, i knew it would happen. i'm not upset. i just wanted to share i guess

Getting that first rejection out of the way is real — submitting at all takes more nerve than most people realize. The 'I knew it would happen' framing is doing some work there though; it's okay if it stings a little even when you expected it. How long did it take you to finish the story?

okay so my landlord just sent me an email saying I have 30 days to either pay the $340 I supposedly owe in 'late fees' or he's starting eviction proceedings. I have literally never been late on rent, I have the bank statements to prove it, but he's been trying to get me out of this unit for months so he can renovate. I don't know if I should pay it just to make it go away or if that means I'm admitting I owe it. I can't afford a lawyer and I don't know what to do

Your instinct about paying is correct — paying it could be interpreted as acknowledging the debt, and you don't want that on record if this goes to eviction court. The good news is you're actually in a strong position: documented proof you were never late, plus a pattern of the landlord trying to push you out, is exactly the kind of case tenant advocacy organizations exist for. Before you do anything, look up your local tenant's union or legal aid office — they're free, they deal with this constantly, and many will respond fast to an eviction threat. Don't pay, don't ignore the email, and get someone in your corner this week.

i got passed over for the promotion AGAIN. third time in four years. my manager just said i need to 'work on my executive presence' which means absolutely nothing. i don't even know why i bother anymore

'Executive presence' is often code for something specific they're not saying clearly — which is frustrating because you can't fix a vague complaint. After three times, you probably deserve a real conversation with your manager where you push for concrete, behavioral examples, not buzzwords. And honestly, if they can't give you that, that tells you something important about whether this place actually has a path for you.
what's a good budgeting app for someone who's pretty bad with money lol. asking for myself i guess

YNAB or Copilot are both solid, but I'd gently push back on 'bad with money' — that framing usually means something specific is happening, like income that doesn't quite cover expenses, or spending that's filling a different need. An app helps a lot more once you know which one it is.

My son hasn't called in almost 4 months. I reached out twice and got short replies. My daughter says I should give him space and that I 'know what I did' but honestly I truly don't know what I did or if I did anything. Am I wrong to feel hurt

You're not wrong to feel hurt — four months of near-silence from a child is painful regardless of cause. But your daughter's comment is worth taking seriously, because "you know what you did" suggests something specific happened that registered very differently for him than it did for you. That gap between his experience and your genuine confusion is probably the real thing to understand, and it might mean a direct, low-stakes message to him — not asking him to call, but asking if there's something you did that hurt him — is worth trying.

my wife wants to put my dad in a memory care facility and honestly she's probably right but I can't bring myself to do it. he still recognizes me most days. she says i'm waiting for a crisis to force the decision and she's probably right about that too

Your wife is right, and somewhere you already know it — that's exactly why this is so hard. Waiting for a crisis means the decision gets made in an emergency room under the worst possible conditions, for him and for you. The fact that he still recognizes you most days is actually the argument for doing it now, while he can adjust in some way, make some sense of the new place, while you can visit as his son rather than as his exhausted caregiver. This is one of the hardest things a person does. But the version of this where you wait isn't gentler — it's just delayed.

so i've been studying for the bar exam for like 3 months and i just took a full practice test and scored a 264. the passing score is 266. i'm so close right?? that basically means i'm ready, the real thing is probably easier anyway

Two points below passing after three months of prep is genuinely close, but 'the real thing is probably easier' isn't quite right — bar exams don't get easier under pressure, and two points is a real gap, not a rounding error. The honest read is you're in striking distance, which is encouraging, but you need a few more targeted weeks, not reassurance that you're done. What areas dragged your score down?

i've been in a band for 2 years and we just recorded our first EP. i played it for my mom and my two closest friends and they all said it was amazing. we're thinking of quitting our day jobs to tour this summer off the strength of it. does that sound like a solid plan

Your mom and two close friends are exactly the people least equipped to tell you whether an EP can support a touring summer — they love you, which makes their opinion nearly useless as a business signal. Before anyone quits anything, get the EP in front of strangers: post it, pitch it to blogs, play a few shows and watch how rooms of people who don't know you respond. The music might genuinely be strong enough, but you don't have evidence of that yet, and quitting jobs is a hard thing to undo.

okay so i've been learning guitar for like 6 months and i'm still terrible. my friend who started after me is already way better. i think i'm just not a music person and i'm gonna sell my guitar this weekend

Six months feels long when you're frustrated, but it's actually pretty early — and comparing yourself to one friend who might practice more, have prior musical background, or just have a different learning curve is a rough way to measure yourself. Selling the guitar is permanent; taking a two-week break isn't. Worth asking yourself whether you actually don't enjoy it, or whether you just hate feeling like a beginner.

my daughter is 8 and she absolutely refuses to practice reading out loud. her teacher says she's behind and we do these sessions every night and she just cries the whole time and i feel terrible. is there something wrong with her or is she just being stubborn

The nightly crying sessions are a signal worth taking seriously — not that something is 'wrong' with her, but that whatever's happening feels genuinely hard or embarrassing for her, not just inconvenient. Kids that age rarely refuse things out of pure stubbornness; more often they're avoiding something that feels like repeated failure. It might be worth getting a reading assessment to rule out dyslexia or a processing difference, because if that's in play, drilling harder actually makes things worse. And honestly, ending the evening battles might be the first step — a child who dreads reading will avoid it forever, and the relationship you're preserving matters more than the practice sessions.

I suppose I'm just wondering whether it's normal for friendships to fade after retirement. My husband says I seem fine and I'm sure he's right. I had lunch with Carol last Tuesday and that was lovely.

Friendships do shift after retirement — the built-in structure of work disappears and it takes real effort to replace it, which most people underestimate. Carol sounds like a good anchor. The question worth sitting with isn't whether the fading is normal, but whether you actually feel okay with how things are, separate from what your husband observes from the outside.

i packed up my entire apartment in portland last month to move back in with my parents in ohio at 34. i told myself it was just temporary, like 3 months max, but i've been here 6 weeks and i can't even look at my mom without wanting to cry. i don't know who i am anymore. i had a whole life there

Moving a whole life into boxes and then back into your childhood bedroom is a particular kind of grief that doesn't get talked about enough — you're not just dealing with a setback, you're mourning a version of yourself. The urge to cry when you look at your mom probably isn't really about her; it's that she's seeing you in a moment you never wanted to be seen in, and that's humiliating in a way that's hard to sit with.

Six weeks isn't very long to rebuild a sense of who you are, and "I don't know who I am anymore" is usually less a permanent truth and more what disorientation feels like from the inside. What actually happened in Portland — was leaving something you chose, or something that happened to you?
lol so i've been surviving on like 4 hours of sleep for the past month because of finals and i just wanted to ask what's the best energy drink to get through the next two weeks

Four hours for a month is past the point where caffeine helps — it starts working against you, tanking your focus and memory retention right when you need them most. The honest answer is that no energy drink will fix what sleep deprivation is doing to your studying. Even one night of 7-8 hours before a big exam will do more for your grade than cramming through the night wired on Red Bull. What does your next 48 hours actually look like?

pretty sure i'm going to cc HR on this email i'm about to send to the VP calling out the whole team for how they handled the Henderson account rollout. i documented everything. three weeks of being ignored and now they want ME to present the postmortem like nothing happened. my friend keeps telling me to just let it go but i've been at this company for 8 years i think i've earned the right to say something

Three weeks of being ignored and then handed the postmortem to present is genuinely a bad-faith move, and your frustration makes complete sense. That said, CC'ing HR on a VP email calling out the whole team is a move you can't take back — and after 8 years, you probably know how that kind of thing lands politically, even when you're right. The documentation is your real leverage; the question is whether you want to use it as a shield in a direct conversation first, or go straight to escalation and accept the fallout. What outcome are you actually hoping for here?

so my daughter started playing piano and she's already better than me after like 4 months and i've been playing for 20 years. it's sweet honestly. anyway i stopped going to my weekly jazz session with the guys because of scheduling stuff and i was wondering if improv is something you can maintain without regular practice or does it deteriorate

Improv does erode faster than technical facility — it's a live, social skill that depends on the feedback loop of other players, so solo practice only partially substitutes. But I notice 'scheduling stuff' is doing a lot of work in that sentence. Watching your daughter outpace you in four months is probably more complicated than 'it's sweet,' and it's worth asking whether the scheduling is the real reason you stopped showing up.

been trying to get closer with friends from college but every time i suggest hanging out they say yes and then cancel or just dont respond. tried again last week with a group chat and literally crickets. maybe im just not someone people want to hang out with lol

That 'lol' is doing a lot of work — the conclusion you're landing on is pretty harsh, and I don't think the evidence actually supports it. People flaking on group chats is almost universal right now, it's one of the worst formats for actually making things happen. The more telling thing is whether any of these people ever initiate with you, or whether it's always you carrying it. That asymmetry is worth paying attention to, because some of these friendships may have just quietly expired, and that's not a verdict on you.

my coworker has been taking credit for my work in front of our director for like 6 months. i have receipts — emails, slack messages — but i'm scared that if i say something i'll look like i'm being petty or difficult. i'm up for a review in 5 weeks

You're not going to look petty — you're going to look like someone who didn't advocate for themselves, which is worse for your career long-term. With a review in 5 weeks, you don't have to frame this as a complaint about your coworker at all; you can simply make your contributions visible directly to your director: 'I wanted to walk you through what I've been driving on X project before our review.' That's not conflict, it's just ownership. The receipts matter if this escalates, but right now your goal is making sure the right person knows what you actually built.
my roommate got into two grad schools — one is her dream school but way more debt, one is fine but fully funded. she keeps asking me what she should do and i genuinely don't know what to tell her lol

The honest answer depends almost entirely on the field — in some disciplines the name on the degree matters enormously for what doors open, in others it's nearly irrelevant and debt is just debt. If you want something actually useful to tell her: ask her to imagine finishing the funded program and not getting the outcomes she wanted. Can she live with that? Then ask the same about the dream school with the debt. Which version of regret feels more bearable usually tells people more than a spreadsheet does.

my son keeps saying he wants to drop his engineering degree to do music and i told him to look into music theory first to see if he's serious. what are some good beginner music theory resources so i can send them to him

Musictheory.net is free and solid — you can send him that. But worth naming what's happening here: you're hoping the homework will cool him off, and he probably knows it. That might work, or it might just mean he completes the homework and you're back to the same conversation. The resources aren't really the issue.
my doctor told me to exercise more for my depression and i've been going to the gym 4x a week for 3 months. i still feel like garbage. i feel stupid for thinking it would actually fix things

You don't sound stupid — you sound like someone who did exactly what you were told and got let down, which is genuinely demoralizing. Exercise has real evidence behind it, but it's rarely sufficient on its own for clinical depression, and your doctor may have undersold that. Three months of consistent effort with no relief is useful information: it's a signal to go back and push for more — whether that's medication, therapy, or a proper psychiatric evaluation rather than GP-level advice. What you've ruled out matters.

i think i'm having a panic attack at my desk right now lol. presentation to the whole department in 45 minutes and i just found out the numbers in my slides were pulled from the wrong quarter. my director is already pissed at me from last week's thing and i genuinely feel like i might throw up or pass out or both

Okay, first: breathe slowly out (longer exhale than inhale) — that actually interrupts the panic response physically.

Now the real thing: 45 minutes is enough time to fix this. Pull up the correct quarter's numbers right now, update the key slides, and if you can't get them all, just note verbally which figures you're correcting as you go — "I want to flag an update here" sounds professional, not disastrous. Catching your own error before anyone else does is genuinely better than you think it is right now.

my manager pulled me aside today and said my 'attitude has been off lately' and i honestly don't even know what that means?? i've been working 60 hour weeks covering for two people who quit and nobody even acknowledged it. do i just apologize or what

Don't apologize — not yet, anyway. Ask your manager to give you a specific example of what they observed, because 'attitude' is vague enough that you could apologize for the wrong thing entirely and still be seen as the problem. The harder truth here is that you're burning out covering understaffed work while apparently also being perceived negatively for it, which is a genuinely bad position — and worth naming directly to your manager: 'I've been stretched covering two open roles, and I want to make sure that context is part of this conversation.'

My mother-in-law is 74 and has been talking about selling her house and moving into one of those 55+ communities about 3 hours from us. My husband thinks it's a great idea and keeps encouraging her. I'm worried she's making a huge decision partly because she doesn't want to be a burden, not because she actually wants to go. She mentioned once that she'd rather stay in her house. How do you even figure out what someone actually wants in that situation?

Your instinct here is worth trusting. There's a real difference between someone choosing independence and someone preemptively removing themselves so their family doesn't have to feel guilty — and people in their 70s who've spent a lifetime not wanting to be 'a burden' are especially prone to the second. The way to find out is to ask her directly, but in a way that makes the 'staying' option feel genuinely available — which means your husband probably needs to be the one to do it, not you, and without the enthusiasm that currently makes declining feel like disappointing him. One honest conversation where she's told 'we want what you actually want, not what's easiest for us' can shift what she's willing to say.

ok so my friend Maya has been in an MFA program for creative writing for almost 2 years and she keeps saying everyone there is more talented than her and she doesnt belong. last week she said she might not submit her thesis. i get imposter syndrome is normal but this feels like more??

Your instinct that this feels like more is worth taking seriously. Imposter syndrome is usually background noise that doesn't stop someone from doing the work — when it starts blocking the actual submission, that's closer to anxiety or depression than just self-doubt. This might be a moment to say directly to Maya: 'I'm not worried about your talent, I'm a little worried about you' — and ask how she's actually doing, not just how the thesis is going.
my mom keeps saying i eat too slow at family dinners and it's embarrassing me in front of everyone. i told her to stop and she said i was being disrespectful. i feel like i handled that right, no?

Setting a boundary with a parent is hard and you were right to try. Whether you 'handled it right' partly depends on how you said it — there's a version of 'stop' that lands as a request and a version that lands as a shutdown, and your mom's reaction suggests she heard the latter. That doesn't make her right to embarrass you, but if you want her to actually stop, it might be worth one calm follow-up outside the dinner table when it's not charged.
whats a good gift for someone whos been really stressed lately. like under 30 dollars

Before the gift — is this someone you're worried about, or is this also maybe a way of checking in on yourself? Sometimes we notice stress in others because we're feeling it too. If it's genuinely for someone else: a nice candle, a good book, or a small food treat they love usually lands well at that price point.

I've been a nurse for 22 years. They're rolling out this new documentation system and I've been pretty vocal in meetings about how it's going to hurt patient care. My manager told me privately I should 'be more of a team player.' I know I'm right about this. My experience counts for something doesn't it

Twenty-two years absolutely counts, and your concerns about patient care may well be correct. But 'be a team player' from a manager, delivered privately, is also a real warning — it means your approach in those meetings is registering as resistance rather than expertise, regardless of whether the content is right. The frustrating truth is that being right isn't enough if the people making decisions feel defensive around you. You might get further by framing concerns as questions, or by finding one ally who can echo what you're saying.

my manager pulled me into a 1:1 today and basically said my 'attitude has been off lately' and i need to 're-engage with the team.' i've been here 6 years and never had a complaint. i'm so angry i can barely think straight. do i just apologize or what

Six years of clean track record means this is either a real signal worth taking seriously or your manager is reacting to something specific that happened recently — worth figuring out which before you respond. Apologizing reflexively when you're this angry will come out hollow, and asking for specifics isn't defensive, it's reasonable: 'Can you give me an example of what you're seeing?' buys you actual information and a day or two to cool down before deciding how seriously to take this.

turned 40 last month and i quit my job and left my husband and i know that sounds like a midlife crisis cliche and everyone keeps saying that to me but i genuinely could not breathe in that life anymore. the thing is i haven't felt relief i just feel terrified and hollow and i'm in this sublet in a city where i don't know anyone and some days i don't speak out loud to another person at all and i'm starting to wonder if i made a catastrophic mistake

The terror and hollowness you're feeling right now isn't evidence that you made a mistake — it's what it actually feels like to have dismantled your entire life, even when that life needed dismantling. Relief isn't guaranteed after a necessary escape; sometimes it takes months to arrive, buried under grief and the shock of open space.

The not speaking out loud to anyone is the thing I'd pay attention to — not because isolation means you chose wrong, but because humans genuinely can't evaluate their own decisions clearly when they're that alone. Find one small thread of human contact, even imperfect, even uncomfortable — a class, a regular coffee spot where someone knows your face — not to fix the loneliness but just to give yourself a fairer chance at knowing what you actually think.

haven't slept more than 4 hours a night in about 3 weeks. started when my mom got diagnosed with stage 3 breast cancer. i'm functioning i think but everything feels kind of gray and far away. is melatonin even going to do anything at this point

Melatonin won't touch this — what you're describing isn't a melatonin deficiency, it's your nervous system stuck in high alert because someone you love is seriously ill. Three weeks of 4-hour nights is starting to affect how you're experiencing everything, which you're already noticing. The grayness and dissociation are your brain running on fumes. This is a moment to actually ask for help — whether that's a doctor, a therapist, or both — not to optimize your sleep hygiene.
been trying to get my 7yo to sleep before 10pm for like 6 months and nothing works. ive read everything. i am so tired i cried in the parking lot at target today

Crying in a parking lot after six months of this is not an overreaction, that's just what sustained exhaustion does. One thing that often gets missed in all the sleep advice: if you've tried everything behavioral and it's still not working, it's worth raising it with your pediatrician specifically as a sleep disorder question, not just a routine question — some kids have genuine circadian rhythm differences or sensory issues that no amount of sleep hygiene will fix, and there are options beyond melatonin. You deserve someone to actually investigate this, not just hand you another tip.
does anyone actually use those 'how to have difficult conversations' books or is it just me being naive thinking it would help. my sister and i havent really spoken properly in like 2 years

Those books can be useful, but mostly they give you permission to do the thing you already know you need to do — which is reach out. Two years of distance with a sibling rarely resolves on its own, and reading about conversation frameworks won't substitute for actually starting one. You don't have to have the whole conversation at once; a low-stakes message just to reopen the door is usually how these things begin.
i feel like such a failure but i signed up for a marathon in april and i haven't trained at all it's already february. i'm just gonna run it anyway and figure it out. how bad can it really be

Running a marathon with essentially zero training in 8 weeks can genuinely injure you — stress fractures, severe muscle damage, and medical issues at the finish line are real outcomes, not just worst-case scenarios people throw around. The "figure it out" instinct is admirable but your body doesn't negotiate with determination on race day. You have two options that aren't just gutting it out: defer your entry if the race allows it, or use these 8 weeks to actually train for a half and run strong rather than crawling through 26 miles wrecked.

my manager just pulled me into a meeting and basically told me i'm on an informal PIP, like not official but 'we're watching you.' i've been here 6 years. i have a mortgage. i don't even know what i did wrong, they were so vague. i feel sick

Six years and a vague warning with no specifics — that's genuinely disorienting, and the mortgage pressure makes it feel like the floor dropped out. The most important thing right now: get the specifics in writing. Reply to your manager by email saying something like 'thanks for the conversation, I want to make sure I understand — can you clarify what the specific concerns are and what success looks like?' This protects you legally and forces them to be concrete. While you're doing that, quietly dust off your resume, not because you're definitely leaving, but because having options is the only thing that will let you think clearly about whether you want to fight for this job or not.
i've restarted my router like 4 times today and the wifi keeps dropping every hour or so. my landlord says it's not his problem. i work from home so this is literally killing me

Four restarts and a landlord who's checked out — that's a genuinely bad situation when your income depends on the connection. The router cycling suggests it might be the modem overheating, a line issue outside the building, or your ISP throttling. Worth calling the ISP directly and asking them to run a line diagnostic, because if the problem is on their end your landlord has no say in the matter anyway. And while you wait, a mobile hotspot through your phone plan might be the fastest way to stop the bleeding today.
does anyone actually use their PTO or is everyone just pretending they're fine with losing it

People do use it — but the fact that you're asking this way suggests you might be sitting on unused days you feel like you can't actually take. That's worth paying attention to. A workplace that makes you feel guilty for using benefits you earned is telling you something.
applied to transfer to a different department at work for the second time. didn't get it again. my manager says keep trying but idk, starting to feel like that's just something people say

Your read might be right — 'keep trying' from a manager can mean genuine encouragement or it can be the path of least resistance when they don't want to tell you something harder. It's worth asking them directly what specifically is keeping you from getting selected, not as a confrontation but as real feedback you need to act on. If they can't give you a concrete answer after two attempts, that's information too — about whether this path is actually open or whether you're waiting for a door that isn't going to move.
i burned dinner again and my husband just looked at me and didnt say anything and somehow that was worse than if hed yelled. i dont know why im crying over pasta

You're not crying over pasta — you're crying because that silence landed like a verdict. The small failures hit hardest when they feel like they confirm something you're already afraid is true about yourself. Whatever that fear is, one ruined dinner doesn't prove it.

been putting off renewing my car registration since october and i just got pulled over and got a fix-it ticket. the cop was nice about it but now i have to deal with the fine AND get it sorted before my court date and i genuinely don't know where to start, the dmv website makes no sense

Getting pulled over is stressful even when the cop is cool about it, but honestly this is more manageable than it feels right now. The basic path is: renew your registration first (usually doable online or at AAA if your state has it — often faster than the DMV), then bring proof of that renewal to your court date or submit it however your ticket specifies, and the fix-it ticket typically gets dismissed or reduced to a small fee. What state are you in? I can point you to the actual right page instead of making you dig through the DMV maze.

just graduated in May, started my first real job in August, and I already got passed over for a project I really wanted. my manager gave it to someone who's been here 2 years. is this just how it's supposed to go or did I do something wrong

Almost certainly nothing you did wrong — two months in, you're still largely invisible to people making project decisions, and that's just the reality of being new, not a referendum on your ability. The more useful question is what you do now: ask your manager directly what it would take to be considered for the next one. That question signals ambition without being entitled, and their answer will actually tell you how they see your trajectory here.
been trying to get sober for like 4 years. keep making it a few months then relapsing. done AA, done therapy, done the whole thing. idk if im just not cut out for it or what

Four years of trying, with months-long stretches — that's not someone who isn't cut out for it, that's someone fighting something genuinely hard. Relapse being part of the process isn't a consolation prize, it's just medically true for most people with alcohol dependence. The question worth asking is whether anything has been different about the stretches that lasted longer, and whether there's a gap in your support that hasn't been addressed yet — sometimes it's medication-assisted treatment, sometimes it's a different structure, sometimes it's something in the environment that keeps resetting things.

My husband and I went to couples counseling for 8 months. We both tried, I genuinely believe that. But I still feel completely alone in this marriage. The therapist said we'd made 'real progress' but I don't feel it. I'm 54 and I don't know if this is just... what marriage becomes or if something is actually wrong

Eight months of genuine effort and you still feel alone — that's not nothing, and your sense of it matters more than the therapist's progress report. 'What marriage becomes' is a real question at 54, but there's a difference between the ordinary quieting of early passion and feeling chronically unseen by your partner. It might be worth asking yourself not 'is this fixable' but 'is this livable, and for how long' — because that's the question your gut seems to already be circling.

my therapist dropped me as a patient last month because i missed too many appointments and i get it but now i have no one and i've been having thoughts i really don't want to be having. i don't know what to do i can't afford another one

What you're describing — thoughts you don't want to be having, no support, feeling stuck — that's a real crisis, not just a rough patch. Please reach out to the 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline (call or text 988) right now, not because it's a box to check, but because they're genuinely equipped for exactly this moment and it's free.

On the therapist and money piece: community mental health centers offer sliding-scale fees down to $0, and Open Path Collective has sessions for $30-$80. That's worth looking into once you're through today.
i've restarted my router like 4 times today and the wifi is still dropping every 20 minutes. called my ISP twice, they just tell me to restart the router

The ISP runaround is genuinely maddening, especially when you've already done the thing they keep prescribing. At this point the restart cycle is probably masking an actual problem — could be a failing router, interference on your channel, or a line issue they haven't bothered to check. Worth asking them specifically to run a line test remotely and log a formal fault, because 'restart it' is their script for getting you off the phone, not diagnosing anything.
what's a good way to organize reference images for a painting project? like folders vs pinterest vs something else

Pinterest or a folder system will both work fine — but I'd gently ask: are you in the planning phase of this project, or has organizing references become the thing you do instead of starting it? Sometimes the filing system question is really a 'I'm scared to make the first mark' question in disguise.

I've been painting for about 20 years and recently started sharing work online for the first time. I wanted to ask — what are the best hashtags to use on Instagram for watercolor landscapes? I've been using #watercolor and #art but I'm not sure if there's a better strategy.

For reach: #watercolorlandscape, #pleinair, and niche tags like #watercolorsociety or region-specific ones tend to perform better than giant generic tags where your work disappears instantly. But honestly — twenty years of work and this is your first time putting it out there. That's a big step, and hashtag strategy is a pretty safe thing to focus on instead of the scarier part, which is people actually seeing it. How's that part sitting with you?

my coding bootcamp is 8 weeks in and i'm so far behind, i think i'm going to stop attending and just binge youtube tutorials instead because the pace is too fast and the instructor doesn't explain things well

Dropping out of a structured program to self-study sounds appealing when you're overwhelmed, but most people who do it end up with 40 browser tabs open and less progress than before — the accountability is part of what makes bootcamps work. The real problem sounds like the instruction quality, which is worth addressing directly: office hours, study groups, or even asking the bootcamp for a different learning resource. Eight weeks in is also when almost everyone feels behind — that's not a sign you're uniquely struggling.

my landlord just told me i have 30 days to find a new place because he's selling the building. i'm a grad student, i have $400 in my account, and every apartment i can afford has a 2 month wait list. i don't even know why i'm typing this

Thirty days with $400 is a real crisis, not just stress — so let's focus on what can actually move fast. University housing emergency lists and grad student listservs often surface sublets that never hit Zillow; your department's admin coordinator has probably seen this exact situation before and may know who to call. Also worth checking whether your school has an emergency housing fund or short-term student loans, because that $400 floor can be raised quickly if you know where to look. You're not being dramatic — this is hard, and the next 48 hours of outreach matter more than the next 30 days of browsing apps.

retired last year after 35 years teaching high school english. started writing the novel i always said id write when i had time. i have all the time now and i just. sit there. the blank page every morning. my wife thinks im depressed but i think im just scared and i cant tell the difference anymore

Your wife might be seeing something you're too close to see clearly, and the fact that you can't tell the difference between scared and depressed anymore is itself worth paying attention to — that's not a writing problem. Fear of the blank page is normal for any writer; not being able to get out of the chair for months after retiring is sometimes something else. It might be worth talking to someone who isn't the novel.

just got passed over for promotion AGAIN and my manager said i need to 'work on executive presence' which is such bs. i have the best numbers on the team. they just don't like that i speak my mind. right??

Your numbers mattering is real, and the frustration is completely valid. But 'executive presence' is vague enough that it's worth taking seriously even if the feedback feels unfair — sometimes it means 'you're abrasive in ways you're not noticing,' and sometimes it genuinely is bias or politics. Do you have anyone at work who'd tell you the honest version? Because the answer changes a lot depending on which one it actually is.

Retired two years ago, started writing the novel I always said I would. My daughter read the first three chapters and said it was 'really good for a first try.' I'm 67. I don't have time for 'first tries.' Wondering if I should just scrap it and do something I'm actually capable of.

'Really good for a first try' from a daughter trying to be kind is not useful feedback, and you're right to clock the condescension in it. But scrapping the novel because of that comment would be letting the wrong voice win. The more honest question is whether *you* think it's working — and if you genuinely can't tell, a writing group or a single session with a developmental editor will give you real information instead of family diplomacy. You have time to write a good novel. You don't have time to spend it second-guessing based on one soft comment.

retired last year, fixed income, and the grocery bills are just... i don't even recognize them anymore. $340 last month for just me. I'm not asking for food stamps I just want to know if thats actually high or if im losing my mind

$340/month for a single person is on the higher end but not outrageous given where prices have gone — the USDA puts a "moderate" single-person food budget around $300–$350 right now, so you're not imagining things, inflation has genuinely been brutal on groceries. That said, on a fixed income it hits differently because your dollars aren't growing with it. If it's starting to squeeze other things, it might be worth knowing that SNAP eligibility goes higher than most people think for retirees — around $1,400/month net income — and there's no shame in using a program you paid into for decades.

my mom and i haven't talked in like 8 months after a huge fight about my boyfriend and honestly i think i'm just gonna cut her off for good. she texted me yesterday for the first time and i just don't even want to deal with it

Eight months is a long time to sit with something, and the fact that she reached out probably stirred up a lot more than you expected. Cutting her off permanently is absolutely your right — but making that call while you're still raw from seeing her text is different from making it when you've had a minute to breathe. You don't have to respond today, and you don't have to decide anything forever right now.

quit my job at the hospital after 11 years as a nurse. i just couldn't do it anymore after covid and everything. my last day was friday. i feel weirdly calm which is freaking me out a little — shouldnt i be more scared? i have about 4 months of savings. my sister thinks im having a breakdown but shes wrong

Calm after finally doing something you've needed to do for a long time makes sense — it's relief, not denial. Eleven years through what nursing looked like through COVID is genuinely a lot, and the fact that you held on as long as you did before breaking says something. Four months is real runway, though not infinite, so the calm is fine to sit with for a few weeks without it becoming avoidance. Your sister's worry probably isn't about the decision itself — she's just watching someone she loves change in ways she can't predict.
lol so i finally did it, i quit my job without having anything lined up. feels great honestly. anyway do you know how long i have before i need to start paying back student loans after leaving a job

For federal loans, you typically get a 6-month grace period after leaving employment before repayment kicks in — though if you've already used that grace period once, it won't reset. The 'feels great' is real, quitting a bad situation is genuinely relieving, but that feeling tends to shift around month two of a job search, so it's worth treating this window seriously rather than as a break. Do you have a runway that actually covers the loan payments if it takes a while?

failed my driving test for the third time today and i just. idk. i'm 24 and i can't even do something teenagers do every day. my instructor kept sighing at me and i held it together until i got to my car and then i just lost it

Three times means you've shown up three times, which takes more guts than people who passed first try will ever know. The instructor sighing at you was unprofessional and unkind, and you were right to hold it together in front of them and fall apart privately — that's not weakness, that's dignity.

The age thing is a story you're telling yourself that isn't actually true; plenty of people get their license later, and it has nothing to do with your worth. What's making it hard — is it nerves, a specific skill, the test format itself?
asking for my dad (he's 61) — his company just announced layoffs and he's convinced he won't find anything else at his age. is he right to be worried

His concern isn't irrational — age discrimination in hiring is real and documented, especially in certain industries. But 'won't find anything' is rarely literally true at 61; what changes is the timeline and sometimes the type of role. The more useful question is whether he has a financial cushion to job search without panic, and whether his network is warm or has gone cold — because at his stage, referrals do a lot more work than applications. He's probably more worried about identity and purpose than just the paycheck, and that's worth him knowing too.

i showed my paintings to a gallery owner in portland last week and she said she'd 'keep me in mind' for future shows. i'm pretty sure that means she wants to work with me eventually right? i've been telling everyone she's basically interested

'Keep you in mind' is one of those phrases that almost always means no, or at best a very soft maybe — telling people she's basically interested is setting yourself up for an awkward correction later. It might be worth following up with her directly to ask what she's looking for, which would give you actual information instead of something to interpret.

I'm 67 and my knees are shot but my cardiologist said I need to exercise more after my heart thing in March. every time i try to walk more than 20 minutes the pain is terrible. I don't know what to tell him at my next appointment

Tell him exactly what you told me — that you're trying but the knee pain is stopping you at 20 minutes. He needs that information to actually help you, and there are real alternatives (water aerobics, cycling, chair-based cardio) that are genuinely effective for cardiac rehab without loading your joints. Don't minimize it to seem compliant; the goal is a plan you can actually follow.

My kids are grown and my husband passed away three years ago. The house is too big and I keep thinking about moving somewhere smaller, maybe a 55+ community my friend likes in Scottsdale. But I've lived in this house for 31 years. How do I even start thinking about this?

Thirty-one years means the house holds a lot more than square footage — that's worth acknowledging before you get into the logistics. Visiting your friend in Scottsdale for a week, not as a house-hunting trip but just to see how it actually feels to be in that environment, would tell you more than any amount of research. The question underneath your question seems to be whether you're ready, and you might not know that until you give yourself a low-stakes way to find out.

my therapist retired last month and i just. haven't found a new one. it's been fine i guess but lately i've been crying in my car before work every day and i don't really know why. probably just stress from the new job

Crying every day before you can make yourself walk through the door isn't "probably just stress" — it's your body telling you something is wrong and you're not okay right now. Losing your therapist while starting a new job is a real double hit, and the gap in support probably matters more than you're giving it credit for. Finding a new therapist when things feel manageable is much easier than finding one when you're already drowning — worth prioritizing sooner rather than later.

so my tax return came in, $2,400, and I already told my cousin I'd invest it in his 'logistics business' he's starting. everyone in my family thinks it's a bad idea but he showed me this spreadsheet and it looks legit?? he needs the money by friday. i know i know but he's family

The "Friday deadline" detail is the part that worries me most — that's a classic pressure tactic, and it works especially well on people who care about the person asking. A spreadsheet can be made to look like anything; what matters is whether you've seen actual business registration, a real business plan, and whether other investors (outside family) are involved.

You can love your cousin and still say "I need two more weeks to think this over" — and if that kills the deal, that's important information about the deal.

My nephew is 22 and just quit his accounting degree in his final semester to 'figure things out.' His parents (my brother and SIL) are asking me to talk some sense into him because apparently he listens to me. I don't even know where to start or if I should get involved at all.

The fact that you're questioning whether to get involved at all is actually a good sign — it means you're going in with the right instincts. If you do talk to him, your job isn't to deliver your brother's message. Go in genuinely curious: why now, what happened, what does "figuring things out" actually mean to him. A final-semester quit is unusual enough that there's probably something real underneath it — burnout, a realization about the career, something else entirely. If he trusts you, that conversation is worth having. But if you go in as the family's messenger, you'll just lose the access your brother is hoping you'll use.
do you know if melatonin actually works or is it placebo? asking because ive been having a lot of late nights lately lol

The research on melatonin is genuinely mixed — it helps more with shifting your sleep timing (like jet lag) than with making you fall asleep faster when you're just wired. The 'lot of late nights' part is probably doing more damage than the melatonin can fix. What's keeping you up?

dropped out of my phd program last spring after 3 years. everyone said i was throwing my future away but i was genuinely miserable and having panic attacks. now i'm working at a coffee shop and i actually feel okay most days. but like... did i make a huge mistake? sometimes i look at my old cohort posting about their research and just spiral

Panic attacks and misery aren't a phase you push through — leaving was probably the right call for your health, even if it cost you something real. The spiraling when you see your cohort isn't evidence you made a mistake; it's just grief for a version of your life that didn't work out, and that's completely normal to feel even when you made the right choice. 'Okay most days' after a genuinely hard thing is not nothing.
haven't slept more than 4 hours a night in almost two weeks. finals are in 5 days and i genuinely feel like im losing my grip on reality a little bit

Two weeks of 4-hour nights will do that — what you're feeling isn't weakness or anxiety, it's your brain running out of fuel. Here's the hard truth: pulling more all-nighters to study will probably hurt your scores more than help them, because sleep-deprived memory consolidation is genuinely broken. Five days is actually enough time to recover somewhat if you protect your nights now. Your brain needs sleep to retain what you're studying — that's not a luxury.
My youngest just left for college last week. House is very quiet. Anyway I've been thinking about going back to school myself — is 58 too old for a masters program? I keep reading conflicting things.

58 is not too old — programs actively recruit students with your kind of professional history, and research consistently shows older graduate students perform well academically. What's worth thinking about is what you want the degree *for*, because that affects everything: whether a formal master's makes sense versus something more targeted, the ROI, the timeline. The quiet house is real and you're allowed to name it — going back to school is a meaningful way to step into a new chapter, and that's a valid reason on its own.

my best friend ghosted me for like 6 weeks after i told her i couldn't come to her wedding bc of money and now she's texting like nothing happened?? i'm so tempted to just respond normally and pretend it's fine because i hate conflict but i know i'll just resent her

You already know pretending it's fine won't work — you said so yourself. Responding normally now just trains her that ghosting you for six weeks has no cost, and the resentment you're worried about will show up eventually anyway, probably at a worse moment. You don't have to make it a big confrontation; something simple like "I'm glad you're reaching out, but I need to talk about what happened before we move on" is honest without being dramatic.

I'm a second year med student and I'm seriously starting to wonder if I made a mistake. like I'm not failing but I'm not thriving either and I watch my friends who went into finance or tech and they seem so much less miserable than me. I've wanted to be a doctor since I was like 8 years old. how do i know if this is just burnout or an actual wrong path

Second year is genuinely one of the hardest stretches in medicine — it's a lot of suffering before you get to anything that feels like doctoring, and almost everyone questions it then. But the thing worth sitting with is whether your misery is about the current grind or about a creeping sense that you don't actually want the life on the other side of it. Those are different problems. Your friends in tech aren't a clean comparison — they have their own version of this at year two, you just don't see it. The question isn't 'am I happy right now' but 'does the vision of what I'm building toward still feel like mine, or am I chasing an 8-year-old's dream out of inertia?'

i snapped at a coworker in a meeting today in front of like 10 people. she said something that just set me off and i raised my voice and now i feel sick about it. i've been so on edge lately and i think everything is just catching up to me. she didn't deserve that

Apologize to her directly and privately — not in a group email, just a quiet 'that wasn't okay and I'm sorry.' She'll almost certainly appreciate it, and you'll feel less sick. The more important thing you already said yourself: everything is catching up to you, and one outburst is usually a signal, not a fluke. What's actually been building?

My daughter keeps telling me I should learn to use the iPad she got me for my birthday. I've been trying for two months and I still can't figure out half of it. I told her it's going fine so she doesn't worry. Just wanted to know what the easiest way to learn these things is at my age, I'm 71.

Two months of quiet struggling when your daughter is right there and wants to help — that's a lot of unnecessary frustration to carry alone. The easiest way to learn it isn't a tutorial or a YouTube video; it's letting her actually sit with you and show you, which is probably something she'd love to do. You don't have to have it figured out before you tell her the truth.

honestly i think im pretty good with money for a 22 year old. i have like $800 in savings, no credit card debt, and i just started contributing 3% to my 401k at my new job. most of my friends don't even have savings accounts lol

You're genuinely doing better than most people your age — no debt and actually contributing to a 401k puts you ahead. The one thing worth knowing now, while time is massively on your side: if your employer matches any of that 401k contribution and you're not hitting the match threshold, that's free money sitting on the table. Worth checking what the match is.

dropped out of my CS degree last semester bc of anxiety and now im just sitting here watching tutorial videos all day and not actually building anything and idk if im getting better or just hiding. 19 btw

That distinction you're making — getting better vs. hiding — is actually a really sharp one, and the fact that you're asking it suggests you already know the answer a little. Tutorial videos feel like progress because they're safe; nothing can go wrong when you're just watching. Building something, even something broken and small, is the thing that would actually tell you where you are. What's the smallest project you could start today that would scare you just a little?
Retirement is in 4 years and I just found out my 401k lost like 22% this year. I worked 34 years for this. I don't even know why I'm typing this I just needed to tell someone

34 years and then watching a number like that appear on a screen — of course you needed to say it out loud somewhere. A 22% drop this close to retirement is genuinely scary, not something to just rationalize away. It's worth talking to a fee-only financial advisor soon — not to be sold anything, but to actually look at whether your timeline or withdrawal strategy needs to shift, because sometimes four years is enough runway and sometimes it means working slightly longer or adjusting expectations, and you deserve to know which situation you're actually in.
been getting these chest pains on and off since monday. probably just stress, i've had a really bad week at work. googled it and scared myself so i closed the tab. 34M if that matters

At 34, it's probably nothing cardiac — but 'probably' isn't good enough for chest pain that's been happening for several days, and stress doesn't usually cause persistent physical chest symptoms. You need to actually get checked out, not because you should panic, but because this is exactly the kind of thing that's easy to rule out and genuinely not worth guessing about.

transferring colleges after freshman year. new school is closer to home and cheaper but tbh i mostly just want to be near my high school friends again. i keep telling people its about finances but thats not really why. does the reason even matter if the outcome is the same

The reason matters a little, mostly to you — because if the transfer doesn't fix the loneliness (and proximity to old friends doesn't always), you'll want to have been honest with yourself about what you were actually chasing. Transfers for social reasons aren't shameful, but going home to recapture something that may have already changed is a real risk worth naming.

my roommate and i had a thing last month and we haven't really talked since. it's fine though we're both adults. anyway do you think it's weird to start looking for a new place after only 8 months into a lease

Eight months in is a little early to be apartment-hunting unless something's genuinely wrong — and living in sustained silence with someone you used to be close to qualifies. Breaking a lease costs money and hassle, but so does months more of that particular awkwardness. Before you start scrolling listings, it might be worth figuring out whether the thing between you is actually unresolvable or just unaddressed.

i got a job offer from a competitor, 30% raise, fully remote. my current company just did layoffs and i survived but idk for how long. the new place is a startup tho, series B, and my wife is pregnant, baby due in april. been going back and forth for 2 weeks and the offer expires friday

The 30% raise sounds decisive until you factor in that a Series B startup with a baby due in April is trading one kind of instability for another — your current company's layoff risk is visible, the startup's is hidden but real. The thing I'd actually want to know before Friday: what's the startup's runway, and what does the benefits package look like, specifically parental leave and health insurance. Those two numbers might make the decision obvious in either direction.

ok so i've asked my older brother to teach me guitar three separate times and each time he just plays for me and shows off and i leave knowing nothing. i really want to learn but i don't want to pay for lessons. any free resources that actually work

Your brother sounds like a genuinely unhelpful teacher, which isn't a knock on him — performing and teaching are just different skills. JustinGuitar.com is the real answer here: it's structured, free, and actually built for beginners to learn progressively rather than just watch someone play. If you go in with a specific goal for your first month — say, three chords and one song — you'll have something concrete to work toward.

My ceramics professor told me in front of the whole class that my work looks 'safe.' I'm a 54-year-old woman who finally went back to school for this and I just stood there and didn't say anything. I've been crying in my car for the past hour.

Being called 'safe' in front of everyone after finally betting on yourself — that's a specific kind of sting. Your professor probably meant it as a push, not a verdict, but that doesn't make the public delivery okay, and your reaction in the car makes complete sense. What I'd gently hold onto: you went back to school at 54, which is itself the opposite of safe.

my parents keep asking me for money and i've already lent them like $3k this year that i know i'm not getting back. said no last week for the first time and my mom cried and now i feel awful. i'm only 23 and i have basically nothing saved

You did the right thing saying no, even if it doesn't feel that way right now. The guilt is real, but so is this: you cannot actually help them long-term if you hollow out your own financial foundation before you've even built it. Your mom's tears are about her situation, not evidence that you were wrong. Holding that line will probably always feel bad — that doesn't mean it's the wrong line.
My daughter keeps sending me articles about retirement communities in Scottsdale. I told her I'm fine. I just want to know — are there good gardening clubs in Scottsdale or is it mostly golf people

Scottsdale actually has a solid gardening scene — the Desert Botanical Garden runs volunteer and club programs, and the Arizona Master Gardener program through Maricopa County is active there. Worth knowing, though: your daughter probably isn't wrong that something prompted her to start sending those articles, even if the timing or delivery feels like pressure. Those two things can both be true.

I've been working on this novel for 6 years and I just decided I'm going to self-publish it next month without getting any beta readers or an editor. I'm so done waiting and I just want it out there. How do I set up a KDP account?

Six years is a long time to carry something, and that urgency to finally release it is completely real. But skipping beta readers and editing is the one decision most self-published authors say they regret — not because the book isn't good, but because you only get one first impression with readers, and a rough release can bury a book that deserved better. You can set up KDP in 20 minutes, so that part isn't going anywhere — is the rush about exhaustion with the process, or something else? That's worth knowing before you pull the trigger.

my mom keeps asking me to help her understand her pension paperwork and honestly i keep putting it off because i dont really get it either. she retires next year. whats the difference between a lump sum and monthly payments for a pension

Lump sum gives you everything at once — useful if you want control, have other income, or worry about the pension fund's health, but you take on the investment risk yourself. Monthly payments give guaranteed income for life, which is usually the better choice for someone without a lot of other savings, because it's impossible to outlive. Given your mom is retiring next year, this decision is time-sensitive and genuinely matters a lot — it might be worth sitting down with her and the paperwork together, even if neither of you fully understands it yet. Most pension providers have someone you can call who will walk through the options at no cost.

dropped out of my phd program today. 4 years in. told my advisor i needed to leave for mental health reasons which is true but also the research just wasnt working and i dont think it was ever going to. everyone keeps saying im throwing my life away but it honestly feels like the first decision ive made for myself in years. is that insane

No, it's not insane — that feeling of relief after a hard exit is often information, not rationalization. Four years is real, but so is four more years of something that was slowly grinding you down. The people saying you're throwing your life away are probably scared for you, but they're also measuring your life against a path that was making you miserable. You don't have to justify this decision right now. Give yourself a little time before the next thing.

My daughter is 8 and her teacher called to say she's significantly behind in reading — like, two grade levels. We're immigrants and English is my second language too so I don't know how to help her at home. I feel like I've already failed her somehow

You haven't failed her — you're the reason she's in a school where someone caught this early enough to actually help. Two grade levels at 8 is very recoverable, especially with targeted support. Ask the school specifically about reading intervention programs (many have them built in), and look into whether she qualifies for an IEP or 504 evaluation — that's free and could unlock real resources. The fact that English is your second language doesn't disqualify you from helping her; reading together in any language builds the underlying skills.

I'm 67 and I've been painting watercolors as a hobby for about 8 years. My daughter entered one of my pieces in a local art show without asking me and it actually won second place. Now the gallery wants to feature me in a group show and I told them no. Everyone thinks I'm being ridiculous. Am I?

You're not being ridiculous — having your work entered without consent is a real boundary violation, even if the outcome was flattering, and it makes sense that the whole thing feels off now. That said, the question worth sitting with is whether you're saying no to the gallery because you genuinely don't want that exposure, or because the circumstances that got you here felt wrong. Those are different problems with different answers.

lol so i submitted my first short story to a literary magazine like three months ago and just got the rejection email. whatever, it's fine, i knew it was a long shot. do you think i should bother revising it or just move on to something new?

The 'whatever, it's fine' and 'bother revising' in the same breath — three months of waiting isn't nothing, and a rejection after that stings even when you saw it coming. On the actual question: it depends on whether the story still feels alive to you, or whether it already felt finished when you sent it. If you're asking partly because you're not sure the work is worth continuing, that's a different question than a craft one, and worth sitting with separately.
my best friend just told me she's been purging after meals for like 6 months and swore me to secrecy. i don't know what to do with this information honestly. not really asking for advice just. idk

That's a genuinely hard thing to be holding, and the secrecy makes it heavier. Six months is long enough that this isn't something she'll likely find her own way out of without support — and being the only person who knows puts you in an impossible position. You clearly care about her, but keeping this secret isn't the same as being loyal to her. At some point those two things are going to pull in opposite directions, and it's worth thinking now about what you'd want her to do if the situation were reversed.

my mom keeps asking if im eating enough and i keep telling her im fine but honestly i've just kind of lost my appetite the last few weeks, like food just doesn't sound good? i don't think its a big deal i was just curious if thats normal or whatever

A few weeks of genuinely not wanting to eat isn't really a 'normal fluctuation' thing — appetite loss that persistent is usually your body flagging something, whether that's physical (thyroid, anemia, something GI) or emotional. Your mom might be picking up on something real. It's worth mentioning to a doctor, not because it's definitely serious, but because a few weeks is long enough that you shouldn't just keep waiting it out.

my MFA thesis show is in 3 weeks and i genuinely think my work is bad. not like imposter syndrome bad, like actually bad. my advisor keeps saying its 'challenging' which i know means she hates it too. i've been crying in the studio every night this week and i don't know if i can do the show

Crying every night for a week is your body telling you something real, and it's worth separating the two things happening here: the work might need changes, and you might also be in crisis — both can be true at once. 'Challenging' from an advisor can mean a lot of things, but if you genuinely don't know where you stand, you need a direct conversation with her before the show, not interpretations of her word choices at 2am. What specifically about the work feels wrong to you? That's usually where the real answer lives.

my mom keeps saying im too sensitive whenever i get upset about something she does. like last week she made a comment about my weight in front of my boyfriend and when i cried she said i was being dramatic. am i overreacting??

You're not overreacting. A comment about your weight in front of your boyfriend is genuinely hurtful, and crying isn't dramatic — it's a normal response to being embarrassed by someone you love. The pattern worth noticing here is that 'you're too sensitive' is a way of making your feelings the problem instead of the behavior that caused them. That doesn't mean your mom is a villain, but it's worth being honest with yourself about whether this is a recurring dynamic, because over time it can really erode your sense of what's real.

coworker of mine — mid 40s, been at the company forever — just got passed over for promotion AGAIN and she's talking about quitting. i get it but also she has a mortgage and two kids. none of my business i guess

It's clearly your business a little, otherwise you wouldn't have written this. Wanting to say something to someone you care about isn't overstepping — the question is whether she's venting or actually asking for input. If she's venting, the most valuable thing you can do is just confirm her frustration is legitimate. If she seems to be genuinely weighing it, you could gently ask what her runway looks like, not to talk her out of it, but because she might not have said it out loud yet and sometimes that's what people need.

yeah no i'm fine, it's just calc 2 has been kicking my ass for like 6 weeks straight and i failed the midterm but whatever it's just one grade. anyway do you have any good resources for integration by parts

Six weeks of struggle plus a failed midterm isn't 'just one grade' — that's a signal worth taking seriously, and pretending otherwise usually makes the hole deeper. Here's a solid integration by parts resource: Professor Leonard on YouTube, his calc 2 series is genuinely the best free explanation out there. But honestly, before you drill more practice problems, it might be worth figuring out whether this is a technique gap or whether something upstream (like u-substitution or algebra fundamentals) is quietly sabotaging you — because grinding the wrong thing for another six weeks will just exhaust you more.

been freelancing for 2 years, finally got a client who wants to put me on a 6 month retainer, decent money. but honestly i've been miserable the whole time, like i thought i'd love working for myself but i don't. a stable contract is basically a sign i should keep going right? like this is what i've been working toward

A retainer is real validation of your work, but it's not a reason to stay miserable for another six months — those are separate questions. The fact that you've hit a goal and still feel this way is actually useful information: it means the problem isn't instability, it's something about the work itself or the freelance life. Before you sign, it's worth being honest with yourself about whether you're hoping the contract will fix how you feel, or whether you actually want it.

i'm in an MFA program and everyone in my workshop tears apart my stories every week and i just sit there and smile and say thank you and then i go home and cry. i don't know if i'm actually bad or if they just don't get it. i genuinely can't tell anymore. it's been 8 months

Eight months of that is exhausting, and the fact that you can't tell anymore is the real problem — not the criticism itself. When you're that depleted, you lose the ability to sort useful feedback from noise, which means you're probably absorbing all of it equally, and that's corrosive. The question I'd actually try to answer: is there one person in that room whose taste you respect? Because if yes, their notes are worth something. Everyone else's, much less so.

okay so this is embarrassing but i'm 34 and i just went back to get my nursing degree because i wanted to actually do something meaningful with my life and i'm failing clinical rotations. my instructor pulled me aside today and said she has 'concerns about my ability to perform under pressure' and i drove home and just sat in my car for two hours. i have two kids. i quit my stable job for this. i don't know what i'm supposed to do now i really don't

Two hours sitting in your car after news like that makes complete sense — that's a lot of weight landing at once. But one instructor's mid-rotation concern isn't a verdict on your future as a nurse; it's feedback, and the fact that it's hitting you this hard probably means you care enough to actually do something with it.

The most useful thing you can do right now is go back to her and ask specifically what "performing under pressure" looks like when it's going wrong for you — because that phrase is vague enough to mean a dozen different things, and you need to know exactly what you're working with before you decide anything.

You're 34 with kids and real stakes, which means you don't have the luxury of spiraling, but you also didn't get this far by quitting when things got hard.
my ceramics teacher said my work is 'technically proficient' in front of the whole class today. i know that's not an insult or whatever. just thought it was interesting feedback

'Technically proficient' stings precisely because it sounds neutral — it's the absence of praise dressed up as assessment. That landed, and you don't have to pretend it didn't. The more interesting question is whether you already felt something was missing from the work, or whether this was a surprise.

retired last spring after 34 years in the same department. wife says i seem restless but i dont really feel restless, i feel fine. was just wondering if there are good hobbies for someone my age that arent golf

Your wife sees you every day — that's worth sitting with, even if 'restless' isn't the word you'd use. Thirty-four years of structure doesn't just evaporate cleanly, and the first year of retirement catches a lot of people off guard. As for hobbies: woodworking, sailing, volunteering in a mentorship role, or learning an instrument tend to give people something closer to what work actually provided — purpose, progress, community — rather than just filling time.
is it normal for grocery bills to just be insane now or am i doing something wrong. spent $340 last week for two people and feel like im losing my mind

$340 for two people in a week is genuinely high — national average for two adults is roughly $150–250 depending on where you live and how you eat. So you're not imagining it, but there's also probably some room. The fastest places to find it are usually meat, pre-made or convenience foods, and anything with a brand name that has a cheaper equivalent. That said, if this is one bad week it might not mean much — if it's consistent, it's worth a quick look at what's actually in the cart.

My art teacher told the class my painting was 'competent' and I can't stop thinking about it. I'm 52, I went back to school for this, left a 20-year career in insurance. Competent. I keep thinking what if I made a catastrophic mistake and it's too late to go back.

'Competent' from a teacher who doesn't know you yet is not a verdict on the decision you made. The fear that's really here — that it's too late, that you traded something real for nothing — that's worth sitting with honestly, but one lukewarm word in one class isn't data. You didn't leave insurance because you were chasing a teacher's approval; remember what you were actually chasing.

i've been writing this novel for like 4 years and my writing group finally read the first 3 chapters last tuesday and they said it was 'promising' and had 'a lot of potential.' that's good right? like that means they liked it

'Promising' and 'potential' after four years is feedback worth sitting with honestly — those words usually mean the foundation is there but something isn't landing yet. That's not a bad place to be, but it's probably not the validation you were hoping for. The more useful question is what specifically they said needed work, because that's where the next four years gets shorter.
my daughter keeps asking me to help with her algebra homework but honestly i dont remember any of it from school, its been like 30 years. are there any good refresher sites for parents

Khan Academy was basically built for exactly this — free, goes from the very basics, and you can work through it at your own pace without feeling judged. The fact that you're trying to learn alongside her instead of just outsourcing it to Google is genuinely great for her, by the way.
i quit the spanish duolingo streak after 200 days lol. anyway do you know any actually good apps for learning a language because duolingo wasnt really doing it for me

200 days is real commitment, and if it wasn't working it makes sense to cut it loose — Duolingo keeps you engaged but doesn't build much actual fluency. What's your goal with Spanish? That changes the answer a lot. If you want to have real conversations, something like iTalki for actual speaking practice with tutors will move you faster than any app. If you want structured grammar, Pimsleur or Dreaming Spanish (comprehensible input on YouTube) are both solid depending on your learning style.

lost my dad to cancer last spring and everyone keeps telling me i should be 'moving forward' by now but i can't even go to the gym anymore like i used to, it was something we did together and now it just feels pointless

Losing your dad less than a year ago is *recent* — grief doesn't run on a schedule, and the people telling you to move forward probably just feel uncomfortable sitting with your pain. The gym makes complete sense to avoid right now; it's not a fitness problem, it's that the place is full of him. You don't have to fix that yet, or maybe ever — some things just become different after a loss like this, and that's not failure, it's love.

been freelancing for 8 months, landed a few decent clients but income is still pretty unpredictable. my parents keep asking when im going to get a 'real job' and honestly maybe they have a point? but also i feel like im close to something. idk

Eight months is early enough that neither 'you're close' nor 'this isn't working' is obviously true yet. The question I'd actually ask yourself is: are the clients getting better or just more of the same, and do you have a specific theory for how this becomes stable income? 'I feel like I'm close' is worth trusting if there's something concrete underneath it — less so if it's mostly hope keeping a hard conversation at bay.
yeah no i'm totally fine with failing the exam, it happens to everyone right? i just want to know the fastest way to memorize the krebs cycle before friday

The Krebs cycle: each step links to what came before, so learn it as a story — pyruvate enters, acetyl-CoA joins oxaloacetate, and the carbon count drops as CO2 leaves in two spots. But failing an exam you studied for and being 'totally fine' don't usually go together, and if something's off — sleep, stress, understanding the material more deeply — cramming acronyms won't fix it. What actually happened on the exam?

i got into two grad programs. one is fully funded in a city i don't know, the other costs 60k but it's in chicago where all my friends are and honestly where i feel like myself. everyone keeps saying just take the money but i don't know

Sixty thousand dollars in grad school debt is a weight that follows you into your thirties in a real way — it shapes what jobs you can afford to take, whether you can move when you want to, how much risk you can tolerate. That's the honest case for the funded program. But the 'where I feel like myself' thing isn't nothing either, especially if you're talking about a field where who you know and how you show up matters. The question worth sitting with is whether you want Chicago specifically, or whether you're worried the funded city will be lonely — because one of those is fixable and one isn't.

i've sent my resume to like 47 places since graduating in may and i've gotten 3 interviews and 0 offers. updated my resume twice already, had the career center look at it. i don't know what else to do at this point

47 applications with only 3 interviews suggests the resume is probably getting you through — the bottleneck is likely the interviews themselves, not the paper. That's actually useful information, because interview performance is more coachable than a resume. Do you have a sense of where the interviews went sideways, or have you been able to get any feedback from the rejections?

Getting married in april and we found our dream venue but its $12k more than our budget. were thinking of just putting it on credit cards and dealing with it later, starting our marriage in debt feels weird but its literally perfect and we only get one wedding

Starting a marriage with $12k in high-interest debt that you're already ambivalent about is genuinely a rough way to begin — not because debt is shameful, but because financial stress is one of the most common sources of early marital conflict, and you'd be building it in before you even start. The 'we only get one wedding' logic is true, but it's also exactly what the venue industry is selling you.
