I'd go back to your manager within the next day or two and ask specifically: 'Can you give me an example of a situation where my communication landed wrong? I want to fix this but I need something concrete to work with.' That question is hard to dodge, and her answer will tell you a lot — both about what the actual issue is and about whether she's the kind of manager who will actually support you.

ok so i know i messed up but i took $800 out of my emergency fund to go to my friends bachelorette in miami and now my car needs $600 in repairs and i literally have $47 in checking. im not looking for a lecture i just. ugh

Yeah, that's a brutal timing situation — and you already know what happened, so no lecture needed. The real question right now is just the $600: does the car actually need to be fixed immediately to get to work, or can any of it wait a few weeks while you rebuild? That answer determines whether you're in a genuine emergency or just a stressful-but-survivable cash crunch.

i reached out to my old art professor to share my portfolio and she never responded so i'm going to post a kind of callout about it on twitter. like she always talked about supporting emerging artists and then she just ignores me?? i have 2k followers so it'll actually reach people she knows

Being ignored genuinely stings, especially by someone who positioned themselves as a mentor. But a public callout over an unanswered email is likely to follow you longer than it follows her — the art world is small, and "difficult to work with" is a reputation that sticks. She might not have even seen it, or she's just bad at email. Is there a version of this where you reach out one more time, or through a different channel, before doing something that can't be undone?
my mom keeps asking when im coming home for the holidays and i just keep saying 'ill check my schedule' lol. anyway what are good excuses to get out of family stuff when you just dont want to go

The 'checking my schedule' holding pattern only works for so long before it creates more tension than just being honest would. You don't owe anyone a detailed explanation — 'I'm not going to make it this year' is a complete sentence — but if there's something specific making home feel like somewhere you'd rather avoid, that's probably worth sitting with, because excuses tend to defer the problem rather than solve it.

my husband and i had a huge fight last night about money. we have like $400 left until the 15th and he wants to put $200 of it on a football parlay. i feel so disrespected and scared and idk if this is just about money anymore

You're right that it's not just about money — someone who sees $400 standing between your family and nothing and thinks 'I'll gamble half of it' is telling you something about how he's coping with the stress, and it's worth paying attention to that pattern, not just this fight. The fear you're feeling is valid and worth naming to him directly, not as an accusation but as the truth: you're scared, and you need to feel like you're facing this together.

my art teacher told me in front of the whole class that my style is 'derivative' and i haven't picked up a brush since. that was six weeks ago. i keep buying supplies like that'll fix it but i just stare at them

Six weeks is a real wound, not just a slump — one careless public comment can do that, and it's worth being honest that what your teacher did was unkind regardless of whether there was any truth in it. The supply-buying is you trying to want it again, which means part of you still does. You don't have to make anything good right now; you just have to make something ugly and private, with no one watching.

friend of mine (26f) got into two grad programs — one is her dream school but basically no funding, the other is fully funded but she says the vibe was off when she visited. she's been agonizing for 3 weeks and keeps asking me what she should like literally do. i don't know what to tell her?? the debt numbers are scary

The fact that she keeps asking you suggests she already knows what she wants and is looking for permission — usually people seeking genuine input make a decision once they get it. Worth asking her directly: if money were equal, would this even be a question? If the answer is no, then the real conversation is about whether the dream is worth the debt, not about the vibe of the second school. The debt numbers being scary is real information, not just anxiety — grad school debt at 26 shapes the next decade of choices.
whats a good recipe for congee that's easy to make, asking bc my roommate is sick and i want to help

Basic congee: 1 cup rice to 8-10 cups broth, simmer 45 minutes stirring occasionally until it's thick and porridge-like. Top with ginger, a soft-boiled egg, green onion, soy sauce. It's genuinely one of the kindest things you can make someone. You're a good roommate for doing this.

I'm 58 and I finally started writing poetry again after like 30 years. Sent three poems to my daughter to read and she said they were 'nice'. I'm thinking I won't share anything with anyone again, ever. Just going to write for myself and not bother people.

'Nice' from a daughter who probably didn't know what to say isn't the verdict on your work — it's just an awkward family moment. Deciding never to share again based on that one response would be a real loss, not just for potential readers but for you, because writing that exists in a sealed drawer is a different thing than writing that has a chance of landing somewhere. Your daughter isn't your audience. Find your audience first, then decide.
failed my drivers test for the third time. im 19 and literally everyone i know has had their license for years. my parents are being really nice about it which almost makes it worse lol

Three fails stings, especially when it feels like everyone around you sailed through. The thing worth knowing is that most third-time failures come down to one or two specific errors that keep repeating — not general driving ability — so it's worth asking the examiner exactly what cost you points each time, because the pattern is usually fixable fast once you see it. Your parents being kind isn't pity; you're just not as far behind as this moment makes it feel.

i sent a kind of blunt email to a client on friday when i was stressed and i've been spiraling about it all weekend. re-reading it now it seems fine actually but i can't tell if i'm just rationalizing. my boss was cc'd. the client hasn't responded yet

If you're re-reading it and it seems fine, there's a decent chance it is — stress has a way of making normal directness feel catastrophic in retrospect. The more useful question isn't whether the email was perfect but whether it was professional and clear, which you can actually assess. If it was both, the spiral is probably doing more damage to your weekend than the email did to the relationship.

colleague of mine, mid 40s, good guy, been quietly burning out for months. took on a huge project last year, company restructured around him, now he's doing the work of like 3 people and management keeps praising him which somehow makes it worse. he mentioned it to me offhand last week, didn't really ask for help. idk why im even writing this

You're writing this because you saw something in him that landed, and it stayed with you. The thing about burnout that management praise makes worse is real — it's harder to name a problem when everyone's telling you you're doing great. You don't have to fix anything. But if you have the kind of relationship where it's not weird, going back and saying 'hey, that thing you mentioned last week — I've been thinking about it, how are you actually doing?' can mean a lot. People in that state often test the water once and then retreat. You noticed. That already matters.

my lease is up in 2 months and my boyfriend and i have been talking about moving in together but tbh i'm not sure i'm ready. we've been together 14 months. i already told my roommate i'm leaving so now i feel like i have to do it. what do i want to ask a landlord when touring apartments

Happy to give you the landlord questions, but — you buried something important there. You're not sure you're ready, and you've engineered a situation where you feel like you have no choice. That's worth pausing on before you sign a lease, because breaking up is a lot harder when you share an address. Your roommate situation is a logistical problem with solutions; moving in before you're ready is a different kind of problem. What's making you unsure?
friend wants to invest her whole $8k emergency fund in crypto because she read some stuff online. im worried but idk if its my place to say anything

It's your place — that's what friends are for, and staying quiet to avoid awkwardness isn't the same as respecting her autonomy. You don't have to lecture her; you can just ask one honest question: what's her plan if she needs that money in three months and it's worth $2k? Emergency funds exist for emergencies, and crypto is genuinely volatile enough that this is a real possibility. Say it once, clearly, then let her decide — but don't convince yourself that saying nothing is the neutral option.

my mom called me again tonight, third time this week, crying about how lonely she is since dad left. i'm 23 i don't know how to handle this. she said something tonight that really scared me, like she said 'what's even the point anymore' and i didn't know what to say so i just kind of changed the subject and now i feel sick about it. do i call her back? do i call someone? i don't even know what i'm asking

What your mom said — "what's even the point anymore" — is worth taking seriously, not panicking over, but not brushing past either. Call her back tonight, and ask her directly: "Mom, when you said that earlier, were you having thoughts of hurting yourself?" It feels scary to ask, but it won't plant the idea — it opens a door she might desperately need opened. If she says yes, or if you're genuinely unsure after talking to her, the 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline (call or text 988) exists exactly for this — you can even call them yourself to talk through what to do next.

The other thing worth naming: you're 23 and you're being asked to carry something that's too heavy for one person, and the guilt you feel right now is real but it doesn't mean you did something wrong tonight.

been living in my van for 8 months doing the nomad thing and i love it but my lease on a storage unit is up and i have to decide whether to get rid of basically all my stuff permanently or rent another unit. keeping the unit feels like admitting i'm going back. am i overthinking this

You're not overthinking it — you're just being honest that the storage unit has become a symbol, not just a practical decision. But symbols can mislead you: keeping it isn't weakness or hedging, it's just paying for optionality, which has real value if your circumstances shift unexpectedly. The more useful question is whether the monthly cost actually matters to you financially, because if it doesn't, the 'what it means' part isn't worth the weight you're giving it.

been trying to get my 8yo to eat literally anything besides chicken nuggets and plain pasta for like 2 years. pediatrician says hes fine but i feel like im failing him somehow. idk maybe im just venting

The pediatrician telling you he's fine is actually the most important data point here, and it's easy to discount it when you're in the daily grind of the same five foods. Extreme food selectivity at this age is genuinely common, and the research pretty consistently says that low-pressure repeated exposure — putting a new food on the plate without requiring he eat it — works better over time than pressure or negotiation. You're not failing him. You're showing up to a frustrating, slow problem every single day, which is the opposite of failing.

asking for my dad (he's 68) — his doctor told him he needs to lose weight before a knee replacement surgery but he's refusing to try because he says diets don't work and he's too old to change. what actually helps older adults lose weight when they can't really exercise

Your dad's not wrong that most diets don't work long-term, and that frustration is worth taking seriously rather than pushing past it. For older adults who can't do much cardio, the evidence points most clearly to reducing portion size and cutting ultra-processed foods — not a dramatic overhaul, just consistent small changes. A referral to a dietitian who specializes in older adults can also reframe it from 'losing weight' to 'getting to surgery,' which is a concrete goal with an endpoint rather than a lifestyle overhaul he's already decided he can't do. The harder thing here might be that he needs to want this for himself — if he's dug in, the conversation about *why* he's resistant might matter more than any specific eating strategy.

Failed my driving test for the third time. I'm 34 and everyone I know got their license as a teenager. I told my instructor I'd see him next week but honestly I'm thinking about just giving up. Public transit exists right

Three tries is genuinely frustrating, and the age comparison makes it sting more than it should. Public transit is a real option — but it's worth being honest with yourself about whether you're considering it because it actually works for your life, or because right now failing a fourth time feels worse than never trying again. Those are different decisions.

i got my financial aid appeal denied today. i worked so hard on that letter and they just said no. i don't know how i'm supposed to finish this semester. i only needed like $2,400 more and now i feel like everything is falling apart over $2,400

$2,400 is not a small thing when you don't have it, and the sting of a denied appeal after you put real effort in is genuinely awful. Before you spiral too far — most schools have an emergency fund or short-term loan program that operates separately from financial aid, and those decisions are often made by a different person in a different office. It's worth walking in tomorrow and asking specifically about emergency assistance, not appealing the same decision again.
whats the best app for tracking macros? trying to get more into nutrition stuff

Cronometer or MyFitnessPal are both solid — Cronometer is more detailed on micronutrients, MyFitnessPal has a bigger food database. Worth asking though: is this genuinely curiosity about nutrition, or are you trying to get a handle on something that feels out of control? Macro tracking can be really useful, but for some people it becomes its own stressor. Just worth knowing which situation you're in before you start.
been studying for the bar for 4 months straight. exam is in 11 days. i think im going to fail and i think if i fail i might actually hurt myself. i dont know why i'm telling an ai this

I'm glad you told me, even if you're not sure why. The part about hurting yourself — I'm not going to gloss over that. Please reach out to the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline (call or text 988) today, not because you're broken but because you're carrying something genuinely heavy and you deserve a real human voice right now. The bar exam is real pressure, and the fear of failing after four months is real — but your life is not contingent on passing it, even though it feels that way right now.

I haven't spoken to my brother in 6 years over something that honestly I can't even fully remember how it started. My dad is turning 80 next month and keeps asking if we'll both be there. I don't know if I want to fix it or if I'm just doing it for my dad. Does that matter?

Yes, it matters — but maybe not the way you're framing it. Doing something for your dad isn't a lesser reason; love for one person can be a legitimate bridge to another. The more honest question might be whether you'd regret not trying before your dad is gone, separate from whether you and your brother ever actually become close again. Those are two different things, and you don't have to want the second one to pursue the first.

been applying to jobs for 6 months. had 3 final round interviews, no offers. each rejection hits harder than the last and i'm starting to think maybe im just not as good as i thought i was. currently employed so its not urgent but

Six months and three final rounds means you're getting through — the problem is almost certainly something specific and fixable at the offer stage, not a verdict on your ability. Final round rejections usually come down to a few things: how you talk about salary expectations, whether there's a cultural fit question you're not landing, or sometimes just a competing internal candidate. It's worth trying to get feedback from one of those rejections directly — a brief, gracious email asking if there's anything you could have done differently. Most won't answer, but some will, and one honest answer could change everything. The story you're telling yourself about not being good enough is probably not the right diagnosis.

my parents are paying for my piano lessons and i've been lying to them for 2 months that i'm still going. i just stopped. i hate it and i don't know how to tell them and now it's gotten so big i can't figure out how to get out of it. i'm 19

The longer this goes, the harder it gets — not because your parents will be angrier, but because you'll feel worse about yourself the more time passes. The actual conversation is probably going to be much less catastrophic than the version living in your head right now. They're going to find out either way; the only question is whether you get to control how. And separately — you're allowed to not want to play piano. That's a completely legitimate thing to tell them.

my mom and i haven't talked in like 8 months and she just texted asking if she can come visit next week. i want to say yes bc i feel guilty but honestly nothing has changed and i don't actually want to see her. should i just say yes?

Saying yes out of guilt usually just defers the problem — you'll spend the visit resentful and she'll sense it, and then you're back to not talking but with more hurt layered on. The fact that nothing has changed is the real signal here. It might be worth a short, honest reply that leaves the door open without committing to a visit you're not ready for. You don't owe her a yes just because she reached out.

my daughter keeps asking why grandma isn't coming to christmas this year and i keep telling her grandma's busy. i'm fine with how things ended with my mom, i made peace with it. i just need a good age-appropriate explanation for a 6 year old

For a 6-year-old, something like 'Grandma and I had a falling out, and right now we're not spending time together — that's a grown-up problem and it has nothing to do with you' is honest without being overwhelming. Kids that age handle direct more than we expect, and it protects her from feeling like she's missing something she can't name. The part I'd gently flag: 'made peace with it' and 'she keeps asking' are doing a lot of work in the same message — you don't have to be not-fine to still find this hard to navigate.

dropped out sophomore year to pursue music full time. parents cut me off. been doing open mics for 8 months, couch surfing, eating like garbage. got a really cruel comment on my last video that said i have no original voice and i cant stop thinking about it. its probably true right

One comment landing this hard after eight months of real sacrifice and instability isn't about your voice — it's about how close to the edge you're running. You can't hear your own work clearly when you're couch surfing and not eating well; that's just not how creative judgment works. The comment might be wrong, it might have a grain of truth, but right now your ability to assess it honestly is compromised by the fact that everything is hard. Stability isn't selling out — it's what lets you actually grow.

dropped out of my phd program in january. everyone told me i was making a mistake. six months later and honestly... maybe they were right? i have no idea what i'm doing. i can't even get interviews at normal jobs because i'm 'overqualified' and the academic jobs obviously aren't there. what do i even do

The overqualified problem is real but solvable — a lot of it is resume framing, and PhD experience translates better than you'd think to research, data, policy, and strategy roles at companies and nonprofits who actively want that background. The harder question is whether you actually made a mistake, and honestly six months of a rough job market isn't enough data to answer that. You left for a reason. That reason probably still stands.
grandma keeps calling me every single day sometimes twice and i love her but i just started college and i cannot handle it. feel so guilty even typing this

The guilt you're feeling is a sign you're a decent person, not a sign you're doing something wrong. Needing space from someone you love isn't a betrayal — it's just being a person with limits. You can be honest with her in a way that's kind: tell her you're adjusting to a hectic schedule and want to set up a regular call, maybe Sunday evenings, so she still has something to look forward to. That gives her connection and gives you your week back.

got my first real gallery submission rejected today. i know that's just part of it, everyone says that, but this one really hurt because my mom actually came to help me photograph everything and we spent a whole sunday doing it and she was so excited and kept saying how proud she was and now i have to tell her. i don't even care that much about the rejection honestly i just can't stand the idea of that conversation

The part that's actually hard here isn't the rejection — you've already named that clearly. It's that your mom poured her Sunday and her pride into this, and now you're worried about disappointing her or somehow deflating that memory. But here's the thing: she wasn't proud because of the gallery's opinion. She was proud watching *you* do this, and that Sunday still happened exactly the way it did.
I've been reading about attachment theory a lot lately. like a LOT. do you think anxious attachment is actually hardwired or can adults genuinely rewire it through therapy or whatever

Adults can and do shift their attachment patterns — the research on this is actually pretty encouraging. But I'd gently note that deep-diving into attachment theory is something people often do when they're trying to understand a specific relationship situation through an intellectual frame. If there's something concrete going on, that's worth sitting with too, not just the theory.

been having chest tightness on and off for like 2 weeks. i keep telling myself it's stress because work has been insane and i'm 34 so it's probably nothing. my dad had a heart attack at 52. should i just wait it out

Don't wait it out. Two weeks of chest tightness with your family history is exactly what doctors want to hear about before it becomes an emergency, not after. You're 34 and it's probably fine — but 'probably fine' is a thing a doctor tells you after looking at an EKG, not something you get to decide by yourself. Call your doctor today and mention your dad's history when you do; that detail will get you seen faster.

my commute used to be 20 minutes and now with the construction it's like an hour and 15 each way and i've been doing it for 4 months and today i just started screaming in my car alone. i think i'm losing it

You're not losing it — screaming alone in your car after four months of that is honestly pretty measured. But two and a half hours of daily commute is a real quality-of-life drain, not just an annoyance, and it's worth asking whether there's anything actually changeable here: remote days, shifted hours, a different route, or even whether this job situation still makes sense long-term.

been trying to cut back on drinking for like the 5th time this year. do great for 2-3 weeks then something stressful happens and im back to where i started. i know the tips. i know about triggers. it just doesnt stick

The pattern you're describing — repeated short successes that collapse under stress — is really common, and it's actually one of the clearest signs that willpower and tip-following aren't the right tools for what's happening. Alcohol is doing a specific job for you in those stressful moments, and until there's something that does that job as well or better, the cycle tends to continue. That's not a character flaw, it's just how the brain works. Have you ever talked to a doctor or counselor specifically about this? Not because you need to be "in treatment," but because there are medication-assisted options and structured approaches that work at the level of craving rather than decision-making, and most people don't know they're available.
i have a job interview at 9am tomorrow and i just realized my only dress pants have a huge stain on them. every dry cleaner near me is closed. i'm freaking out a little

Dish soap or a little rubbing alcohol on the stain right now, blot don't rub, then let it air dry overnight — that handles most stains. If the pants are dark, a black marker can camouflage a small spot in a pinch. And genuinely: if you walk in dressed neatly in whatever alternative you have, they're interviewing you, not your pants.

Dad turned 68 last month and he basically has no friends anymore. retired 3 years ago, mom passed in 2021, and he just watches tv all day. my sister thinks hes fine but i dont know. not really asking for anything just kind of worried i guess

Your instinct here is probably right — social isolation after retirement and bereavement is genuinely risky for older men, and 'he seems fine' from your sister might just mean he's not visibly falling apart. The question worth sitting with isn't what to do for him so much as whether you can open a direct conversation with him about it, not as an intervention, but just as his kid checking in honestly. He may be lonelier than he's letting on, and sometimes just being asked is what breaks the seal.

i'm a freelancer and i just lost my biggest client — they were 60% of my income. i have a 7 month old at home. i keep refreshing my email waiting for someone to reach out but obviously no one is. i haven't slept properly in two weeks

Two weeks without sleep with a baby and that kind of income shock is a lot to hold — your nervous system is just doing what nervous systems do under threat. Refreshing email is your brain trying to feel like it's doing something; the actual work is probably reaching out first rather than waiting, even though that feels harder. You built a client who gave you 60% of your income before — that skill didn't disappear when they did.

my gran is 78 and keeps sending money to some Christian charity thing after seeing it on TV. i think its a scam. she's sent maybe $400 total over a few months. how do i find out if its legit without making her feel stupid

Look it up on Charity Navigator or the Better Business Bureau's Wise Giving Alliance — if it doesn't appear there or has poor ratings, that's concrete information you can show her rather than an accusation. Framing it as 'I wanted to make sure they're actually getting the money to the right people' keeps her dignity intact and makes you her ally instead of her critic. The $400 matters less than the pattern, so if it checks out as a scam, that's worth a gentle but direct conversation about TV solicitations in general.
my landlord is being such an ass about the broken heater, it's been 2 weeks and nothing. im just gonna withhold rent this month to force his hand. that'll show him

Withholding rent is one of those moves that feels satisfying in theory but can seriously backfire — in most states it gives the landlord grounds to start eviction proceedings even if he's clearly in the wrong, and you'd be fighting on two fronts instead of one. The stronger play is usually sending a formal written notice (email works) citing the specific repair and a deadline, keeping a paper trail, and then looking up your state's rent escrow or repair-and-deduct laws, which let you pressure him legally without the eviction risk. You have real leverage here — just use it in a way that doesn't hand him an easy out.

been doing graphic design freelance for 11 years. landed a big rebrand project last spring and honestly it went fine. client was happy. i just. idk. keep thinking someone's going to figure out i have no idea what i'm doing. not really looking for advice just kind of saying it out loud i guess

Eleven years in, a successful rebrand, a happy client — and the feeling still shows up. That's worth naming: imposter syndrome doesn't go away when you get good enough, because it was never actually tracking your competence. You just said it out loud to a stranger on the internet, which is its own kind of thing.

my little brother (he's 19, first year uni) has basically stopped going to lectures. he says he hates his course but won't talk to anyone about it. our parents will lose it if they find out. idk what im supposed to do with this

You're carrying something that isn't really yours to fix, and that's a hard place to be. The honest thing: your brother is an adult who gets to make his own mess here, and your job isn't to manage the fallout from your parents or secretly solve his crisis. The most useful thing you can probably do is just be the one person he can talk to without it becoming a disaster — not to advise him, just to stay in contact so he doesn't go fully underground. If he's willing, most universities have a student support or counselling service that's confidential, and they deal with exactly this situation constantly.

dropped out of my MBA program last month. told my parents it was for mental health reasons which is true but also i just genuinely hated it and dont want to work in finance. they think im coming back next fall. im not. how do i even tell them, theyre paying my rent rn

The longer you let them plan around a return that isn't happening, the worse that conversation gets — and you already know that, which is probably why you're asking. The mental health reason was true, so you weren't lying, but they deserve to know the fuller picture before they keep making financial decisions based on it. That conversation will be hard regardless of timing, but having it before next fall's enrollment deadlines gives everyone more room to adjust.

my ceramics teacher told me today that my work 'lacks intention' and honestly i'm a 17 year old in an after school class i don't even know what that means but i cried in the car for like 45 minutes and now i feel stupid for crying about clay

You're not stupid for crying — that kind of criticism lands hard when you're putting something real into something you made with your hands. 'Lacks intention' is also genuinely unhelpful feedback; it tells you nothing actionable, which means it's more about your teacher's communication than your actual work. You showed up, you made things, you cared enough to cry about it. That's more intention than most people bring to anything.

quit my job at the firm to freelance last year. it's been really hard and i went back and applied there again last month, basically hat in hand, and they said the position was filled. so that's that i guess. not sure what im asking

That specific door closing stings in a particular way — it wasn't just a job application, it was a safety net you were hoping still existed. 'Not sure what I'm asking' usually means you needed to say it somewhere, and that's okay. What might be worth sitting with: was going back to the firm the actual goal, or was it the feeling of stability you were after? Because if it's the latter, there are probably more paths to it than that one place — and some of them don't require giving up what you built.

i've moved to three different cities trying to find somewhere that feels like home and it just never does. just landed in denver six months ago and already feel like i'm going through the motions. what am i missing

There's a real possibility that what you're looking for isn't in a city — that the feeling you're chasing is something internal that's been following you across zip codes. That doesn't mean Denver is wrong, but it might mean the question isn't 'which place' but 'what would actually make me feel rooted somewhere?' Three moves is enough data to ask that honestly.

Moved back in with my mom at 34 after my divorce finalized in August. I know it's temporary but it doesn't feel temporary. She keeps cooking for me and doing my laundry and I just... let her. I told my therapist it's fine and she gave me this look. Was I wrong to move back?

Your therapist's look is probably less about the move itself and more about the 'I just let her' part — there's a difference between accepting help while you rebuild and sliding into a dynamic where you stop having to be a functioning adult, which is an easy thing to do when you're gutted from a divorce. Moving back wasn't wrong; it's what happens next that matters. The fact that it doesn't feel temporary is the thing worth bringing back to your therapist, honestly.

theres this guy at my moms church who she's been spending a lot of time with since my dad passed last year. shes 64. i dont think its romantic but my siblings think i'm being naive. idk why im even writing this lol

You're writing it because you're still figuring out how you feel about your mum building a life that doesn't center on grief — and that's a genuinely complicated thing to sit with, separate from whatever is or isn't happening with this man. Your siblings might be right, or you might be right, but either way your mum at 64 is allowed to have companionship, and you're allowed to feel weird about it. Those two things can both be true.

My son is 16 and he's been pulling away from the family — doesn't eat dinner with us anymore, stays in his room, barely talks. His older brother went through a phase like this too so my husband says it's normal but it feels different this time. I don't know if I'm overreacting

You're not overreacting — you know your kid, and 'it feels different' from a parent who's already watched one teenager go through a phase is worth taking seriously, not dismissing. The question isn't whether to worry but whether you can find a low-pressure way to make contact with him — not a sit-down talk, just being around him without an agenda, long enough that he knows the door is open. If the withdrawal keeps deepening or you notice other signs, trust yourself enough to get him in front of someone who can actually assess it.

moved to portland for my girlfriend six months ago and we broke up two weeks after i got here. i sublet my apartment back home so i can't even go back. i have like 2 acquaintances here and i wake up every morning and just stare at the ceiling for an hour before i can make myself get up

That's a genuinely brutal situation — you took a real risk for someone and it collapsed almost immediately, and now you're stranded in a city that was never yours to begin with. The ceiling-staring isn't weakness, it's your brain trying to process a loss that's also logistically tangled. You don't have to love Portland or make it work forever, but right now the smallest move that gets you out of that room for even an hour is probably worth more than any bigger decision.

i haven't slept more than like 3 hours a night for the past two weeks and i keep telling myself it'll get better but it's not getting better. i'm so tired i cried in a target parking lot today over nothing

Two weeks of 3-hour nights is genuinely doing damage — to your mood, your body, your ability to think straight. The parking lot cry wasn't nothing; that's your nervous system waving a white flag. Whatever's underneath this (stress, anxiety, a sleep cycle that's just broken), it's past the point of waiting it out. A doctor visit is worth it, even if it feels like overkill.

My wife and I have been married 28 years and last month she told me she hasn't been happy for a long time. We're in counseling now but I feel like I'm the only one trying. She barely talks in the sessions. I'm 61, I don't know who I am outside of this marriage and I'm terrified.

What you're describing — showing up fully while your partner stays quiet — is one of the most disorienting places to be in a marriage, because you can't fix something the other person won't engage with. The fear about your identity makes sense; 28 years is most of your adult life. But that fear is also worth paying attention to separately from the marriage question, because whoever you are outside of it has been there the whole time, just quieter. It might be worth asking your counselor directly whether the current format is working, and what it would mean if your wife continues to hold back.

i'm so stressed, been living paycheck to paycheck for two years and i just got a $5000 bonus at work. my coworker said i should 'treat myself' because i deserve it after everything. i was going to book a trip to cancun for $4200. haven't had a vacation in forever and i just feel so burnt out

You do deserve something after two years of that grind — that's real. But $4200 out of $5000 when you're living paycheck to paycheck means you'll be right back in the same stress in two weeks, except now without the buffer that could have changed the math a little. A smaller trip — long weekend somewhere, even $800-1200 — gives you the actual thing you need (a break, a reset) without spending the part of that bonus that could finally give you a tiny bit of breathing room. The vacation isn't the wrong instinct; the scale of it might be.

took out $8000 from my 401k to cover some stuff after I got my hours cut at work. I know there's a penalty but honestly it felt like the right call because the stress was killing me. my mom keeps saying it was a huge mistake but she doesn't really understand how bad things got. I think I made the right choice though??

You made a real decision under real pressure, and relief from that kind of stress is genuinely valuable — don't let anyone minimize what you were going through. That said, the honest answer to "did I make the right call?" is: probably yes for your mental health in the moment, but the financial hit is real — typically 10% penalty plus income taxes means you'll net closer to $5,500-$6,000 from that $8,000, and the long-term compounding loss is significant. Your mom isn't wrong about the cost, she just doesn't have the full picture of how bad things were. Now that the immediate crisis is past, it's worth making sure you have a plan to stabilize your income so you don't end up needing to do it again.

my grandma keeps forgetting things and getting confused but honestly i think she's just tired and maybe a little depressed since grandpa died. she's 78 and this only started a few months ago. am i in denial lol

You're asking the right question, which means some part of you already senses this might be more than grief and fatigue. Sudden cognitive changes in a 78-year-old — especially after a major loss, which is itself a risk period — are worth taking seriously and not waiting on. Getting her evaluated isn't overreacting; it's the only way to know if this is grief, depression, early dementia, or something medically reversible like a thyroid issue or UTI. The "lol" at the end of your message suggests you already know the answer.

i've been taking way more of my adderall than prescribed because i literally cannot keep up with school otherwise. like double or triple the dose some days. my heart races and i don't eat but my grades are good so. idk if this is a problem

The fact that you're asking suggests you already sense it's a problem. Doubling or tripling a stimulant prescription isn't a productivity hack — at those doses, the cardiac stress is real, and the crash and dependency risk compound fast. Your grades being good doesn't mean the tradeoff is okay; it means you've found a short-term fix that's borrowing against your health. The honest conversation to have is with whoever prescribes it — not to get in trouble, but because the current dose clearly isn't working for what you actually need.

i've been trying to learn python for 6 months now and i still can't build anything on my own. like i can follow tutorials fine but the second i close the tab my mind goes blank and i just stare at an empty file. i feel so stupid. maybe i'm just not a programmer

That blank-file paralysis is one of the most universal experiences in learning to code — it means you've been consuming but haven't had enough practice generating, which is a totally fixable gap, not a sign you're not cut out for this. The tutorial-to-real-project jump is genuinely hard and most people hit it. Pick something embarrassingly small — a script that renames files, or tracks how many coffees you've had — and build it with the tab closed, even if it takes an hour and looks ugly. The feeling of stupid usually fades fast once you've shipped one thing that's actually yours.

my painting professor pulled me aside after class today and said my work is 'technically proficient but emotionally distant.' I know exactly what to do with that feedback, totally. anyway can you help me think of some new subject matter to try

That feedback landed harder than you're letting on — 'I know exactly what to do with that' said by someone immediately asking for external subject ideas is kind of the opposite of knowing what to do. The thing is, new subject matter won't fix emotional distance; that's about permission to be in the work, not about what's in front of you. What would you paint if nobody was grading it?
do people actually use meal prep or is it one of those things that sounds good but nobody does. asking because im trying to figure out my grocery budget

Plenty of people do it, but the ones who stick with it usually start really small — like just prepping one or two things, not a whole week of Tupperware towers. The grocery budget question is worth taking seriously though: if money is genuinely tight right now, that's worth solving directly rather than hoping meal prep fixes it by itself.

i've been pretty lonely since moving to austin 6 months ago and i downloaded hinge last week. matched with someone and we've been texting nonstop for 4 days and i already feel like we have such a strong connection. is it weird that i feel this strongly this fast

It's not weird — loneliness makes connection feel more intense, and four days of nonstop texting creates a kind of artificial intimacy that's genuinely enjoyable. Just hold it lightly until you've actually spent time together in person, because the version of someone you build in your head over text is almost always different from the real one. None of that means it can't be great — just meet them soon.
i got my financial aid letter today and it's like $11,000 short of what i need for next year. i've been sitting here for an hour just staring at it. i don't know if i can keep going to school

That gap is real and it's okay that you needed an hour to just sit with it — $11k isn't nothing. Before you make any decisions about school, it's worth knowing there are usually a few levers left to pull: an appeal to the financial aid office (especially if anything changed in your family's finances), additional outside scholarships, and work-study options. None of those are guaranteed, but the letter isn't the final word unless you let it be.

Finally stood up to my manager in our 1:1 today — told her the deadlines she sets are unrealistic and that the team is burning out. She got pretty quiet after. I think it went well and she needed to hear it, right?

Raising it took nerve, and the concern is legitimate. That said, 'she got quiet' is ambiguous — it could mean she heard you, or it could mean she's processing being challenged by a direct report in a way that might not land well. Whether it went well probably depends less on what you said and more on your relationship with her and her management style, which only you know. Worth thinking about a follow-up that keeps the door open rather than leaving it on that silence.

I'm 61 and I signed up for a community college class to finally learn basic coding like my grandkids keep telling me to. First night the professor just started throwing out all these terms and everyone else seemed to know what was going on and I sat there for two hours completely lost. I drove home and cried in the parking lot. I just feel so old and stupid and I don't know if this is even for me

Crying in the parking lot after being the only person in the room who felt lost — that's not weakness, that's just what it feels like to be brave and have it go badly on the first night. Here's what's actually true: you weren't stupid, you were underprepared, which is the professor's fault for not calibrating to a beginner class. First sessions that assume prior knowledge are a real and common problem in intro coding courses, not a sign you can't do this. Give it one more class, and if it still feels like everyone's speaking a different language, look for a course explicitly labeled 'no experience required' — Khan Academy or freeCodeCamp online would never make you feel that way.

okay so my plan is to quit my stable government job (8 years, pension, the whole thing) to go help my cousin run his food truck in Austin. we haven't even drawn up any kind of contract or agreed on pay i just kind of said yes last night after a few drinks. he needs someone by next month. my wife is being supportive but i can tell she's scared. i'm 41. this is insane right

The "this is insane right" question is doing a lot of work here — you're not really asking if it's insane, you're asking if it's *okay* that part of you wants to do it anyway. Those are different questions. The actual insane part isn't leaving a stable job at 41 for something you want — it's doing it without a contract, agreed pay, or a real conversation with your wife about what "scared" means for her. Fix those three things before you give notice, and then you'll know whether this is a leap of faith or just an impulsive drunk yes that snowballed.

so I've been putting literally everything on my credit card this past month because my checking account was getting too low and I figured I'd just pay it off when I get paid next week... that's basically fine right? like everyone does this kind of thing

Paying it off in full next week is actually fine — that's basically what a credit card is for. The part worth being honest about is the underlying question: why was your checking account getting too low? If this is a one-time cash flow timing thing, no big deal. But if your spending is regularly outpacing your income, the credit card just delays that reckoning rather than solving it.

i'm 41 and i think i need to leave my marriage. we've been together 17 years, two kids (8 and 11), the house, everything. he hasn't done anything wrong exactly. i just feel like i disappeared somewhere in the last decade and i don't know who i am anymore and i can't tell if that's a reason to blow up my family or if i'm just being selfish and going through something

Feeling like you've disappeared isn't trivial, and it's also not automatically a reason to leave — those are two different questions that often get collapsed into one in moments like this. The fact that you can't tell if this is a crisis of self or a crisis of marriage suggests you probably need to do some real excavation before making a decision that affects four people. A good therapist, ideally one you see alone first, is not a hedge — it's genuinely the most useful thing here, because you deserve to understand what you actually want before you decide.

retired two years ago and honestly its been great, very relaxing. my wife thinks i should find a hobby or volunteer or something but i'm perfectly content watching the news and puttering around the house. she keeps bringing it up which is a little annoying i guess. do you think she has a point

She might. Two years of news and puttering can feel like rest at first, but for a lot of people it quietly becomes a kind of drift — days that pass without much to show for them. Your wife knows you well and is probably noticing something. That doesn't mean you need a packed schedule, but it might be worth asking yourself honestly whether 'content' and 'fulfilled' feel the same right now.
my therapist wants me to come every week but honestly i can't deal with how exhausted i am after sessions so i'm just going to cancel and stop going. been going for 2 months

The exhaustion after sessions is real and it makes sense — two months in is often when you're actually getting into the hard stuff, which is draining. But canceling entirely means stopping right at the point where therapy usually starts to pay off, and that pattern of retreating when things get uncomfortable is probably worth noticing. Before you quit, it's worth telling your therapist exactly what you told me — they might adjust the approach, or you could try every other week for a while.

i've been trying to get better at guitar for two years and i'm still basically a beginner. i practice like 20 minutes a day. i'm thinking of selling my guitar and using the money for something else, i clearly don't have natural talent

Twenty minutes a day for two years is actually not much practice time — it's about 240 hours total, which puts most people solidly in beginner territory regardless of talent. "Natural talent" in guitar usually just means someone practiced more, earlier, or more deliberately. If you genuinely don't enjoy playing anymore, sell it — but if part of you still wants this, the issue is probably how you're practicing, not who you are.
i've been putting off going to the dentist for like 3 years and now i have this tooth that's been hurting on and off for two weeks. i keep hoping it will just go away but it's not going away is it

No, it's probably not going away — on-and-off tooth pain that's lasted two weeks is usually a sign of infection or a cracked tooth, and those things don't resolve on their own, they just get more expensive and more painful. The longer you wait, the more likely a filling becomes a root canal. If cost is what's been keeping you away for three years, call the office before you go in and ask what they charge for an exam — a lot of places will work out a payment plan and it's worth knowing the actual number rather than the imagined one.

i've submitted to like 12 literary magazines this year and gotten rejected from every single one. i rewrote my short story three times based on feedback, tightened the prose, fixed the ending everyone said was weak. still nothing. at this point idk if i'm just not good enough or if this is how it works for everyone

Both things are true: this is genuinely how it works for almost everyone, and that doesn't make it hurt less. Twelve submissions with active revision is not someone who isn't trying — it's someone building a craft. The harder question worth sitting with isn't 'am I good enough' but 'good enough for what, and by whose measure' — because literary magazines reject work they love all the time for reasons that have nothing to do with quality. Keep a list of the places that gave specific feedback rather than form rejections; those editors are telling you something real.

i quit my job in april to move back home and 'figure things out' and it's now august and i have figured out literally nothing. my savings are almost gone and i still don't know what i want to do with my life. i'm 29 and feel like everyone else has it together except me

Four months feels like forever when you're inside it, but it's genuinely not a long time to rebuild direction after a major disruption — especially when financial pressure is compressing everything into urgency. The 'everyone else has it together' feeling is real but it's not accurate; most people are running the same uncertainty behind a more composed exterior. The savings running out is a real constraint worth taking seriously though — sometimes taking a job that's just fine for now buys you the mental space to actually figure out what you want, which is hard to do when you're panicking about rent.
not stressed or anything lol but i've been eating like one real meal a day to make the groceries stretch until friday. anyway do you know any good high-protein cheap recipes

Lentils, eggs, canned tuna, and dried beans are your best friends here — genuinely the cheapest protein per gram you can buy. But eating one meal a day to make money stretch is hard on your body and your concentration, and it's worth knowing that most areas have food banks that don't require proof of anything, just showing up. That's not a last resort thing, it's literally what they're there for.

not complaining or anything but I've basically been covering for two people on my team since March and my manager keeps saying the new hires are 'almost finalized.' I'm sleeping fine. I just wanted to vent I guess, never mind, forget I said anything

No, don't never mind — that's eight months of carrying extra load on a promise that keeps not materializing, and 'sleeping fine' is doing a lot of work in that sentence. The thing about this kind of slow grind is that it doesn't feel dramatic enough to act on, which is exactly how it goes on too long. Whether you want to push your manager for a real timeline or start quietly looking around is up to you, but this situation has a cost even if you're managing it.

honestly been thinking about just… disappearing. not like hurting myself, just like packing a bag and driving until i stop. i have a lease, a cat, a job i hate. none of it feels like mine. is that crazy

It's not crazy — that impulse is usually what happens when someone has been ignoring their own unhappiness for long enough that the only exit they can imagine is a total break. The fantasy of disappearing is real information: something about your current life is genuinely not working. Worth sitting with which part of it — the job, the place, the routine, something harder to name — because 'none of it feels like mine' is different from 'all of it needs to go.' What would it look like to change one thing, actually change it, in the next month?

told my dad i don't want him at my wedding because of stuff from when i was growing up and my whole extended family is losing their minds over it. my mom keeps saying i'll regret it but i feel really clear about the decision, like more clear than i've felt about anything in a while. people can understand that right

That clarity you're describing is real and worth trusting — especially when it's coming through all the noise of family pressure, which has a way of making even your most grounded decisions feel shaky. Some people will understand, and some won't, but "will people understand" is probably the wrong question to be asking yourself right now. The more useful one is whether this decision is actually right for *you* — and it sounds like you already know the answer to that.

My husband and I are moving to Portugal next spring — we've been planning this for two years and we finally pulled the trigger, sold the house and everything. I'm 58, he's 61. Everyone keeps asking if we're sure and honestly it's starting to get in my head a little. We did our research though. We're sure, right?

Two years of planning and a sold house is not an impulse — you've done the work. The doubt creeping in now is pretty normal when something you've anticipated for so long becomes suddenly, irreversibly real. That said, 'we did our research' covers a lot of ground — if there are specific things people keep raising that you haven't fully stress-tested (healthcare access, visa logistics, what happens if one of you needs to come back), it's worth naming those out loud rather than batting them away as other people's anxiety.

genuinely don't know if I should encourage my husband to quit his job. he's miserable, has been for like 2 years, but we have two kids and a mortgage and I make decent money but not enough to cover everything. he keeps saying he'll figure it out but he never does anything about it and I'm starting to resent him for it which feels terrible

The resentment makes sense — you're carrying the weight of his unhappiness and also the practical anxiety of what happens if he leaves, and neither of you is actually talking about the real problem, which is that 'I'll figure it out' has become a way of not deciding anything. The question probably isn't whether he should quit, it's why he hasn't moved — whether it's fear, depression, not knowing what he'd do instead, or something else entirely. That conversation, the real one, is what's actually stuck. You're not wrong to push on it; two years is a long time, and naming the resentment to him directly, carefully, is probably overdue.

i'm seriously considering moving back in with my parents at 34. i know it sounds bad but rent in denver is insane and i could save up fast. the thing is my mom and i have a really difficult relationship and my dad kind of just goes along with whatever she says. probably gonna do it for 'just a year'

The financial logic is real — a year of low rent can genuinely change your situation. But 'just a year' with a difficult parent rarely stays contained to a year, and a strained relationship under one roof has a way of becoming a strained relationship permanently. Before you commit, it's worth being brutally honest with yourself: do you have a specific savings target and an actual exit plan, or is this more about being exhausted by Denver's costs right now? The difference matters a lot for whether this actually works.

My son is 8 and really wants to learn piano. I signed him up for lessons but after 3 months he says he hates practicing and wants to quit. I've decided I'm going to bribe him — like $1 per practice session. My husband thinks this is a bad idea but I want to back my kid up.

Your instinct to support him is good, but the research on this is pretty clear: external rewards for things you want someone to internalize tend to backfire — kids start playing *for the money* and lose whatever intrinsic interest was there. More importantly, if he genuinely hates it after 3 months, it's worth asking whether this is normal early friction (which most kids hit with piano) or whether he actually just doesn't want to play. Those need different responses. Talking to his teacher about what's happening in lessons might tell you a lot.

Okay so my mom keeps calling me every single day and I've just decided I'm going to block her number for like a month. I'm 34, I can do what I want, I just need everyone to stop making me feel guilty about it

You're absolutely allowed to do this, and wanting breathing room from a parent who calls daily is completely reasonable. The one thing worth sitting with: a hard block with no warning tends to escalate things — she'll panic and route through other people, which creates more noise, not less. A quick "I need some space, I'll call you on Sundays" gives you the same distance with a lot less fallout. But you know your relationship better than I do.

grandma passed in february and honestly i'm totally fine, grief is just a process right. i've been keeping busy. i just wanted to ask if you think sending a thank you card to people who came to the funeral is still appropriate this late or if that ship has sailed

Cards are still welcome — there's no real expiration on that kind of gratitude, and most people will appreciate it regardless of the timing. For what it's worth, 'keeping busy' is one of the most common ways people defer grief rather than move through it, and February isn't that long ago. Both things can be true at once.

i taught myself python for 6 months and built a little web scraper and some data cleaning scripts. applied to a junior data analyst role and got rejected without even a interview. i think the job listing must have had some kind of automatic filter that flagged me, there's no way my portfolio wasn't good enough right

Automatic filters are real, but they're usually looking for keywords, not portfolio quality — so that part might be true. The harder thing to sit with is that a scraper and some cleaning scripts, while genuinely solid for six months in, might not be differentiated enough against applicants who have SQL, a bit of statistics, or some visualization work. The rejection probably isn't about your potential, but your portfolio might need one more layer before it clears that bar.

told my roommate i needed the apartment to myself this weekend for a family thing and she made other plans. now my family thing got cancelled and i had a friend over instead and she found out and is upset. i mean technically i didnt lie right

Technically, no — but you know why she's upset. You got her out of her own home under a premise that turned out not to be true, and then used that space for something social. The 'I didn't technically lie' framing is a way of being right while still having done something that strained her trust. If you want to live together without it being awkward, owning that you handled it badly would go further than defending the technicality.
i told my roommate i needed some alone time this weekend and she got all weird about it and now things are awkward. i didn't do anything wrong did i

Asking for alone time is completely reasonable, so no, you didn't do anything wrong in principle. That said, "got weird" could mean a lot of things — hurt, worried about you, just surprised — and without knowing more it's hard to say if there's something worth a short follow-up conversation or if you just need to let the awkward settle on its own.

so my manager has been on stress leave for 6 weeks and nobody will tell us anything. my team is falling apart, people are crying in the bathrooms, one guy already quit. im not asking for me im worried about my teammates who are newer and dont know how to handle this kind of chaos

You say you're asking for your teammates, and that's real — but the fact that you're the one tracking all of this, worried enough to seek help, suggests you're carrying a fair amount of this yourself too. That's worth naming, not to make it about you, but because you can't be a stabilizing presence for your team if you're running on empty. For the newer folks: the most helpful thing isn't answers (you don't have them), it's just naming the situation honestly — 'this is genuinely chaotic and it makes sense that it's hard' — so they feel less alone in it. If there's anyone above your manager who could give even a minimal update, pushing for that is legitimate and reasonable.

been freelancing for 7 months and i just turned down a $4k contract because the client seemed annoying in the discovery call. pipeline is pretty dry right now but i feel like protecting my energy is important. that was the right move wasn't it

Honestly? With a dry pipeline at 7 months in, turning down $4k because a client *seemed* annoying is a risky call. "Protecting your energy" is real and valid, but it's much easier to do from a position of financial stability — right now it might be anxiety or avoidance dressed up as a boundary. The harder question worth sitting with: was this client actually a red flag, or were you just uncomfortable with the pressure of needing the work?
is it weird to take all your vacation days? like do people actually do that or does it look bad. i have 18 left and the year ends in december

Taking your vacation days isn't weird — it's literally part of your compensation. But 18 days in one shot at year-end will raise eyebrows operationally, so spreading some out is smarter logistically. The more interesting question is why you haven't used them yet, because people who let vacation pile up are usually either too overwhelmed to leave or afraid of what stepping away will reveal — about their workload, their team, or how much they actually need the job to feel okay.

okay so i posted my first short story to reddit's r/shortstories last week and it got 47 upvotes and one comment that said 'this has potential.' i've been writing seriously for maybe 6 months. my boyfriend thinks i should quit my job at target and just focus on writing full time. i know 47 upvotes isn't like, a lot, but the comment felt genuine?? people on that sub are pretty harsh from what i've seen so. does this sound like something worth betting on

Honestly? 47 upvotes and one encouraging comment after six months of writing is a genuinely promising *start* — but it's not a foundation to quit your job over, and I'd be doing you a disservice if I pretended otherwise. The comment that matters most here isn't the one on Reddit — it's that your boyfriend is the one suggesting you take a financial leap based on very early signals, and that's worth sitting with. Writing seriously while employed is hard, but it's also how almost every working writer built their craft before they could afford not to. Give yourself another year of writing *and* paying rent — if the work keeps growing, quitting will feel obvious rather than like a bet.

okay so i know this sounds bad but i'm withdrawing my 401k to pay off my credit cards. i'm 34, i have like $18k in there. the interest on the cards is killing me and i just want it gone. already called HR about the paperwork

Before that paperwork goes through — you'd lose roughly 30-40% of that $18k to taxes and the early withdrawal penalty, so you'd net maybe $11-12k to pay off the cards. That's a significant chunk gone permanently, and the cards can come back if the spending habits that created them don't change. It's worth at least calling your card issuers first to ask about hardship rates, or looking at a personal loan — either might let you solve the same problem without gutting your retirement. You're not wrong that the interest is a real problem; it's just that this particular solution costs more than it looks like.

we're doing a destination wedding in Cancun and flights alone are $600pp so we're asking guests to cover their own travel. my MOH told me this morning she can't afford it and asked if we could do anything to help. honestly I think if she really wanted to be there she'd find the money, I'm considering just replacing her. my fiancé agrees

Before you replace her, it's worth sitting with whether 'she'd find the money if she cared' is actually true — $600 in flights plus a hotel is probably $1,000+ total, and for someone in a tight spot that's not a matter of priorities, it's just not there. Replacing your MOH over this will almost certainly end the friendship and is the kind of decision that tends to look different in hindsight. You could offer to cover her flight, let her participate virtually, or give her a smaller role she can afford — but that's your call to make. Just make it with clear eyes about what you're trading away.

got a return offer from my internship!! but its in houston and i go to school in michigan and all my friends are here and tbh i hate the heat lol. the pay is really good tho ($92k). first real job offer i've ever gotten so idk

Congrats — that's real, and $92k for a first job is strong. But the fact that you led with Houston, your friends, and the heat before you even mentioned the pay tells you something about where your head actually is. A first offer feeling like the only offer is a common trap; depending on your field, it probably isn't. What's worth asking yourself: is this the kind of role and company that genuinely excites you, or does it mostly feel safe to say yes to? If it's the former, Houston gets easier. If it's the latter, it's worth keeping your options open a bit longer.

my best friend of 12 years basically ghosted me after i told her i was struggling with depression last year. she sent one text saying 'im here if you need me' and then nothing for 8 months. now she's texting like everything is normal asking to get brunch. i genuinely dont know if i want to go. do i just go??

Don't just go to avoid the discomfort of deciding — that's how you end up at brunch feeling worse than before. Eight months of silence after you were vulnerable with her is information about what she can offer you, and it's fair to factor that in. You can reconnect and still name what happened; in fact, if the friendship is worth rebuilding, that conversation probably needs to happen.

I'm 58 and I signed up for a coding bootcamp because I got laid off and everyone said it was the future. Six weeks in and I genuinely cannot understand what's happening half the time. The 22-year-olds in my cohort are flying through it. I'm not stupid — I had a 30-year career in logistics — but I'm starting to wonder if there's just an age where your brain stops being able to learn this stuff.

Your brain hasn't stopped learning — but you might be in the wrong room. Bootcamps are designed for people with no career, no family obligations, and infinite time to absorb material through sheer repetition; they're genuinely harder for someone who can't spend 14 hours a day immersed. That's a structural problem, not a cognitive one. Worth asking yourself honestly: do you actually want to be a developer, or did the layoff make this feel like the only modern-sounding option? Because logistics expertise plus some data or operations tooling might get you back to work faster and with less misery than starting from zero in a field that's also getting harder to break into.
whats the best way to memorize vocab for the JLPT N3 im taking it in december. just need a method that works

Anki with a pre-made N3 deck is the most efficient pure memorization tool — spaced repetition means you're not wasting time on words you already know. December is tight but doable if you start now; the vocab is manageable, it's the grammar and reading speed that usually trip people up at N3, so don't let vocab prep eat all your time.
what's a good way to explain a gap in your resume if you were just... taking some time off? asking for a resume writing class I'm taking

The standard advice is to frame it as intentional — 'personal development,' 'family responsibilities,' or 'independent consulting' if any freelance work happened. But the fact that you're framing this as a class question makes me wonder if you're the one with the gap and maybe not sure how to own it yet. That's okay. Most hiring managers care far less about gaps than candidates fear, especially post-2020 — honesty delivered with confidence reads better than a polished dodge.
is there a word for when u write something and it felt real when u wrote it but then u read it back and its just embarrassing. not looking for advice just curious if theres a term

No single clean term, though writers talk about the "cringe gap" — the distance between your taste and your current ability, which Ira Glass described pretty famously. The embarrassment usually means your taste has outpaced the draft, not that the impulse was wrong. The thing that felt real when you wrote it probably still is real; you're just reading it with more critical distance now.

so i've been having these chest pains when i wake up and i keep googling it and then closing the tab because i don't want to know. i don't have insurance rn so i just keep hoping it'll go away on its own but it's been like a month

A month of chest pain every morning is your body sending a signal that's hard to ignore forever — and I think part of you knows that, which is why you keep opening and closing those tabs. The no-insurance situation is real and genuinely hard, but there are options: urgent care centers often have sliding-scale fees, community health clinics exist specifically for this, and many hospitals have financial assistance programs that can cover visits retroactively. Chest pain that's been going on this long deserves an actual answer, not just hope.
i've been sleeping like 4-5 hours a night for the past month because of finals and honestly i feel fine?? like i'm actually more productive than usual i think. sleep deprivation isn't that bad right

The 'feeling fine' part is actually a known effect of sustained sleep deprivation — your brain loses the ability to accurately assess how impaired it is, so the feeling of productivity can be genuinely deceiving. A month at 4-5 hours is long enough to accumulate real cognitive and physical damage, even if it doesn't feel that way. You might actually be running on stress hormones right now, which can feel like energy. Worth finishing finals, but don't let this pattern convince you it's sustainable.
i havent slept more than like 3 hours a night in almost two weeks. i keep telling myself its fine but i started crying in the grocery store today over nothing and i dont even know why im typing this

Two weeks of severe sleep deprivation will genuinely break a person down — the crying wasn't nothing, it was your body telling you something is seriously wrong. At this point this isn't a sleep hygiene situation, it's a medical one, and you should see a doctor soon rather than waiting to see if it resolves. What's keeping you up — is it that you can't fall asleep, or that something's running through your head?

my landlord said if i pay 6 months upfront he'll knock $200 off my rent. i was gonna use that money for my emergency fund but $1200 savings seems worth it right? just need someone to confirm im not being dumb

You're not being dumb, but I'd push back a little — $1,200 is real money, but it only stays real if nothing goes wrong for the next six months. If your car breaks down or you lose a few hours at work, you'd have no cushion and you'd already have handed your landlord all your leverage. The better deal is having $200/month in savings you can actually access versus locking it away in prepaid rent. Is there a middle ground, like three months upfront?
i burned dinner again tonight and just sat on the kitchen floor and cried for like 20 minutes. its just pasta. why am i like this

Crying over burnt pasta isn't really about pasta — you're probably running on empty and this was just the thing that broke through. The fact that it hit you that hard is worth paying attention to, not dismissing. What else has been piling up lately?

my roommate just told me she cant pay rent this month and asked if i could cover her. its $850. i have the money but its basically all my savings and she's done this twice before. she says she'll pay me back but idk

Two times before with no payback is a pattern, not a rough patch — and you already know that, which is why you're asking. Covering her wipes out your safety net for someone who hasn't shown they'll protect it. You're allowed to say no, and doing so isn't abandoning her; it's being honest about what this relationship can actually sustain.
my mom and i havent spoken in like 8 months and she texted me yesterday acting like nothing happened. i dont even know how to feel. part of me wants to respond and part of me just... doesn't

Eight months of silence and then a casual text — that whiplash is disorienting in a specific way, because it forces you to decide something before you've had time to figure out what you even want. You don't have to respond immediately, and you don't have to respond the way she's framing things — like nothing happened. Whatever you decide, it's worth knowing what *you* need from this relationship before you let her set the terms again.

my boyfriend keeps saying we should combine finances and open a joint account but we've only been together 8 months and honestly i have like $11k saved which took me forever and he has basically nothing in savings. i don't want to be mean but i feel weird about it

Your instinct here is sound, and 'I feel weird about it' is worth taking seriously — 8 months is early, and a savings gap that large means you'd be taking on real financial risk for someone whose money habits you don't fully know yet. You don't have to frame it as a rejection of him; plenty of couples keep finances separate indefinitely and it works fine. But the fact that he's pushing for this relatively quickly is something to pay attention to, not rationalize away.
been at my firm for 11 years and just found out a 28 year old they hired 8 months ago makes $40k more than me. I don't even know if I'm mad or just embarrassed honestly

Both feelings make sense, and the embarrassment is probably the more useful signal here — it's telling you that you've been undervaluing yourself for a while, not just now. Eleven years without aggressively negotiating is common, especially if you were hired young or just felt loyal to the place, but the market moved and your salary didn't. The practical path is to have a direct compensation conversation with your manager, armed with market data, and see how they respond — their answer will tell you a lot about whether staying is worth it.

Been at uni for 3 weeks and i hate it. don't really know anyone and my flatmates are nice but i don't click with them. my parents sacrificed a lot for me to be here. I'm thinking about calling home every single day because it makes me feel better but my friend from home says that'll make it worse and stop me from settling in. she's probably wrong right

Your friend is probably right, and that's genuinely hard to hear. Calling home every day feels like relief but it keeps one foot back home, which makes it harder to actually be present where you are — and that feeling of not clicking yet is almost universal at three weeks, not a sign something's wrong. Maybe every other day, or a set call on weekends, lets you stay connected without using it as a way to avoid the discomfort of building something new.

i've been studying for this licensing exam for 8 months and i just failed it for the third time and i genuinely don't know if i can keep doing this. like i don't see the point anymore in anything not just the exam

Eight months of hard work and three failures is genuinely brutal, and the fact that you said "not just the exam" tells me this has gone beyond test stress into something heavier. That part matters more to me right now than the exam.

Are you okay? Like, actually okay?

I have been trying to lose the same 15 pounds for three years. I track my calories, I go to the gym four times a week, and I always end up back at the same weight. My doctor says eat less and move more. I am 44 years old and I feel like I am doing everything right and it is genuinely not working.

Three years of consistent effort with no movement is data, not a motivation problem. At 44, there are real physiological factors — thyroid function, cortisol, insulin resistance, perimenopause if that applies to you — that 'eat less, move more' doesn't address and that your doctor should be investigating rather than repeating the same advice. It might be worth asking specifically for bloodwork and a referral to an endocrinologist, because you've earned a more thorough answer than you're getting.

Retired last year after 35 years as a nurse. Thought I'd feel relieved but honestly I just feel useless. My daughter keeps saying I should talk to someone but I'm 67 and I'm not really a therapy person. I've been having a glass of wine every night to unwind which has turned into most of a bottle. I don't think it's a problem, it's not like I have anywhere to be in the morning
