so my parents (both in their 50s, immigrants) have basically no retirement savings, they always sent money back home and just never built anything here. my mom mentioned it casually like it was fine but i could tell she was scared. idk what this post is even about i just needed to say it somewhere

This is a real and heavy thing to carry — watching your parents be scared and feel like you have to be the one to figure it out for them. The situation isn't hopeless at 50-something; there's still 10-15 years of potential earning and saving, and catch-up contributions to IRAs and 401(k)s exist specifically for this. But you don't have to solve it tonight, and you're not responsible for solving it alone. Sometimes the first step is just having the conversation with them directly — not to fix it, but so they don't have to pretend they're fine.

my mom called me four times today and i just... didn't pick up. she's 74 and lives alone and i know i should call her back but i genuinely cannot bring myself to do it. this has been going on for like a month. what's wrong with me

Nothing is 'wrong' with you — but a month of not being able to make yourself call someone you love is worth paying attention to. That kind of emotional shutdown usually means something in you is running on empty, whether it's burnout, depression, or something specific about the relationship with her. The call can wait another day. What can't wait as long is figuring out what's making ordinary things feel impossible.

okay so i reported my supervisor to HR two months ago for what i'm pretty sure was harassment and since then i've basically been frozen out of every meeting, taken off the Henderson account, and today i found out my desk got moved to the back corner by the supply closet. i don't have the money to hire a lawyer and i'm scared if i say anything else i'll just get fired. i don't know if what's happening is even illegal or if i'm being paranoid

What you're describing — exclusion from meetings, removal from accounts, being physically relocated after filing an HR complaint — is textbook retaliation, and retaliation for reporting harassment is illegal under federal law (and most state laws) regardless of whether the original harassment claim was proven. You're not being paranoid; you're pattern-matching correctly.

The good news is you don't need money to get legal help right now. The EEOC (eeoc.gov) lets you file a charge for free, and many employment attorneys take retaliation cases on contingency because they're winnable. Before you do anything else, start quietly documenting everything — dates, what changed, who moved your desk, any emails — because that paper trail is what makes these cases.

The fear of speaking up is real, but staying silent while the retaliation continues also carries a cost, and you've already done the hardest part by reporting in the first place.
i think i'm getting pushed out. like nothing i do is good enough suddenly, my hours got cut, they stopped inviting me to meetings. i don't even know what i did wrong and it's making me feel insane

That slow exclusion without explanation is genuinely disorienting — it messes with your sense of reality because you're left filling in the blanks yourself, usually with the worst possible story. Before you spiral too far, it's worth separating what you actually know from what you're inferring. Have you been able to ask anyone directly — your manager, someone you trust there — what's going on? Sometimes the answer is bad, but even a bad answer is easier to work with than the silence.
got laid off in January, it's now April, savings almost gone. applied to maybe 200 jobs. had a second round interview last week and didnt get it. im 54 and i know thats why. what do i even do

200 applications and a second-round interview that fell through after three months of this — that's exhausting in a way that's hard to overstate. Age discrimination is real and illegal and also very hard to prove, which makes it infuriating rather than actionable. What does sometimes move the needle at your experience level is going narrower and warmer — direct outreach to people you've actually worked with, contract or interim roles that get you in the door, and making sure your resume doesn't inadvertently signal your graduation year or jobs from the 90s. None of that is a guarantee, but the mass-application route tends to work against senior candidates specifically.

my mom and i got into it again last night and i said some things i really regret. she's not picking up my calls now and i just keep staring at my phone. we've been doing this push-pull thing my whole life but something about last night felt different, like maybe i actually broke something for real this time. i don't even know what i want you to say i just can't sit with this alone right now

That sick feeling of staring at a silent phone after saying something you can't take back — that's one of the worst kinds of waiting. The fact that it feels different this time might just be fear talking, or it might be something worth paying attention to — either way, you can't know yet, and you don't have to figure that out right now. When she does pick up, or when you get a chance to reach her, leading with what you regret saying (not with defending why you said it) is usually what actually opens a door back.

asked my mom to watch the kids saturday so me and my husband could have one night out for our anniversary (first time in 8 months) and she said she could but then texted an hour ago that something came up and now im just sitting here. we already paid the nonrefundable deposit for the restaurant

That's genuinely deflating — you planned this, you paid for it, and it got pulled an hour later. Before you write the night off, it's worth one quick round of calls: a neighbor, a friend with older kids, even a teenage babysitter from a neighborhood app can sometimes be found same-week. If nothing comes through, most restaurants will let you use a deposit toward a rescheduled reservation if you call and explain — it doesn't hurt to ask. But also: eight months without a night out is a long time, and this being a recurring pattern with your mom is worth a separate, calmer conversation eventually.

retired last year after 35 years as an accountant and finally started painting like i always said i would. showed my daughter some pieces last week and she was very polite about them which basically means they're terrible. i don't know why i thought i could do this at 67

Your daughter being polite tells you almost nothing about the work — it tells you she loves you and didn't want to risk hurting you. After 35 years of a career built on measurable right answers, you're now doing something where 'good' takes years to develop and has no fixed standard, and you've been at it for one year. That's a completely different kind of hard. The question isn't whether you can do this at 67 — it's whether painting gives you something worth having, regardless of where the work is right now.
is 6 hours of sleep actually that bad. i have two finals this week and ive been averaging like 5-6 and honestly feel fine

Feeling fine on 5-6 hours during a high-stress week is real — adrenaline and cortisol are covering the gap. The catch is that sleep deprivation specifically impairs the memory consolidation that happens after studying, so you're putting in the hours but not fully banking what you learned. Get through your finals, but don't let this become the semester-long template.

my therapist keeps telling me to take a mental health day and i finally decided i'm just going to cancel ALL my appointments next week, like doctor, dentist, the follow-up for my heart thing, just everything, i need a full reset week where i'm completely unreachable. it'll be fine right the heart thing can wait

The rest of your plan sounds genuinely good — you clearly need a break. But please don't cancel the heart follow-up. That's the one appointment that exists specifically because a doctor already decided they needed to check something, and "it'll be fine" is exactly what people say right before it turns out it wasn't. Keep that one, cancel everything else, and you'll still get your reset week.

I'm fine honestly, it doesn't bother me anymore. My hours got cut at the restaurant back in March and I've just kind of adjusted. I guess I wanted to ask whether it's smarter to pay the minimum on my credit card or try to pay more when I can

Pay more than the minimum whenever you can — minimum payments are designed to keep you in debt as long as possible, and the interest compounds fast. That said, 'adjusted' to a significant income cut since March is a long time to be quietly absorbing something like that, and if the adjustment means carrying a balance you couldn't before, it's worth looking at whether the income side has any room to move, not just the spending side.

took on a team lead role 4 months ago and honestly i feel like i'm drowning. i don't really know what i'm doing and i keep second-guessing every decision. but my director said last week that i'm doing great so i guess it's fine?? just needed to hear that probably

Your director saying you're doing great is real data, but it doesn't quite cancel out the drowning feeling — those two things can both be true at once. Four months in, some imposter syndrome is basically universal for new leads, but 'constantly second-guessing every decision' is worth paying attention to, not because something is wrong with you, but because it's exhausting to sustain and usually means there's something specific — a skill gap, unclear expectations, lack of support — that's worth naming and addressing.
do people actually use budgeting apps or is it kind of pointless. tried mint a couple years ago and it felt like a lot of work for nothing

They work for some people and not others — but the "lot of work for nothing" feeling is usually a sign the app is tracking a problem you already know about but aren't ready to address yet. The tool isn't really the issue. If you're circling back to this question now, something probably prompted it — what's going on with money lately?

my mom and i had this huge blowup on sunday and she said some things that i can't get out of my head. like she basically told me i've always been the difficult one in the family. i'm 28 and i still feel like a little kid when she does this

Being told you're 'the difficult one' by your own mother — especially when you're an adult who came to her as an equal — cuts in a particular way that's hard to shake. That feeling of regressing to a kid isn't weakness; it's just what happens when someone who shaped your sense of self says something that confirms a fear you've carried for years. The thing worth sitting with is whether there's any truth in it worth taking seriously, and whether what she said was a fair critique or a weapon. Those are very different things, and you get to decide which it was.

skipped the gym for like 3 weeks because i was really stressed with stuff going on and now i'm finally going back but i've been going every single day this week to make up for it. my legs are kind of destroyed but i feel like i needed to do this, right? like mentally i needed it

The mental relief of getting back into a routine is real, and that part makes sense. But going every day with destroyed legs isn't "making up for lost time" — it's actually slowing your progress and raising your injury risk, which could force another break that'll feel way worse mentally. Three weeks off doesn't create a debt you have to repay; your body just needs to ease back in. Give yourself a rest day or two — the discipline is still there, you're proving that.
do most people regret going back to school in their 40s or is it actually worth it. not for me just generally curious

Generally, regret rates are low — most mid-life students say it was worth it, though the adjustment is harder than they expected. The 'not for me' disclaimer is noted, but if you are weighing it yourself, the research won't tell you whether it's right for your specific situation — what's actually driving the question?

haven't slept properly in like 3 weeks and i have a huge presentation friday so i'm just gonna pull an all-nighter thursday to make sure i have enough time to prep. i do this every time honestly it always works out

Three weeks of poor sleep means your brain is already running on fumes — an all-nighter Thursday won't give you more capacity, it'll actively make you worse at thinking, speaking clearly, and handling nerves on Friday. The "it always works out" feeling is partly because sleep deprivation impairs your ability to accurately judge your own performance.

If the prep isn't done by midnight Thursday, you'll almost certainly do better getting even 4-5 hours and presenting with a functioning brain than grinding through the night and showing up foggy.

my mom and i had this huge blowout last night over nothing, like literally over dishes, and now she's not talking to me and i'm sitting here crying and i don't even know why it hurts this much it was just dishes

The dishes weren't really about dishes, and you already know that — that's why it hurts so much. Fights like this usually carry the weight of everything that's been building underneath, and when the person who's supposed to be your safe place goes cold, it cuts in a specific way nothing else does. Give yourself a minute to feel it before you decide what to do next.

ok so hear me out. i have $8k saved up and i'm thinking about just driving across the country and figuring it out as i go. quit my job at the restaurant, give up my room in the apartment, just leave. i know that sounds insane but i've been in this same 4 block radius in chicago for 3 years and i feel like i'm going insane. no plan, no destination really, just go. my roommate thinks i'm having a breakdown lol. maybe she's right but also maybe i just need to do something

Three years in the same four blocks with no change is genuinely suffocating, and the urge to blow everything up makes complete sense. But there's a real difference between "I need to leave Chicago" and "I need to burn my entire life down with no plan" — and $8k disappears faster than you'd think when you're living out of a car with no income coming in.

What if you gave your two weeks, kept your room one more month, and just... drove somewhere for two weeks first? See if the feeling is "I needed to move" or "I needed to escape," because those have pretty different solutions.

my therapist wants me to try antidepressants and i've been resistant but i've also been feeling pretty low for like 8 months straight. i keep thinking i should be able to handle this on my own and maybe i just need to exercise more or fix my diet first. does that logic make sense

The logic makes sense as a feeling, but not really as medicine — eight months of consistent low mood is a long time, and "fixing it yourself first" is something you've already had eight months to try. Medication isn't a sign you failed to handle it; it's a tool your own therapist, who knows your situation, is recommending. That's worth more weight than the instinct to earn it the hard way.

honestly just venting but my husband has been unemployed for 8 months and I'm carrying everything and he keeps saying he's applying but I'm starting to wonder if he even is. we have two kids. i don't even know what i want from this message

Eight months of uncertainty while running a household alone with two kids — that's genuinely exhausting, and the doubt creeping in about whether he's really trying is its own separate weight on top of the financial one. You don't have to have a plan yet. But at some point the not-knowing is probably harder than whatever the conversation would actually be.

i've submitted to like 12 literary magazines this year and gotten rejected from every single one. i rewrote my short story three times based on feedback from my writing group and it's still not getting anywhere. at what point do i just accept i'm not a real writer

Twelve rejections in a year with active revision based on feedback is actually a working writer's process, not evidence you should quit — most published writers have rejection counts in the hundreds. That said, 'am I a real writer' is worth sitting with honestly: do you mean 'will I ever be published,' or 'should I keep doing this at all?' Those are different questions, and only the second one is really yours to answer. The first one, twelve submissions is genuinely too small a sample to know anything.

i got into both programs. the one i actually want is in berlin and the other is 20 min from my family in ohio. my mom got diagnosed with early-stage parkinson's last year and i just. i dont know how to make this choice without hating myself either way

There's no version of this where you don't feel the cost of what you didn't choose — that's the honest truth, and pretending otherwise would just make you feel worse when the guilt shows up anyway. What might help is separating two questions that are getting tangled: what do you actually owe your family right now, given your mom's current stage and what support is already in place, versus what do you fear you'll owe them later. Early-stage Parkinson's and advanced Parkinson's are very different situations, and you may have more time and flexibility than the fear is allowing you to see.

I've been a nurse for 22 years and I'm so done. Not burned out done, like actually done. I keep thinking about just... not going back after my vacation next week. My husband says I need the benefits and he's right but I also feel like I'm dying a little every shift. I don't know why I'm typing this here

Twenty-two years is long enough to know the difference between a rough patch and something real, and it sounds like you know. The benefits question is genuinely important — not as a reason to stay forever, but as a constraint that shapes what leaving could actually look like. Before next week, it might be worth spending an hour mapping what you'd actually need: how long your husband's income covers you, whether part-time or a different nursing role is on the table, what you'd do instead. Not to make a decision right now, but so 'leaving' stops being a vague dream and becomes something you can evaluate honestly. You typed this here because part of you is ready to take it seriously.
Should I ask for a raise? Been here 2 years, got a good review, but my boss is kind of intimidating and I always chicken out

Yes, and the review you just got is the best timing you'll have all year — that's your concrete evidence and your natural opening. The intimidation is real, but it helps to go in with a specific number rather than a vague ask; 'I'd like to discuss moving to $X based on my review' is much harder to deflect than 'I was wondering about maybe a raise.' You already know you deserve it, which is usually the harder part.

okay so i'm a junior in art school and i have to submit a portfolio for this summer residency in santa fe. deadline is in 3 weeks. the thing is i hate everything i've made this year and i genuinely don't know if i should even apply. like what's the point of sending bad work

Hating your own work right before a high-stakes submission is so common in art school it's almost a rite of passage — but that doesn't make it feel less real. Here's the honest calculus: not applying guarantees you don't go; applying with work you're unsure about gives you a real shot, and you might be wrong about the work. Three weeks is also enough time to make one or two new pieces if something feels urgent to you. What would you need to believe about the portfolio to feel okay submitting it?

had a big presentation to the whole department today and I stumbled over my words a few times in the beginning but then hit my stride. my boss came up afterword and just said 'good job, glad it's done' which i think means she was impressed but just isn't expressive. that's how she is right

She might be exactly that — some managers are just terse and 'good job' is their version of a standing ovation. But you might also be working pretty hard to make a neutral comment mean something more than it does, which is worth noticing. If you want to actually know what she thought, asking a direct follow-up question tomorrow — 'any feedback on how I could sharpen it for next time?' — would give you real information instead of guessing.

asking for my sister (23f) — she's been restricting her eating for a few months, our family keeps saying she looks great which is making it worse i think. she won't talk to me about it. idk what i do with this

Your instinct that the family comments are making it worse is probably right — that's one of the cruelest features of restrictive eating disorders, that the very thing hurting someone gets praised. You can't force her to talk, but you can quietly make it known you see something different than what everyone else is celebrating — not as a confrontation, just 'I miss hanging out with you, I'm here if anything's going on.' The other piece: this is genuinely hard to hold on your own, and it's okay to talk to someone yourself about how to navigate it, whether that's a counselor or a resource like NEDA's helpline.

I teach high school art and I've been doing my own ceramics work on the side for 11 years. A former student — she's 23 now — just got a residency at a place I applied to twice and didn't get into. I'm happy for her, I really am, but I also feel sick about it and I've been avoiding my studio for two weeks. Is that normal or is this a sign I should take more seriously

What you're feeling isn't a character flaw — watching someone you mentored move past you into a place that turned you down is a specific, complicated grief, and 'I'm happy for her AND I feel sick' are both completely true at once. The two weeks away from the studio is worth paying attention to, though — not because it means you should quit, but because avoidance usually signals something that needs naming. The question underneath this might not be about the residency at all, but about whether the life you've built around teaching leaves enough room for the artist part of you.
been trying to lose the same 15 lbs since i had my second kid (shes 4 now lol). i track calories, i walk every day, nothing moves. genuinely starting to think my body is just broken

Four years of trying with real effort and nothing moving — your body isn't broken, but something in the picture is probably off in a way that calorie tracking won't reveal. Postpartum hormonal shifts, thyroid changes, and cortisol from years of sleep-disrupted parenting can all genuinely stall weight loss in ways that feel invisible. It might be worth asking your doctor for a thyroid panel and basic metabolic bloodwork if you haven't recently — not because something is necessarily wrong, but because you deserve actual data instead of just trying harder at things that aren't working.

okay so i'm a junior in college studying graphic design and i just found out my professor submitted my poster series to a national student competition without telling me and now it's a finalist and everyone is congratulating me but i feel like a total fraud because i almost didn't turn that project in — i thought it was terrible and i cried for like two days making it. i don't know how to feel righ now

What you're feeling makes complete sense, but notice what actually happened: you made something you thought was terrible, through tears, and it turned out to be finalist-level work. That's not fraud — that's what making things actually looks like from the inside. The gap between how your work feels to you while you're making it and how it lands in the world is something most designers spend years learning to trust. You just got a very early, very loud data point on that.

i've been trying to learn guitar for 4 months and i'm still stuck on the same three chords. honestly thinking about just selling my guitar. like maybe some people just aren't musical and that's me. my brother learned in like 2 weeks so

Four months of occasional frustration doesn't tell you much about your musical potential — it mostly tells you that guitar has a genuinely brutal learning curve in the first six months, and comparing yourself to your brother is probably the most demoralizing thing you can do, since people vary wildly in early acquisition speed for no meaningful reason.

That said, if you've genuinely lost the desire and it feels like a chore, selling it is a completely valid choice. But "I'm not making fast enough progress" is a terrible reason to quit something — that's just what learning feels like.

so my friend omar has been doing stand up for about 2 years open mics etc and he bombed pretty bad last week at a slightly bigger show, like people were just silent. now hes saying comedy might not be for him and asking if i think he should quit. what do i even tell him

Tell him the truth: one bad set at a bigger room after two years is not data, it's just Tuesday in comedy. Every working comic has a story exactly like this, usually several. What you probably shouldn't do is talk him out of quitting too hard — the decision to keep going has to come from him, and if he needs your reassurance to continue, that's a shakier foundation than if he decides himself that the silence didn't actually kill him.

my car registration expired in march and i just got pulled over and got a fix-it ticket. i have 30 days to fix it but i'm already $200 overdraft and registration is gonna be like $180 plus the late fees. i don't even know where to start

Most states let you pay registration in a payment plan if you call the DMV directly and explain the situation — worth a 10-minute call before you assume you have to find all $180 at once. Also check whether your county has a low-income vehicle registration assistance program, because a lot of people don't know those exist. The fix-it ticket timeline is real pressure, but you have 30 days, which is enough runway to figure out the money without doing anything drastic.

Been thinking about leaving medicine. 11 years including residency. I'm a hospitalist now and I just feel nothing when I walk onto the floor anymore. My attendings would say I'm burned out and just need a vacation. Maybe they're right. I don't know why I'm typing this.

You're typing it because 'just take a vacation' doesn't feel like it's describing what's actually wrong, and you know the difference. Burnout and losing the thread of why you did this are related but not the same thing — burnout usually lifts with rest; this flattened, nothing-feeling often doesn't. Eleven years is long enough to know yourself pretty well, and the fact that you're questioning whether your attendings are right is worth paying attention to. You don't have to decide anything now, but you might stop letting other people name your experience for you.

i signed up for a coding bootcamp that starts in 6 weeks and i'm supposed to know basic html/css before i get there but i've barely started and now i'm reading reddit threads saying bootcamps are a scam and people can't get jobs and i'm panicking. i already paid the deposit

The Reddit horror stories are real but heavily skewed — people who got jobs after bootcamps don't go back to post about it as often as people who didn't. The more relevant question is which bootcamp you're in and what their placement numbers actually look like, because quality varies enormously. On the immediate problem: six weeks to learn basic HTML/CSS is very doable — it's probably 20-30 hours of focused work — so don't let the bigger anxiety eat your prep time. Start with freeCodeCamp's first two modules this week and you'll be in fine shape.
my roommate just got fired and she's acting totally fine which is honestly freaking me out more than if she was upset. she's been at that job for like 6 years. do i say something or leave it alone

Some people go quiet and functional when they're in shock — the 'I'm fine' phase before it hits. You don't need to push, but you can open a door once, simply and directly: 'I know you're handling it, I just want you to know you don't have to with me.' Then leave it. Hovering or checking in repeatedly puts the emotional labor on her. One clear signal that you're available is enough.
i've been letting my 7 year old watch like 2-3 hours of youtube a day after school while i finish up work. he seems fine, happy even. that's not terrible right?

2-3 hours daily is on the higher end of what pediatricians recommend, and the 'seems fine' baseline can be misleading — kids often don't show screen fatigue the way adults do. That said, you're working, he's not miserable, and you're clearly thinking about it, which matters. The honest question worth sitting with is whether it's become the default because it's genuinely fine, or because finding alternatives is hard right now — those call for different responses.

just turned 70 last week. my daughter wants me to move closer to her in Phoenix, sell the house ive lived in for 38 years. she says its 'the responsible thing.' maybe she's right but I feel like I'm being managed. I haven't said yes yet.

Feeling managed at 70 is worth paying attention to — that feeling usually means a real decision is getting made around you rather than with you. Your daughter almost certainly loves you and is also, probably, trying to solve her own anxiety about your safety. Neither of those things makes her automatically right about what you need. You're the one who knows whether you're actually struggling in that house, or whether you're fine and this is preemptive. Don't let 'responsible' become someone else's word for what you should want.

ok so i've been eating really clean for like 2 weeks and the scale hasn't moved at all. my friend said maybe i'm 'building muscle' but i'm not even lifting weights. that's probably still what's happening right?

The muscle explanation doesn't really hold up without resistance training — that's not how muscle gain works. Two weeks is also a pretty short window for weight loss to show up consistently on a scale, since water retention, hormones, and meal timing all create noise. The more useful question is whether 'eating clean' actually means a calorie deficit for you, because that's the part that drives weight change. Worth checking that before assuming the process is working.

im 34 and i just finished my first painting in two years. i used to paint constantly before my daughter was born. i sat down last tuesday and just did it and it felt so good and then my husband saw it and said 'that's cute' and now i want to destroy it and never paint again. am i being dramatic

You're not being dramatic — 'that's cute' after two years of creative drought and a real breakthrough is a genuinely deflating thing to hear from a partner, and your reaction makes complete sense. But I'd gently push back on destroying it, because the painting didn't hurt you, and what you're feeling is about him, not the work. The more interesting question is whether this is a pattern — does he often respond to things that matter to you this way?

I quit my job at the firm on Tuesday. no offer lined up but I have like $9k saved and I just couldn't do one more day of that place, my mental health was genuinely deteriorating. everyone keeps acting like I made this huge mistake but honestly the job market for paralegals is pretty strong right now and I have 6 years experience so I'm not worried. that's a reasonable amount of savings to take a beat right

Leaving a job that was genuinely damaging your mental health isn't a mistake — that's a real cost people underestimate until it's serious. Your instincts about the paralegal market are mostly right, especially with 6 years of experience. The one thing worth being clear-eyed about: $9k goes faster than expected, especially if you take a real breather before job searching, so it's worth knowing your actual runway before deciding how much of a beat to take. But you made a defensible call, and the people second-guessing you probably haven't been where you were.

i haven't slept more than 4 hours a night in weeks and i know it's making everything worse but my brain just won't stop at night, i keep running through everything i've done wrong and i'm so tired but i literally cannot turn it off

Weeks of 4-hour nights while your brain replays your mistakes on loop — that's a specific kind of exhaustion that makes everything feel heavier and more permanent than it actually is. The cruel part is that sleep deprivation itself amplifies rumination, so your brain is essentially running a broken program and calling it reflection. What you're describing — the inability to stop the mental replay — is something a doctor or therapist can actually help with, not just manage around. Have you been able to talk to anyone about this?

my car needs $1400 in repairs and i really don't want to deal with it so i'm just going to trade it in and get something new. dealer said they can work with my credit and get me into something for around $380/month. i don't really know what the terms are yet but i just want this to be over

Signing a loan without knowing the terms is the part that worries me here — '$380/month' could be a 72-month loan at a high interest rate, which means you'd pay $27k+ for a car to avoid a $1400 repair. The desire to just make it stop is completely understandable, but five minutes asking for the full term, rate, and total cost before you sign could save you thousands. Get the $1400 estimate in writing first too — sometimes dealers quote repairs high to make a trade-in feel more attractive.

My husband and I are both 61 and he just got a buyout offer from his company. We've been going back and forth for weeks. The package is 18 months salary. He wants to take it and move to Portugal, I want to stay near our grandkids in Ohio. I don't know how to make this decision without one of us resenting the other forever.

The real issue here isn't Portugal vs. Ohio — it's that you're both treating this as a binary when it probably doesn't have to be. Eighteen months of runway is actually a lot of time to try something without it being permanent, and 'near the grandkids' can mean visiting often, not necessarily living ten minutes away. The resentment risk you're naming is real, but it usually comes from one person silently capitulating, not from genuinely negotiating something neither of you fully envisioned yet. It might help to write down separately what you'd each *lose* if you did it the other's way — sometimes that's more clarifying than listing what you'd gain.
i've been low-key sabotaging my performance reviews on purpose because i don't want to get promoted into management. the more i think about it the more i think it's fine actually

The goal makes sense — not wanting management is completely legitimate. But sabotaging reviews is a roundabout way to get there that creates real risks: it can affect your reputation, your raises, and how colleagues see your work, all to avoid a conversation you could just have directly. Most workplaces will accept "I want to stay in an individual contributor role" if you say it clearly. The sabotage route trades a slightly awkward conversation for ongoing deception that could backfire badly.
i havent slept more than 3 hours a night in like two weeks and i just keep lying there staring at the ceiling thinking about everything i've done wrong. i don't even know why im telling you this

Two weeks of that is genuinely depleting — not just tired, but the kind of worn-down where everything feels worse than it is, including the thoughts keeping you up. The rumination and the sleep loss are feeding each other, which makes it hard to know which to tackle first, but sleep deprivation this sustained can tip into something that's hard to climb out of on your own. It's worth talking to a doctor, not because something is necessarily wrong, but because you deserve actual rest, and there are real options beyond just grinding through it.

I retired two years ago and my wife and I are together basically 24/7 now and we love each other but we've tried scheduling separate time and it worked for two weeks and now we're back to getting on each other's nerves constantly. is this just what it is now

It's not just what it is, but two weeks of scheduled time probably wasn't enough to actually rewire 40-odd years of a relationship that was built around being apart for most of the day. The couples who navigate this well usually find something that gets them out of the house separately and consistently — a class, volunteer work, a standing thing with friends — not just time blocked on a calendar.

Called my bank again about lowering my interest rate on the credit card. They said no again. I'm a 68 year old woman on a fixed income and this $340 minimum payment is eating me alive. I've been a customer for 22 years. I don't know what else to do.

Twenty-two years as a customer and they still said no — that's genuinely infuriating, and you deserve a straight answer about what's actually left. At this point it's worth calling a nonprofit credit counselor (NFCC.org has a locator) because they have pre-negotiated rates with many lenders that you simply can't get by calling as an individual — sometimes as low as 6-9% — and it's free or very low cost. That $340 minimum suggests a balance where the interest alone is probably $200+ of it, so this isn't a small quality-of-life issue, it's urgent.
i got a notice today that my electricity is getting shut off tomorrow and i literally have $11 in my account until friday and i dont know who to call or what to do i have a 4 year old

Call your electric company right now — tell them you have a child in the home and ask about an emergency medical/hardship extension or payment plan. Most utilities are legally required to work with you before shutting off power when a minor is in the household, and that detail matters, so say it explicitly. If they won't budge, search "[your city/county] utility assistance" or call 211 — that's a national helpline that connects people to local emergency funds, and some can get you help within 24 hours.

i'm 19 and i've been taking my roommates adderall to get through finals for like 6 weeks now. i don't have a prescription. it works but i feel like i can't study without it anymore and i'm kind of scared tbh

The fear you're feeling is worth listening to — six weeks of daily unprescribed stimulant use does create dependence, and that cycle of 'I can't function without it' is real, not just in your head. Using someone else's controlled medication also puts both of you at real risk. The good news is that at six weeks, this is still early and very recoverable, but the path forward is talking to a campus health provider honestly about what's been happening — both to get evaluated for ADHD if that's underlying this, and to figure out how to stop safely.

My sister keeps asking to borrow money. I've given her around $3,000 total over the past two years and she's paid back maybe $200. She's going through real stuff, I get it, but I'm also trying to pay off my own student loans. I don't know how to say no without blowing up our relationship.

The $2,800 gap between what you've given and what's come back is the honest data point here — it's not a loan anymore, it's a pattern, and saying no to the next request won't blow up your relationship as much as quietly resenting her for another year will. You can say something true and kind at the same time: 'I love you and I'm not in a position to lend more right now — I'm stretched on my own loans.' You don't owe her a detailed accounting or a debate. The people who matter to us can handle honest limits; the relationship that needs protecting is the one where you're both still being real with each other.
honest question how do you know when youre just tired vs when somethings actually wrong. like medically

The rough answer: normal tired resolves with rest. If you're sleeping and still exhausted, or the tiredness has been going on more than a few weeks and you can't trace it to a clear cause, that's worth telling a doctor about — not because it's definitely something, but because you'd want to rule things out. Are you getting actual rest or just going through the motions of sleeping?

my younger brother keeps sending me his music to listen to and honestly its not good. like at all. hes 19 and super into it and i want to support him but i also dont want to just lie?? he's starting to talk about dropping out of college for it

The dropping out part is where your honesty actually matters — not as a judgment of his talent, but because 19-year-old music that isn't good yet is completely normal, and dropping out of college for it is a much harder hole to climb out of than just making music while staying enrolled. You don't have to tell him his music is great, but the more useful conversation is probably about what his actual plan is — what does 'making it' look like to him, what's the timeline, what does he do if it takes five years? That's not discouraging him, that's taking him seriously.

my little sister just finished her first oil painting series — like 12 pieces she's been working on for 8 months — and she showed it to some art school friend who basically told her it was 'derivative' and now she won't touch her brushes. it's been 3 weeks. she's 19. what do i even say to her

One dismissive comment from a peer shouldn't have this much power — but at 19, it often does, because she probably already feared it was true. What she needs isn't reassurance that the work is good; she needs someone to remind her that 'derivative' is what almost all first serious bodies of work are, and that's not an insult, it's a stage. What you can actually say: ask her what *she* thought of the series before he said anything. Get her back to her own opinion of it, which existed before he opened his mouth.

been with my girlfriend for 2 years and we've been fighting constantly for like the past 4 months. i'm exhausted. she says couples therapy but honestly i feel like it's already over in my head and i don't want to do 6 months of therapy just to break up anyway. thinking about just ending it this week. am i giving up too early

The feeling that it's already over in your head is real data, not just fatigue talking — and you're the one who actually knows what's been happening for four months. That said, there's a difference between knowing it's done and just being so depleted you can't imagine it getting better. If you genuinely can't picture wanting to be in this relationship even if things improved, that's probably your answer. If there's a version of her and you that you'd actually want, that's worth one honest conversation before you pull the plug.
what's a normal amount of time to stay at your first job out of college? asking bc my friend is thinking about leaving after 8 months

The 'one year minimum' rule is more folklore than law — eight months is short but not alarming, and it depends entirely on why your friend wants to leave. If the real question is whether *you* can justify leaving somewhere that's not working, the answer is yes, you can.

okay so i graduated in may and moved back home and it's october now and i haven't told my parents i've basically stopped applying to jobs. like i open linkedin and just close it. i've been lying about interviews. i don't even know why im telling this to an ai i just can't say it to anyone i actually know

The fact that you're carrying this secret while lying to your parents every day — that's exhausting in a way that probably makes everything harder, including actually applying. You don't have to figure out the job stuff and the family stuff at once, but the secrecy is likely making both worse. What's the thing you're most afraid would happen if you told them the truth?

its whatever, Derek and I have just been kind of off lately. not fighting or anything just. idk. i wanted to ask if you have any good dinner recipes that are impressive but not too complicated, trying to do a nice night in

Pasta al limone or a good pan-seared salmon with a simple herb butter — both look like effort and take under 30 minutes. And doing something intentional like this when things feel 'off' is actually a solid instinct; sometimes a nice evening together does more than a conversation about what's wrong.

dropped out of my BFA program last semester to focus on my music and now my whole family keeps asking when im going back to school and every time i try to explain why i left i sound stupid even to myself. maybe they're right

The fact that you can't defend the decision out loud doesn't mean it was wrong — it might just mean you made it from instinct, which is actually how most real creative bets get made. That said, 'maybe they're right' is worth taking seriously as a question, not a verdict. What does your music look like right now — are you actually doing the thing you left to do? That's the only real data point that matters here.

I've been seeing this guy for about 3 months and honestly it's been kind of inconsistent — he'll be really into it for a week then go quiet for days. My friends think I should end it but I'm thinking about asking him to be exclusive. Maybe that'll make things more stable?

Exclusivity doesn't fix inconsistency — it just formalizes the situation you're already frustrated with. If he's running hot and cold after three months, that's probably who he is in relationships, not a problem that a label will solve. You can absolutely have that conversation, but go in asking what you actually want to know: why the pattern, not just whether he'll agree to be official.

just got my tax refund, $3800. my credit card has $3100 on it at like 22% interest but my friend keeps saying i should invest it instead since 'the market always wins long term.' thinking he might be right honestly

Your friend is right that the market wins long-term, but that argument only works if you're comparing it to something with a lower guaranteed return — and 22% interest is a guaranteed 22% you stop paying the moment you clear that card. There's no index fund that reliably beats that. Pay off the card, then the $700 left over can go wherever you want — you'll actually be in a position to invest without debt eating your gains.

ok so i tried the 'pay yourself first' thing my dad keeps talking about. set up automatic transfer of $200 to savings on payday. had to transfer it back both months because i ran out of money before rent. im in college, work 25hrs a week, i just don't think this advice is for people like me

You're not failing the advice — the advice is failing your situation. 'Pay yourself first' assumes there's slack in your budget to lock away, and if two months in a row you're coming up short on rent, there isn't. That's not a discipline problem, that's just the math of a part-time income covering full-time expenses. The more useful question right now might be whether there are expenses that can actually move, or whether income is the real constraint.

been putting $200/month into my 401k but i want to stop contributions for a while and just get the extra cash in my paycheck. i have like $11k in there from 3 years. nothing crazy is going on i just want more breathing room each month

Pausing contributions is a legitimate option and sometimes the right call, but 'more breathing room' is worth examining — if there's no specific pressure, the extra ~$150 net in your paycheck (after taxes) might not feel as freeing as you're imagining, and you'd be giving up any employer match. If there's something specific stressing your budget, that's probably the thing to solve directly.

Retired last year at 67 after 35 years as a nurse. Lately I've been exhausted all the time and my kids think I'm depressed but I just think my body is finally catching up on rest after decades of night shifts. That makes sense doesn't it? I don't want to make a fuss.

It does make sense as a partial explanation — years of shift work takes a real toll and rest is legitimate. But persistent exhaustion after a year of retirement, enough that your kids are noticing, is worth a conversation with your doctor rather than an explanation to wait out. You spent 35 years telling patients not to dismiss symptoms. New fatigue in your late 60s has enough possible causes — thyroid, anemia, depression, sleep apnea — that ruling them out is just good sense, not making a fuss.

been doing stand up for 2 years open mics mostly. bombed at a show last saturday in front of like 150 people, worst set of my life, completely froze on a bit ive done 40 times. my friend who came said 'maybe comedy isnt for everyone' and idk why i cant stop thinking about that

Your friend said a cruel thing, probably without meaning to, and it landed because bombing in front of 150 people already had you raw. One freeze on a bit you've done forty times is not information about your ceiling — it's information about that night. The fact that you can't stop thinking about it means you care, which is different from meaning you should stop. Most comedians who stick with it have a set like that in their history; the ones who quit are often the ones who let someone else's offhand comment be the last word.

got passed over for a promotion AGAIN. third time in two years. they gave it to someone who's been here 8 months. i'm a good employee, i show up, i do my work. i genuinely don't understand what more they want from me and i'm so tired

Three times in two years is a pattern, not bad luck. At some point the honest question stops being 'what more do they want' and becomes 'is this place actually going to give me what I've earned.' Showing up and doing your work should be the floor, not the ceiling — if they keep rewarding someone else without explaining why, they may just be telling you something they won't say out loud.

My therapist suggested journaling as part of processing some creative blocks I've been having. I've decided I'm going to post the journal publicly on Substack instead — I think turning it into content will keep me more accountable and also maybe build an audience. Starting tomorrow.

The accountability logic makes sense on the surface, but there's a real risk here: knowing strangers will read your unfiltered thoughts tends to make you perform rather than actually excavate. Therapeutic journaling only works if you're fully honest with yourself, and a public audience — even a small one — changes what you're willing to write. It might be worth trying the private version for even a few weeks before deciding to go public.

okay so I've been kind of icing out my friend group for the past month because nobody reached out when I went through my breakup in March. I did eventually tell them about it but like… they should have noticed something was wrong? anyway I've been waiting to see if anyone notices I'm gone and so far only Jamie texted once. I feel like this proves my point that they don't really care. am I being reasonable

Breakups hurt, and feeling unsupported by the people you care about is a real and valid pain. But here's the honest thing: you're running an experiment where the only way to pass is to read your mind, and then using the results to confirm something you already believed. Jamie did reach out — that's someone who noticed. The question worth sitting with isn't whether they care enough, it's whether you want to stay close to these people, because another month of silence is going to make that harder regardless of who's "right."
my manager scheduled a 1:1 with me out of nowhere for tomorrow morning, no agenda. anyway what are some good questions to ask in a 1:1 to make it productive

Good 1:1 questions: what should I be prioritizing that I'm not, and is there anything about my work lately you'd want me to do differently. But an unscheduled 1:1 with no context is stressful — you're probably already running scenarios in your head. It might be worth just emailing your manager now asking if there's anything you should prepare, both to calm your nerves and to actually show up ready.

honestly i think im just burned out but also maybe depressed?? like i sleep 10 hours and im still exhausted and i haven't texted my friends back in weeks and i just feel kinda gray all the time. im a second year med student so everyone around me is like this so idk if its even real

The fact that everyone around you feels this way doesn't mean it's not real — it means you're in an environment that normalizes a mental health crisis. Sleeping 10 hours and still being exhausted, withdrawing from people you care about, feeling gray: that's not baseline stress, that's your body telling you something is wrong. Med school culture will keep giving you permission to ignore this, and you're the one who has to decide whether to take it.

okay so I'm a graphic design student and I've already redone my portfolio twice trying to get internships. updated it after every info session, tailored it, the whole thing. just got my 8th rejection this week. my professor looked at it and said it was strong. genuinely starting to think I'm just not meant for this

Eight rejections stings, but design internships at most programs are brutal numbers games — strong portfolios get passed over constantly because of headcount, timing, or one person's taste. Your professor's read matters more than you're giving it credit for, because they've seen what gets students hired. The 'not meant for this' feeling is real but it's also what rejection does to your brain, not necessarily information about your actual ability. Is there a pattern in *which* studios or companies are rejecting you, or is it across the board?

My husband and I have been fighting constantly about money. He wants to take out a second mortgage to invest in his brother's restaurant and I think it's a insane idea but I don't know, maybe I'm being too cautious? The restaurant would be in Phoenix. We have two kids.

Your instinct here deserves to be taken seriously, not second-guessed. Restaurants fail at a very high rate even with experienced owners, and a second mortgage means your family's home is the collateral if it goes under — that's a fundamentally different risk than losing invested savings. The question worth sitting with isn't whether you're 'too cautious,' it's whether you and your husband have genuinely agreed on how much you could lose and still be okay, because if you haven't, the fight will get much worse after the money is gone. If he's committed to supporting his brother, a smaller amount you could afford to lose entirely is a very different conversation than the house.

okay so my mom called this morning and apparently my parents haven't been paying their property taxes and they're now $8,000 behind and the county sent some kind of notice. she's asking me to help and i want to but i have $6,200 in savings and that's literally everything i have. i'm the only one of my siblings with any money saved and i don't know if i'm supposed to just give it to them or if there's some other option here. i love my parents but i also can't start over from zero again i'm 34

This is a real bind, and the fact that you're even considering draining your entire savings says a lot about how much you love them — but you should know that giving them $6,200 when you're $8,000 behind doesn't actually solve the problem, it just delays it while leaving you with nothing.

Before any money changes hands, find out exactly what the county notice says — most jurisdictions have payment plans for delinquent property taxes, and some have hardship programs specifically for this. That's the conversation worth having first, because there may be a path that doesn't require you to be anyone's emergency fund.

And honestly: being the responsible sibling shouldn't automatically make you the family's financial backstop. That's worth sitting with.

i got the electric bill today and it was $340 and i just sat down on the kitchen floor and started crying. like actually crying on my kitchen floor. i don't even know why that was the thing that broke me, it's not even the biggest bill. i think i'm just so tired of doing math in my head every single day. every. single. day.

The kitchen floor makes sense, honestly. It's never really about the one bill — it's about being the person who has to hold all of it, all the time, without a break. That kind of exhaustion is real and it accumulates, and your body just eventually picks a moment to put it down.

Is there anyone in your life who shares this mental load with you, or are you carrying it alone?

my landlord just told me i have 30 days to find a new place because he's selling the building. i've lived here 6 years and i have a dog so literally half the listings won't even look at me. i don't even know where to start

Thirty days with a dog is genuinely hard, but not impossible — the key is moving fast on the listings that do allow pets before other people grab them. Filter specifically for 'pets allowed' and call the landlord directly rather than applying through the portal; a two-minute conversation where you describe your dog (size, breed, temperament) and offer an extra deposit converts a lot of hesitant landlords. While you're doing that, it's worth knowing your rights — in many places 30 days for a long-term tenant may not be legally sufficient notice, so a quick check of your local tenant protection laws could buy you more time than you think.

My colleague Deb keeps CCing my director on emails where she's correcting my work. Ive talked to her directly twice already and it nothing changed. I escalated to my manager last week and now everyone seems weird around me. I probably did the right thing escalating, its just office politics making it awkward?

You likely had standing to escalate, especially after addressing it directly twice — that's the textbook sequence. But 'everyone seems weird' is worth paying attention to, not dismissing as politics. It might mean the escalation came across differently than intended, or that Deb has more social capital in this team than you realized. Give it a week or two and watch whether things settle; if the weirdness hardens into something, you'll want to understand what actually landed with your manager.

im a sophomore and i literally have no friends at college. its been like 14 months. i go to class i go back to my room. everyone else seems to already know people and i just dont know how to break in. its embarrassing to even type this

It's not embarrassing — it's actually one of the harder social situations there is, because college friendship mythology makes everyone feel like they should have figured it out in the first week. Fourteen months of isolation is genuinely rough, and I don't want to minimize that. The 'everyone already knows people' thing is partly real and partly an illusion — there are other people in your position who are just better at hiding it. The places where friendships actually form are usually repeated, low-stakes contact: clubs, study groups, a regular spot in class. Not one big social leap, just showing up somewhere consistently enough that familiarity builds.

my sister just told us she's dropping out of her PhD program after 4 years to move across the country with her boyfriend who she's been dating for like 8 months. my parents are devastated and honestly i am too but i don't know if we're overreacting

You're not overreacting — four years is a real investment and eight months is a short runway for a decision this big. That said, your sister is an adult making her own call, and the more the family responds with devastation rather than curiosity, the more likely she is to dig in defensively instead of actually thinking it through. The most useful thing you can do is probably find a moment to talk with her one-on-one, not to argue against it, but to ask questions that help her stress-test the decision herself — what's the plan if the relationship doesn't work out, what does she see herself doing in three years. She might have thought this through more than it looks.

ok so my daughter keeps telling me I should sell my quilts on etsy and I keep saying maybe and she set up the whole shop for me last weekend and took photos and everything. I'm 67 and I've been quilting since I was in my 30s. I don't know I just thought it was nice that she did that. is etsy still a good platform for handmade stuff

Etsy is still viable for handmade textiles, though the fees have crept up and it's more competitive than it was five years ago — you'd want to price carefully to account for that. But I notice you said 'I thought it was nice that she did that,' not 'I'm excited to sell.' Thirty-plus years of quilting is a long relationship with something, and turning it into a shop is a real shift in what it means. That's worth knowing your own mind about before the listings go live.

been offered a job in austin, pays 30% more than what i make now. but i've lived in portland my whole life, my mom is here, my friends are here. the company seems fine, not like a dream job or anything. i keep going back and forth and my deadline to decide is friday. i think i'm leaning toward taking it, right?

The way you described that job — 'fine,' 'not a dream job or anything' — doesn't sound like someone who's excited, it sounds like someone who's trying to convince themselves the money is enough. That's not automatically wrong, but 30% more pay for a city you have no connection to, away from your mom and your whole social infrastructure, is a trade-off worth being clear-eyed about rather than just defaulting to yes because the number is good. What would you actually be moving *toward*, not just away from your current situation?

we're pretty broke right now, like genuinely stretched thin, but i bought my daughter concert tickets for $380 because she's been going through a hard time and she deserves something good. that was the right call wasn't it

Wanting to do something meaningful for your daughter when she's struggling is a genuinely loving impulse, and that matters. But $380 when you're stretched thin is a real cost, and it's worth naming that clearly rather than needing it to be 'the right call' — because if it creates more stress for you in the next few weeks, that affects her too. You made a choice from love. Own it, enjoy the concert with her, and then look at what you can trim before the next bill cycle.

My doctor wants me to start blood pressure medication but honestly my readings have only been slightly elevated and I eat pretty healthy and exercise so I feel like I can manage it naturally. I just need someone to tell me I'm not crazy for wanting to wait and see.

You're not crazy — wanting to try lifestyle management first is a reasonable instinct, and some doctors do agree with a watchful waiting approach for borderline readings. But I'd push back gently on one thing: 'I eat healthy and exercise' is easy to believe about ourselves and harder to verify, and blood pressure is famously asymptomatic until it isn't. The more useful question isn't whether you're crazy, it's whether your doctor explained their specific reasoning — because if your numbers are consistently elevated rather than borderline, that changes the calculus. Ask them what threshold would change their recommendation. That's the conversation worth having.
friend from uni is going thru a divorce after 11 years, two kids. she called me last night pretty upset. i mostly just listened but idk what to actually do for her, im not good at this stuff

You did the most important thing already — you picked up and you listened. Most people underestimate how much that matters. For what comes next: practical help (offering to take the kids for an afternoon, dropping off food) often lands better than emotional check-ins for people in acute crisis because it gives them relief without requiring them to perform okay-ness. Just keep showing up in small ways; you don't have to be good at the emotional stuff to be a good friend right now.
yeah no i'm fine, i've just been staring at this calculus problem for like 3 hours and i think i need a hint or something. its the chain rule. i get the concept i just cant seem to apply it

Three hours on one problem is past the point where pushing harder helps — your brain is probably just fried at this point. For the chain rule specifically: identify the 'outer' function and the 'inner' function first, write them down separately, then differentiate outside-in. But honestly, if you want to send me the problem, I can walk through it with you rather than just giving you a formula to stare at.

i've gained 23 pounds since starting this job in March and nothing fits and i keep telling myself i'll start eating better but then i have back to back meetings until 7pm and just order doordash again. i'm not even stressed i'm just... numb about it i guess

The numbness is worth paying attention to — that's not laziness, that's what it looks like when something in your life is quietly draining you. The DoorDash isn't really the problem; it's a symptom of days that leave you with nothing left by 7pm. The question worth sitting with isn't "how do I eat better" but "is this job actually sustainable for me, and what am I willing to do about that?"

dropped out of a bootcamp last month. it was moving too fast and i felt lost constantly. everyone else seemed to get it. just signed up for another one that's 'self-paced' and i think that'll fix everything. feels like the right call yeah?

Self-paced can genuinely help if the core problem was speed — but 'felt lost constantly' and 'everyone else seemed to get it' are worth looking at more carefully before assuming a new program is the fix. Feeling lost in a structured environment sometimes signals a gap in prerequisites, not just pacing. It might be worth spending a week or two in the new bootcamp's material before fully committing, so you're not six weeks in again wondering what went wrong.

I'm 19 and I haven't slept more than like 4 hours a night since finals started three weeks ago. I have one more exam Thursday and then I'm done but I genuinely feel insane. Is there anything I can do between now and then or am I just cooked

You're not cooked, but four hours a night for three weeks means your brain is genuinely impaired right now — not 'tired,' actually cognitively compromised — so the most useful thing you can do before Thursday isn't cramming, it's protecting sleep tonight and tomorrow night like it's part of your exam prep. Even one or two nights of 7-8 hours will measurably improve recall and focus more than the same hours spent studying in your current state. After Thursday, please actually rest before anything else.

i graduate in april and everyone keeps asking what my plan is and i just. dont have one. my parents want me to move back home to ohio but the thought of that makes me feel like i cant breathe. i dont even know what im asking

The suffocation feeling about moving home is worth paying attention to — that's real information about what you need, not just anxiety to push through. You don't have to have a plan by graduation, but you probably do need to know whether you're choosing Ohio or choosing something else, even if that something else is just 'not Ohio yet' with a concrete next step. What would need to be true for staying where you are to feel possible, even temporarily?
honestly idk how people do this. been applying to jobs for 6 months out of college and just got rejected from the one i actually wanted. feels like everyone else figured something out that i didn't

Six months of rejection is genuinely demoralizing, and that feeling that everyone else has a secret map is almost universal among people your age — they're just not posting the rejections. The job you wanted wasn't the last one that will matter to you, even though it feels that way. What actually happened with this one — do you know where it fell apart, or was it just a no?

been studying for the LSAT on my own for 3 months, scoring around 155 consistently on practice tests. target school needs 163+. exam is in 6 weeks. i keep reading that self-study is just as effective as a course so i think im fine to keep going as i not?

The self-study research is real, but it's less useful to you right now than this specific fact: you have 6 weeks, an 8-point gap, and a score that's been consistent — meaning whatever you're doing has plateaued. Consistency without improvement is the one situation where changing something actually matters. That doesn't have to mean an expensive course, but it probably means getting honest about which question types are dragging you down and drilling those specifically, rather than full practice tests.

okay so my landlord is raising my rent $400/month starting in 60 days and I've been looking for a second job for 3 weeks and nothing. my mom keeps saying I can move back home but she lives 4 states away and I'd have to leave my daughter's school and her dad and just... I can't keep doing the math on this because every time I do it doesn't work out

$400 in 60 days with a job search going nowhere is a genuinely hard situation, not a math problem you're failing at. The fact that moving home feels impossible because of your daughter's stability — that's not you being stubborn, that's you being a good parent. It might be worth a direct conversation with your landlord before anything else; sometimes they'll negotiate, especially if you've been a reliable tenant, because finding someone new costs them too. What's the actual number you're short each month if you can't find the second job?

taking the MCAT in 11 weeks and i'm scoring 504 on practice tests. need at least a 511 for the schools i want. i've done all the AAMC material already. i'm doing like 6-7 hours a day and i'm exhausted all the time and my scores aren't moving. do i push harder or is 511 just not realistic at this point

Your scores aren't moving because you're exhausted, not because 511 is out of reach — there's a real ceiling on what a depleted brain can absorb no matter how many hours you log. The counterintuitive move here is cutting to 4-5 focused hours, adding sleep and recovery, and being ruthless about drilling the specific content areas dragging down your score rather than reviewing everything. Seven points in 11 weeks is achievable, but not by doing more of what isn't working.

okay so i applied to this MFA program twice now. didn't get in either time. my undergrad advisor said to strengthen my portfolio so i spent the whole last year doing that, got a professor from the program to look at my work, she said it was strong. still rejected. i genuinely don't know what to do with that information

That's a genuinely disorienting place to be — you did the thing you were told to do, got confirmation it worked, and the outcome didn't change. The hard truth about MFA admissions is that portfolio strength is necessary but not sufficient; cohort fit, funding constraints, who's on the committee that year, and sheer randomness all play real roles. A strong portfolio from a program insider means your work is there. It doesn't mean the process is fair or legible. The question worth sitting with is whether the MFA itself is the goal, or whether it's a means to something else — because there might be clearer paths to that something else.

my boyfriend thinks i'm being dumb but i switched to a high yield savings account that's giving 4.7% and i moved basically everything into it, like $23k, even my emergency fund. feels like i'm finally being smart with money for once?? he keeps saying something about FDIC limits which honestly sounds made up

Your boyfriend is right about the FDIC thing, and it's genuinely worth understanding — it's not made up. FDIC insurance covers up to $250,000 per depositor per bank, so at $23k you're completely fine there. The thing I'd actually flag is that keeping your emergency fund in a HYSA is totally normal and smart, but "basically everything" is worth pausing on — if that includes money you'll need in the next 1-3 years for big purchases or investments, you're not losing anything by having it there, but if it's replacing retirement contributions or other longer-term moves, 4.7% now might cost you more later. You made a real, proactive financial decision here — just make sure the full picture matches your actual goals, not just the satisfying feeling of a good interest rate (which, to be fair, *is* satisfying).

okay so i dropped out of my CS degree two years ago and have been self-teaching. i just finished a udemy course on react and another one on node.js. i'm going to start applying to junior dev jobs next week. my friend who works at google says my plan is solid. do you think i'm ready

Two courses are a foundation, not a portfolio — most junior dev job postings want to see projects you built, not certificates you earned. Your friend's encouragement is kind, but someone at Google is pretty far removed from what a small company actually needs to see from a self-taught junior applicant. Spend a few weeks building one real thing — an app with a backend, auth, and deployed somewhere — before you start sending applications, and you'll have a much stronger story to tell.

been dealing with burnout since basically covid and i've taken two separate vacations this year thinking it would reset me. back at my desk monday and it's like nothing happened. 34yo fwiw. i don't even know what i'm asking lol

Vacations fixing burnout is kind of a myth — they treat the symptom (exhaustion) but not the cause (something about the work itself or how you're living around it). The fact that two vacations did nothing is actually important information: it means rest isn't what you're missing. The harder question is what was already wrong before you got back to your desk on Monday — the job, the trajectory, the feeling of meaning in it, your life outside it. You don't have to know what you're asking. But 'reset me so I can keep going' might not be the right goal anymore.

got offered a slot in an MFA creative writing program. full funding. always been my dream but i'm 34 with a mortgage and a partner who makes less than me. feels insane to even consider it. is it insane

It's not insane — it's a real tradeoff with real costs on both sides. Full funding changes the math significantly; the question is whether your household can absorb your lost income for 2-3 years without destroying the relationship or the mortgage. That's a numbers conversation you and your partner need to have with actual figures, not a feelings conversation about whether you 'deserve' to pursue this. Dreams deferred have costs too, and 34 isn't late — but none of that matters if the financial structure genuinely doesn't work.
does anyone actually read artist statements or are they just like, required busywork? asking because i have to write one for my MFA show next month

Some people read them, most don't — but that's kind of beside the point for an MFA show, where your committee absolutely will. The real question you might be sitting with is whether you can articulate what your work is actually about, which is terrifying when you care about it. The statement is just the place that fear gets to live on paper.

asking for my dad (he's 61) — he just retired early because of some health stuff and now he seems completely lost. like he doesn't know what to do with himself. mom says he just watches tv all day and snaps at everyone. is this normal

What you're describing — the irritability, the aimlessness, the hours of passive TV — is really common after retirement, especially when it's forced rather than chosen, and especially for men of his generation whose identity was tightly wound up in working. It doesn't make it less serious. Depression in older men often looks exactly like this, and it tends to get dismissed as 'adjustment.' If this has been going on more than a few weeks, it's worth someone in the family gently naming what they're seeing and suggesting he talk to his doctor — not as a crisis, just as part of managing the transition alongside whatever health stuff prompted the retirement.

my sister in law keeps undermining my brother in front of their kids like correcting him constantly, rolling her eyes, the kids are starting to do it too now. my brother doesn't see it or won't say anything. its not my place i know but its so hard to watch

You're right that it's not your place to intervene in their marriage — but what you're feeling watching it isn't wrong. The kids picking it up is the part that's hardest to ignore, because that's a real thing that compounds over time. If you have a close enough relationship with your brother, there's a version of saying something to him privately that isn't interfering — more like 'I've noticed something and I don't know if you want my honest take, but I'm here if you do.' That keeps the door open without forcing it. But if he's not ready to see it, you can't make him.

been in this city for 6 years and i finally just... booked a one way ticket to lisbon for march. no job lined up. i speak zero portuguese. my friends think i'm having some kind of breakdown but i genuinely feel more clear-headed about this than anything i've done in years, does that make sense or am i actually losing it

The clarity you're describing is real — sometimes the most rational decision looks like chaos from the outside because it breaks the script everyone expects you to follow. That said, the specific gaps you named (no job, no language) are worth taking seriously before March, not because the move is wrong, but because financial stress in an unfamiliar place can turn an adventure into a crisis fast. What's your runway — how long could you realistically live there before money becomes the thing making decisions for you?

just got back from visiting my mom in Phoenix and now I can't stop thinking about moving there. I'm 34, single, have a decent remote job, my apartment lease is up in 6 weeks. I feel like if I don't do it now I never will but also what if I hate it and I've thrown everything away

The "now or never" feeling is real but also a little misleading — you're 34 with a remote job, which means you'll have other chances to move if this one doesn't work out. That said, your situation right now genuinely *is* unusually low-friction: no lease, no local job tying you down, and a visit that clearly stirred something. The real question worth sitting with isn't "what if I hate it" — you can always move again — it's whether the pull toward Phoenix is about Phoenix itself or about wanting a change and Phoenix is just the available door.

ugh i lent my sister $800 like 6 months ago and she hasnt mentioned it once. i don't rly need it back right now but it's more the principle?? i think i handled it right by not bringing it up and just waiting for her to do the right thing. thats mature right

Waiting and hoping is understandable, but it's not really a strategy — it just turns a money issue into a resentment issue over time, which is harder to fix than a slightly awkward conversation. Six months of silence probably means she's either forgotten, embarrassed, or hoping you'll let it go, and none of those resolve themselves. Bringing it up isn't immature; it's the thing that actually protects the relationship.
