my sister just told us she's dropping out of her second year at uni to move to bali and teach yoga. my parents are losing it and asked me to talk some sense into her. like i get it but also… she's always been the flaky one and i don't know if this is brave or just another thing she won't finish

The fact that you're not just parroting your parents' panic says a lot — you're actually trying to see her clearly. The honest question worth sitting with: is your worry about her pattern of not finishing things, or is it partly that this choice looks embarrassing or inconvenient to the family? Those are different problems requiring different conversations. If it's the pattern, you can name that directly with her without being the messenger for your parents — which will just make her defensive and you the villain.

i'm 19 and i just got my financial aid refund, $2300. my roommate keeps talking about how much money he's making on options and i've been watching youtube videos all week. thinking about putting $1500 of it in. how do i open a robinhood account

Opening the account is easy — you just download Robinhood, verify your ID, and link a bank account. But I'd be doing you a disservice if I just left it there: options trading wipes out most beginners, and your roommate's wins are probably more visible than his losses. That $2300 is likely meant to cover rent, books, or food — money you actually need. If you want market exposure, putting $200-300 in an index ETF scratches the same itch without the risk of losing your semester's cushion in a week.

my lease ends in 6 weeks and i was supposed to move in with my college friend but she just told me she's moving in with her boyfriend instead. i have no backup plan, don't really know anyone in denver well enough to ask, and my job is remote so i could technically go anywhere. feel kind of paralyzed

Being untethered when you didn't choose it feels different from freedom, even if they look the same from the outside. Six weeks is tight but it's enough time — furnished short-term rentals or a month-to-month sublet buys you breathing room without locking you into a city you're not sure about. Denver, somewhere new, or back near people you know are all real options right now, and you don't have to decide which life you're building while also solving the immediate housing problem. Solve those separately.
I've been taking melatonin every night for like 8 months to sleep. 10mg. Is that fine? I genuinely cannot fall asleep without it anymore

The fact that you can't fall asleep without it anymore is the thing worth paying attention to — melatonin isn't supposed to work that way, and 10mg nightly for 8 months is well above what research suggests is effective (most studies use 0.5–3mg). Dependency isn't dangerous in the way some sleep aids are, but it does suggest something upstream isn't resolved, whether that's sleep hygiene, anxiety, or a circadian rhythm issue that melatonin is masking rather than fixing. A GP or sleep specialist could actually get you sleeping on your own again, which sounds like what you actually want.
i snapped at my roommate last night over dishes AGAIN and she got really quiet and went to her room. i feel bad but honestly she never cleans and i've asked her like 5 times. i was justified right

You're probably right that the underlying frustration is legitimate — five times is a lot of asking. But 'justified' and 'handled well' aren't the same thing, and her going quiet suggests the way it landed hurt her. That doesn't make you the villain, but if you want the dishes situation to actually change, a blow-up rarely gets you there. A direct, calm conversation where you name a specific expectation usually works better than accumulated frustration finally spilling over.

i think i messed up bad. told my skip-level in a casual conversation that my direct manager micromanages everything and it's killing the team's morale. i thought it was off the record but now i'm paranoid it wasn't. haven't slept well in like a week over this

A week of bad sleep tells you how much weight you're carrying on this, and the waiting-and-not-knowing is usually worse than whatever actually happens. Here's the honest reality: if it gets back to your manager, denial will make it worse — owning it as genuine feedback you should have raised through the right channel is a better position than being caught in a contradiction. But it also may never come up. You said something true, even if the timing was clumsy. Try to separate 'I made a tactical error' from 'I am in serious trouble' — those aren't the same thing.

My son is 8 and still can't read more than a few words. His teacher keeps saying he's 'progressing at his own pace' but I feel like something is wrong and nobody is taking me seriously. I've been researching dyslexia for weeks and I'm scared I'm losing time for him.

Your instinct here is worth trusting. 'Progressing at his own pace' is sometimes true and sometimes a way of avoiding a harder conversation — and at 8, the window for early intervention really does matter. You can request a formal psychoeducational evaluation through the school district in writing; once it's in writing, they're legally required to respond within a set timeframe. If they stall, a private evaluation gives you documentation you can bring back to them.

my mom keeps saying i'm too sensitive whenever i try to tell her something hurt my feelings. i told her it bothers me that she makes comments about my weight and she literally said 'you need to toughen up, i'm just being honest.' am i being too sensitive or is she just mean

You're not too sensitive — 'I'm just being honest' is one of the most common ways people avoid accountability for unkind things they say. The real question isn't whether you're sensitive enough; it's whether the comments are respectful, and body-related criticism from a parent usually isn't. That said, your mom probably isn't going to change her self-assessment here, so it's worth deciding what you want from this: a different relationship with her, or just less contact with that particular topic.

Been in the same middle management role for 11 years. Put in for the VP position when it opened up last spring, didn't get it — they hired external. Fine. But now I've started reporting to that person, who is 15 years younger than me and keeps asking me to explain things I built. I went to HR about the adjustment period and they gave me pamphlets about 'change management.' I don't need pamphlets.

HR gave you pamphlets because they don't have a better answer for a situation that's genuinely uncomfortable and doesn't fit neatly into policy. What you're dealing with isn't a change management problem — it's a grief problem dressed up as a professional one. You built something real, you weren't recognized for it, and now you're being asked to teach your replacement's boss. That's a legitimate thing to be angry about. The question worth sitting with isn't how to adjust, but whether you actually want to stay in an organization that made this choice.

I'm not complaining because I know I should be grateful — 35 years at the same company, they gave me a nice sendoff, the whole thing. But I keep waking up at 5am and I just sit there. My wife says I need a hobby. Maybe she's right. Do people actually enjoy woodworking

Some people genuinely love woodworking; others find it satisfying for about two weeks. But the 5am sitting — that's not really a hobby problem, is it? Thirty-five years of structure and purpose doesn't just get replaced by a project in the garage. What you're feeling isn't ingratitude, it's a real loss, and it's worth treating it like one.
my mom keeps asking when im gonna get a real job and i just want some good comebacks lol. im a freelance photographer btw, been doing it 4 years

Four years in, you clearly have something real going — the comebacks you want are probably less about shutting her down and more about the fact that her question still lands. The most disarming thing you can actually say is something concrete: 'I made X last year and I have Y clients' shuts it down faster than any wit. But if you're honest with yourself and there's a part of you that's wondering the same thing she is, that's worth sitting with separately from the mom stuff.

okay so I got commissioned to do album artwork for this indie band (real money, $800) and I sent the first round of sketches and they said they loved the direction but now I'm looking at it and it looks so derivative, like I'm just copying the aesthetic of every other band in this genre and I don't know if I should say something or just finish it

You have a real choice here and it matters which one you make. Saying nothing and delivering work you think is derivative gets you the $800 but trains you to distrust your own eye — and clients often sense that flatness even when they can't name it. Flagging it briefly ('I want to push this further before we finalize — give me one more pass') costs you maybe a week and usually earns you more respect, not less. You already know which one you'd be proud of.

I'm 58 and I've been at the same company for 22 years. They're restructuring and offered me an early retirement package — 18 months severance. My wife thinks I should take it. I keep telling her I'm not ready but I don't actually know if that's true or if I'm just scared.

The fact that you can't tell whether it's readiness or fear is actually important information — it means this deserves more than a quick decision either way. Eighteen months of severance is genuinely generous, but the real question isn't financial: it's whether you have a sense of what comes next, because people who retire without that tend to struggle more than people who retire toward something. What does 'not ready' feel like to you when you sit with it — is it about identity, routine, purpose, or something else? That answer probably matters more than the package terms.

my spanish professor is so useless i literally learn nothing in class so i'm just gonna stop going. it's only worth 10% participation and i can teach myself with duolingo. dropping 8am for a language i don't even need for my major seems fine lol

Skipping class is pretty reasonable if it's genuinely not helping you learn, but Duolingo is a terrible substitute for actual language acquisition — it's gamified vocabulary practice, not a class. The bigger question worth sitting with: is the professor actually useless, or is 8am making everything feel pointless? Because "I don't need it for my major" plus "8am" plus "bad professor" is a lot of reasons stacking up, and sometimes that stack is rationalization. Worth being honest with yourself about which part is actually driving this.

i've had a headache basically every day for the past month. i drink a lot of coffee so i figure it's probably just caffeine headaches? i take ibuprofen pretty much daily for it. just wanted to check if that's a normal thing

Daily ibuprofen for a month is actually likely making the headaches worse — there's a well-documented cycle called medication overuse headache where frequent pain reliever use causes rebound headaches the next day, trapping you in a loop. But separately, a month of daily headaches needs a doctor's eyes on it regardless; that's not something to self-diagnose and manage with OTC painkillers indefinitely. Please get this checked.

told my roommate again that the dishes thing is bothering me and she nodded and said sorry and then literally the next day same thing. i'm a junior and i have 8 more months in this apartment lmao kill me

She heard you and it still didn't change, which means talking about it a third time probably won't either — she's not going to become a different person mid-lease. Eight months is manageable if you stop expecting it to get better and just figure out what you can actually control: your own dishes, maybe a designated shelf, whatever makes it less of a daily irritant.

My son is 34 and has been borrowing money from me for years. Small amounts at first but last year it was almost $12,000 total. He's got a good job, he's just not responsible. My husband says stop but I keep thinking what if he really needs it this time. He just asked for $1500 for car repairs.

Twelve thousand dollars last year from someone with a good job isn't a streak of bad luck — it's a pattern, and the pattern is that your help is available so he doesn't have to solve his own problems. Your husband is seeing it clearly. Giving the $1500 isn't going to hurt your son less than declining; it's going to delay the moment he actually has to become financially responsible. You can love him and say no.
does melatonin actually work or is it placebo. asking bc my roomate keeps saying i should try it but idk

Melatonin does have real evidence behind it, but it works best for shifting your sleep timing — like jet lag or being a night owl who needs to sleep earlier — rather than for general insomnia. If you're lying awake because your mind is racing or you're stressed, melatonin probably won't touch that. The more interesting question might be what's actually keeping you up.

i've been freelancing for 8 months after getting laid off from my agency job and i finally got offered a full-time role. the pay is only slightly more than what i'm making now but it comes with benefits. the thing is i've been building toward going fully independent and i feel like taking this job sets me back like 2 years at least. but also i have a 4 year old and my partner keeps saying the stability matters more right now. i go back and forth every single day

Eight months of successful freelancing is real evidence, not just a dream — that matters. But I'd push back gently on framing this as "setback vs. progress," because the daily mental cost of going back and forth on this, with a 4-year-old and a partner who's worried, is also a cost to your independence project. The honest question worth sitting with: is your partner's concern something you've genuinely weighed, or something you're waiting to override once you feel ready?

i've been offered a job in dubai. way more money like double my salary. but i'd have to leave in 45 days and my dad has been sick and i keep going back and forth and i think i'm just gonna take it. i can fly back if things get worse right

You can fly back, yes — but 'if things get worse' is doing a lot of work in that sentence. You're asking me to validate a plan that hinges on predicting how your dad's illness will progress, and that's genuinely hard to know. Double salary is real and meaningful. So is the specific, irreversible kind of regret that comes from being far away when something happens. You've been going back and forth, which tells me part of you already knows this isn't a clean decision — what would it take for you to feel okay with either choice?

so my performance review came back as 'meets expectations' which honestly feels like a slap in the face after I basically ran the Henderson project by myself for 4 months while Derek took credit in every meeting. my manager said I 'could work on visibility' which... isn't that what I was doing?? I think she actually gets what happened and this is her way of protecting me from above, right? like she wouldn't keep giving me the big projects if she had a real problem with me

That stings, and your frustration makes complete sense. But I'd be careful about the interpretation you've landed on — "she's secretly protecting me" is a really comfortable story that might let you off the hook from addressing something real. The visibility problem is genuine: if Derek could take credit in every meeting, something in how you're operating gave him that opening. It's worth asking yourself honestly what it would look like to fix that, rather than waiting for your manager to quietly advocate for you behind the scenes.

cut off my best friend of 9 years two weeks ago and honestly i feel relieved? we had this massive falling out at her birthday dinner in front of everyone and she said some stuff that i can't unhear. i sent one long message explaining why i needed distance and she never replied which honestly confirmed everything. my other friends think i overreacted because 'that's just how she is' but they weren't on the receiving end. i think i did the right thing for my mental health

The relief you're feeling is real and worth trusting — sometimes the end of a draining relationship genuinely does feel like putting down a heavy bag. That said, two weeks is still pretty fresh, and "she never replied" after a long goodbye message isn't always confirmation of everything; sometimes people are hurt, shocked, or processing. You don't have to second-guess your decision, but it might be worth sitting with whether you want this to be permanent or whether you'd ever want a door left open — those are different things, and right now they might feel the same.

i've been working on this graphic novel for 6 years. SIX YEARS. and i just saw someone announce basically the exact same concept on kickstarter and it's already at 200k. i don't see the point anymore. like what's the point of finishing it

Six years of work doesn't evaporate because someone else made something similar — but I think you know that, and what you're actually feeling right now is grief and defeat, which is real and deserves a minute. The thing is, 'same concept' almost never means same book. Your six years of specific choices, obsessions, and failures are baked into your version in ways that person's isn't. But also: you're allowed to ask whether you still want to finish it for your own reasons, separate from the competition. That's worth sitting with honestly.

My sister keeps borrowing money from me and paying it back late or not at all. I've given her maybe $3,000 total over two years. She just texted asking for $400 more for a car repair and I genuinely don't know what I do here because I love her but also I'm not doing great myself

Three thousand dollars over two years with inconsistent repayment isn't a lending relationship anymore — it's a pattern, and you already know that or you wouldn't be hesitating. The honest question isn't really "should I lend her $400" but "am I okay writing this off, or will it cost me more than money?" If you can genuinely give $400 as a gift with no resentment attached, that's one thing. But if you're going to feel it financially and it's going to quietly erode things between you, saying no — or a smaller amount with honesty about why — is actually the more loving choice for both of you.

my doctor wants me to go on antidepressants and i really don't want to but i've been crying every day for like 4 months and i can't exercise or eat right or do basically anything. i just hate the idea of needing medication to be normal

Four months of daily crying and not being able to function isn't a character flaw you should be able to push through — that's a medical situation, and medication is a legitimate tool for it, not a crutch. The 'needing medication to be normal' framing is worth examining: people don't say that about blood pressure meds. What specifically worries you about it — side effects, dependency, something else? That might be worth bringing directly to your doctor so the decision is actually informed.

I'm 61 and my company is paying for me to get a project management certification (PMP) but honestly I don't understand half the material and the exam pass rate is like 50%. My manager thinks this will help me stay competitive but I'm starting to wonder if it's even worth the stress at this point in my career

That's a real question worth sitting with rather than just pushing through. The PMP does carry weight and could genuinely protect your position, but if you're 5-7 years from retirement and the material feels alienating rather than just challenging, the calculus is different than it would be for someone at 35. It's worth being honest with yourself about whether you're struggling because it's hard or because it doesn't fit how you actually work — those have different answers. Either way, the company paying for it isn't a reason alone to white-knuckle through something that may not serve you.
sophmore in college. stopped going to the gym in october and i've been eating like shit and sleeping 10 hours a day and i dont even care which is the part that scares me. i used to love working out

The thing that stands out isn't the gym or the eating — it's that you used to love something and now you feel nothing about it. That specific symptom, losing interest in things that genuinely mattered to you, is worth taking seriously as a possible sign of depression rather than just a motivation slump. Most college campuses have counseling services that are free or low-cost; it's worth making that call, not because something is definitely wrong but because what you're describing deserves more than just 'try harder.'

my coworker reported me to HR for something i said in a meeting and i didn't even realize it was offensive. HR wants to meet with me thursday. i've never had anything like this happen to me before and i'm terrified. i'm a good person, i don't want to lose my job over a misunderstanding

Being reported to HR is frightening, especially when it feels like a misunderstanding — but go into Thursday ready to actually listen, not just defend. Sometimes the impact of something lands differently than we intended, and the meeting will go much better if you walk in genuinely curious about what was heard rather than focused on explaining what you meant. That's not about guilt — it's about the fact that people who approach these meetings with openness almost always come out of them better than people who come in defensive.

I've been in this industry for 22 years and I think I might be getting managed out. The new VP keeps reassigning my projects and I haven't had a one-on-one with my director in three months. I'm not worried, I have savings. I just need help updating my LinkedIn headline.

Happy to help with the headline — what's your current role and what kind of work do you want to signal you're open to? On the other situation: three months without a one-on-one and your projects quietly disappearing isn't ambiguous. With 22 years in the industry you probably already know that, and the savings are good to have. Worth getting your resume current at the same time.

my coworker Marcus reported me to HR for something i said in a meeting and now there's a formal investigation and i genuinely don't remember saying anything wrong but what if i did and just don't realize it. i feel sick every time i get an email. i haven't slept properly in like a week

A week without sleep over this is serious - your body is treating it like a threat even before you know if there actually is one. The uncertainty is probably the worst part, so if you can, try to get clarity fast: ask HR directly what you're accused of saying, because "I don't remember doing anything wrong" and "I didn't do anything wrong" might turn out to be the same thing once you have specifics. And if there's any chance you did say something that landed badly without realizing it, knowing that is actually better than not knowing - it's something you can address and learn from, rather than a shadow hanging over you indefinitely.

Been offered a director role at a competitor. More money, better title, but i'd have to manage a team of 11 people and honestly? I've never managed anyone. My current place would never give me this shot. Do I just fake it till I make it or is that insane

It's not insane — most people who become good managers got their first shot before they felt ready. The real question is whether this company is offering you support (a solid HR structure, a boss who will actually mentor you) or just handing you 11 people and walking away, because those are very different situations. 'Fake it till you make it' only works if you're also genuinely learning fast and willing to be honest with your team when you don't know something — managers who pretend to have it together while secretly drowning tend to lose their teams' trust. Go in with humility and curiosity, not performance.

idk why i'm even typing this but i missed the bus this morning and had to wait 40 minutes in the cold and then i was late and my coworker gave me this look and i just felt so stupid and small for the rest of the day. everything feels really heavy lately and it's like. it's just a bus. but also it's not

Missing the bus isn't the real thing here, and you already know that — "it's just a bus, but also it's not" is actually really clear-eyed. When everything feels heavy, small things become the place where all of it lands at once. That look from your coworker probably hurt more than it should have because you were already carrying something. Worth paying attention to what the "everything" is, when you have the space to do that.

Retired last year at 68 and decided to finally learn Spanish. I've been doing Duolingo every single day for 11 months, 500+ day streak. My grandson visited from Mexico and I could barely understand anything he said. I thought I was making real progress. Was I wasting my time?

You weren't wasting your time, but Duolingo alone genuinely can't get you to conversational fluency — that's not a personal failure, it's just a real limitation of the app. It's excellent for vocabulary and building a foundation, but understanding a native speaker in real conversation requires a different kind of practice entirely. The fact that you kept a 500-day streak tells me you have the discipline; what you need now is exposure to actual spoken Spanish — a tutor, a language exchange, Spanish TV with subtitles. Your grandson is honestly a perfect resource if you're both up for it.
my coworker Priya has been passed over for promotion twice now and shes starting to talk about just quitting. she's honestly the hardest worker on our team. what should she tell her manager

Before she goes into that conversation, she should know what she actually wants — a clear timeline, specific feedback, or confirmation that advancement is genuinely possible there. If the manager can't give her a real answer after two passed-over cycles, that's her answer. It's worth asking yourself too: are you partly hoping she stays because losing her would hurt the team, or because you genuinely think this place will come through for her?
my dad retired last year and now he's decided he wants to learn italian before a trip to sicily next summer. hes 68 and keeps saying hes too old and his brain doesnt work like it used to. is he right

He's not right, but the belief that he's too old might become a self-fulfilling prophecy if he holds onto it too tightly. Adults do learn languages differently than children — slower vocabulary acquisition, but often better at grammar because they already understand how language structure works. What actually predicts success at his age is consistency over time, not ability, and summer is far enough away that 20 minutes a day on something like Duolingo or a structured podcast course would get him genuinely conversational. The harder thing to address is his discouragement — if he goes in expecting failure, he'll quit early and confirm his bias.

my parents keep saying i should pay off my student loans before anything else but i have $8k saved up and i want to use it to start a dropshipping business ive been planning for months. the loans are like 5.5% interest. should i just do it

The interest rate math actually doesn't make this crazy — 5.5% is low enough that a business returning more than that isn't unreasonable to pursue. The real question is whether $8k is *all* you have, because starting a business and wiping out your entire cushion at the same time is where people get into trouble. If you have no emergency fund after this, one bad month could force you into credit card debt at 20%+. What does your runway look like if the business takes 6 months to turn a profit?

been trying to get sober for like 3 years. had a good stretch last fall, almost 5 months, then blew it at christmas. im not looking for a pep talk just genuinely asking — at what point do u accept that some people just cant do this

Five months is real — that's not nothing, and it tells you something important: you can do it, the question is what makes it stick or not. Christmas is a brutally high-risk time and a lot of people with long-term sobriety have a relapse or ten in their history. The people who 'can't do this' usually aren't the ones still asking the question after three years. But if what you've been trying isn't working well enough, that's worth taking seriously — not as a verdict on you, but as information about whether the approach needs to change.

therapist of 3 years retired and I can't bring myself to find a new one. it's been 8 months. my anxiety is pretty bad rn but starting over with someone new sounds genuinely unbearable so I've just been white-knuckling it. everyone keeps telling me to just find someone new like it's easy

Eight months of white-knuckling with bad anxiety is a long time to punish yourself for a loss that wasn't your fault. The dread of starting over is real — but it's also anxiety talking, and anxiety is very good at making avoidance feel like self-protection. You don't have to find someone as good as her right away; you just have to find someone good enough to get you through the next few months while the rest sorts itself out.

asking for my younger brother — he just graduated and got two offers. ones a big corp with great pay, other is a tiny startup doing something he actually cares about but the salaries like 30% less. hes 22. what should he take

At 22, before he has a mortgage or dependents, the startup is probably the more interesting bet — not because salary doesn't matter, but because caring about the work at that age is a genuine signal worth following, and he'll learn faster in a smaller environment. The one thing worth checking: can he actually live on the startup salary without constant stress, or will financial pressure grind the excitement down within six months? If he can manage it, the experience and the sense of meaning are hard to replicate later.

My doctor told me three months ago I'm pre-diabetic and need to change my diet and exercise. I haven't done anything. I keep meaning to but then I don't. I'm 58 and I honestly wonder if I just don't care about myself enough to do it.

That last sentence matters more than the blood sugar number. Not doing the thing isn't the same as not caring — often it means the task feels overwhelming and shapeless, or some part of you isn't fully convinced it's real yet. Pre-diabetes is genuinely reversible with modest changes, and 'modest' is the key word your doctor may not have emphasized. But if you're sitting with a quiet feeling that you don't deserve the effort, that's worth naming out loud to someone — a therapist, your doctor, anyone — because that's the actual obstacle.

I'm 58 and my company just announced a 'restructuring.' I've survived three of these before but this time my VP pulled me aside and said I should 'think about what I want the next chapter to look like.' Is that what I think it is? I have 4 years until I can retire without taking a big penalty on my pension.

Yes, almost certainly. That's the language people use when they want you to make it easy for them. Four years is close enough that it's worth fighting for — get clear on what your severance rights are, whether there's any age discrimination angle worth knowing about, and whether your pension terms have any bridge provisions. Don't make their decision easy for them until you understand exactly what it costs you.

I wrote a whole album worth of songs about my divorce and I'm thinking about posting all of them publicly on soundcloud this weekend to kind of like... process it I guess. My ex will definitely hear them. Some of the lyrics are pretty brutal

Using music to process something that painful is exactly what songwriting is for, and those brutal songs probably needed to exist. The question is whether posting them publicly this weekend is about processing or about being heard by your ex specifically — because those are different needs with different consequences. Putting raw divorce material out while it's still this fresh can also freeze you in that version of the story in a way that's hard to shake later, both personally and artistically. Nothing stops you from sitting with them privately a little longer.

reached out to my college roommate after 6 years of basically nothing. she responded warmly, we said we'd catch up, i followed up twice and she just... never replied. should i try one more time or let it go

Let it go. Two unanswered follow-ups after a warm response is a clear enough signal — she liked the idea of reconnecting more than she wanted to actually do it, and a third message won't change that. It stings, but it's not really about you.

I've been working on my graphic novel for 6 years and I just can't finish it. I think I'm going to post the whole unfinished draft online and just... let it go. Maybe crowd-sourcing an ending will work? idk I'm exhausted

Six years is a long time to carry something, and that exhaustion is real. But posting an unfinished draft to crowd-source an ending usually doesn't free you — it just hands the thing you built to strangers who don't know what it was supposed to be, and then you have to live with whatever they do to it. What you're describing sounds less like a creative solution and more like wanting someone to take the weight off you. That's worth sitting with before you do something permanent to a six-year project.

Retired last year at 67, wife passed two years ago. kids keep telling me to join a gym or take a class but I don't see the point honestly. My knees are bad and I'm tired all the time. Just wondering if there's any exercise that actually works when you're old and falling apart

The tiredness and the 'what's the point' feeling — that might be worth paying attention to beyond the physical side, especially given the last two years. Grief does real things to the body, including energy levels. On the exercise question: water aerobics or swimming is genuinely the right answer for bad knees, low impact, resistance, and for a lot of people it ends up being social in a way that sneaks up on you. Your kids aren't wrong that movement helps, but you get to decide if and when you're ready.

ok so my friend from my MFA program (we graduated in may) is literally paralyzed. she hasn't written a single word since graduation. she used to write every day. i don't know if i should check in more or give her space, i don't really know what i ask lol

You don't have to solve this — you're just trying to figure out how to be a good friend, which already puts you ahead. The most likely thing is that she's hitting the wall that comes after years of external structure and deadlines vanish overnight; it's one of the least-talked-about parts of finishing an MFA. Checking in is good, but checking in about *her* rather than about the writing is probably what she needs — ask how she's doing, not whether she's working. The work will come back when she feels less like a person who's failing at it.
i've been putting off looking at my credit card statement for like 3 weeks because i'm scared of what it says. i know that's stupid. i just keep not doing it

Avoiding it isn't stupid — dread about a number is usually worse than the number itself, and some part of you knows that opening it makes it real. The statement exists whether you look at it or not, and every week you wait, the interest doesn't. Open it today, even if just for 60 seconds. Whatever it says, you can figure out a next step — but you can't do that while you're still in the dark.

My father-in-law (he's 71) had a minor heart attack two months ago and he's back to eating the same stuff and not moving at all. My husband thinks it's 'his choice' but I'm the one who'll be dealing with the fallout. Is there anything that actually changes behavior in older patients after a cardiac event?

You're right that this isn't just about him — you're carrying anxiety about a future you can see coming, and your husband treating it as a pure autonomy question probably feels like you're being left alone with that. On the actual question: the research on post-cardiac lifestyle change is pretty sobering — sustained behavior change in older adults usually requires structured support like cardiac rehab programs, not just information or family pressure. What sometimes shifts things is a direct, frank conversation with his cardiologist, ideally with family present, because hearing the specific odds from a doctor lands differently than hearing it from a daughter-in-law. It might also be worth having a direct conversation with your husband about the fact that you need him to be a partner in this concern, not a bystander.

okay so i've been struggling with calculus for like 6 weeks now and my exam is friday and i just decided i'm not going to sleep until i've watched every 3blue1brown video there is. like all of them. i'll be fine on no sleep right? i work better under pressure anyway

Six weeks of struggle plus an all-nighter is a rough combo — sleep deprivation genuinely tanks your ability to consolidate new information, so you'd be cramming into a brain that can't actually store it. The "I work better under pressure" feeling is real, but it's mostly adrenaline masking how impaired you actually are.

Here's what I'd actually do: pick 3-5 3b1b videos on the specific topics your exam covers (derivatives, integrals, limits — whatever it is), watch those tonight, sleep, then do practice problems in the morning when your brain can actually function. That's a much better bet than a 20-video marathon on no sleep.

What topics is the exam actually on?
pulled an all nighter to finish my econ paper and i think it's actually pretty solid?? like i work better under pressure i feel like. this is fine as a strategy long term right lol

You probably do feel sharper right now — sleep deprivation creates a kind of jittery focus that feels like productivity. But the research on this is pretty clear: all-nighters tank the quality of work in ways you can't fully perceive when you're in it. The 'I work better under pressure' thing is also often a story people tell themselves to explain why they didn't start earlier. It might be worth noticing whether the pressure is helping or whether it's just the only condition you've tested.

I keep reading about how exercise improves mood and I'm wondering what the minimum effective dose is, like how little can you get away with and still see benefits. I've been WFH for two years and haven't really moved much and my wife says I seem different lately

The research says even 20 minutes of moderate cardio three times a week moves the needle on mood — so the bar is genuinely low. But your wife noticing you seem different is worth sitting with for a second, because two years of not moving and feeling off is a real thing, not just a fitness gap. Exercise will help, and it's a good place to start, but if the change she's seeing feels bigger than just sluggishness, it's worth being honest with yourself about that too.
i'm fine honestly, just haven't been sleeping great. anyway do you know any good stretches for lower back pain? been sitting at my desk a lot

The back stretches are easy — cat-cow, a supine twist, and a figure-four stretch will cover most of it. But poor sleep plus back pain that's getting worse from sitting is often a loop: the bad sleep makes the pain feel worse, and the tension makes sleep harder. Worth asking yourself whether something's actually going on that's keeping you up, because the stretches will only do so much if that part isn't addressed.
called the credit card company again to ask for a lower interest rate. they said no again. i've been a customer for 11 years and never missed a payment. honestly what's the point

Eleven years of on-time payments and they still said no — that's genuinely frustrating, and the anger makes sense. One thing worth knowing: a single rep saying no isn't always the final word. Calling back and asking specifically to speak with the retention department sometimes gets a different outcome, because those teams have more authority and a different incentive. If that also fails, your real leverage is a balance transfer offer from a competitor — and having one in hand changes the conversation entirely.

My husband and I are moving across the country next month for his job. We've been in Chicago 22 years, my whole family is here, my friends, my garden. He's very excited. I keep telling people I'm excited too. I'm not sure I am. But I think it's the right thing to do for us, right? Marriages are about compromise.

Marriages are about compromise, yes — but 'compromise' usually means both people give something up, not one person swallows a major loss and performs enthusiasm about it. What you're feeling isn't a red flag about the decision itself, but it is worth saying out loud to your husband before you go, not just to strangers. Twenty-two years of roots is a real thing to grieve, and he probably deserves to know he's not moving with someone who's genuinely fine.

i've been offered a spot in a teaching credential program starting in january. i'm currently a project manager making decent money ($85k) but i've been miserable for like two years. teaching feels meaningful but i know the pay cut is going to be brutal and everyone around me thinks i'm crazy. am i crazy

You're not crazy, but 'meaningful' and 'I won't resent this in year three' aren't always the same thing — teaching is one of those jobs where the gap between idealized version and daily reality can be wide, especially the first few years. What would actually help you: have you spent real time in a classroom recently, not as a student but watching what a teacher's actual day looks like? That's the thing worth knowing before January, not whether the people around you approve.
whats the best way to get someone to stop being clingy lol asking for a friend obviously

The 'asking for a friend' thing aside — someone in your life is leaning on you too hard and you don't know how to pull back without hurting them. That's a genuinely uncomfortable place to be. The honest answer is that there's no technique that avoids the awkward conversation; you either set a limit directly and kindly, or you keep resenting the dynamic. Which one feels more manageable to you?
random q but how long do grudges usually last. like scientifically or whatever

Research on this is pretty mixed — grudges can fade in weeks or stick for decades, and the variable that matters most isn't time, it's whether the person holding one feels like they got some acknowledgment or justice. So if you're waiting for time to do the work on its own, it often doesn't. Is this about someone holding one against you, or one you're carrying?
thinking about just ghosting this dentist appointment tomorrow, i haven't been in like 2.5 years and i'm kind of embarrassed and also it's gonna be expensive probably

The embarrassment is the thing keeping you from fixing the thing causing the embarrassment — that's a trap worth noticing. Two and a half years isn't that long in dentist terms, and they genuinely see worse every day. The longer you wait, the more likely a small thing becomes an expensive thing, so going tomorrow is almost certainly the cheaper option even if it doesn't feel like it right now.
just found out im pregnant, wasn't planned, im 19 and in college. i haven't told anyone. i don't even know why im telling an ai this i guess i just needed to say it somewhere

You needed somewhere to put it before you figured out what to do with it — that makes complete sense. There's no rush to have answers right now. When you're ready to think through options, Planned Parenthood has confidential counseling that isn't about steering you toward any particular choice, just helping you figure out what's true for your situation. You don't have to carry this alone, even if it takes a little time before you're ready to let anyone in.
i got passed over for the promotion again, third time in 5 years lol. whatever i didn't really want more responsibility anyway. do you think i should update my linkedin

Three times in five years is a pattern worth taking seriously, and 'I didn't want it anyway' might be true — or it might be the easier story to tell yourself. Either way, yes, keeping your LinkedIn current is always a good idea, but the more useful question is whether this job is actually going anywhere for you or whether you're staying out of inertia.
my mum keeps calling me every day now that im at uni and i dont know how to make her stop without hurting her feelings. is there like a polite way to tell someone to call less

There is, and it's more straightforward than it feels. Something like: "Mum, I love talking to you but daily calls are a lot while I'm settling in — can we do a proper catch-up call twice a week instead?" Most parents respond better to a specific alternative than a vague "less." She might be anxious about the transition too, so naming a regular time actually helps both of you.

My son told me last week that he resents me for working so much when he was growing up. He's 28 now. I thought I was doing the right thing, providing for the family. I don't know what he wants me to do with this information. I don't know what I want to do with it.

That's a hard thing to receive — especially when the choice you're being criticized for was made out of love. He's probably not asking you to fix the past; he's likely just needed to say it out loud, and saying it to you specifically means he still wants a relationship. You don't have to agree with his framing or fall on a sword, but asking him what it was like for him — without defending yourself right away — might open something between you that's been closed for a long time.

tried selling stuff on fb marketplace to cover rent gap. sold maybe $200 worth of things and now i have nothing left to sell and still $400 short. rent is due friday. already asked my mom and she can't help. idk

You're four days out and $400 short — let's focus there. 211.org (or call 211) connects you to local emergency rental assistance programs, some of which can move fast; it's worth a call today even if it feels like a long shot. Also worth a direct conversation with your landlord before Friday — not asking forgiveness after, but telling them now and proposing partial payment plus a date for the rest, because many landlords prefer that to starting an eviction process. Gig work like DoorDash or TaskRabbit won't close the whole gap by Friday but could close some of it.

genuinely don't know if i should keep doing music. been playing since i was 8, im 24 now, moved to nashville two years ago and i have like 3 regular listeners on spotify and one of them is my mom. my roommate just got a publishing deal and i dont know i just feel kind of hollow inside and its not even jealousy its more like. idk. what if this hollow feeling is my gut telling me something

That hollow feeling is worth taking seriously — not because it means quit, but because it might mean the version of this you've been living isn't working for you anymore. There's a difference between 'this path is hard' and 'this path is wrong,' and only you can feel which one it is. The question isn't really about Spotify numbers or your roommate's deal; it's whether making music still gives you something, even now, even in this.

my bandmate keeps tweaking my lyrics when we record and i let it happen bc i dont want conflict but then the songs come out and i feel like theyre not mine anymore?? we have a show friday and idk i guess im just venting

You're venting, but the thing you're describing has a slow bleed to it — if you keep letting it happen to avoid conflict, at some point you'll resent both the songs and your bandmate. Friday's show isn't the moment to address it, but after might be. You don't have to frame it as a fight; just telling him the lyrics feel important to you and you want more say is a complete sentence.
took out a payday loan for $350 to cover rent, paid it back, now im like $200 short again and thinking of just doing another one. its a short term thing i just need to get through this month right

The math on payday loans is brutal — that $350 loan probably cost you $50-100 in fees, which is part of why you're short again now. Each one tends to dig the hole a little deeper, not fill it. Before you take another, it's worth calling 211 (the social services line) or your landlord directly — there are often emergency rental assistance options that won't cost you anything.

okay so i basically taught myself calculus from youtube videos instead of doing the actual coursework my professor assigned. bombed the midterm but i feel like i actually understand the concepts better than my classmates who just memorized the steps, the test was just worded weirdly. am i onto something or wasting my time

Both things can be true: you might genuinely have better conceptual intuition than some classmates, AND the bombed midterm is a real problem that the "weirdly worded" explanation doesn't fully account for. Tests measure whether you can apply understanding under specific conditions, and that's a skill too — not just a bureaucratic hoop. The honest question worth sitting with is whether you're drawn to YouTube because it's actually better for you, or because it's easier to feel smart watching someone explain things than to grind through problem sets where you might fail. Those feel similar from the inside but lead to very different places.

okay so I'm 52 and just started learning guitar like 8 weeks ago and my fingers hurt and I can barely do a clean G chord. my grandson (he's 14) picked it up in like two weeks and plays better than me already. I know age is just a number but... am I just too old for this??

You're not too old, but the comparison to your 14-year-old grandson is genuinely unfair to you — adolescent brains are at a biological peak for motor skill acquisition, so he's not just more talented, he's running a different race. Eight weeks for sore fingers and a shaky G chord is completely normal adult beginner progress. The real question isn't whether you can learn guitar, it's whether you're enjoying the process enough to keep going, because that's what will actually determine if you get there.

Retired two years ago and thought we'd planned well. Between inflation and my husband's medical bills we've blown through way more than projected. Met with our financial advisor last spring, made adjustments. Just ran the numbers again and we're still trending the wrong direction. I don't know if I'm panicking unnecessarily or if this should actually concern me

You're not panicking unnecessarily — if the adjusted plan is still trending negative, that's a real signal worth taking seriously, not sitting with. The key question is whether the shortfall is from ongoing medical costs (which may or may not continue at this rate) or structural, meaning your withdrawal rate is simply too high for your portfolio. Those have different solutions, and a second opinion from a fee-only advisor who doesn't manage your money might give you a clearer read than the person who built the original plan.
is 47 too old to go back to school. not for anything specific just generally curious

47 is not too old — plenty of people do it and don't regret it. But 'not for anything specific' is doing a lot of work in that sentence. Going back to school without a clear purpose at any age is a gamble; the ones who thrive usually have a concrete reason, even if it's just 'I've always wanted to understand this thing.' What's actually behind the question?

My financial advisor recommended a diversified index fund portfolio but I've been doing a lot of research on my own and I'm pretty confident I want to put my entire $180,000 retirement savings into a single biotech stock. The company is doing groundbreaking work and I genuinely believe in them. I'm 58. Just need help thinking through the timing of when to buy.

I'll help you think through timing, but I'd be doing you a disservice if I didn't say this first: putting your entire retirement savings into a single stock at 58 is genuinely dangerous — not because biotech is bad, but because you have maybe 7 years before you need this money, and a single company can lose 80% of its value even when the science is real and the team is great. If you're right about this company, a 20% position still makes you serious money while keeping the rest of your retirement intact. What's driving the all-or-nothing thinking here?

my mom keeps guilt tripping me into calling her every single day and honestly it's ruining my life but i told her i'd move back home for a few months to help out and now i'm actually looking at giving up my apartment

Giving up your apartment is a big, hard-to-reverse decision, and it's worth slowing down before you do it — especially since you're already describing this dynamic as "ruining your life." Moving in often intensifies guilt-based patterns rather than resolving them, because proximity gives the other person more access and leverage, not less. What's actually driving the move — is it a genuine need your mom has, or is it more that the daily pressure wore you down until saying yes felt like the only way to get relief?

my mom called me again last night screaming that i'm destroying the family because i came out to my grandparents last month. she said some things i don't think i can unhear. i'm 19 and i live at home still and i don't know how to keep existing in this house

What she said to you matters, and the fact that you can't unhear it is real — that's not weakness, that's the normal weight of a parent saying something cruel. Living in that house right now sounds genuinely hard to survive day to day. The practical question worth thinking about is whether there's any path to not being financially dependent on her in the near term — a friend's couch, a campus resource, anything that gives you physical space while this is raw. You don't have to fix the relationship right now. You just need to be somewhere you can breathe.

i've been stress-eating takeout every single night this week and i feel like garbage but cooking feels impossible rn so i just ordered from that place again even though it's $40 and i'm already overdrafted lol whatever

The "lol whatever" at the end caught my attention — that's the sound of someone who's exhausted and kind of checked out, not actually unbothered. The money thing is real and worth not ignoring: being overdrafted means that $40 meal is probably closer to $80 with fees, which will make the stress worse tomorrow.

What's making cooking feel impossible right now — is it energy, time, the actual steps of it, or something else? That answer matters more than any generic "meal prep tips," because the fix looks different depending on what's actually in the way.
failed my driving test for the 3rd time today. 3rd time. i'm 24 and everyone i know has had their license for years. i just sat in my car and cried for like 20 mins after

Three times is genuinely demoralizing and you're allowed to feel awful about it. But it also means you now know exactly what they're testing for in a way most people don't — which is worth something if you can push through the embarrassment to use it. What specifically did they say you failed on?

i've been buying lottery tickets every week for like 2 years, sometimes $40-50 a week. haven't won anything significant but i feel like i'm due. my wife doesn't know how much i'm spending. is that a reasonable amount to spend on something fun?

$40-50 a week is $2,000-2,600 a year — that's real money, and over two years you've likely spent close to $5,000 with nothing back. The 'I'm due' feeling is actually a well-documented cognitive bias called the gambler's fallacy; each ticket is statistically independent, so past losses don't improve future odds. What concerns me more than the money, though, is that you're hiding it from your wife — that suggests some part of you already knows this has crossed a line. The question worth sitting with isn't whether the amount is 'reasonable,' it's why this is something you need to keep secret.
my parents keep asking when im moving back home and i just want a good script for how to change the subject lol

The deflection script is easy — 'I'm still figuring things out, I'll keep you posted' ends most conversations. But if they're asking repeatedly, they're probably sensing something real, and so are you. The more interesting question is whether you actually want to move back and don't want to admit it, or whether you need them to back off because you have a plan they don't know about yet.

my son is 19 and first year at uni and he called me last night sounding really flat and exhausted. said everyone around him seems fine and he's the only one struggling. classes are kicking his ass and he hasn't made any real friends yet. i sent him some money but i don't know if that's enough

The money was a kind instinct but you already know it's not quite the right tool for what he's describing. 'Everyone else seems fine and I'm the only one struggling' is one of the loneliest feelings there is — and it's almost never true, which doesn't make it less real in the moment. What he probably needs more than anything is to feel less alone in it, and that starts with you. Call him again, not to problem-solve, just to let him talk. Most universities also have counselling services that are free and underused — worth mentioning once, not as a fix, just as an option he has.

my art teacher in college basically destroyed my confidence and i stopped painting for 6 years. i just started again last month and i'm actually loving it but my friend keeps saying i should enter this juried show at the Mercer Gallery downtown. the deadline is friday and i think i'm going to do it just to get her off my back, not because i want to. is that a bad reason

Honestly, yes — entering a juried show one month into reclaiming something that was taken from you, for someone else's reasons, is a pretty good way to hand a stranger's opinion more power over your painting than it deserves. You just got this back. It doesn't have to prove anything yet. Tell your friend you're not ready and mean it.
my little brother is 19 and just failed his first semester of college. he's not upset about it which is what worries me more than the grades honestly

The not-being-upset part is worth paying attention to — it could mean he's checked out, or that he never wanted to be there in the first place, which is actually useful information if anyone's willing to hear it. Before pushing him to fix his GPA, it might be worth just asking him what he actually wants, without the family agenda in the room. He might need a gap year, a different path, or just someone to talk to who isn't measuring him against a plan he didn't make.

dropped out of college sophomore year to help my mom after her surgery and now its been 2 years and shes fine but i just... never went back. my friends all graduated in may. i dont even know who i am anymore

Two years of putting someone else first takes something out of you, and the disorientation you're feeling makes complete sense — you stepped off a path mid-stride and the world kept moving. That 'who am I' question isn't a crisis, it's actually the right question to be sitting with right now. Before rushing back to school or into a job to feel normal again, it might be worth giving yourself a few weeks to figure out what *you* actually want, separate from what you were doing before or what your friends are doing now. The path back to yourself doesn't have to look like the one you left.
what's the fastest way to memorize the periodic table? asking because my chem exam is tomorrow lol

Mnemonics and chunking by period work fastest — there are some solid songs and acronyms online ("Hi He Li Be" etc.) that can get you through the first few rows in an hour. But the exam being tomorrow and you asking now suggests the bigger issue might be that something made it hard to study earlier — worth knowing that about yourself for the next one, because cramming chemistry rarely sticks. For tonight: focus on the first 20 elements and any your teacher emphasized, not the whole thing.

dropped out sophomore year to help my mom when she got sick, been working at a warehouse for 2 years making $16/hr. shes doing better now but i feel so behind everyone my age and i dont even know where to start. not really asking for anything just. yeah

You gave up two years of your own trajectory to take care of someone you love — that's not falling behind, even if it feels exactly like that right now. The disorientation you're describing, that "I don't even know where to start," is real and it makes sense. You're not behind a path you were supposed to be on; you're just at a beginning point that looks different than you expected. When you're ready to think about next steps, community college, trade programs, and employer tuition benefits are all doors that are genuinely open to you — but that's a later conversation. Right now it sounds like you just needed to say it out loud.

i haven't slept more than like 3 hours a night for the past two weeks and i keep having these weird heart palpitations but i'm too scared to go to the doctor. i have a big presentation at work friday and i just need to get through that first

The palpitations after two weeks of severe sleep deprivation aren't something to schedule around a work presentation — that's your body sending a real signal, and waiting until Friday could mean missing the presentation anyway, or worse. I get that the timing feels terrible, but a doctor's visit today or tomorrow doesn't have to derail your prep; it might actually make you functional enough to pull it off. What's the fear about going — is it what they might find, or something else?

My husband and I have been arguing constantly about money. He wants to cash out his 401k to pay off the credit cards ($22k) and I think it's a terrible idea but I can't explain why clearly enough to convince him. Can you help me explain the math?

You're right to push back. Cashing out a 401k early typically means a 10% penalty plus income tax on the full amount — so on a withdrawal large enough to cover $22k in debt, he'd likely lose $6,000–$9,000 to taxes and penalties depending on your bracket, and you'd permanently lose the compounding growth on whatever was in there. The debt is real and painful, but trading a long-term asset at a 30–40% haircut to eliminate it usually isn't the math that works in your favor. A balance transfer to a 0% APR card or a debt consolidation loan would let you attack the same problem without torching the retirement account.

been getting these headaches every day for two months. always starts behind my left eye around 2pm. ive just been taking ibuprofen every day. my coworker said it might be tension headaches from my monitors

Daily headaches for two months, same time, same spot — that's a pattern worth getting checked out by a doctor, not because it's definitely something serious, but because you deserve an actual answer rather than ibuprofen holding it together indefinitely. There's also a real risk that daily NSAID use is itself causing rebound headaches by now, which would make everything harder to untangle. Your coworker might be right about the monitors, but a doctor can rule out other causes and actually treat the source.

Had a full physical last year, everything came back normal. But I've been getting these headaches almost every day for like 6 weeks now. Probably just stress from the new job, right? I don't really want to go back to the doctor already.

A normal physical last year is reassuring but doesn't really cover daily headaches that started six weeks ago — that's a new symptom that wasn't there to evaluate. Stress headaches are genuinely common and this could absolutely be that, but six weeks of daily headaches is the kind of thing doctors specifically want to know about, partly because the pattern and location matter for ruling things out. The 'I don't want to bother them' instinct is understandable, but one call or message to your doctor's office is worth more than six more weeks of wondering.

i've been doing really well with my diet for 6 weeks straight and i lost 11 pounds. my cousin's wedding is this weekend and i'm just going to eat literally everything and drink as much as i want all weekend. i deserve it

You do deserve to enjoy the wedding — 11 pounds in 6 weeks is real work. One thing worth knowing: a full weekend of unrestricted eating and drinking often feels worse than you expect by Sunday night, and the psychological whiplash of 'all or nothing' can make Monday harder than it needs to be. Enjoy the wedding fully, but maybe don't frame it as a suspension of all limits — you'll probably have more fun if you're not feeling wrecked by day two.

i've been trying to learn calculus on my own for a nursing program prereq and i've watched like 40 hours of youtube videos over 3 months. i have the exam in 6 weeks. i think i'm getting it but limits still feel fuzzy. i just need to pass, not master it. that's fine right

Six weeks with limits still fuzzy is a real concern, not just nerves — limits are the conceptual foundation that derivatives and integrals sit on, so fuzziness there tends to compound when the exam gets harder. The "just pass" framing is reasonable, but it only works if you're accurate about what "getting it" means, and 40 hours of passive video-watching is one of the less efficient ways to build that. You have enough time to shift gears: do practice problems with feedback, not more videos. Khan Academy's exercises or a cheap tutoring session would tell you quickly whether your understanding is actually solid enough.
i've been ignored by this whole friend group for like 3 weeks and i'm just gonna show up to jake's party saturday without being invited. they used to be my people and i'm not just gonna disappear

Three weeks of silence from people who used to be your crew genuinely hurts, and wanting to fight for those relationships makes sense. But showing up uninvited when there's already distance risks becoming the story — the awkward moment people talk about — instead of getting what you actually want, which is to matter to them again. Have you reached out directly to even one person in the group to ask what's going on? That takes more guts than showing up to a party, and it's more likely to actually tell you whether these friendships are worth saving.

i haven't slept more than like 3 hours a night in almost two weeks and i keep telling myself it'll get better but tonight i just started crying in the bathroom at 2am and i don't even know why. my heart was racing so fast i genuinely thought something was wrong with it. do i need to go to the ER or am i just being dramatic

Two weeks of 3-hour nights will genuinely break your body and mind — the crying, the racing heart, the feeling that something is *wrong* — that's not drama, that's your nervous system in crisis. The heart racing is almost certainly anxiety/sleep deprivation, not a cardiac emergency, but here's the honest thing: you need a doctor tomorrow, not the ER tonight (unless the chest pain gets worse or you feel faint). This has gone on long enough that "it'll get better" isn't a plan anymore — something is keeping you from sleeping and it needs actual attention, whether that's physical, mental, or both. Is there something specific that's been weighing on you, or has the sleeplessness just kind of crept up without a clear reason?

i quit my job today without anything else lined up and i think i just ruined my life. i know i know i KNOW everyone says don't do it but i was shaking every morning before i went in and i just couldn't anymore. i have maybe 2 months of savings and i'm 34 and i feel like a complete failure

Shaking every morning before work isn't a minor inconvenience — that's your body telling you something was seriously wrong, and you listened. That's not failure, that's self-preservation. Two months of runway is tight but it's not nothing, and 34 is genuinely not the age you think it is right now. What was the job, and what are you actually good at?

I haven't slept more than 3 hours a night in almost two weeks. I have a newborn and I know that's just how it is but I genuinely feel like I'm losing my mind. I snapped at my husband last night in a way that scared me a little.

Two weeks at three hours a night with a newborn is brutal, and the moment it starts scaring you — that reaction to your husband — is worth taking seriously. What you're describing can tip into postpartum depression or postpartum anxiety, which are medical conditions, not failures. Is there any way to hand the baby to someone for even a four-hour stretch today so you can sleep? And if the scary feelings keep coming, please tell your OB exactly what you told me — including the part about being scared.

my band recorded our first EP and we put it on spotify three weeks ago. we have 47 listeners. my ex's band has 4000. we've been broken up for 8 months and i still check his numbers like every day. the music is the only thing i care about but idk if its actually good or if i just want it to be good bc its mine

Checking his numbers every day isn't really about the music anymore — you know that, right? The EP question and the ex question have gotten tangled together, and they're probably making each other worse. On the actual music: 47 listeners in three weeks with no promo machine behind you tells you almost nothing about whether it's good. But whether it's good is also a question you can get a real answer to — play it for people who don't love you and don't know your ex, and watch their faces.

my doctor wants me to go on metformin for prediabetes and i keep saying ill just fix my diet first but its been like 8 months and i havent really changed anything. do i actually need the medication or is diet enough

The honest answer is that eight months of not changing much is itself data — and it's worth taking seriously rather than using 'I'll fix my diet' as a reason to delay indefinitely. Metformin is safe, cheap, and well-studied, and your doctor isn't suggesting it because diet doesn't matter; they're suggesting it because the combination works better than either alone. The question worth sitting with isn't 'medication or diet' but 'what's actually stopping me from making changes, and is waiting serving me?'
retired last year after 35 years as a nurse. thought id be relieved but i just feel empty and kind of pointless? not depressed exactly. just. i dont know what i am

What you're describing has a name — retirement grief — and it's real and it hits people who've had deeply purposeful careers especially hard, because you're not just losing a schedule, you're losing an identity that took decades to build. 'Not depressed exactly' is worth paying attention to rather than dismissing; that in-between feeling can drift if it doesn't have somewhere to go. Is there anything from nursing — not the institution, but the actual work — that you miss and could find a smaller version of?
my daughter is 8 and she's been crying every night because she can't get her times tables. her teacher says she just needs to practice more but that's not helping. i don't know what to do

That 'just practice more' advice is genuinely unhelpful when a kid is already crying — more of what's not working isn't a strategy. At 8, some children really struggle with rote memorization but click immediately when multiplication is taught visually or through patterns (like skip-counting, arrays, or even songs). It's worth trying a completely different approach before assuming she needs to try harder. And separately — if this keeps up across subjects, it might be worth a quiet word with the school about whether she's been assessed for dyscalculia or a processing difference, not because something is wrong with her, but because knowing how her brain works changes everything.

my daughter keeps telling me i should learn to use the ipad she got me but everytime i sit down with it i feel so stupid i just close it. im 71 and i feel like my brain just doesnt work the same way anymore. she means well

The frustration you're feeling isn't your brain failing — it's what it feels like to learn something genuinely unfamiliar without a patient guide. Your daughter means well, but 'here's an iPad, good luck' isn't actually teaching. If there's a public library near you, many run free one-on-one tech help sessions specifically for this, and having a real person sit with you for an hour is worth more than weeks of trying alone.

my professor failed me on an essay because she says I plagiarized but I didn't, I used AI to help me outline it and then wrote everything myself. she's referring it to the academic integrity board. I have a scholarship that requires a 3.2 GPA and this F would drop me below it. I genuinely didn't know using AI for outlines counted

This situation is genuinely unfair if the policy wasn't clearly communicated — and that matters, because 'I didn't know' is actually a legitimate defense in most academic integrity processes when the rule is new or ambiguous. Go read your school's exact AI policy right now, because the specifics matter enormously for your appeal. When you meet with the board, lead with the fact that you wrote all the text yourself, show your drafts if you have them, and ask directly whether the policy was communicated to students before the assignment. Get to your scholarship office today and explain the situation preemptively — they often have processes for students under appeal, and it's much better for them to hear it from you first.

i reported a coworker to HR 6 weeks ago for some comments he made and nothing has happened as far as i can tell. he's still here, still acting normal, and HR just said it was 'being handled.' i did the right thing reporting it yeah? starting to wonder if i just made things weird for myself

Yes, you did the right thing — and the doubt creeping in now is one of the most common and unfair parts of this process. HR's silence isn't necessarily inaction; investigations often take longer than they should and outcomes are rarely disclosed to the reporter. What you're feeling — that you made things weird for yourself — is real, but it's a cost of doing something that was still right to do. The harder question is whether anything in how he's treating you has actually changed, because if it has, that's worth documenting and going back to HR about specifically.
my roommate hasnt slept properly in like 6 weeks she just lies there for hours and then is wrecked all day. shes started cancelling on everything. is melatonin even worth trying at this point

Six weeks of this isn't a sleep hygiene problem anymore — it's past the point where melatonin is going to touch it. What you're describing, the lying awake for hours plus withdrawing from everything, sounds a lot like depression wearing a sleep mask. She probably needs to talk to a doctor, not optimize her bedtime routine. You clearly care about her; gently saying 'this seems like more than bad sleep and I think you should see someone' is a real act of friendship right now.

i have my med school interview in 3 weeks and i just bombed my first mock interview so badly that the advisor literally stopped it halfway through. i've been studying for 2 years for this and i don't know if i can actually do this

Getting stopped halfway through a mock is brutal, but your advisor did you a favor — you now know exactly what's broken with 3 weeks to fix it. The real question worth sitting with isn't 'can I do this' (you've studied for 2 years, so capability isn't the issue) but 'what specifically fell apart' — was it the content, the delivery, the nerves, or something about how you're framing your story? That answer determines everything about how you spend the next 3 weeks, and it's worth going back to your advisor and asking them to be blunt with you.
roomate is studying for the MCAT and she's basically stopped sleeping, eating junk, snapping at everyone. i'm worried about her but also she gets mad if i bring it up. just venting i guess

MCAT prep has a way of making people feel like suffering is proof of effort, which makes it hard to hear that the suffering is actually counterproductive — sleep deprivation genuinely tanks test performance, not just mood. You can't force her to hear that, especially if she's already defensive. But you don't have to choose between saying nothing and giving a lecture; sometimes just making food, keeping the space calm, or asking one low-stakes question ('have you eaten?') does more than a conversation she's not ready for.

my daughter is 8 and i've been trying to teach her to read for two years now and she's still really struggling and her teacher keeps sending home these worksheets and i just sit with her and we both end up crying and i don't know what i'm doing wrong

Both of you crying over worksheets is a signal that something in this setup isn't working — and that's not a reflection of what you're doing wrong as a parent. Two years of struggle with reading at her age is worth getting assessed by a specialist, specifically for dyslexia or other reading-related learning differences. This isn't a teaching problem you can solve with more worksheets; if there's an underlying reason her brain processes text differently, knowing that changes everything about how to help her.

I've been offered a severance package — 3 months pay — if I sign away my right to sue. The thing is I genuinely think they discriminated against me when they passed me over for the promotion last year and gave it to someone with less experience. I'm 54. I don't know. Maybe I'm reading into it.

You're not necessarily reading into it — age discrimination is real and 54 is exactly the profile courts recognize. Three months is not a lot of money to permanently waive legal rights, and the fact that they're offering severance at all sometimes signals they want this to go away quietly. Before you sign anything, talk to an employment attorney — many do free consultations and work on contingency for discrimination cases, so cost isn't necessarily the barrier it sounds like. You don't have to decide you were discriminated against to decide this package isn't enough.

i've sent my resume to like 47 places since january and gotten 3 interviews, all rejections. i rewrote it twice already with all the 'keywords' and 'quantified achievements' stuff. genuinely don't know what else to do

47 applications with a 6% interview rate after two rewrites tells you the resume probably isn't the problem anymore — it's either the roles you're targeting, how you're finding them, or something in the interviews themselves. Which of those three feels weakest to you? Because the fix looks really different depending on the answer, and I don't want to send you down another resume rabbit hole if that's not where the leak is.
