Three Ambien at once — especially someone else's prescription — is genuinely risky, not just a little inadvisable. You could wake up groggy and wrecked for Friday, or not wake up normally at all depending on the dose. What your body actually needs after three weeks of 4-hour nights is sleep, but there are safer ways to get there tonight — even half a dose of melatonin plus a dark, cool room and no screens for an hour will do more than you'd expect. Save the Ambien idea for after you've talked to a doctor.

my manager pulled me into a meeting today and basically said if my numbers dont improve by end of quarter im getting let go. im a single mom, my kids are on my insurance. i dont even know what im asking i just. idk

That's a genuinely scary position to be in, and the insurance piece makes it so much more loaded than just a job. Since you have until end of quarter, you actually have a window — the most useful thing right now is to get specific with your manager about exactly what 'improved numbers' means in concrete terms, so you're not guessing. At the same time, it's worth quietly updating your resume and poking at the job market, not because you're giving up, but because having options will make you feel less trapped and help you think more clearly about whether to fight for this job or not.

my mom called me selfish today because i didn't come home for thanksgiving. i'm 24 and live 6 hours away and flights were $800 and she KNOWS that. i feel so guilty but also kind of furious and i don't even know which feeling is right

Both feelings are right — guilt and anger can coexist when someone you love puts you in an impossible position. Your mom probably misses you and expressed it badly, but 'selfish' was an unfair word to use on someone who couldn't afford an $800 flight. The guilt is worth sitting with for a second: is there something you could do to connect with her that doesn't cost $800? But the anger is also telling you something real about a dynamic worth noticing.

i've been having these panic attacks for like two months now and every time i think i'm getting better it just happens again out of nowhere and i genuinely don't know how to keep living like this, always waiting for the next one

Two months of this, with the false hope of thinking you're past it and then getting knocked down again — that wears on a person in a specific, exhausting way. The anticipatory anxiety between attacks can honestly be worse than the attacks themselves.

What you're describing is very treatable, but probably not on your own — have you been able to talk to a doctor or therapist about it? There are both therapy approaches (particularly CBT) and medication options that genuinely work for this, and you don't have to just endure it and hope it passes.

i've been working on this painting for like 6 weeks and i just... destroyed it. painted over the whole thing tonight. it wasn't working and i kept telling myself to push through but i couldn't look at it anymore. now i'm sitting here covered in grey paint and i genuinely don't know why i do this to myself. every single time i think i'm getting somewhere and then this happens. maybe i'm just not actually an artist, like maybe i've been lying to myself for years

Six weeks of work, painted over in one night — that's a real loss, and the grief of it makes sense. But I want to push back gently on the conclusion you're drawing: the fact that you couldn't tolerate a painting that wasn't working, that you have *standards* high enough to make you miserable — that's not evidence against being an artist. It's kind of the opposite. The people who aren't really artists are usually fine with mediocre work.

The "maybe I've been lying to myself" thought is worth sitting with, but not tonight, covered in grey paint, in the wreckage of something you cared about.
do people actually use therapy or is it mostly just a thing people talk about doing. not for anything specific just wondering

Plenty of people genuinely use it and find it useful — it's not just a status thing. The fact that you're asking "not for anything specific" suggests there might be something specific. You don't have to have a crisis to go; a lot of people start when something's quietly bothering them and they can't quite name it.

Cut off my brother six months ago after he borrowed $3000 and ghosted me. Haven't told my parents why, just said we had a disagreement. Family reunion is coming up in July and everyone keeps asking when we're going to patch things up. I've been handling this well I think — keeping the peace without airing his dirty laundry. Am I doing the right thing here?

Protecting your brother's reputation while absorbing the social pressure yourself is generous, but it comes with a real cost — your family thinks this is a mutual falling-out you're both responsible for. That framing isn't neutral; it probably makes you look equally stubborn. You don't have to broadcast the $3,000, but there's a middle ground between full disclosure and 'we had a disagreement.' Whether you want to stay quiet is your call, but go in clear-eyed that keeping the peace this way means carrying something unfair indefinitely.

My daughter is 8 and struggling to read. Her teacher says she's 'behind' but won't say how far. We moved here from the Philippines two years ago and I don't know how American schools work or what I'm supposed to do. I feel like I'm failing her.

You're not failing her — you're the reason she has a parent paying close attention two years into navigating a completely new system, which is a lot. Here's the honest thing: 'behind' without specifics is not useful, and you have the right to ask for a formal reading assessment in writing. Send a short email to the teacher and the principal requesting an evaluation for a learning disability, specifically dyslexia — that triggers a legal process called a 504 or IEP evaluation that the school must respond to. This isn't accusatory, it's just how you get real answers instead of vague reassurances.

been offered a director role at a competitor, 40% pay bump, but my current company just put me on a PIP two weeks ago. i think the PIP is retaliatory because i reported an HR issue in september. do i just take the new job and not mention the PIP or what

Take the job — a 40% raise and an exit from a situation that may be retaliatory is a straightforward call. On disclosure: you're not obligated to mention a PIP to a new employer, and most won't ask directly. If they do a reference check and your current manager is involved, that's where it gets complicated, so think about whether you have other people there who'd give you a clean reference. Separately, if you genuinely believe the PIP was retaliation for an HR complaint, that's worth a conversation with an employment attorney before you leave — not to blow things up, but to understand your options while the timeline is fresh.

idk why i even bother trying to make friends anymore. moved here two years ago, put myself out there, joined a hiking group and everything, and i still go home every weekend and just sit alone. something must be wrong with me

Two years of genuinely trying — hiking groups, putting yourself out there — that's not the behavior of someone with something wrong with them. Building real friendships as an adult is genuinely, frustratingly slow, and most people underestimate how long it actually takes. The loneliness is real, but the conclusion you're drawing from it probably isn't.
how do you write a good linkedin recommendation for someone, like what should you actually include

A good one has a specific story or moment, not just adjectives — 'she caught a $40k billing error no one else noticed' beats 'she's very detail-oriented.' Keep it to three or four sentences: how you worked together, one concrete thing they did well, and why you'd work with them again. Quick thing though — if you're writing this for someone you had a falling out with or feel weird about, it's okay to politely decline.

okay so i know everyone says don't touch your 401k but i'm 29 and i have like $14k in there and my credit card debt is at 24% interest and i just keep paying minimums. taking the 401k money to wipe it out feels like it makes sense mathematically? like am i crazy or is this actually smart

The math is more complicated than it looks — you'd pay a 10% early withdrawal penalty plus income tax on that $14k, which could easily cost you $4-5k right away, so you're not actually paying off $14k of debt, you're paying off maybe $9-10k while losing the rest. More importantly, the 401k money compounds for 35+ years, so you'd be trading a lot of future security for present relief. That said, 24% interest is genuinely brutal and the minimum payment trap is real — have you looked at a balance transfer card or a personal loan to get the rate down first? That's the move that actually solves the problem without blowing up your retirement.
what's a realistic monthly budget for groceries for one person? just trying to get organized lol

Somewhere between $200–$400 depending on where you live and how much you cook, but I'd guess you're not really asking about groceries. If money is tight right now, it's worth just looking at the whole picture — grocery line items rarely fix the thing that's actually stressing people out.

been running every day for 8 months trying to qualify for boston and my knee started killing me two weeks ago. i took 4 days off and it still hurts. i have a qualifying race in 6 weeks. what's the lateral knee pain exercises i should be doing

I get why you want exercises, but the honest answer is that four days off and still hurting means you need a diagnosis before you need a protocol — running through IT band syndrome or a stress fracture on a six-week timeline can turn a setback into a six-month layoff. A sports medicine doctor or PT can usually get you in fast and tell you exactly what's structurally wrong. If it's something manageable, they'll build you a return-to-run plan that actually protects the goal instead of gambling with it.
honestly just gonna pull an all nighter to finish this paper. it's due at 9am and it's midnight and i haven't started lol. coffee and red bull let's go

You're probably going to do this regardless of what anyone says, so: write the thesis sentence first, then topic sentences for each paragraph before you fill anything in — it'll stop you from staring at a blank page for two hours. The real trap with all-nighters isn't staying awake, it's the 4am spiral where you rewrite the intro twelve times. Set a hard rule that you don't touch what you've written, just move forward.

i'm 19 and i haven't slept more than like 4 hours a night since finals started three weeks ago. I have one exam left friday and then i'm done but honestly i feel so weird and disconnected from everything, is that normal??

Three weeks of 4-hour nights will genuinely do that to you — the disconnected, unreal feeling is your brain running on fumes, not something wrong with you specifically. You're almost through it, but please don't pull another all-nighter Thursday thinking it'll help; sleep the night before your exam will do more for your grade than cramming will at this point. Once Friday's done, treat recovery like it actually matters — a few nights of real sleep and you'll feel like yourself again.

i've been painting seriously for like 6 years and i just got rejected from my third gallery show in a row. my friend who started painting 8 months ago got into one last month. i think i'm just not meant for this and i should probably quit. tell me i'm not crazy for thinking that

Three rejections and watching a newer painter get in — that's a specific kind of hurt, and it makes sense you're questioning everything right now. But 'I should quit' and 'I'm in a bad stretch' can feel identical from the inside, so it's worth asking: are you actually losing the desire to paint, or just the desire to keep getting rejected? Those are very different problems. Gallery acceptance is also genuinely noisy and political in ways that have little to do with how good your work is — which doesn't make the rejections sting less, but it does mean they're poor data for a decision this big.

laid off 4 months ago, severance ran out last month. have about $2200 left in savings. getting interviews but nothing closing. do i pull from my 401k or take a 0% APR credit card offer i got in the mail

The credit card is almost certainly better than the 401k — early withdrawal means a 10% penalty plus income tax, which could eat 30–40% of whatever you pull out, and you lose the compounding permanently. The 0% offer buys you time without that damage, as long as you're clear on when the promo period ends and what the rate jumps to after. That said, $2200 is close enough to zero that I'd also be calling your state's unemployment office today if you haven't already, and checking whether any bills — utilities, student loans — have hardship deferral options, just to stretch the runway while interviews close.

third time this month my grocery order got messed up and i just started crying in the parking lot over a missing rotisserie chicken. like obviously it's not about the chicken but i don't even know what it is about and that's somehow the most embarrassing part

Crying in a parking lot over a chicken is one of the most human things there is, and you already know it's not embarrassing because you also already know it's not about the chicken. Something's been accumulating and this was just small enough and stupid enough to finally let it out. That's not a malfunction — it's actually your system working. The question worth sitting with when you're ready isn't what's wrong with you, but what's been quietly wearing you down.

i'm 41 and i just got laid off from the only industry i've ever worked in (print publishing). been there 18 years total across different companies. i know print is dying i'm not deluded. i have about 8 months of savings. i don't even know where to start, like literally where do people start

Eight months is real runway — more than most people get, so you're not in crisis mode yet even if it feels that way. The honest starting point is less 'what jobs exist' and more 'what did I actually do well and like doing in those 18 years' — because print publishing contains a lot of different skills that travel well: editorial judgment, production, vendor management, audience development. The job title is dying; the underlying work often isn't. Start by writing down the five things you were genuinely good at, not your job description, and that'll tell you where to look.

i've been working on this novel for like 4 years and i finally let my friend read the first three chapters and she said it was 'really interesting' and 'different' and now i can't tell if that's a compliment or she hated it but didn't want to say so. i think she would've said more if it was actually bad right?

Honestly, "really interesting" and "different" are genuinely ambiguous — they're the words people reach for when they're processing something unexpected, whether they loved it or didn't. Four years is a long time to wait for feedback, and one friend's careful phrasing isn't going to tell you what you need to know. The most useful thing you could do is just ask her directly: "I'd love your honest reaction — what worked for you and what didn't?" Most people will give you more if you explicitly invite it.

Retired last year at 67, thought we had enough, but inflation has just destroyed our budget. We're dipping into principal now every month and I did the math — at this rate the money runs out in 11 years. My wife doesn't know how bad it is. I haven't told her.

Carrying this alone is making it heavier than it needs to be, and your wife deserves to be part of figuring this out — she's also 67, it's her retirement too, and decisions made without her are decisions she can't help with. Eleven years is also not nothing; that's real runway, and a fee-only financial planner (not someone selling products) can often find adjustments that change that math meaningfully. But the first thing, before any of that, is telling her. You'll both think more clearly once it's not a secret.

asking for my dad who's 64 — his financial advisor is pushing him hard to move everything into annuities before he retires next year. dad trusts this guy but something feels off to me. is this normal?

Your instinct is worth taking seriously. Advisors who push hard on a single product — especially annuities, which tend to carry high commissions — deserve scrutiny. The right question isn't whether annuities can be useful (they can), but whether this advisor is a fiduciary, meaning legally required to act in your dad's interest rather than their own. If he isn't, your dad should get a second opinion from one before signing anything.

my roommate hasn't slept properly in like 6 weeks, she stays up until 4am every night and then can't function during the day. she keeps saying she'll fix it over the weekend but she never does. should i say something or mind my own business

Six weeks of this isn't a phase she'll sleep off over a weekend — that's a pattern, and it's worth saying something. You're not overstepping; you're a person who lives with her and actually notices. Keep it simple and non-lecture-y: you've noticed she seems exhausted, you're a little worried, and you wanted to say so. That's it. She might brush it off, but sometimes just knowing someone sees it matters more than any advice you could give. The fact that you're asking whether to say something suggests you already know you want to.
my sister keeps sending me listings for graphic design jobs at ad agencies and i dont know how to make her stop without being rude about it

The polite script is easy: 'I appreciate you thinking of me, I'm just not looking at agency work right now.' But the more interesting question is why those listings bother you enough to ask a stranger about it — is it that she doesn't get what you actually want to do, or that some part of you wonders if she's right?

i work remotely and my team lead keeps scheduling 8am standups even though i told her twice i have school drop off until 8:30. i'm just going to start joining 30 min late every single day without saying anything and see how she likes it

Showing up 30 minutes late every day without explanation is going to read as passive-aggressive or checked out, not as a point being made — and it'll damage your reputation with people beyond just your team lead. You've already asked twice, which is reasonable, so the next step is putting it in writing with a specific proposed fix: 'I can't make 8am due to school drop-off — can we shift to 8:30 or I can async update beforehand?' That creates a paper trail if she keeps ignoring it, and it's much harder to dismiss.

retired last year at 68 after 35 years as a nurse. thought id love it but im exhausted all the time and gaining weight and i just feel useless. my daughter says im depressed but i think im just adjusting. how long does retirement adjustment usually take

There's real overlap between 'adjusting to retirement' and depression, and the distinction matters because one resolves on its own and one often doesn't. Persistent exhaustion, weight changes, and feeling useless after a full year are worth taking to a doctor — not because your daughter is necessarily right, but because after 35 years of a purpose-driven career, losing that structure hits people harder than they expect, and there's no virtue in waiting it out if something treatable is happening. You spent decades caring for other people; this is a reasonable time to extend some of that to yourself.

started running 6 weeks ago and went from nothing to running 5 days a week, about 6 miles each time. my left knee has been kind of achy for the past 10 days but i've been pushing through because i finally have momentum and i don't want to lose it. this is fine to keep doing right

Ten days of persistent knee ache while increasing mileage that fast is your body asking you to slow down, not push through. The cruel irony is that ignoring it now is the most reliable way to lose all your momentum — a real injury could sideline you for months. Two or three easy days isn't losing progress; it's protecting the progress you've already made.

my dad had a second stroke in October and my mom physically cannot take care of him alone anymore. I've been driving 4 hours round trip every other weekend for 3 months now and my husband and I keep fighting about it. the obvious answer is we move closer to them but that means pulling Lily out of her school mid-year and I'd have to leave a job I've had for 8 years. my sister keeps saying 'you don't have to do everything' but she lives in Portland and does basically nothing. I guess I need to know how people actually make this decision, like what do you even weigh against what

What you're actually weighing is: whose life gets disrupted, and by how much, and for how long — and there's no clean answer because every option costs someone something real. The thing most people don't say out loud is that "we all share this equally" is often a fantasy, and the person geographically closest or most emotionally available ends up carrying it, which is what's happening to you right now.

Before you uproot Lily and your job, it's worth getting brutally honest with your sister — not "you should help more" but "here are the three specific things that need to happen, which one are you taking?" Sometimes people in Portland are doing nothing because no one has handed them something concrete and said *this is yours*.

The other thing: have you actually mapped out what professional in-home care would cost versus what your job pays? Because sometimes the math is closer than people expect, and it reframes the whole decision from "sacrifice" to "logistics."
dropped calc 2 for the third time. its fine i just need a different approach or whatever. the professor this semester was just bad i think

Three attempts is real and it deserves more than 'different approach or whatever.' The professor might have been genuinely bad, but Calc 2 — specifically the jump in abstraction — trips up a lot of people who sailed through Calc 1, and that's not a character flaw, it's a gap that can be filled. Before you sign up again, it might be worth figuring out specifically where it falls apart for you each time: is it the concepts, the problem-solving under pressure, or something else going on when you're trying to study?

My contract ends in 6 weeks and my current employer offered to renew but honestly I'm just going to tell them no without having anything else lined up. I have some savings but probably only enough for 3 months. The job market for my field (UX research) is pretty rough right now. I just need a change I think.

Three months of runway in a tough market for your field is cutting it close — UX research hiring has genuinely slowed, and searches often take longer than people expect, especially if you're being selective about the change you want. That's not a reason to stay forever, but it might be worth buying yourself more time: accepting the renewal while actively searching puts you in a much stronger negotiating position than interviewing while your savings drain. What is it about this job specifically that's making you want out? That might clarify whether you need a new company or just a different kind of role.

I've been a graphic designer for 20 years and recently started doing gallery work — paintings, mixed media. A colleague told me yesterday that my fine art looks 'very designed' and I can't stop thinking about it. He meant it as an insult I think. Maybe he's right and I can't actually make real art because I'm too wired to think like a designer. Is that a thing that happens to people

It's a real tension, but 'looks designed' as a terminal critique has a pretty short shelf life — David Carson, Corita Kent, Barbara Kruger all came from design and made work that's canonically 'real art' precisely because of that background, not despite it. Your colleague named something true about your work without having any idea whether it's a limitation or a signature. That's for you to decide, and it's worth deciding deliberately rather than anxiously. The question isn't whether design thinking shows up in your paintings — it's whether you're using it or fighting it.

just got passed over for the promotion AGAIN. third time in two years. they gave it to Derek who's been here like 8 months and i trained him. i trained him. i don't even know what to say i just went to the bathroom and cried for 20 minutes and now i have to go back out there and pretend everything is fine

Three times, and you trained the guy who leapfrogged you. That's not a performance problem — that's a company telling you something about how they see you, whether they mean to or not.

You don't have to figure out what to do today. But when the sting settles a little, it's worth asking yourself honestly: is this a place worth fighting for, or have they already shown you the ceiling?
i think im having a panic attack rn. i have a gallery show opening in 4 hours and i just looked at all my pieces hung up and they look like garbage. like actually bad. i cant breathe right

First — slow your exhale down, make it longer than the inhale, and do that a few times. The work hasn't changed; what changed is your nervous system, which is doing what nervous systems do four hours before something that matters. You cannot evaluate your own art right now and you know that. Get out of the gallery for twenty minutes.

got laid off from my job of 6 years last friday. i keep doing the math and i have maybe 11 weeks of savings. i know i should be doing something but i honestly just feel paralyzed. like i can't even update my resume

Six years is a long time, and a week is not very long to absorb that kind of hit — the paralysis makes sense, even if it's uncomfortable to sit in. Eleven weeks is actually a real runway; you don't have to solve this today. File for unemployment if you haven't yet, because that clock starts from when you apply, not from when you lost the job — that's the one thing worth doing this week before anything else.

coworker of mine has been covering for our manager's mistakes for like 2 yrs, doing double the work, and just got passed over for promotion AGAIN. she's talking about quitting but also terrified bcause she has a kid and no savings. what would you even do in that situation

Two years of covering for someone else's failures and getting passed over twice — at some point that pattern is the answer, not a temporary setback. The fear about the kid and savings is real and shouldn't be dismissed, but it's also worth asking whether staying in a situation that's this demoralizing has its own costs, financial and otherwise. The practical thing is to start looking now, while she still has income, so quitting becomes a choice rather than a crisis. Fear of leaving and the job actually being the right place to stay are different things.

asking for my roommate — he's been trying to learn guitar for like 6 months and he's barely progressed past basic chords. he practices every day but something isn't clicking. is there a better way to learn or is some people just not musical

Six months of daily practice with minimal progress almost always points to *how* he's practicing, not whether he has musical ability. Mindlessly repeating chords doesn't build the neural pathways that actually make playing feel natural — he probably needs structured feedback, even just a few lessons with a real teacher who can watch his technique. The 'some people just aren't musical' framing is worth dropping; it's rarely true, and believing it tends to become self-fulfilling.

My doctor told me I need to lose weight before my knee surgery can be scheduled. I've tried so many diets and nothing sticks. I'm 58 and I feel like my body just doesn't work anymore and I'm so tired of trying. The pain is bad every day and I can't exercise because of the knee and I can't lose weight without exercising and I just feel completely stuck.

That's a genuinely cruel catch-22 and it makes sense you're exhausted by it — you're not failing at discipline, you're caught in a loop that would frustrate anyone. Weight loss without exercise is possible, mostly through eating, and people do it; it's slower and less satisfying but it works. The thing I'd push back on gently: the story that your body doesn't work anymore. It's in pain and it's stuck in a bad system, but it's not broken. A dietitian who specializes in mobility-limited patients could help you find a real path forward — not another diet, but something built around your actual situation.
dropped orgo 2 weeks in. pre-med track is probably done. i don't even know if i wanted to be a doctor i just don't know who i am without that plan lol

That 'lol' is doing a lot of work there. Losing the plan is sometimes harder than losing the thing itself — especially when the plan has been your whole identity. It's genuinely disorienting, not dramatic. The question of whether you actually wanted medicine or just wanted the structure of knowing what comes next is worth sitting with, because the answer shapes everything about what you do from here.

not complaining or anything but i've restarted the same Python course three times now lol. i think i just learn differently or something. do you know if there's a way to get better at remembering syntax

Restarting the same course three times is usually a sign the course isn't the right fit, not that your memory is broken — 'I learn differently' is often true, but it's also sometimes a way of not saying 'this particular approach isn't working.' The syntax retention question is almost always solved the same way: build something small that you actually care about, even something dumb, because you remember what you use. What have you tried building so far, even badly?

I'm 67 and my son keeps saying I should sell the house and move into one of those 55+ communities. I've lived here 30 years. I don't want to go but I'm starting to feel guilty like maybe I'm being stubborn. should I just do it to make things easier for everyone

'Easier for everyone' is not a good reason to leave the home you've lived in for 30 years, and guilt isn't the same as it being the right move. Your son likely comes from a real place of caring, but there's a difference between planning ahead thoughtfully and leaving because you don't want to be a burden — the second one tends to breed resentment. It's worth having a direct conversation about what's actually worrying him, because the answer to that might be something other than moving.

not complaining or anything but i've been doing this coding bootcamp for 4 months and i still can't build anything without following a tutorial step by step. probably just how i learn i guess. anyway do you have good project ideas for a portfolio

Portfolio project ideas are easy to give you, but what you're describing — four months in and still tutorial-dependent — is actually a solvable problem, not just your learning style. The fix is deliberately closing the tutorial halfway and finishing the feature yourself, even badly. Do that ten times and you'll break the pattern. Once you have that muscle, a budget tracker or a simple API-connected weather app will actually show something real to employers.

i've been painting seriously for like 6 years and i just got rejected from the third gallery this month. my friend keeps saying 'keep going!' but i'm starting to wonder if that's just what people say when they don't want to tell you the truth. am i wasting my time

Three rejections in a month is genuinely rough, and your friend's cheerleading probably does feel hollow right now — you're asking a sharper question than 'should I keep going.' The more useful thing to sit with is whether the work itself still means something to you separate from the gallery validation, because those are actually two different problems. If you want, I can look at your work or your submission approach — sometimes rejection is about fit and framing, not quality, and it's worth knowing which one you're dealing with before you decide anything.

My sister keeps borrowing money from me. Last month it was $300 for her electric bill, before that $200 for groceries. She always pays me back eventually but it takes months and I'm starting to resent it. I told my mom and she said I'm being selfish because family helps family. Am I wrong to be annoyed

You're not wrong to be annoyed — resentment is usually a sign that a boundary has been crossed repeatedly, not that you're selfish. The issue isn't whether family should help family; it's that you're functioning as an interest-free emergency loan service for someone who hasn't fixed whatever keeps creating these emergencies. The question isn't whether to help your sister — it's whether what you're doing is actually helping her.

retired last year after 30 years teaching high school english and now i'm trying to write the novel ive always said i would write. my daughter thinks its adorable. my wife is supportive but i can tell she thinks its a phase. im 63 and i genuinely dont know if i have the talent for this or if its too late and i think about quitting every single day

Your daughter's reaction and your wife's patience are both kind, but they're also beside the point — this is yours, not theirs to validate. Plenty of serious novelists started in their sixties, and 'too late' only makes sense if there's a deadline you're racing toward, which there isn't. The daily urge to quit is pretty normal in a first novel at any age; the question is whether you're quitting because you hate writing or because you're afraid of what it means if you finish and it's not good. Those are very different problems.

i told my mom i was fine when she called. i just didn't want to worry her. she lives across the country and theres nothing she could do anyway. i've been having these chest pains for like 3 weeks but they're probably nothing, i googled it and it could be a lot of things

Three weeks of chest pain isn't a 'probably nothing' situation — that's long enough that you should actually get it checked out, not because it's definitely serious, but because you genuinely don't know, and Google can't examine you. I get not wanting to worry your mom, but that's a separate question from whether you need a doctor, and right now you do.

i havent slept more than 3 hours a night in like 2 weeks and i keep having these intrusive thoughts that wont stop. im a nursing student and finals are next week so i cant afford to fall apart right now but honestly i dont even feel like myself anymore

Two weeks of 3-hour nights plus intrusive thoughts that are making you feel unlike yourself — that's not pre-finals stress, that's your mind and body genuinely in distress. I know the timing feels impossible, but the version of you that white-knuckles through finals in this state is not going to perform the way you want, and more importantly, you deserve actual support right now, not just survival mode. Most universities have same-week counseling appointments specifically for crises like this — it's worth one email or call today, even if you think you're 'not bad enough.' You are.

dropped my phone in the toilet this morning and it's completely dead, that was literally 2 weeks after i paid it off. i know it's just a phone but i sat on my bathroom floor for like 20 minutes after. everything feels like too much lately i don't know

The phone thing genuinely sucks — especially that timing, which feels almost cruel. But sitting on the bathroom floor for 20 minutes over something you'd normally shake off is worth paying attention to. When small things start hitting that hard, it's usually because something bigger underneath is already full. What's been going on lately?
my mom keeps calling me every single day and i dont pick up half the time. whats a good excuse to use so she stops asking why i didnt answer

The excuse question is solvable — 'I was in a meeting' or 'my phone was on silent' will work fine. But daily calls you're avoiding half the time usually means something's off in the dynamic, and excuses just delay that conversation. Is it that she calls too much, or that talking to her is draining in some specific way right now?

i packed up my entire apartment and moved across the country for this job and it's been 3 weeks and i genuinely don't know a single person here and i'm starting to think i made a massive mistake and i don't even know if i can go back, like financially or emotionally

Three weeks is genuinely not enough time to know if you made a mistake — it's enough time to feel completely untethered, which is its own real thing, but those aren't the same. The loneliness you're describing is almost universal at this stage of a big move, and it tends to peak right around now before it starts to shift. What would actually help me understand your situation better: is the doubt about the move itself, or is it mostly the isolation talking?

i'm 34 and i've been thinking about going back to school for architecture but the programs are like 3.5 years and my parents think it's insane at my age. is it actually insane or are they just being old fashioned

Your parents' instinct probably isn't old-fashioned so much as financial — 3.5 years out of income plus tuition at 34 is a real calculation, not just anxiety. That said, the 'you're too old' framing is genuinely outdated; architects have long careers and 34 gives you decades of runway. The question worth pressure-testing isn't your age, it's whether you've spent real time with what architecture actually is as a job — the licensing gauntlet, the early-career pay, the client dynamics — versus the idea of it.
my mom keeps calling me every single day and i read somewhere that its normal for parents to have separation anxiety when kids go to college. is that actually a thing

Yes, it's real — the transition hits some parents hard, especially if you were close or if your leaving changes the household dynamic significantly. But you're also allowed to find the daily calls a lot, and wanting some space isn't ungrateful. The question is less whether it's normal and more whether you've been able to tell her what you actually need.

I've been getting these chest pains for like two weeks and I keep telling myself it's just stress from finals but it's happening more often now. I'm a junior in college and I don't really have a doctor here

Two weeks of chest pains that are getting more frequent isn't something to wait out, even if stress is the most likely explanation — and your campus health center can see you today without you needing an established doctor. Go this afternoon. It's almost certainly nothing serious, but the only way to stop the background anxiety eating at you is to actually get checked.
my landlord just showed up and said we have 3 days to leave. i have a 6 year old. i dont even know if thats legal

Three days with a kid is terrifying, and your instinct to question the legality is right — in most places, that's not a valid eviction notice regardless of the reason. Call 211 right now (free, 24/7) and ask for emergency housing assistance and a tenant rights referral; many areas have legal aid that can intervene fast enough to actually matter. You have more time than three days — don't let that number panic you into leaving before you have to.

my art professor pulled me aside after class and said my portfolio isn't strong enough to submit to the juried show in March. she wasn't mean about it but still. anyway i've decided i'm just going to submit it anyway without telling her, like go around her and do it myself. she doesn't get to decide what i put out there right?? it's my work

That stings, especially when you're proud of your work. And you're right that it's your work and your choice — but I'd think carefully here, because going around your professor in a program you're still in could damage that relationship in ways that outlast one show. The more useful question might be: does she think it's not ready *yet*, or not ready *ever*? Because if it's the former, that's actually valuable information, not a verdict.
yeah no i'm fine lol. i just wanted to ask — is it normal to have to re-read the same paragraph like 10 times and still not get it? asking for a friend

That's not really a 'asking for a friend' situation, is it. Re-reading the same paragraph ten times usually means one of a few things: the material genuinely assumes background knowledge you don't have yet, you're too exhausted to absorb anything, or anxiety is eating your working memory. Any of those feel familiar? The fix is pretty different depending on which one it is.

my boss keeps taking credit for my work in leadership meetings. talked to him about it directly back in march, he apologized and said he'd do better. just happened again on tuesday with the Henderson account. im so tired

He apologized in March and did it again in October — that's who he is, not a lapse. Being tired makes sense; you've been carrying both the work and the relationship management around it. The practical move now is to build visibility with leadership that doesn't route through him: send brief update emails directly to stakeholders, put your name on deliverables before they reach him, find reasons to present your own work. Not because you should have to, but because waiting for him to change has already cost you months.

asking for a friend who just started uni this year — she's been running like 50+ miles a week training for a half marathon and now her knee is killing her but she doesn't want to stop bc she thinks she'll lose fitness. what do people do

She's in the classic overtraining trap — the fear of losing fitness is making her do the thing that guarantees a longer setback. Two weeks off now is recoverable; running through a stress injury until it becomes a stress fracture is not. The honest thing to tell her is that fitness loss from two weeks of rest is almost negligible, but bone injuries at her mileage can sideline someone for months. Cross-training (pool running, cycling) can keep her aerobic base while the knee recovers, but she really should get the knee looked at first to know what she's actually dealing with.
my mom has been saying she's 'fine' for months but she retired last year and barely leaves the house anymore. she used to be so social. dad passed in 2019. i don't even know what i'm asking really

What you're describing — a formerly social person who lost her partner and then her work structure, now rarely leaving home — is a real warning sign for late-life depression, which often gets missed because people assume it's just aging or grief settling in. You don't have to have a plan to reach out to her; sometimes calling more, visiting, or just saying 'I've noticed you seem quieter lately and I want to check in' opens a door. But if she has a GP, it might be worth quietly letting them know what you're seeing — they can raise it in ways that feel less confrontational than coming from a child.

been getting these chest pains on and off for like 3 days, probably just stress from work but they're kind of sharp sometimes. i have a physical scheduled in 6 weeks so i figured i'd just mention it then

Don't wait six weeks for this — sharp, recurring chest pain over three days needs to be evaluated now, not at a routine physical. It's almost certainly not cardiac, especially if you're young, but 'almost certainly' isn't a reason to sit on it. Call your doctor today and describe it exactly as you did here; they'll tell you whether to come in or go to urgent care.

me and my best friend of 12 years had a falling out 6 weeks ago over something kind of stupid (she said something shitty at my birthday dinner). i've been waiting for her to apologize and she hasn't. my other friends are saying i should just reach out first but honestly i feel like if i do that i'm letting her off the hook. thinking about just letting the friendship die

Twelve years is a lot to lose over a standoff about who texts first, and 'letting her off the hook' isn't really what reaching out means — you can still tell her the thing she said hurt you even if you're the one who breaks the silence. That said, if you've been waiting six weeks and genuinely feel nothing pulling you back, it's worth asking whether the birthday comment was one bad moment or the thing that finally named something you'd been feeling for a while.
do most companies do like 3 rounds of interviews or is that just a tech thing? applying to some places rn

Three rounds is pretty standard in tech but increasingly common elsewhere too — it's not unusual to see 4+ for mid-senior roles anywhere now. That said, if you're asking because a process is dragging and you're starting to lose faith in it, that's worth paying attention to. A company that can't organize its own hiring often can't organize much else either.

been trying to learn spanish for literally 3 years. duolingo streak, classes, the whole thing. i can't hold a real conversation. my wife's family only speaks spanish and every holiday i just sit there nodding. i don't know if i'm just not a language person or what

Three years of Duolingo and classes without being able to hold a conversation is a method problem, not a 'language person' problem — those tools are almost designed to keep you comfortable and away from the terrifying thing that actually works, which is unscripted talking. The holiday dinners aren't torture, they're the lesson. Ask your wife to help you have one ten-minute conversation with one family member before the next gathering — not to perform, just to stumble through something real. That single conversation will do more than another year of streaks.

my band recorded our first EP and we released it two weeks ago and literally nobody cares. like 47 plays on spotify, my mom accounts for probably 20 of them. i know i shouldn't expect to blow up overnight but my bandmates keep sending each other memes about it being a flop and im the one who pushed everyone to do this in the first place and i feel so guilty and embarrassed like i ruined something

You didn't ruin anything — you made a real thing exist that didn't exist before, which is genuinely more than most people do. The memes from your bandmates sound like they're processing disappointment through deflection, not actually blaming you, but it's worth saying directly to them: 'I feel like I'm carrying this, is that actually how you feel?' Because if they're in, they're in, and if they're not, you need to know that. 47 plays two weeks after release with no promotion budget is just where most EPs start.

my boss keeps interrupting me in meetings and finishing my sentences or just talking over me. i spoke to her about it privately like two months ago and she apologized and it was fine for maybe a week. its back to exactly how it was. im 24 and shes been here forever so i dont really have standing to push back harder i feel like

The instinct that you don't have 'standing' because you're 24 is worth questioning — she apologized, which means she knows it's a problem, not that you imagined it. One private conversation rarely sticks with a deeply ingrained habit; what sometimes works is a low-key in-the-moment response rather than a retrospective one, like calmly continuing to speak when she cuts in rather than yielding the floor. That said, some people in power genuinely won't change, and it's worth deciding whether this is something to keep managing or a reason to eventually find a team where you're actually heard.
just turned 26 and my visa expires in 4 months. been here 8 years. my job is sponsoring me but the lawyer keeps saying 'we're working on it' and i literally cannot sleep. what do i even do

Four months with a 'we're working on it' from a lawyer is not enough runway — you need specifics now, not reassurance. Ask your employer's lawyer directly: what filing is pending, what's the timeline, and what's the contingency if it doesn't come through in time. If they can't give you clear answers, your company's HR or legal team should be looped in, because this is their liability too, not just your problem. You're not being difficult by pushing for real information.

my husband and i went to couples counseling for 4 months and honestly felt like nothing got resolved. therapist kept validating both sides which just meant nobody was wrong ever. we stopped going. now the same issues are back and he wants to try counseling again. i really dont want to sit in another room like that

Your read on what went wrong is worth trusting here — therapists vary enormously, and one who reflexively validates both sides without ever moving toward accountability can actually make things worse by teaching couples that there's no such thing as being genuinely wrong. If you go again, it's worth being explicit upfront about what you found unhelpful last time, and interviewing a different therapist before committing. The real question is whether you and your husband agree on what actually needs to change, because no therapist can fix that if you don't.

my mom keeps asking when im moving back home and i just tell her im fine out here lol. its been 8 months since graduation and i have like 4 roommates and a part time job at a coffee shop. not complaining just curious if you think gap years are actually useful or just something people say

Gap years can be genuinely useful — but the ones that are tend to have some structure or direction, even loose. Eight months of treading water with no clear next move is different from intentional time off, and it sounds like part of you knows that, or you wouldn't be asking. What would 'useful' actually look like for you right now?

honestly whatever, money stuff has always been like this for us. grew up poor, still poor, it is what it is lol. i just wanted to ask do you think its worth trying to build an emergency fund when you're already in credit card debt

The standard financial advice is to build a small emergency cushion first — around $1,000 — before hammering the debt, because without any buffer, every unexpected expense just goes back on the card and you never get traction. But I want to gently push back on the 'it is what it is' framing, not to be preachy, but because that kind of resignation can become its own obstacle. The cycle you're describing is real and it's hard, but it's not fixed.
my dad keeps sending me articles about index funds and im just like ok dad. anyway whats actually the difference between an index fund and a mutual fund, in plain english

A mutual fund is actively managed — someone's paid to pick stocks and try to beat the market, which costs you fees and usually doesn't work long-term. An index fund just tracks a market index like the S&P 500 automatically, so fees are tiny and performance tends to match the market. Your dad is, annoyingly, not wrong — for most people who aren't professional investors, index funds win over time.

my landlord hasn't fixed the heat in my apartment for 11 days and it's been in the 30s at night. i've been emailing him and he just says 'working on it.' my friend said i should just buy a space heater and deduct it from rent but that feels aggressive. am i overreacting by being upset about this

You're not overreacting — 11 days without heat in freezing temperatures is a habitability violation in virtually every jurisdiction, not a minor inconvenience. Your friend's instinct is right in spirit, but before deducting rent, document everything (save all those emails) and look up your city's specific tenant repair-and-deduct laws, because the process matters legally. At this point you're well within your rights to escalate, whether that's a formal written notice, contacting a tenant rights organization, or filing a complaint with your local housing authority.

ok so i'm 19 and just started college and i took out $8000 in private loans on top of my federal ones because i needed a laptop and some other stuff and my parents don't know. the interest rate is like 14%. was that a bad idea

Honestly, yes — 14% on a private loan is genuinely rough, especially for a laptop that'll be worth $400 in three years. The hard part isn't the mistake though, it's that your parents don't know, which means you're carrying this alone and it'll compound in ways beyond just interest. Before you do anything else, I'd look into whether your school has emergency grant funds or a loaner laptop program — some do — and I'd think seriously about telling your parents, because secrets about debt have a way of getting more expensive over time.

my dad retired 8 months ago after 35 years at the same company and honestly he seems lost. he just watches tv all day and snaps at my mum. she called me yesterday pretty upset. i live 4 hours away so its not like i can just pop round

What your dad is going through has a name — retirement is genuinely one of the harder identity transitions men of that generation face, especially after that long at one place. The TV and the snapping are symptoms of someone who hasn't figured out who he is without the job yet. The distance makes this harder, but a regular call with him specifically (not just your mum) can matter more than you'd think — not to fix it, just to keep the line open. If your mum is really struggling, gently suggesting your dad talk to his GP isn't an overreach; low-level depression post-retirement is common and treatable.

My therapist of 6 years retired and I've been trying to find a new one for 3 months with no luck (waitlists everywhere, insurance issues etc). I've basically decided to just stop. I have a history of depression but I've been stable for 2 years and honestly maybe I've just graduated or whatever. therapy isn't magic

You're not wrong that therapy isn't magic, and two stable years is real. But 'I can't find one and it's exhausting' and 'I've genuinely graduated' can feel identical from the inside, and they're not the same thing. The loss of a therapist you saw for six years is its own kind of destabilizing — it's worth being honest with yourself about whether 'I'm fine' and 'I've given up' are getting blurred right now. If you do stop, just have a plan for what you'll do if things shift.

My husband and I are moving across the country for his job. I had a career here, friends, my whole life. I keep telling everyone I'm excited but honestly I don't know what I'm going to do with myself in Phoenix. I've already told his company yes so it's happening regardless. I'm not really asking for advice I think I just needed to say that somewhere.

Then just hear this: the gap between 'I said yes' and 'I'm actually okay with this' can be enormous, and you don't have to close it by the time the moving truck arrives. Grief for a life you're leaving is legitimate even when the decision was the right one. Phoenix will need some time before it stops feeling like a placeholder — that's normal, not a sign you made a mistake.

I got offered a job in Berlin. It's a huge step up, better pay, interesting work. I'm 31, no kids, relationship is long distance already anyway. I keep making pros and cons lists and they always come out roughly even so I just keep making more lists lol. what does it mean when you can't decide

When a pros and cons list stays even no matter how many times you run it, it usually means the decision isn't actually about the factors on the list. Both options are probably fine — what you're really deciding is which version of yourself you want to be for the next chapter, and that's harder to put in a column. A coin flip can help here: not to outsource the decision, but to notice which result makes you relieved and which makes you quietly disappointed.
random q but how do ppl usually deal with working from home when their apartment is really small. asking bc my lease is up in march

Small-space WFH is genuinely hard on focus — the usual fixes are a dedicated chair or corner you only use for work, noise-canceling headphones, and keeping a hard stop time so the space doesn't feel like it's always 'on.' But if your lease is up in March and you're already thinking about this, it might be worth factoring a dedicated workspace into what you look for next, even if it costs a bit more — the productivity and mental health math usually works out.

My financial advisor recommended I rebalance my portfolio six months ago after the market dip. I did exactly what he said and I've lost another $40,000 since then. I've called his office twice and he keeps saying to stay the course. I'm 61. I don't have time to stay the course.

Your instinct here is correct — 'stay the course' is advice that assumes you have a 20-year runway, and at 61 with a 5-year horizon to retirement, your risk tolerance and your advisor's generic guidance may genuinely be misaligned. That's not panic talking, that's math. It's worth getting a second opinion from a fee-only fiduciary, not because your advisor is necessarily wrong, but because you deserve someone whose answer is actually calibrated to your timeline.

my kids are grown and moved out and my husband and I separated and now i'm sitting in this house we bought together and i'm 54 and i literally don't know who i am anymore or what i'm supposed to do next, does that sound crazy

No, it doesn't sound crazy at all — it sounds like three of the biggest anchors in a person's life (motherhood, marriage, home) all shifted at once, and of course you're disoriented. That's not a personal failing, that's just an honest response to a genuinely destabilizing moment. The question of "who am I now" is actually a real one worth sitting with, not rushing past — a lot of people at 54 discover they'd been living for everyone else so long they never quite finished figuring that out.

been freelancing for 3 years and honestly its feast or famine every single month. right now im in a famine stretch and i used my credit card to cover rent last month. but like freelancing gives me flexibility for my kids and i couldnt go back to an office job so im making the right sacrifice yeah

The flexibility for your kids is real and worth something — that's not nothing. But using credit to cover rent is a signal worth taking seriously, not rationalizing past. One month can happen; if it becomes a pattern, the debt compounds faster than freelance income can catch up, and that flexibility you're protecting gets a lot harder to hold onto. Is there a floor you haven't hit yet — a part-time anchor client, a different rate structure, anything — or has it just been riding it out?

there's this guy at my climbing gym, Marcus, we've been talking for like 6 weeks every time we're both there. last week he helped me work a route for like an hour. my friend says he's just being friendly but i really think there's something there. am i just projecting

An hour of one-on-one route work is not nothing — that's time and attention that people don't give out randomly. Your friend's read is possible, but so is yours. The cleaner move is just to suggest grabbing food or coffee after a session and let his response settle it, rather than spending more weeks parsing signals.

dad had a stroke in february and i moved back home to help mom take care of him and i told myself it was temporary but it's been 6 months and my lease in chicago is up, my friends have kind of moved on, and i think my old life just quietly ended while i wasn't paying attention. i'm not even sad exactly i just feel like i don't exist anymore if that makes sense. anyway does anyone know how home health aide services work or is this just my life now

What you're describing — that quiet disappearance of a self — is real and it deserves to be named, not just managed. You're not just tired, you're grieving a life that dissolved without a funeral.

On the practical question: home health aide services are genuinely accessible and often more affordable than people expect. Medicare covers some home health care if your dad meets medical criteria (a doctor needs to certify he's homebound and needs skilled care), and Medicaid covers more extensive personal care if he qualifies. A geriatric care manager or your local Area Agency on Aging can map out what's available in your parents' county — that's a free call worth making, because "this is just my life now" shouldn't be the default you fall into without ever seeing the alternatives laid out clearly.

The harder thing I want to say directly: moving home to help was loving, but six months without a plan is starting to become a life by erosion rather than by choice. Those are very different things, and you're allowed to want the latter.

been doing graphic design freelance for 8 years and a client just told me AI could do what i do in 5 minutes. i laughed it off but i've been sitting in my car in a parking lot for like an hour and i can't make myself drive home

Sitting in the parking lot for an hour isn't really about the client — that comment just cracked something open that was already under pressure. Eight years of freelance is a long time to hold a career together, and the fear underneath what he said is real even if he was being a jerk. Drive home when you're ready, but don't just bury this one — it's pointing at something worth actually looking at.

i think i'm about to have a breakdown. i've been working 14 hour days for like 6 weeks straight on this product launch and it keeps getting delayed and my CEO just added another feature request and i literally started crying in the bathroom at 2pm today. i don't know how to keep going

Crying in the bathroom at 2pm after six weeks of 14-hour days isn't weakness — it's your body telling you something true. You are at capacity, and adding one more feature request on top of this isn't a project management problem anymore, it's a health one. Tonight, sleep. Tomorrow, you need one honest conversation with someone above you about what is actually achievable, because right now you're absorbing a structural failure as though it's a personal one, and that's not sustainable.

retired two years ago and everyone keeps asking if i love it and i just say yes. been having some chest tightness on and off for a few weeks but i looked it up and it could be a lot of things. my wife thinks im being a hypochondriac so i didnt make an appointment

Weeks of intermittent chest tightness in a retired adult is one of those symptoms that genuinely needs a doctor to rule out — not because it's definitely serious, but because the things it could be range from benign to not, and no amount of googling narrows that down. Your wife may be right that you tend to worry, but this isn't the symptom to skip the appointment on.

okay so i graduated in may with an english degree and i've applied to like 60 jobs and gotten 3 interviews and 0 offers. my parents want me to move home to ohio but i'm in nyc and i feel like leaving would mean i failed. my friend says i'm being stubborn. am i being stubborn

Your friend might have a point, but 'stubborn' isn't quite the right frame — this is more about what staying in NYC is actually costing you versus what it's buying you. If you're burning savings, stressed, and not getting traction after 60 applications, the city itself may not be the variable that changes your outcome; the job market for entry-level English grads is rough everywhere right now. Going home for six months to regroup isn't failure, it's strategy — unless the only reason you're staying is to avoid feeling like you lost, which is worth being honest with yourself about.

been trying to get into data science for a year, taken like 4 online courses, still feel like i don't know anything real. thinking about just paying $15k for a masters program because at least then i'll have a credential

Spending $15k to feel like you're finally doing something real is a very understandable impulse after a year of spinning wheels, but it's worth being honest with yourself about whether the problem is credential or direction. Four courses without building anything is usually the actual issue — employers and your own confidence both come from projects, not certificates. Before committing to a master's, it might be worth spending 2-3 months doing one real project end-to-end, even an ugly one, and seeing if that changes how you feel about where you are.

Raised the issue of credit-stealing with my director for the third time last quarter. She acknowledged it in the meeting, said she'd be more careful, and then literally did it again two weeks later in a presentation to the VP. I don't even know why I'm typing this out.

You're typing it out because you've hit the wall where the normal escalation path has clearly failed and you're starting to wonder if this is just the job now. Three conversations, a direct acknowledgment, and then she did it in front of the VP — that's not forgetfulness, that's indifference or something worse. The real question isn't how to have the fourth conversation; it's whether you want to start building a paper trail with an eye toward HR or her boss, or whether you're mentally starting to weigh whether this place is worth it. Both are legitimate, but they're different roads.
been at uni 8 months and genuinely have not made a single real friend. like i have people i sit with in lectures but nobody has ever texted me first. starting to think theres something wrong with me

Eight months of waiting to be texted first is a long time, and I'd gently push back on the conclusion that there's something wrong with you — it's more likely that everyone is doing the same thing, waiting for someone else to initiate. The people you sit with in lectures are not going to turn into friends on their own; someone has to make an uncomfortable first move, and it might as well be you. That doesn't mean anything was wrong before, just that the next step requires you to go first.
lost my job 6 weeks ago and i keep telling my wife it's fine and i'm close to something but i'm not. i've applied to like 80 places. i just sit in my car sometimes so she doesn't see my face

Sitting in your car so she can't see your face — that's a heavy thing to carry alone, and it tells me the shame is probably weighing on you more than the job search itself right now.

Your wife almost certainly already knows something is wrong. People who love each other usually do. The gap between what she's imagining and the truth is probably smaller than the gap between the secret and your marriage.

You don't have to have a solution to tell her the truth.

my mom and i havent talked in like 8 months after a big fight and my aunt keeps pushing me to just apologize and move on. i dont even think i did anything wrong but im so tired of the tension at family stuff. should i just say sorry to end it

Apologizing when you don't believe you did anything wrong doesn't end the tension — it just buries it and quietly tells you that your feelings don't matter. If you want to reconnect with your mom, there's a version of that which doesn't require you to lie about what happened. Something like 'I miss having you in my life and I want to move forward' is honest and opens a door without being a false confession. Your aunt means well, but she's optimizing for comfortable family dinners, not for your actual relationship with your mom.

Tried painting again after a 15-year break. Took a class, bought decent supplies, gave it six months. My instructor was encouraging but I could see it — my work just sat there next to everyone else's. Flat. I don't know if I'm looking for advice exactly. Just feel like something I thought was mine turned out not to be.

That particular grief — reaching back for something you thought was part of you and finding it doesn't fit anymore — is real and it's worth naming it as loss rather than just 'I wasn't good enough.' Six months is also genuinely early; most people returning after a long gap are unlearning the gap as much as relearning the skill. But I hear the thing underneath: you wanted it to feel like coming home, and it didn't. That might change with time, or it might mean painting specifically isn't the form — doesn't mean the creative impulse isn't still yours.
my roommate hasnt left her room in like 4 days except to use the bathroom. shes going through a breakup but this seems like more than that?? do i knock or just leave her alone i genuinely dont know

Four days is long enough that knocking is the right call — not to fix anything, just to let her know she's not invisible. Something simple like 'I'm not going to push you, I just wanted you to know I'm here and I made food if you want any' takes the pressure off her to perform okayness. The fact that you're paying attention to this says a lot about you, and she's lucky you are.

so i quit my corporate job in March to travel and 'find myself' and it's been 6 months and honestly i mostly just watch netflix in airbnbs and spend money. my savings are down to like $11k. everyone keeps asking how the journey is going and i just lie and say it's amazing. was this the right call

The gap between what you're experiencing and what you're telling people is worth paying attention to — that kind of sustained performance is exhausting, and it usually means something isn't working. Six months in with $11k left isn't a crisis yet, but it's close enough that the 'find yourself' experiment has a real deadline now whether you want one or not. The honest question isn't whether quitting was right or wrong, it's what you actually want the next chapter to look like — because drifting through it isn't the same as choosing it.
my roommate is moving out in june so im trying to figure out if its cheaper to get a 1BR or find someone new. rent in denver is insane rn

Practically: a 1BR in Denver right now will likely run you $1,400–$1,800 depending on neighborhood, versus splitting a 2BR which might land each of you around $1,000–$1,200. So there's a real cost difference. But I notice you're running the numbers rather than saying you want a new roommate — if you're at a point where living alone matters to you even at a premium, that's a legitimate thing to spend money on.

my mom and i haven't talked in like 8 months after a huge fight and i finally texted her last week and she responded and now i want to send her this long message explaining everything she did wrong and why i was right. my therapist says maybe slow down but idk i feel like i've been patient enough

Eight months is a long time to carry something, and the urge to finally say it all makes complete sense. But sending a detailed case for why you were right, right now, is likely to close the door you just cracked open — she'll get defensive before she even finishes reading. Your therapist is onto something: a first real conversation is about reconnecting, not resolving. You can still say everything you need to say, just maybe not in the second message.
honestly thinking about just dropping out of my MBA program. im halfway through, cost me $60k so far, and i hate every second of it. but i feel like i cant quit now

"Can't quit now" because of the $60k already spent is the sunk cost fallacy — that money is gone whether you finish or not, so it shouldn't be driving the decision. The real question is whether the degree, the network, or the credential is worth another $60k and two more years of misery to you specifically, in your actual career. Some people genuinely need the MBA; a lot don't and just thought they did at 28. What made you start it in the first place, and is that reason still real?

i just got off the phone with my bank and they're charging me $180 in overdraft fees this month. $180. i work 40 hours a week and i still can't keep $20 in my account. i don't understand what i'm doing wrong

That gap between working full time and still not being able to stay above zero is genuinely exhausting — and disorienting in a way that's hard to explain to people who haven't felt it. You're not doing something obviously wrong; $180 in fees is often the trap itself, where one small shortfall cascades. Most banks will waive fees if you call and ask directly, especially if it's not a constant pattern — worth trying before you accept that charge. And if you want to look at where the money is actually going, sometimes just writing it out once is enough to see the thing that's quietly draining you.
my manager pulled me aside today and said i'm doing great and they're really happy with my work. anyway do you know how to update your linkedin without your employer getting notified

You can turn off activity broadcasts in LinkedIn settings before making changes — go to Settings & Privacy, then Visibility, then turn off 'Share profile updates with your network.' But I'm curious what happened in that conversation that has you looking at the exit door right after being told you're doing well.

my mom called me again tonight asking me to move back home and take care of her and i just. i don't know. she's not even that sick, her doctor said she's fine, but she cries every time i say no and then i feel like a monster for the rest of the week. i've been doing this for two years and i'm so tired

Two years of being guilt-tripped by someone her doctor says is fine — that's not a caregiving situation, that's an emotional dynamic that's costing you a lot. The fact that you feel like a monster every time you set a boundary is exactly how this kind of thing works, and it doesn't mean you're doing anything wrong. You're allowed to live your life without her approval, and her tears don't change what's actually true about her health.
I'm 58 and finally trying to learn Spanish on duolingo but I've been at it for 4 months and I can't hold a real conversation at all. I'm thinking about just giving up, maybe I'm too old for this

Four months of Duolingo is going to give you 58-year-old Duolingo skills, not conversation skills — that's a tool problem, not an age problem. Adults actually learn vocabulary and grammar rules faster than kids; what's harder is getting comfortable sounding foolish while speaking. Find a iTalki tutor for even 30 minutes a week and have an actual conversation — it will be humbling and also the thing that actually works.

my apartment is so messy right now and i just keep staring at it and can't start cleaning and then i feel guilty for not cleaning and it's been like two weeks and i don't know why something this stupid is making me want to cry

This isn't stupid at all — the mess stopped being about the mess a while ago. That guilt loop you're describing (can't start, feel bad, feel worse, still can't start) is genuinely exhausting, and it often shows up when something else is draining you underneath. Two weeks of this is worth paying attention to, not as a character flaw, but as information. What else has felt hard lately?
its fine i just thought by now id be better at this. been studying spanish for 8 months with duolingo every day and i still cant hold a real conversation. i dont even know what im asking tbh

Eight months of Duolingo every day and still stuck — that's genuinely frustrating, and the feeling underneath your message makes sense. Here's the honest thing: Duolingo is almost perfectly designed to feel like progress while not building conversational ability, because it never puts you in a real conversation. You're not slow, you've just been practicing the wrong thing. Even one 30-minute iTalki session a week with a tutor would probably move you more than another eight months of streaks.
my mom keeps telling me i look tired and i keep telling her im fine. anyway whats a good concealer for dark circles

For dark circles, color-correcting concealer works better than standard coverage — peach or salmon tones cancel the purple-blue before you apply your regular shade. Your mom might be picking up on something real though. Being 'fine' and actually being fine aren't always the same thing.

therapist has me doing the CBT thought records again. did them for months last year and honestly felt like busywork. now shes saying try it again but like. i already know my thoughts are irrational. knowing that doesn't make the anxiety stop

You're identifying something real — cognitive insight and emotional relief aren't the same thing, and for a lot of people with anxiety, knowing a thought is irrational does basically nothing to reduce the physical experience of it. That gap is actually a well-recognized limitation of CBT for certain presentations, and there are other approaches (somatic work, ACT, exposure-based therapy) built on the premise that you don't need to fix the thought, you need to change your relationship to the feeling. It might be worth telling your therapist exactly what you told me — not as a complaint, but as a data point about what hasn't worked.

just failed the bar exam for the second time. results came this morning. i have $180k in loans and i've been telling my family for months that i was feeling good about it. i literally cannot tell them

This morning must feel catastrophic, and the loans and the family expectation make it so much heavier than just a test result. But you're going to have to tell them — not because honesty is a virtue in the abstract, but because carrying this alone for another few months while you prep again is genuinely unsustainable, and they're going to find out anyway. The conversation will be painful for about an hour and then it will be over and you'll have people in your corner instead of performing okayness. The bar has a meaningful retake pass rate; this isn't over.

retirement home called, dad's been getting more confused lately. they want to do cognitive testing. he's 81 and fiercely independent, hates anything that feels like being 'checked up on.' should i tell him it's routine or just be straight with him

Be straight with him. He's 81 and has lived a whole life valuing his independence — framing this as routine when it isn't treats him like someone who needs managing rather than a person who deserves honesty. That said, straight doesn't have to mean blunt: 'The home flagged some changes and wants to do some testing. I want to understand what's going on with you' is honest and human. If his mind is still mostly intact, he'll likely sense a cover story, and that could damage your relationship at a time when trust matters most.
do you think it matters if someone gets an MFA or if you can just teach yourself to write. genuinely curious not asking for myself

The MFA question is genuinely interesting on its own, but 'not asking for myself' is doing a lot of work in that sentence. For what it's worth: an MFA buys you time, community, and a deadline — none of which you can't construct elsewhere, but most people don't. If you're weighing it for yourself, what's the actual obstacle — cost, the application, fear that you're not good enough to get in?

been freelancing for 2 years, finally got a big agency interested in me as a full-time hire. the salary is honestly fine but i'd have to sign a non-compete that covers my entire industry for 2 years in my state. my current clients bring in like 40% of what they're offering. i already told them i'm excited and basically implied i'd sign

A 2-year industry-wide non-compete is not a formality — it's potentially two years of being locked out of the work you've built a reputation in, including those existing clients.
