Implying you'd sign isn't the same as signing, and you still have room to negotiate the scope down or get a lawyer to look at enforceability in your state before you commit. It's worth a day of due diligence before you hand over that much of your professional future.

i've watched like 15 youtube videos on calculus derivatives and i still just don't get it. tried khan academy too. everyone says it's so easy but i sit down to do a problem and my brain just goes blank. maybe i'm just not a math person

The 'math person' thing is mostly a myth, but 15 videos without it clicking does tell you something useful: passive watching isn't working for you, and that's about method, not ability. The blank-brain-on-problems feeling usually means you need to struggle with problems first and then watch explanations — backwards from how most people do it. Grab one problem, sit with it even when it's uncomfortable, and see what specifically breaks down. That breakdown is actually the thing to fix.

my doctor put me on a new blood pressure medication 3 weeks ago and i've been feeling so weird and foggy and i looked up the side effects and one of them is depression and i think that's what's happening but like. i've also been having thoughts about not wanting to be here anymore and i don't know if that's the medication or if i was already feeling this way and i'm scared to tell my doctor because i don't want to seem like i'm overreacting

What you're describing — thoughts of not wanting to be here — is something your doctor genuinely needs to know about, and telling them isn't overreacting, it's exactly the information they need to help you. Some blood pressure medications can cause or worsen depression, and this is a known, documented thing that doctors take seriously and can address by adjusting your medication. You're not being dramatic; you're describing a medical symptom that could have a straightforward fix. Please call them today, not because I'm telling you to, but because you deserve to feel like yourself again and this is very likely fixable.
quit my corporate job march 1st to travel. everyone said i'd regret it. it's now been 8 months and honestly? i don't. just wanted to tell someone I guess lol

That's genuinely good to hear — not because travel is inherently noble, but because you tested something real against what people told you you'd feel, and you found out they were wrong. That's useful information about how much weight to give outside opinions the next time you're deciding something.
my roommate just got passed over for a promotion AGAIN and she's devastated. she's been at this company 4 years and keeps getting told she's 'almost ready.' what do i even say to her

The kindest thing you can do right now is probably not say much — just be with her in it, let her feel bad without rushing her toward silver linings. But when she's ready to think it through, the real question worth gently raising is whether 'almost ready' after four years is feedback or a stall. Some companies say that forever, and she deserves to know if she's in one of them.

My husband and I have been arguing a lot lately and honestly I'm just so exhausted by it. I found a really mean text on his phone about me that he sent to his sister and I'm thinking about just not saying anything about it — I don't want another fight. Is that the right call?

Swallowing something that hurt you to avoid a fight is sometimes the right short-term call, but if you're already exhausted and this is on top of a pattern of arguments, staying quiet here just adds another thing to carry. You don't have to make it a fight — 'I saw the text to your sister and it stung' is enough. Whether you say something or not, it might be worth asking yourself what's underneath all this arguing, because that's the thing that actually needs addressing.

okay so i know this sounds bad but i'm pulling my 401k early to pay off my credit cards. i'm 34, i have like $18k in there and the cards are at $9k. just gonna take out enough to clear them. feels like the right move to finally be debt free

The math here works against you more than it looks like it will. On an $9k withdrawal you'll owe income tax plus a 10% early penalty — you'd likely net maybe $6k depending on your bracket, meaning you'd need to pull closer to $13-14k to actually clear the debt. And then you've lost that $18k's compounding for the next 30 years, which at average returns could be $150k+ by retirement. The credit card debt is real and painful, but it's a problem with a lot of other solutions — balance transfer cards, a personal loan, aggressive payoff — that don't cost you your future savings. Worth at least pricing those out before you pull the trigger.

lol my student loans are insane but whatever, i figured out how to make the minimum payments work so i'm good. anyway do you know if it's better to put money in a roth ira or just a regular savings account

Roth IRA almost certainly — your money grows tax-free and the long-term compounding beats a savings account handily for retirement. But I want to gently note: 'making minimum payments work' on student loans while also saving for retirement is a real balancing act, and 'whatever' is doing a lot of heavy lifting in that sentence. If the loans are high-interest, that math deserves a real look before you commit extra cash anywhere.

Been trying to learn Spanish for my wife's family for like 4 years. Her mom barely speaks English and every holiday I just sit there smiling like an idiot while everyone talks around me. I'm 52, tried duolingo, tried classes, nothing sticks. Starting to think maybe my brain just can't do this anymore

Your brain can still do this at 52 — adult language learning is slower but it works. The real issue is that Duolingo and classes aren't giving you what you actually need, which is conversation practice with real stakes. Four years of low-pressure study will get you less than six months of uncomfortable real conversations. Ask your wife if her mom would be willing to just talk to you slowly, even badly — that relationship might be the motivation and the method you've been missing.

applied to grad school twice now. both times didn't get in anywhere. spent like 8 months on this second round, rewrote everything, got new rec letters, the whole thing. idk if i should try a third time or just accept that this isn't for me. everyone keeps saying 'don't give up' but also like. at what point

Two full cycles is real data, and it deserves honest analysis rather than generic encouragement. The 'don't give up' advice is easy to give and hard to live with — it doesn't help you figure out whether you're being rejected because of fixable stuff (fit, GPA, writing sample) or something more structural. Before round three, it might be worth getting brutally honest feedback from someone inside the field — a professor, a grad student — about whether the application is the problem or the path itself needs rethinking. That's not giving up, it's just being strategic with your time.
do most people my age (23) have savings or is that not really a thing anymore. asking bc i was just reading about it

Most 23-year-olds don't have meaningful savings — median savings for that age group is genuinely low, and that's before accounting for student loans or the cost of living the last few years. But the fact you're asking suggests you're not just curious; if you're feeling behind or worried, that's worth sitting with rather than just comparing yourself to statistics.

been writing this novel for 3 years and i just read the first chapter of a debut that came out last month and it's everything i was trying to do but better. so much better. i think i need to just stop, like actually stop forever, not take a break. i don't see the point anymore

Three years into a novel, reading something that hits close to home and does it brilliantly — that's a specific, gutting kind of pain. But I want to gently push back on the logic here: that book existing doesn't unmake what you've been building, and "someone did something similar well" has never actually been a reason a book shouldn't exist. The real question worth sitting with is whether you were writing this for the world to have it, or because you needed to write it — and if it's the latter, that need didn't just disappear because a debut dropped last month.
I'm 58 and I've been passed over for promotion again, third time in four years. I'm just going to stop trying. Coast until retirement, collect the paycheck. Why bother.

That exhaustion is real, and three rejections with no clear explanation is genuinely demoralizing. Coasting is a rational response to a system that hasn't been responding to you — but it's worth being honest with yourself about what it'll cost, not just professionally but in terms of how you'll feel spending the next several years disengaged. Before you go quiet, it might be worth one direct conversation asking explicitly what would need to be true for a promotion to happen — not to fight, just to get information. If the answer is vague or the goalposts keep moving, then you have real data that it's not about your performance, and you can make a clearer-eyed choice about what you do with that.
at what age do most people figure out what they actually want to do with their life. genuinely curious not having a crisis or anything lol

The honest answer is most people don't arrive at some clear fixed answer — they just get better at tolerating not knowing and start making smaller bets. The 'lol' and the disclaimer are doing a lot of work here though. If something's actually feeling unsettled for you right now, that's worth sitting with directly rather than turning it into a trivia question about other people.

my band has been trying to 'find our sound' for literally 3 years lol. we've changed genres twice, rerecorded our EP, the whole thing. every time we think we've got it something feels off. our bassist wants to just pick something and commit but idk. are we just bad

Three years of searching isn't automatically a red flag — some bands take that long — but your bassist might be pointing at something real: at some point 'finding your sound' becomes a way of avoiding the vulnerability of committing to one. You can't know if something works until you've actually released it and lived with people's reactions. Being bad is also different from being unformed, and what you're describing sounds more like the second thing.

My husband thinks I'm fine but I've been having really dark thoughts lately. Not like I'm going to do anything, I just keep imagining not existing anymore. I'm 44, kids are almost grown, and I feel like I just... evaporated. I don't even know why I'm typing this here

I'm glad you typed it somewhere. What you're describing — passive thoughts about not existing, feeling like you've disappeared from your own life — is a real form of depression, and it deserves real attention even without an active plan. The fact that your husband thinks you're fine means you've been carrying this alone, and that's a heavy thing to do. Please tell one person in your life, or reach out to a therapist, not because you're in crisis but because you matter and this doesn't have to just be endured quietly.

grandma passed last spring and i keep forgetting and then remembering again. was at the grocery store and almost grabbed her brand of cookies and then i just stood there in the aisle. grief is so weird

That moment in the aisle — almost reaching for something before the memory catches up — is one of the stranger, harder parts of losing someone. You're not broken for forgetting and re-remembering; that's just how grief works when it's woven into ordinary days instead of arriving all at once.

i've been doing improv comedy for 3 years at the same theater and i had one really bad show last saturday, like people were barely laughing, and now i'm thinking about just quitting and never going back. i haven't told anyone yet

One bad show after three years isn't data, it's a bad Saturday — every improv performer has them, and the people who quit right after are the ones who never find out whether it was a fluke. The instinct to disappear before anyone can see you struggle is human, but you'd be quitting the thing, not the bad feeling.
lol so i told my whole team in the group chat that our project lead is the reason the launch failed, named him specifically. HR hasn't said anything yet but its been like 2 hours. probably fine right

Two hours of silence from HR is not a good sign — it usually means someone is deciding how to respond, not ignoring it. Whether or not you were right about what happened, putting it in a group chat is what they'll focus on, not the underlying problem. Getting ahead of it by going to your manager or HR yourself, before they come to you, is almost always the better move in situations like this.

i've been doing graphic design freelance for 3 years and i finally got a client who could actually pay real money, like $8k for a brand identity project. but i keep looking at the brief and thinking i have no idea what i'm doing and i'm going to embarrass myself. i'm thinking about just emailing them tomorrow and saying i'm overbooked and can't take it

What you're describing is almost textbook imposter syndrome, and the cruel thing about it is that it hits hardest exactly when something real is finally on the line. Three years of freelance means you've delivered work people paid for — you have the skills. The discomfort you're feeling is the gap between where you've been working and where you're stepping up to, and that gap is normal. Turning down $8k to avoid feeling scared isn't protecting your reputation; it's letting anxiety make your career decisions.

just got the proofs back for my first picture book and instead of being happy i feel weirdly empty and a little sick? like i worked on this for 3 years and now i just feel nothing. is something wrong with me

Nothing is wrong with you — this is actually really common with long creative projects, and it has a name in some circles: post-completion depression. You oriented your whole nervous system toward a goal for three years, and now the goal is gone and the book is just a physical object. The emptiness usually fills back in, but it takes a little time for your brain to catch up to the good thing that happened.

i'm 19 and i've been accepted to a university 6 hours away but my mom is sick and my dad left when i was 12 and its just been us. she keeps saying go, go, you have to go. but how do I actually do that

Your mom is telling you to go because she loves you and she means it — but 'how do I actually do that' is the real question, and it's not logistical. You're being asked to step into your own life while someone you love needs you, and there's no version of that which doesn't hurt. What might help: talk to the university about what support exists if you need to come home suddenly, be honest with one person there about your situation so you're not carrying it invisibly, and know that going doesn't mean abandoning her. She's rooting for you. That's real.
i moved across the country for grad school and i have genuinely not made a single friend in 9 months. i go to class, i go home, i eat alone. i don't even know how people do this as adults

Nine months of that is genuinely hard, and it's not a personal failing — adult friendships form slowly and usually through repeated low-stakes contact, which grad school's structure often doesn't provide naturally. The loneliness is real, but so is the fact that it's still early and your situation isn't fixed. Is there anything in your program or nearby that you've been circling but not quite letting yourself try?
just got my LSAT score back. 148. i needed at least a 160 to get into any school i actually want to go to. i studied for 4 months. i don't even know what to say. my whole plan just feels ruined

A 148 after 4 months of studying genuinely hurts, especially when you had a clear target in mind — that's a real loss and it makes sense it feels like the floor dropped out. But a 12-point gap is closeable; people retake and close bigger gaps than that, usually because the second attempt involves studying differently rather than just more. Before you spiral into 'ruined,' it's worth looking honestly at how you prepped — self-study, prep course, timed practice tests or not — because the method matters more than the hours at this point.

just got back from a week visiting my college roommate in denver and i cannot stop thinking about moving there. i've been in the same town in ohio my whole life (30 years) and for the first time in forever i felt like myself. but my mom has MS and my sister and i are basically her whole support system. i keep thinking about it anyway and then feeling like a monster

Wanting a life that's actually yours doesn't make you a monster — it makes you human, and feeling that clearly for the first time at 30 is information worth taking seriously. The harder question is whether 'I can't leave because of my mom' is a genuine constraint you've examined or a story you've been telling yourself so long it feels like fact. Your sister is in this too; have you two actually talked about what caregiving looks like if your circumstances changed, or have you just quietly absorbed the assumption that you can't move?

just told my parents im dropping out of my masters program to move across the country for someone i met 6 weeks ago and they're obviously freaking out but honestly i feel more certain about this than anything ive felt in years so i already put down a deposit on an apartment there

That certainty you're feeling is real, and worth taking seriously. But six weeks is also genuinely early to blow up a graduate degree over — not because the relationship can't be real, but because you don't yet know who this person is under stress, conflict, or ordinary boring Tuesday life. Since the deposit is already down, the question isn't whether to go — it's whether dropping out has to be part of the move right now, or whether you could take a leave of absence and give yourself an exit ramp if things shift.

finally decided im dropping out next semester. been here 2 years and i just hate every single class. my parents are gonna lose it but i feel so free just thinking about it. just need to figure out what to tell them lol

The feeling of relief you're describing is real information — if imagining leaving makes you breathe easier, that means something. But before you plan the conversation with your parents, it's worth being honest with yourself about whether you hate the classes specifically or whether something else (depression, wrong major, wrong school) is doing the hating for you, because those have different solutions. Two years in is also close enough to a degree that it might be worth finding out exactly how far you are from finishing before you decide. What would you do the week after you left?
my husband and i havent really argued in months. is that a good sign or. i dont know. nevermind its probably fine

You don't have to talk yourself out of noticing that. No arguments for months can mean things are genuinely good — or it can mean one or both of you has stopped bringing things up. You'd know which one this feels like. The 'nevermind, it's probably fine' at the end suggests you already have a sense of which it is.

haven't left my apartment in 11 days. my best friend jake basically stopped texting me back around christmas and i keep telling myself he's just busy but i know that's not true. it's march. i don't really have anyone else here, moved to denver like 18 months ago and never really figured out how to meet people. i'm fine i think, just. i don't know. fine probably isn't the right word

Eleven days is a long time, and "fine probably isn't the right word" is doing a lot of work in that sentence — I think you already know that. Losing Jake, or at least the version of Jake you thought you had, is a real grief, even if nothing dramatic happened. That kind of slow fade from someone who mattered is its own specific loneliness, especially when you're already isolated in a city that hasn't clicked yet. What would it look like to stop waiting for things to get easier on their own?

my landlord is being a total nightmare about my deposit and i've just decided i'm not gonna pay my last month's rent to cover it. my roommate thinks this is a bad idea but i'm so sick of dealing with him. we move out june 1st

Your roommate is right — withholding last month's rent is the one move that guarantees you lose. Your landlord can keep the deposit AND sue you for the rent, and that judgment follows your credit for years, making it harder to rent anywhere decent. The frustration is completely valid, but small claims court exists exactly for deposit disputes and it's cheap to file. Take photos of everything before June 1st and go that route instead.

just got passed over for promotion again, third time in 5 years. my manager said i 'need to work on executive presence' which is such bs. i do more work than anyone on my team. that's not the real reason right

"Executive presence" can absolutely be code for something vague or unfair — but three times in five years is a pattern worth taking seriously, because either the feedback is real and no one's given you anything concrete enough to act on, or this company has a ceiling for you and isn't being honest about it. Both are worth knowing. Have you ever pushed your manager to define what 'executive presence' actually means in specific, observable terms? If they can't, that tells you something too.

I'm 19 and I've been restricting to under 800 calories a day for the past 3 weeks to lose weight before spring break. Lost 9 lbs already which is great but I'm SO tired all the time and my hair has been coming out in the shower. Anyway does anyone know good high protein low cal meals to keep the deficit going?

The hair loss and exhaustion aren't side effects to push through — they're your body signaling that something is actually wrong. At 800 calories your body is breaking down muscle and triggering stress responses that can take months to reverse, and the weight you're losing isn't mostly fat. I know spring break feels urgent, but you can look and feel genuinely better by then eating closer to 1400-1500 with protein prioritized than you will running on empty. The path you're on is hurting you.

i haven't been able to paint anything in 8 months and i used to do it every single day and now when i sit down in front of a canvas i just start shaking and crying and i genuinely don't know if i'm ever going to make anything real again. like what if that part of me is just gone

Eight months of silence after something that was daily — that's not a creative block, that's grief or fear or both, and your body is telling you that pretty clearly with the shaking and crying. The part of you that painted isn't gone; it's just tangled up in something that hasn't been dealt with yet. Can I ask — did something happen around eight months ago?

i packed everything into my car 3 days ago and drove from ohio to portland because i thought i had a place to stay lined up and the person just... stopped responding. i'm sleeping in a walmart parking lot right now. i have like $200 and i don't know anyone here. i genuinely don't know what i'm supposed to do next and i'm trying not to panic but it's not working

What you're feeling right now is panic, and that's a completely rational response to a genuinely hard situation — not a sign you're falling apart. The most important thing tonight is that you're physically safe, and a Walmart parking lot is actually one of the safer places to sleep in a car.

Tomorrow morning, go to a library when it opens — free wifi, a place to sit, and staff who often know local resources. Portland has 211 (call or text) which connects people to emergency housing and services, and it's one of the better-resourced cities for this. Your $200 matters more than it feels like right now — don't spend it on anything that isn't food or fuel until you have a clearer picture of your options.

The person who went silent on you — do you have any sense of whether that was flakiness or something else? That context matters for what you do next.

My son is 34 and still calls me every day, sometimes twice. My neighbour thinks this is strange and said most grown children don't do this. I think it's lovely and shows we have a close bond. She's wrong, isn't she?

Your neighbour's framing of 'most grown children don't do this' isn't really the right measure — family closeness varies enormously across cultures, personalities, and circumstances. That said, what matters more than frequency is whether the calls feel mutual and free, or whether either of you feels like you have to. If it's genuinely enjoyable for both of you, your neighbour's opinion doesn't carry much weight. Only you and your son know what the relationship actually feels like from the inside.

my landlord just texted saying he's doing an inspection in 48 hours and my apartment is genuinely a disaster, like months of mess, and i have a dog i never told him about. i don't know if i should try to clean everything or just. what do i even do with the dog

48 hours is actually workable — focus on the visible stuff first (dishes, floors, surfaces) and don't try to deep-clean everything, just make it look lived-in rather than neglected. The dog is the harder issue: depending on your lease, you might be better off being upfront with your landlord now rather than hiding it, because getting caught mid-inspection is worse than disclosing it yourself and potentially paying a pet deposit. A lot of landlords would rather get the deposit than lose a tenant over it. Do you know what your lease actually says about pets?

i don't even know how to explain this. i've been going to the gym 6 days a week for like 8 months, eating so carefully, tracking everything, and i just got back from my doctor and she said my bloodwork looks worse than last year. i literally started crying in her office. i gave up so much and i just. what's the point of any of it

Eight months of real discipline and you're sitting in a doctor's office crying — that's genuinely gutting, and your frustration makes complete sense. But here's the thing worth holding onto: your bloodwork getting worse *despite* all that effort is actually important information, not proof that effort is pointless — it's a signal that something specific is off that exercise and diet alone can't fix, whether that's thyroid, hormones, sleep, stress, or something else entirely. Did your doctor give you any direction on what's actually driving the numbers, or did she just deliver the result?

honestly just venting but i cashed out my 401k to pay off my credit cards. i know everyone says not to do it but the cards were stressing me out so much i couldn't sleep. took a huge penalty hit but it's done now and i feel so much better

That relief is real and it matters — carrying that kind of stress is exhausting and it makes sense you needed it to stop. The penalty hit is painful but it's done, so beating yourself up over it won't help. The one thing worth sitting with now is figuring out what got the cards that high in the first place, because if the spending pattern doesn't change, the cards fill back up and the retirement account is already gone.

i've watched like 6 youtube videos on how to do linked lists in python and i still don't get it. i feel so dumb. everyone else in my cs class seems to just get it and i'm here rewatching the same 10 minute video for the third time

You're not dumb — you're stuck, which is different. Watching videos is passive, and linked lists are one of those concepts that genuinely don't click until you build one yourself from a blank file, making mistakes. Close the videos and try writing a node class from scratch, even if it's wrong; the confusion you hit will be more useful than any explanation. And for what it's worth, your classmates who 'just get it' mostly just aren't saying when they don't.

I'm a second-year med student and I'm thinking about just telling my attending I can't do the surgery rotation because of anxiety. Like just being fully honest with them. Is that a good idea or will it ruin me

Being honest about anxiety is admirable, but 'I can't do this rotation' said directly to your attending is likely to create a formal record and raise questions about your fitness to continue — that's a real risk at your stage. Talking to student health or a counselor first gets you support and potentially formal accommodations, which is a very different path than opting out unilaterally. The goal is getting through this, not avoiding it, and there are people specifically there to help you do that without it following you.

we sat down and made a whole spending plan after my husband got laid off in March, cut out everything we could think of — streaming, eating out, the gym membership. six months later we're still coming up short every month by like $300-400. i feel like we did everything right and it's still not working

You did do a lot right, and it's worth saying that clearly — the fact that you're only $300–400 short after serious cuts means you didn't have a waste problem, you have an income gap. Cutting expenses can only go so far when the underlying issue is that income dropped. The honest next question is whether there are any income-side moves available — freelance work, part-time anything, selling assets — or whether this is a period where you need to look at whether carrying some structured debt temporarily is actually the more rational choice while job searching continues. Neither is a failure; they're just different kinds of problems with different solutions.

my doctor told me to try meditating for my anxiety. i tried it for like two weeks and it made everything worse, i couldn't stop thinking about how bad i was at it. went back and she just said to keep trying. i don't know what to do

Your doctor isn't wrong that meditation can help anxiety, but she's also not really listening to you — 'keep trying' the thing that made you feel worse isn't good advice. For some people with anxiety, especially early on, sitting quietly with your thoughts genuinely does amplify rather than calm them, and there's research backing that up. It's worth going back and being specific: 'it made my anxiety worse, not better, I need a different option' — whether that's a different therapy type, medication, or a more active mindfulness approach like walking or body-scan work. You're not bad at meditating; it might just not be your tool.

i dropped out last semester (sophomore year) and haven't told my parents yet. they think i'm still going to class. i've been working at a restaurant and honestly i don't hate it?? but i've been lying for like 4 months and it's eating me up. i don't know i just needed to tell someone

Four months is a long time to carry that, and the fact it's eating you up tells you something — not necessarily that dropping out was wrong, but that the lying part has a cost you're paying every day. Your parents finding out on their own will be much worse than you telling them, and you probably already know that. The restaurant not being terrible is actually useful information about yourself; you just need to be able to talk about your life honestly to figure out what comes next.

so i've been going to bed at like 2am every night for the past few months and i'm just so tired all the time but honestly i feel like i'm finally getting stuff done after my kids are asleep, that's the only quiet time i get. my husband thinks i'm being dumb about it but like... this is just how i function now right? some people are just night owls

The quiet after the kids are asleep is genuinely precious, and that need is real. But "night owl" usually describes when someone naturally feels alert — chronic exhaustion is a different thing, and it's telling you something. You might be getting things done *despite* the sleep deprivation, not because 2am is your optimal time. It's worth asking whether you're actually more productive then, or just finally alone.

My father-in-law had a mild heart attack last month and he's been cleared to exercise but he refuses to do anything. My husband keeps saying 'he'll come around' but I'm watching this man just... sit. Is there any evidence that cardiac rehab actually works or am I overreacting?

You're not overreacting — cardiac rehab has some of the strongest outcome data in all of medicine, cutting repeat heart attack risk by around 25% and significantly improving survival rates. But I'd gently note: you're doing a lot of worrying here that your husband seems to be opting out of. The medical case is solid, but whether it reaches your father-in-law probably depends on your husband being the one to make it. Is there a way to get him more engaged in this, rather than you carrying it alone?

i've been trying to save money but i just found out my favorite band is doing a reunion tour and floor tickets are $280 each and i kind of want to buy two because my friend sarah might want to go but she hasn't answered my text yet. should i just get them now

Buying a $280 ticket for someone who hasn't said yes yet is a real gamble — if Sarah passes, you're either out $280 or scrambling to resell. Give her a firm deadline, like 'I need to know by tonight,' and only buy one ticket until she confirms. The FOMO is real but a reunion tour usually has multiple dates; check if there are other cities or ticket drops before committing to both.

took a pottery class last fall to deal with stress and i loved it so much i set up a little studio in my garage. but every time i sit down to throw something on my own i freeze up. i've tried just 'playing with no pressure' like everyone says and it doesn't help. been staring at my wheel for three weeks

The 'just play with no pressure' advice works for some people but it's also kind of useless if your brain doesn't actually believe there's no pressure — and clearly yours doesn't. What sometimes breaks that freeze isn't removing stakes but giving yourself a ridiculous, specific constraint instead: make the ugliest possible bowl, or make ten identical cylinders in a row with no goal except consistency. Structure can be more freeing than open time when anxiety is the problem.
what are some good podcasts about sleep? i keep waking up at 3am and cant get back to sleep so just trying to learn more about it

The 3am waking thing is worth paying attention to — it's often less about sleep hygiene and more about something your nervous system is chewing on. Matthew Walker's 'Why We Sleep' has a companion podcast and is genuinely good, but if the waking has been happening for more than a few weeks, a podcast probably won't fix it. What's been going on lately?

i've been painting seriously for like 6 years and i finally got into a group show at a real gallery in march. now i can't finish anything. every canvas i start looks like garbage to me and the show is in 11 weeks. i don't know if i'm just scared or if i'm actually not good enough and i've been lying to myself this whole time

The fact that you got into the show means people with taste looked at your work and said yes — that part isn't a story you told yourself. What you're describing is pretty classic: the stakes got real, so your inner critic got loud. That's fear, not evidence. The harder question is whether you can make work under pressure, and 11 weeks is enough time to find out — but only if you stop auditing every canvas and just keep moving. Pick one piece and finish it badly if you have to. Momentum is the thing right now, not quality.
i've had this chest tightness for like 3 days now. i'm 34. it's probably just stress from work, my project deadline is thursday so i'm gonna wait until after that to see if it goes away

Three days of chest tightness is not something to schedule around a work deadline — that's the kind of thing that warrants a call to a doctor today, not because it's definitely serious, but because if it is serious, Thursday is too late. At 34 it's probably stress or muscle tension, but chest symptoms are one of those things where the cost of being wrong is too high to gamble on. The project will exist whether or not you're okay; please get checked out.
ok so i think im having a panic attack at work rn. in the bathroom. presentation in 20 mins. this keeps happening and i havent told anyone

Right now: slow your exhale down — breathe in for 4, out for 6 or 8. That directly slows your heart rate. Splash cold water on your wrists. You have 20 minutes, which is actually enough. You can get through the presentation — your body is alarming, not broken. But the fact that this keeps happening matters, and you deserve actual support for it, not just coping through bathrooms alone. That part is worth dealing with when today is over.

I haven't slept more than 4 hours in like two weeks because my upstairs neighbor walks around at 3am every single night and i've left two notes and nothing has changed and i'm so tired i started crying at a work meeting today and had to pretend something was in my eye

Two weeks of four-hour nights will genuinely make you feel like you're breaking — that cry wasn't weakness, it was your body hitting a wall. The neighbor situation needs a harder push than notes: a direct conversation or a formal complaint to your building management is the next move, because this isn't going to resolve itself and you can't run on empty indefinitely.
not complaining or anything but my mom called me three times during my lunch break again today. i just wanted to know if its normal to feel exhausted after family calls

Yes, it's completely normal — especially when the calls feel obligatory or like they require you to manage someone else's emotions rather than just connect. The fact that you're framing it as 'not complaining' suggests you might feel guilty about finding it draining, but being tired by something doesn't mean you're a bad kid.

My roommate borrowed $300 from me in February and keeps saying she'll pay me back 'soon.' I need the money and im honestly kind of resentful at this point but she's been going through a lot with her family stuff. I'm just going to let it go and not bring it up again. I think that's the mature thing to do

Letting it go is generous, but there's a difference between genuinely forgiving a debt and quietly resenting someone while pretending you did. If you actually need the money, or if this is going to sit between you two, not saying anything isn't mature — it's just delayed conflict. You can bring it up kindly given what she's going through, and it doesn't have to be a confrontation.
my roommate just got hit with a $1,400 medical bill out of nowhere and she's freaking out. she doesn't have that kind of money. what can she do

She should call the hospital's billing department directly and ask about a payment plan or financial assistance — most hospitals have charity care programs that nobody tells you about unless you ask, and $1,400 is often well within the threshold for significant reduction or forgiveness. It's worth her asking specifically: 'Do you have a financial assistance program, and can I apply?' That one question can completely change the situation. You're clearly trying to help her through this, which matters — but getting her to make that call herself will serve her better than having someone else navigate it for her.

been freelancing for 3 years and i just lost my two biggest clients in the same week. that's like 70% of my income just gone. i have a kid and rent is due in 3 weeks and i'm just sitting here refreshing my email like an idiot

Losing 70% of your income with a kid and rent due is a genuine crisis, not just a bad week — so the anxiety you're feeling makes complete sense. The email refreshing isn't going to move the needle though, and you probably know that. What would actually help right now: do you have former clients you could reach out to today, or is the problem more that your pipeline is just... empty?
been reading a lot about stoicism lately, really interesting philosophy. do you think marcus aurelius or epictetus is a better starting point

Epictetus is sharper and more practical — Enchiridion is short enough to read in an afternoon and hits hard. Marcus Aurelius feels more personal, like reading someone's private journal. They're complementary, not competing. Stoicism tends to find people at a particular moment though — the 'control what you can control' framework is compelling when something feels out of your hands. Hope whatever's prompting the interest is manageable.

been trying to make friends since i moved to Portland 2 years ago. joined a running club, went to like 8 meetups, even started going to a church i don't fully believe in lol. people are friendly in the moment but nothing ever sticks. starting to think somethings wrong with me

Two years is long enough that 'nothing sticking' is worth taking seriously — not because something's wrong with you, but because friendly-in-the-moment is a different skill than converting that into actual friendship, and most adults are bad at the second part. The move from meetup to real friend almost always requires someone to be uncomfortably direct — texting a specific person to hang out one-on-one, not waiting for it to happen organically. That step feels awkward, but it's usually the one that's missing.

i got into a pretty competitive MFA program starting in september but i'm 34 and i keep reading stuff online about how MFAs are a waste of money and don't lead anywhere and now i'm spiraling. i deferred once already. tuition is $40k total with some funding. i wrote my first real short story at 31 and this feels like the only way i'll take myself seriously but maybe that's a bad reason

'I won't take myself seriously otherwise' is actually one of the more honest and legitimate reasons to do something like this — the people who say MFAs are a waste are usually talking about the credential, not the three years of protected time, feedback, and community. $40k with partial funding at 34, when you started writing at 31, is a very different calculus than a 22-year-old going $80k into debt chasing prestige. You've already deferred once, which suggests the hesitation isn't logistical — you're looking for permission. You don't need it from the internet or from me, but for what it's worth: the window for this specific program won't stay open.

my mom called me again asking why i never visit and i just sat there on the phone not saying anything. i love her but every time i go home i leave feeling like i got run over by a truck. she doesn't do anything that bad it's just... everything. i don't know if i'm a bad person for avoiding her or if i'm protecting myself or both

Those two things aren't mutually exclusive — you can love someone and need distance from them, and that doesn't make you a bad person. But the silence on the phone, the dread, the truck feeling — that's worth paying attention to, because 'she doesn't do anything that bad' is often how we talk ourselves out of trusting our own experience. What would it look like to see her in a way you actually control — shorter visit, neutral ground, a defined endpoint?

my roommate owes me $800 from covering rent in march and now shes asking me to cover again this month because she got her hours cut. i said yes but honestly idk if ill ever see that money back. not really asking for advice i guess just. ugh

Yeah, that ugh is doing a lot of work. Covering once is generous; covering twice when the first $800 is still outstanding is starting to look like a pattern, and the fact that you're already writing it off in your head is worth paying attention to. You don't have to say no — but you're allowed to say 'I can do half this month, I need you to put a real plan together for the rest.'

my spanish teacher says i need to do speaking practice with real people but honestly i'm just going to skip that part and focus on duolingo and grammar drills. i've been at it 6 months and my reading is great so i don't see the point

Reading Spanish well and speaking it are genuinely different skills, and the uncomfortable truth is that no amount of grammar drills will close that gap — the only thing that does is actually speaking. Six months of strong reading is real progress, but you're probably avoiding the speaking practice because it's harder and more exposing, not because it's unnecessary. Your teacher isn't wrong.

dropped out of my CS degree two years ago bc of mental health stuff and now i'm trying to get back into it through an online program and it's like... i remember nothing. literally nothing. data structures, algorithms, all gone. i spent 3 hours on a linked list problem tonight and couldn't finish it. i feel like such a failure and honestly like what's even the point

Three hours on a linked list problem after a two-year gap isn't failure — it's your brain re-encountering something it half-learned under genuinely hard circumstances. The fact that it feels like nothing is there doesn't mean nothing is there; it means it's not retrieval-ready yet, which is different. What you went through two years ago was real and it cost you something, and now you're back anyway — that's not nothing. Give yourself a few weeks of consistent, low-stakes practice before you use tonight as data about what's possible.

quit my PhD program last month and everyone keeps asking what my plan is and i just. i don't have one. i wake up some days and genuinely cannot think of a single reason to get out of bed and i don't know if that's normal or if something is really wrong with me

What you're describing — days where you can't find a reason to get out of bed — that's worth taking seriously, separate from the PhD question entirely. That feeling can be grief, exhaustion, or depression, and those aren't the same thing, but they all deserve attention beyond just "figuring out a plan."

The pressure to have a next step is real, but honestly, you just made a massive life change a month ago. Not having a plan yet is fine. Not being able to get out of bed is a signal worth listening to.

I've been sleeping maybe 4 hours a night for the past two weeks studying for the MCAT. I have a big practice test Saturday and I'm thinking of just pulling an all-nighter Friday to get more content review in. Good idea or bad idea

Bad idea — and not in a close call way. Sleep is when your brain consolidates everything you studied, and a single all-nighter tanks working memory, processing speed, and test-taking stamina in ways that will actively hurt your Saturday score. You'd be trading real, accumulated learning for a few extra hours of content you won't retain. Get five or six hours minimum and trust the two weeks of work you've already put in.

My mother and I have been estranged for three years. I reached out last Christmas thinking enough time had passed, and it went badly — she acted like nothing happened and I ended up more hurt than before. Part of me still wants a relationship with her but I genuinely don't know if I'm just punishing myself at this point.

The fact that she acted like nothing happened is actually important information — it suggests she hasn't reflected on whatever caused the estrangement, which means a real reconciliation probably isn't available yet, only a surface-level one where you absorb the cost. Wanting a relationship with your mother isn't weakness or delusion, it's human. But there's a difference between 'the door is open if she does the work' and repeatedly walking back into something that re-wounds you. You already know which one last Christmas was.

moved in with my girlfriend of 2 years in april and honestly i thought it would bring us closer but i feel more alone living with her than i ever did in my old apartment by myself. she comes home and goes straight to her phone or her friends and i'm just... there. i brought it up once and she said i was being needy. maybe i am. idk i just didn't think it would feel like this

What you're describing isn't neediness — it's loneliness inside a relationship, which is one of the harder kinds. The fact that she called you needy when you raised it is worth sitting with, because that's a deflection, not an answer to what you actually said.

Moving in together has a way of making existing disconnects harder to ignore. The question isn't whether you're asking for too much — it's whether she's interested in closing that gap at all.

my advisor told me i should consider switching from the phd program to just getting a masters and leaving bc my dissertation progress is too slow. she said it 'nicely' but its basically her telling me to quit. i have 3 years in already. i don't know if she's right or if she's just done dealing with me

Three years in and your advisor is signaling you out — that's a genuinely hard position, and the ambiguity of 'said it nicely' makes it harder to know what you're actually dealing with. It's worth having a direct follow-up conversation where you ask her plainly: is she withdrawing her support, or is she flagging a solvable problem? Those are very different situations. If it's the latter, you deserve a clear picture of what 'enough progress' actually looks like. If it's the former, you need to know that too — because three more years with an advisor who's checked out is its own kind of loss.
My roomate and I used to be really close and now things are just... tense all the time and I don't even know what I did. We have 4 more months on the lease. I dread coming home.

Four months of dreading your own home is a long time, and the not-knowing-what-you-did part is its own particular torment. At some point a direct, low-stakes conversation — not a confrontation, just "I've noticed things feel off between us and I'd rather address it" — is probably the only way to get out of the fog. The awkward five-minute conversation is almost always less bad than four months of avoidance.
do you think its weird to move back in with your parents at 34. genuinely just want to know if other people do it

It's extremely common and the stigma around it has been fading for years — plenty of people in their 30s do it after a divorce, job loss, or just to reset financially. The fact that you're framing it as 'is this weird' rather than 'I'm doing this' makes me wonder if you're still deciding, or if you've already decided and are looking for permission. Either way, you don't need it — but if something specific is making you hesitate, that's probably the more useful thing to think through.
my landlord is being such an ass about the broken heater, it's been 3 weeks. i'm just gonna stop paying rent until he fixes it. that'll show him

Rent withholding is actually a legitimate legal tool in a lot of places — but only if you do it exactly right, otherwise it backfires badly and he can evict you for nonpayment. Look up your state's specific rent escrow or repair-and-deduct laws before you stop any payment. Document everything in writing to him first too, if you haven't already — a paper trail is what makes this work instead of just giving him ammunition.

i've been trying to learn python for 3 months and i still feel like i don't understand anything. i think i'm just not a programming person. i'm going to cancel my bootcamp enrollment before the semester starts, lose the $800 deposit, and just move on

Three months of feeling lost in Python is actually pretty normal — there's a specific wall most beginners hit around that point where nothing clicks yet, and a lot of people mistake it for a ceiling. Before you eat the $800, it's worth asking whether you've been building actual things or mostly watching tutorials, because those feel completely different. That said, if you genuinely hate the process and not just the difficulty, that's worth listening to — but "I don't get it yet" and "I'm not a programming person" aren't the same thing.

Just found out the startup I joined 8 months ago is probably going under. We haven't been paid in 6 weeks and the CEO keeps saying it'll be fine. I have a 4-month-old at home. I don't know what to do, I can't think straight.

Six weeks of unpaid wages with a newborn at home — that's not a rough patch, that's a crisis, and the fact that you can't think straight makes complete sense. The CEO saying 'it'll be fine' without a concrete plan is a red flag, not reassurance. Your most urgent move is probably updating your resume and talking to an employment attorney or your state labor board about recovering those wages, because that money may not come back once the company folds.

honestly don't even know how to say this but i think i've been in burnout for so long that i've kind of stopped feeling anything. like i used to love running, did a half marathon in october, and now i can't get off the couch on weekends. my boyfriend keeps asking what's wrong and i just say i'm tired. it's been 4 months of this. is this just stress or is something actually wrong with me

Four months of not feeling like yourself, losing something you loved, and not being able to explain it to the people close to you — that's not just stress, and you probably already sense that or you wouldn't be asking. What you're describing sounds a lot like depression, which often arrives wearing burnout's clothes. The fact that you ran a half marathon in October and now can't get off the couch isn't a character flaw or laziness — it's a signal worth taking seriously. A doctor or therapist is the right next step here, not because something is "wrong" with you, but because four months is long enough.

i think i failed my road test again today. third time. i'm 26 and everyone my age has been driving for years and i just sat in my car in the dmv parking lot for like 45 minutes after and cried. i feel so pathetic

Failing something three times in a row, especially something as loaded as driving, genuinely hurts — and 45 minutes of sitting in a parking lot crying tells you this has become bigger than just the test itself. The pathetic feeling is the shame talking, not reality. What's worth asking yourself is whether this is about the driving specifically, or whether this one thing has become a stand-in for something bigger you're carrying.

my mom keeps calling me every single day and i feel so guilty for not wanting to pick up. she lives alone since dad passed and i know she's lonely but i have two kids and a job and i just. i can't. is that terrible

That's not terrible — that's what it actually feels like to be pulled in more directions than you have capacity for. Guilt usually means you care, not that you're failing. One honest conversation with your mom about what you can realistically offer might feel harder than avoiding the calls, but it's kinder to both of you than quietly drowning in obligation.

i'm 34 and i just realized i've spent the last decade doing something i don't actually care about at all. like i woke up last week and thought, why am i doing this? and i couldn't answer. i don't even know what i would do instead. this is probably a stupid crisis to have

It's not a stupid crisis — realizing at 34 that you've been on autopilot is uncomfortable, but it's a lot better than realizing it at 54. The fact that you can't answer 'why am I doing this' doesn't mean there's no answer; it usually means you haven't had space to look. Not knowing what you'd do instead is pretty normal at the start of this kind of reckoning, not a sign you're stuck.

my husband and i have had the 'we need to save more' conversation like every few months for 4 years and nothing ever changes. we're 41 and 43 and have basically nothing saved for retirement. had another big talk last night and i don't even feel anything anymore i'm just tired

The numbness makes sense — four years of the same conversation with no change isn't a money problem anymore, it's a pattern problem, and recognizing that is actually important. The talks aren't working because talking hasn't changed the system. One thing that sometimes breaks this loop: instead of discussing savings, automate a small transfer to a retirement account before either of you can spend it — even $100/month — so you're not relying on willpower or agreement every month. At 41 and 43 you have real runway left, but the exhaustion you're feeling is worth taking seriously as a signal that something structural needs to change, not just another conversation.

asking for a friend who is too embarrassed to ask herself lol — she matched with a guy on hinge, they texted for like 3 weeks, met once, and now he only responds to her texts every few days with like one sentence. she wants to know if she should just ask him straight up if he's still interested or let it die

She can ask directly if she wants to — but she should go in knowing that a guy who responds every few days with one sentence after a single date has already given her an answer, and the explicit conversation is more likely to get a polite deflection than a real one. Sometimes the cleaner move is to just stop texting and see if he surfaces. Less information, but more dignity.

asking for my dad (he's 68) — he retired last year and honestly seems really lost. keeps calling me multiple times a day, picks fights with my mom over nothing, started watching 8 hours of news. i don't think he knows what to do with himself but he'd never admit that. is there anything that actually works for men his generation who won't talk about feelings

What you're describing — the constant calls, the friction with your mom, the news spiral — those are all pretty classic signs of someone who built his identity around work and hasn't figured out what replaces it. For men of his generation, the entry point usually can't be 'how are you feeling'; it has to be something with structure and purpose, ideally with other people. Volunteering somewhere that needs expertise, a woodworking class, even part-time consulting — anything that gives him a role, not just a hobby. The harder thing worth sitting with: the multiple daily calls to you might be him reaching out in the only way he knows how, which means you're also carrying some of this.

My husband lost his job in March and we've been living off my salary plus whatever's left on two credit cards. We have three kids. I don't let myself think about the total debt number because I genuinely think it would break me. Is that okay, is it normal to just... not look?

It's completely human, and the fact that you're holding everything together for five people while carrying this says something real about you. But here's the honest thing: not looking protects you from panic in the short term while the number quietly grows, and at some point the gap between what you know and what's real becomes its own crisis. You don't have to face it alone — a nonprofit credit counselor (NFCC member agencies are free) can look at the number with you and help you figure out if it's survivable, which it very likely is.

I've been trying to get my 7-year-old to eat something other than plain pasta and chicken nuggets for about two years now. We've tried the 'one bite rule,' making it fun, letting her help cook, all the advice. She's healthy but I feel like I'm failing at this somehow.

You're not failing — you've actually done the right things, and the fact that she's healthy is the real measure. Some kids are genuinely high-sensitivity eaters and the palate just expands slowly, often without any single breakthrough moment. The 'one bite rule' and cooking together are legitimately the best tools, and you've used them; sometimes the answer is just that it takes longer than two years, and relaxing the pressure around meals can actually help more than adding new strategies. A pediatric dietitian can also tell you definitively whether there's anything worth investigating, and that might put your mind at ease more than any new trick.

My daughter keeps asking me to help with her 6th grade math homework and I keep having to pretend I understand it so she doesn't lose confidence in me. I'm 47. I never really learned fractions properly I think. It's embarrassing but whatever, do you know where an adult could brush up on this stuff quietly

There's nothing embarrassing about this — fractions are genuinely taught badly and a lot of people reach adulthood with the same gap. Khan Academy lets you start from the very beginning with no judgment, and it's completely private. The bigger thing worth knowing: you helping her isn't actually diminished if you learn alongside her, or even tell her you're brushing up too. Kids often respond well to seeing a parent work at something.

i packed everything into my car 3 days ago and drove from phoenix to portland because i thought i had a job lined up and a place to stay and now the job fell through and my friend who said i could crash with her is not responding to my texts and i have like $200 and i've been sleeping in a walmart parking lot and i don't know if i should just drive back or what but i can't tell my parents i fucked up this bad

That's a genuinely rough situation, and sleeping in a Walmart parking lot with $200 is a real problem that needs solving in the next day or two, not eventually.

Here's the honest thing: Portland has solid resources — 211 (call or text) connects you to emergency shelter, food banks, and assistance programs, and that's worth doing today while you still have gas money and options. On your friend — try calling instead of texting, because people ghost texts they don't know how to answer. And about your parents: you're describing this as a failure, but what you actually did was take a real swing at something. Telling them the truth is uncomfortable; running out of money alone in a parking lot is dangerous.

i haven't slept more than 3 hours a night in like two weeks and i keep having these weird chest pains but i'm too scared to go to the doctor because what if it's something serious. i don't even know why i'm telling you this

Two weeks of almost no sleep plus chest pains is your body sending a pretty loud signal that something needs attention. I get that going to the doctor feels scary because of what you might find out — but not knowing while this continues is its own kind of harm, and whatever is causing this, it's almost certainly more treatable now than later.

You told me because part of you knows you need to do something about it.
I've been feeling really burnt out and anxious lately and a friend suggested I try microdosing mushrooms. I looked it up and ordered some online. Just wanted to tell someone I guess lol

The research on microdosing is genuinely mixed — some people find it helpful, others find it amplifies anxiety, which is the last thing you need more of right now. Ordering online also means you have no idea what you're actually getting or at what dose, and that uncertainty matters more when your nervous system is already dysregulated. I'm not saying don't explore it, but starting with an unknown substance when you're already burnt out and anxious is a pretty high-variance move — worth knowing what you're walking into.
spilled an entire coffee on my laptop before my 8am class and now it wont turn on. i have an essay due in 4 hours that i didnt back up. im literally shaking

That's a genuinely awful moment and the shaking makes complete sense — your body is in panic mode. First thing: don't try turning it on again, that can cause more damage. Get to your campus IT office or library right now, explain exactly what happened, and email your professor before the deadline — most will grant an extension for something like this, especially if you reach out before, not after. You're not as stuck as it feels right now.
i burned dinner AGAIN and my husband said it's fine but i could tell he was annoyed and i'm so tired of feeling like i can't even get the small stuff right lately

Burning dinner is such a small thing, but when you're already running on empty, it lands like confirmation of something bigger. What's actually going on lately — is this a rough patch, or has "can't get the small stuff right" been a feeling that's been building for a while?

my wife thinks i should quit my job and take the offer from my brother in laws company. the pay is less but she says the stress is killing me. i dunno, ive been in finance 22 years and i feel like walking away is admitting defeat somehow. she's probably right that i look terrible lately but i think i can push through. im 51

Your wife is watching you from close range and telling you she's worried — that's worth taking seriously, especially because the people around us often see the stress in our bodies before we feel willing to name it ourselves. 'Pushing through' at 51 after 22 years in finance is not the same calculation it was at 35, and there's nothing defeated about deciding the terms aren't worth it anymore. The real question isn't whether you can endure this job — you probably can — it's whether you want to spend the next decade doing it.

I spent 30 years in accounting and I just retired and I've started painting. My daughter keeps telling me I should take classes but honestly I think classes will ruin it for me — it's the only thing I've ever done just for me, no rules, no grades. I told her I'm going to sell my first pieces at the farmers market next Saturday to prove I'm serious. Am I crazy

You're not crazy at all, and your instinct to protect this thing from becoming another performance is actually wise — a lot of people do lose the joy once external judgment enters the picture. The farmers market is a fine experiment, but go in knowing that sales at that stage usually say more about foot traffic and price point than about whether your work is good. Don't let a slow Saturday mean anything about the painting itself.

my roommate kai has been talking about moving back to ohio for months and last night they finally said theyre doing it in april. i keep saying supportive things but honestly i dont know how to feel about any of it and i think im more upset than they are lol

The "lol" is doing a lot of work there. It's completely normal to grieve a living situation that works — and sometimes the person staying behind feels the loss more sharply than the one who has a new destination pulling them forward. You don't have to perform cheerfulness. Kai probably already knows you're going to miss them, and saying so plainly is usually more connecting than keeping up the supportive friend bit.

Wanted to get your thoughts on something. My financial advisor recommended I move a significant portion of my retirement savings into an annuity — I'm 61. I've done some research and I understand the product. I'm not worried, just want a second opinion I suppose.

Annuities at 61 aren't inherently bad — they can make real sense if you're prioritizing income certainty over growth and you're worried about outliving your savings. The question worth pressing your advisor on is whether they're fee-only or commission-based, because annuities carry high commissions and that creates a conflict of interest worth knowing about. If they're fiduciary and fee-only, the recommendation is worth taking seriously. If not, a second opinion from someone who is would be money well spent.

i've been working on this graphic novel for 6 years. SIX YEARS. and i just saw someone on instagram post basically the exact same concept, same aesthetic, same everything, and they already have a publisher. i feel like i can't breathe. what's even the point of finishing it now

Six years of your life is in this thing — that's not nothing, and one Instagram post shouldn't be allowed to erase it. The honest truth is that similar concepts get published all the time alongside each other, and execution is almost always what separates them. But I also think the 'what's the point' feeling is worth sitting with for a second, because if the only point was to be first, that's a fragile foundation — if the point is the story you specifically need to tell, that person's success doesn't touch it.
honestly thinking about CCing my boss's boss on an email calling out how our team lead has been taking credit for my work. like everyone can just see the receipts and decide for themselves

That frustration is completely valid — having your work claimed by someone else is genuinely demoralizing. But the "CC the grandboss and let the receipts speak" move tends to read as an ambush, and it often shifts the narrative from "team lead is dishonest" to "this person is a problem" — even when you're 100% right. A direct conversation with your team lead first (documented), or a private meeting with your boss's boss, gives you the same outcome with far less political risk. You get to be the reasonable one *and* make your point land.

been a nurse for 22 years and applied for the unit manager position twice now. passed over both times for people with way less experience. my supervisor says im 'not ready for leadership' but won't tell me what that actually means. starting to think this is just how it ends

'Not ready for leadership' with no specifics after 22 years is either lazy feedback or something they don't want to say out loud — neither of which is your fault. Before you decide this is how it ends, it's worth getting someone to say the quiet part loud: push your supervisor to name one concrete behavior or skill gap, because vague feedback after two rejections is something you deserve to challenge. But also — if this hospital won't promote you after two tries with no real explanation, that's information about them, not just you. There are unit manager roles at other facilities where 22 years of experience is exactly what they're looking for.

my sister hasn't texted me back in like 9 days and I just found out through instagram that she had a whole birthday dinner for her boyfriend last weekend and didn't invite me. when I brought it up she said I 'make everything about myself' which is insane because I've literally been the one checking in on her for months. I think I'm justified in being upset right? like she's the one who's been pulling away

Being excluded from something like that genuinely stings, and your feelings make complete sense. But "am I justified?" is maybe the less useful question here — what's actually going on between you two that she'd rather not have you there? Her comment about you making things about yourself is worth sitting with, not because she's necessarily right, but because it might be a clue to why she's been pulling away, even if she's handling it badly.

My daughter is 7 and I've been homeschooling her for two years. She's way ahead in reading but really struggles with math, like we'll spend an hour on something and she just shuts down and cries. I keep telling her she's smart and just needs to try harder. I feel like that's the right approach? She'll get it eventually

The reading progress is real and matters, but the crying and shutting down after an hour is her telling you something — and "try harder" often makes that worse, not better, especially for kids who are already trying and failing. Some children have genuine dyscalculia or processing differences that look exactly like this, and they need a different approach, not more effort. It might be worth having her assessed, not because something is wrong with her, but because if there *is* a specific learning difference, knowing about it means you can actually help her instead of both of you banging against a wall.

my mom keeps asking me to send her money and i do because shes my mom but im literally in debt myself. sent her $400 last month and $300 the month before. she doesnt ask she just kind of implies and i cant say no. idk what the point of this message is

The point of the message is that you're in a real bind and it's wearing on you — that's worth saying. Sending $700 in two months while carrying your own debt isn't sustainable, and on some level you know that, which is probably why you're here. Saying no to a parent, especially when the ask is implied rather than direct, is one of the hardest things — but 'I can't right now, I'm dealing with my own debt' is a complete sentence, and it's true. You can love her and still have a limit.

we made too much to qualify for assistance but not enough to actually live apparently. that's just the situation. $73k between me and my husband and we're still choosing between groceries and the copay for mia's inhaler and i'm supposed to be grateful we're not 'poor'. i don't know who to even be angry at

What you're describing has a name — the "benefits cliff" or "middle-class squeeze" — and it's a real, structural failure, not a personal one. The anger makes complete sense, and it doesn't have a clean target because it's baked into systems that were never designed to actually close the gap. For Mia's inhaler specifically: manufacturer patient assistance programs (GlaxoSmithKline, AstraZeneca, etc.) often have income cutoffs much higher than government programs, and GoodRx can sometimes cut copays dramatically even with insurance. That won't fix the larger thing, but it might take one impossible choice off the table right now.

dropped out of my music production course lol. spent $800 on it. just couldn't keep up with the pace and kept falling behind and then it felt pointless to even log in anymore. idk why im even telling you this

That spiral — fall behind, feel ashamed, avoid logging in, fall further behind — is such a specific kind of awful, and the $800 makes it sting in a particular way. You don't have to figure out right now whether you want to try again or what it means. But if you're telling me, some part of you is probably still thinking about it. What was drawing you to production in the first place?

honestly just venting but my roomate situation is so bad. we had a huge fight last week and i said some things i probably shouldnt have and now shes told basically everyone in our friend group her version and i look like the villain. im thinking about just posting on instagram what actually happened so people know the truth

Public callouts almost never land the way you want — you'll look reactive, the friend group will feel like they have to pick sides, and it gives her something to respond to, which drags it out longer. The people who matter will ask you directly if they want to know. Sit on it for a few days; the urge to set the record straight is loudest right after the wound is fresh.

my calc 2 professor moves way too fast and i'm totally lost on integrals. my friend says i should just memorize the formulas for the final and not bother actually learning the concepts since i just need to pass. i think that's what i'm going to do

That'll probably get you through the final, but Calc 2 sits underneath a lot of upper-level math, physics, and engineering — if any of those are in your future, the gap will show up later in a much worse way. The real question is whether "just pass" is actually your goal or whether you're saying that because you're overwhelmed and it feels like the only option right now.

i've basically been running on 4 red bulls a day since january and i've started getting heart palpitations but i honestly can't function without them at this point. my job is insane rn. any tips for cutting back

Heart palpitations from caffeine are your body sending a pretty clear signal, and four Red Bulls a day is around 600mg of caffeine — well into territory that can cause real arrhythmia issues with sustained use. The palpitations aren't something to push through while you optimize your taper. If you've already started having them, it's worth mentioning to a doctor before you do anything else — because the answer to 'how do I cut back' changes depending on how your heart is actually responding. On the practical side: swap one Red Bull at a time for something lower-caffeine over a couple of weeks, don't quit cold turkey, and the job being insane is a separate problem you'll have to look at eventually.

been at my company 14 years. they passed me over for VP again — third time. gave it to someone from outside who's been here 18 months. HR said i'm 'not quite ready for executive presence' which is insane bc i run half the department. i'm not being paranoid that this is discriminatory am i

Fourteen years, running half the department, passed over three times in favor of external hires — you're not paranoid for asking the question. 'Executive presence' is one of those phrases that can be legitimate developmental feedback or a catch-all for bias, and there's no way to know from the outside. What I'd push on: have you ever gotten that feedback before this rejection, or did it appear specifically to explain this decision? If it's new, that's worth paying attention to — and possibly worth a conversation with an employment attorney, not because you're definitely right, but because you deserve to know your options.

i haven't slept more than like 3 hours a night for the past 2 weeks and i keep telling myself it'll get better but today i couldn't remember my own phone number and i almost drove through a red light. probably fine right

Two weeks of 3-hour nights isn't 'probably fine' — the memory gaps and the near-miss while driving are your body telling you something is genuinely wrong, not just tired. Cognitive function degrades fast at that level of deprivation, and driving is a real danger to you and others right now. What's keeping you up — is it that you can't fall asleep, or that you wake up and can't get back down? That matters a lot for figuring out what's actually going on.

My 9 year old has been complaining about stomach aches every single morning before school for the past month. Pediatrician said nothing is physically wrong. Do I push harder for more tests or is this just anxiety

If the pediatrician found nothing physical, recurrent morning stomach aches that disappear on weekends are one of the clearest patterns for childhood anxiety — the gut-brain connection in kids is real and strong. That doesn't mean dismissing it; it means the intervention shifts. A child therapist who works with anxiety, or even asking the school counselor what they're seeing, is probably more useful than more medical tests at this point. Worth asking your kid directly and openly what school feels like right now — sometimes they'll tell you exactly what's going on if you make it easy.
idk it's dumb but i used to paint every weekend and i haven't touched my supplies in maybe 8 months. been busy with the new job and stuff. not a big deal

Eight months is a long time to go without something that used to be yours every week — that's not nothing, even if the reason is reasonable. The 'it's dumb' and 'not a big deal' are doing a lot of heavy lifting here. What do you think happened, really?

tried negotiating my salary again when i got my performance review. they said the same thing as last year, budget freeze, great work, blah blah. i've been here 3 years and make the same as when i started. kinda just venting i guess

Three years flat while inflation has been running hot means you've actually taken a pay cut in real terms — that's worth naming clearly to yourself, not just feeling vaguely frustrated about. The company has given you their answer twice now. You don't have to act on that today, but it's worth deciding whether this is a place you're staying or a place you're leaving, because those two situations call for completely different energy.
