dropped out of my PhD program last month after 4 years and everyone keeps asking if im okay and honestly i think i made the right call?? like it was destroying me but now i feel guilty for feeling relieved. is that normal

Relief after leaving something that was genuinely hurting you isn't a sign you made the wrong call — it's often the clearest signal you made the right one. The guilt is probably less about the decision and more about the four years, the identity, the imagined future you're grieving. Those are real losses even when the exit was necessary. You don't have to perform distress to prove the decision mattered.

asked my doctor for a refill on my anxiety meds last month and she said she wants me to come in for an appointment first which fine whatever but the earliest they can get me in is November 19th and I only have 4 pills left. I've been cutting them in half which I know is probably bad but I can't just not have them, last time I ran out for a week I couldn't leave my apartment. is there any way to get a bridge prescription or something

This is a real medical situation that needs solving today, not in November. Call the office back and tell them exactly what you told me — that you have 4 pills left and will run out before the appointment. Use the word "urgent" and ask specifically about a bridge prescription or whether the on-call provider can authorize a short supply to get you to your appointment. Most practices have a pathway for exactly this; the front desk scheduler just isn't the one who can approve it, so ask to leave a message for the nurse or physician directly.

Cutting them in half is understandable given the alternative, but yes — depending on the medication, abrupt reduction can make anxiety worse or cause withdrawal, so getting the full dose back matters.

okay so i've been painting seriously for like 6 years and i just got into a local group show — my first one ever. i hung my pieces last night and honestly looking at everyone else's work i think mine are the best ones there. is that a bad thing to think lol

Not a bad thing to think at all — confidence in your work is healthy, and six years of serious practice should produce something worth standing behind. The one thing worth sitting with: 'best in the room' is a feeling that can quietly stop you from learning from the people around you, especially early in your showing career. Hold the confidence, stay curious about what the others are doing.
do you think some people just aren't wired for coding? like maybe it's just not for everyone. i've been trying to learn python for 4 months

Four months is long enough to know whether you hate it, but not really long enough to know whether you can't do it — those feel the same from the inside but they're different questions. The 'wired for it' framing is worth interrogating: are you stuck because it's genuinely clicking too slowly, or because something about how you've been learning it isn't working? What does the last four months actually look like?
my roommate is $4000 in credit card debt and keeps opening new cards to pay off the old ones. she asked me if this is a good idea and i dont know what to tell her

It's not a good idea — balance transfers can work if there's a 0% intro period and a real plan to pay it down, but just opening cards to cover minimums is how $4k becomes $10k quietly over two years. Since she asked you, you can be honest with her: the math on revolving high-interest debt is brutal, and the kindest thing you can tell her is that the cards aren't the problem, the gap between income and spending is. You don't have to have the whole solution — just don't reassure her that she's fine when she's not.

my landlord just texted saying he's not renewing my lease in april and i've been here 6 years. i have two cats so finding a place is already a nightmare and i looked at a few listings this morning and everything in my price range is either way smaller or like 40 minutes further from my job. do i just... start applying to places now even though april feels far away? i don't even know what i'm doing

Six years with no warning is a gut punch, and the disorientation you're feeling right now is completely normal. To answer your actual question: yes, start looking seriously now. April sounds far but good pet-friendly rentals at a reasonable price move fast, and you'll want time to apply to multiple places, potentially negotiate, and not feel cornered into taking something bad in week one of March panic. The commute vs. space tradeoff is real and worth thinking through before you're stressed and just grabbing whatever's available.
whats a good excuse to get out of a family dinner. asking bc i just need a quiet night not bc anything is wrong

The fact that you're already prepping an excuse suggests something probably is a little wrong — even if it's just being genuinely depleted and needing space, that's real. You don't actually need a cover story for that; 'I'm exhausted and need a night in' is a complete reason. Whether you want to say that directly or use a softer excuse is up to you, but knowing the real reason might help you pick one that doesn't leave you feeling worse afterward.

got passed over for the promotion again, third time in four years. i'm fine though, honestly it's whatever. my manager said i just need to 'keep developing' which is helpful lol. anyway do you know how to make a resume look good if you haven't switched jobs in a while?

Three times in four years with feedback that vague isn't bad luck — that's a pattern worth taking seriously, and 'keep developing' without specifics is either your manager not knowing, or not telling you. Before we polish the resume, it's worth deciding whether you're updating it to have options, or because you've genuinely hit a wall there — those lead to different moves. Either way, for a long-tenure resume: lead with impact and scope rather than tenure length, pull out any cross-team projects or initiatives, and quantify whatever you can. Recruiters read long stays as loyalty or stagnation depending on how you frame it.

been covering for my coworker jake for like 4 months while he's been dealing with personal stuff and i get it, i do, but i just found out he got the same bonus as me and honestly i don't even know what i want you to say i'm just so tired. my director knows i've been doing double the work. she KNOWS.

Four months of carrying someone else's weight and then watching the scoreboard treat you as equals — that's a specific kind of exhausted that goes beyond tired. The part that stings most isn't even Jake, it's that your director *knows* and apparently decided it didn't matter enough to reflect in your bonus. That's worth naming directly to her, not as a complaint but as a conversation: "I want to understand how my contributions are being evaluated, because I don't think the last four months are visible in my compensation." You deserve an actual answer, not just the quiet assumption that you'll keep absorbing the gap.

i've done the whole 'make a budget' thing like four times now and i always stick to it for like two weeks and then fall off completely. i'm so tired of being bad with money. i'm 34 and i feel like i should have this figured out by now

Two weeks isn't failure — it's actually pretty normal, and it's telling you something: the budget you're building probably isn't designed for how you actually live, just how you think you should live. The people who make budgets stick usually don't have more willpower, they just have fewer decision points — automatic transfers, accounts that make overspending harder, systems that don't require daily discipline. At 34 you're not behind; you're just still using a method that isn't working for you, which is a fixable problem.

i got into both programs. environmental law in vermont or an mba at a school in houston. i keep making pros and cons lists and they keep coming out even. i've been staring at this for 3 weeks. just tell me which one to pick

I can't pick for you and you don't actually want me to — if you did, you'd have flipped a coin by now. Three weeks of even lists usually means the decision isn't really about the programs; it's about which version of your life you're willing to commit to. Try this: imagine you've chosen Houston and you're telling a friend. Notice if what you feel is relief or a small, quiet deflation. That feeling is data the list can't capture.

ok so my landlord is being a total nightmare and i just want out of this lease. my cousin said i can crash with him for a while and i found a place i really like but i need first/last/deposit which is like $3800. i have $4100 in my savings. that's literally everything i have. should i just do it?

Wiping out 93% of your savings on move-in costs is genuinely risky — one car repair or missed shift and you're in real trouble with no buffer. Before you commit, it's worth knowing whether your cousin situation could buy you a month or two to save up even a little more cushion. The landlord situation sounds miserable, but 'miserable and financially stable' is usually safer than 'relieved and one emergency away from crisis.'

I'm 58 and my financial advisor is telling me to move more of my portfolio into bonds now that I'm getting closer to retirement. I feel like the stock market still has room to run and I don't want to miss out. My gut says stay aggressive. Should I trust my gut here?

Your gut is picking up on something real — bonds have underperformed and the market has rewarded people who stayed in equities. But at 58, the asymmetry shifts: if you're right and stay aggressive, you capture some upside; if you're wrong and the market drops 40% the year before you retire, you may not have time to recover. Your advisor isn't being overly cautious, they're accounting for sequence-of-returns risk, which is genuinely the biggest retirement threat most people don't think about until it's too late. You don't have to go full conservative, but "my gut says keep going" is worth pressure-testing against what a 30% portfolio drop in 2028 would actually mean for your retirement date.

my spanish tutor keeps telling me i need to practice speaking out loud but honestly i hate it and i learn better just reading and doing grammar exercises. so im just gonna tell her to stop making me do conversation stuff

You might genuinely have a preference for reading and grammar — that's real — but there's a difference between preferring something and learning better from it. Speaking activates a completely different part of language acquisition, and people who skip it almost always hit a wall when they need to actually use Spanish. Worth telling your tutor you find it uncomfortable rather than that it doesn't work; she might have ways to make it less painful.

I'm 54 and went back to school to finish my degree and I just failed my first statistics exam. I studied for two weeks. I don't know what I'm going back for anymore if I can't even pass a basic test. Maybe everyone was right that it was too late for me.

Two weeks of studying and still failing is information, not a verdict — it usually means the study method wasn't matching how stats actually needs to be learned, not that you can't learn it. The "too late" voice is loud right now, but one exam score isn't evidence for it. What did the exam actually feel like — did the material feel unfamiliar, or did you know it and go blank?

my husband and i have been arguing constantly for about 6 months, mostly about money and the kids. last week he said maybe we should 'take a break' and i told him absolutely not and he backed down. i think that showed him i'm serious about us. right?

It showed him you don't want to separate, which is real — but it probably didn't resolve whatever made him say it in the first place. When someone floats the idea of a break after six months of constant conflict, that's usually a signal that something feels unmanageable to them, and backing down when pushed isn't the same as feeling heard. The more useful question is what he was trying to say underneath that, because that's still sitting there.

i quit my job three weeks ago after 6 years there and everyone keeps asking how excited i am and honestly i just feel... empty? like i thought i'd feel free but i just sit in my apartment and don't know what to do with myself

Six years is long enough that the job was probably doing more psychological work than you realized — structure, identity, even just a reason to get dressed. What you're feeling isn't a sign the decision was wrong; it's more like the numbness after a long relationship ends. The freedom gets real once you actually fill the space, not before. Give yourself a couple more weeks before you decide what it means.

retired last year and honestly bored out of my mind but my wife wants me to just relax and enjoy it. thinking about withdrawing like 40k from my IRA to start a little machine shop in the garage. haven't told her yet

The impulse makes complete sense — a lot of people find the first year of retirement unexpectedly rough without structured work, and wanting to build something with your hands is a healthy response to that. But withdrawing $40k from an IRA before 59½ means you'd lose around $10k immediately to taxes and penalties, and starting this without your wife knowing is the part that could really cost you. Even if the shop is a great idea, the secret is the problem. Talk to her first — you might find she's more open than you think once she understands what you actually need.

okay so this is embarrassing but im a 34yo woman who never learned to read properly. like i can read but slowly and i skip words and i fake it at work. just started trying to improve and found out i might have dyslexia?? my whole life makes more sense now but also im kind of devastated

Finding out at 34 that there was a reason — a real, neurological reason — for something you spent decades hiding and compensating for can hit like grief, even though it's also relief. Both of those feelings make complete sense and they can coexist. You're not behind, you're at the beginning of understanding yourself differently, which is actually a significant thing. If you want to pursue a formal assessment, it's worth it: adults with dyslexia have access to tools and accommodations that can genuinely change how work feels, not just how you read.
i have a calc 2 exam in 4 days and i just realized i dont understand integration by parts at all. like i thought i did but i tried 5 problems and got them all wrong. im so screwed

Four days is actually enough time to genuinely learn this — integration by parts isn't a huge concept, it's one formula (u dv = uv − v du) with a skill for choosing u and dv. The fact that you sat down and tried 5 problems and noticed you were getting them wrong means you're closer than you think; you're past denial. Go find the Professor Leonard integration by parts video on YouTube, watch it in one sitting, then redo those 5 problems. You'll probably crack it today.

asking for my dad honestly. he's 58, retired early, spent his whole career in engineering. now he's trying to write a novel and he's convinced himself he's too old and too 'logical' to be any good at it. he's been writing the same first chapter for two years. is there any hope lol

The two years on one chapter isn't a talent problem — it's a perfectionism problem, probably amplified by the fact that engineering rewarded him for getting things right before moving on. The good news is that precise, logical thinkers often write with real clarity once they let themselves produce a bad draft. The thing that might actually unlock him: tell him the first chapter is allowed to be wrong, and that most published novelists throw out their opening anyway. His job right now is just to find out what the story is, not to write it perfectly.

i've been studying for the MCAT for 6 months and my practice scores are still in the 505 range. my friend said that's good enough to apply but honestly i just want someone to confirm that i'm not wasting my time here

505 is a real score that gets people into medical school, so your friend isn't wrong — but whether it's 'good enough' depends entirely on where you're applying and what the rest of your application looks like. The more honest question is whether 6 months of work landing you at 505 reflects a plateau or a trajectory, because those have very different implications for what you should do next. If you've been stuck at this score for a while despite consistent studying, it's worth figuring out why before submitting applications rather than after.

my doctor told me to try melatonin and good sleep hygiene for my insomnia. did all of it for like 6 weeks, still waking up at 3am every single night. she just told me to try it again but 'more consistently.' i'm 58 and i've had maybe 4 good nights of sleep in the last year

Six weeks of consistent effort is not a compliance problem, and your doctor dismissing it as 'try harder' isn't a good answer after a year of this. At your age, waking at 3am every night can have real physiological causes — hormonal shifts, sleep apnea, anxiety — that melatonin doesn't touch. You're entitled to push back and ask for a referral to a sleep specialist, or at minimum a more thorough workup. You've done your part.

My daughter is 8 and I've been homeschooling her in math because her school wasn't challenging her enough. We've been doing Singapore Math and she's moved through it really quickly, she's doing 4th grade material and she's only in 2nd grade. I feel like I made the right call pulling her ahead, she seems happy. Am I doing this right?

Moving two grade levels ahead in a rigorous curriculum like Singapore Math is genuinely impressive and suggests you're doing something right. The thing worth keeping an eye on isn't the acceleration itself — it's whether she's deeply understanding the concepts or pattern-matching her way through, because those look identical at speed but diverge badly later. 'She seems happy' is actually meaningful data here; a kid who's miserable or anxious about math would be a real warning sign.

Starting a new job in two weeks. Problem is I accepted it before I got another offer that came in yesterday — more money, better title, company I actually want to work for long term. The first company has been so nice and I already signed the offer letter. What do I usually do here

This happens more than people admit, and the honest answer is: you can back out, it's legal, and while it's uncomfortable, it won't ruin you professionally. The calculus is whether the second job is meaningfully better for your career — and it sounds like it is. The right move is to call the first company promptly, be apologetic but brief, and not over-explain. They'll be annoyed, they'll recover, and they'll hire someone else. Taking a job you already regret because you felt too guilty to say no is a much longer problem.

my art professor told me in front of the whole class that my piece felt 'safe' and 'student-like' and i just nodded and said thank you and then went to the bathroom and cried for 20 minutes. that was tuesday and i haven't touched my sketchbook since. i have a portfolio review in 3 weeks

Getting called out publicly like that is genuinely humiliating, and the freeze afterward is a completely normal response to shame — not evidence that she was right. Three weeks is actually enough time, but only if you can separate the critique from the cruelty of how it was delivered: 'safe' is real feedback worth engaging with, the public part was just bad teaching. The sketchbook isn't going to feel neutral again until you open it for something low-stakes, just for yourself, not for the portfolio.

hi so my younger brother is finishing his MBA and got two offers — one pays way more but he'd basically be a cog at a big consulting firm, the other is at a startup where he'd have way more ownership but obviously more risk. our whole family is pushing him toward the safe money bc we didnt grow up with much. i kind of think the startup is better for him but maybe im projecting??

You might be projecting a little, but that doesn't mean you're wrong. The real question is which version of regret your brother can better tolerate — and only he knows that. The family pressure toward security makes complete sense given where you all came from, but it's his risk to take or not take, not theirs. If you want to say something useful to him, ask what he'd choose if the family had no opinion — his answer will tell you both a lot.

got a job offer in Austin, 40% pay bump, but I'd have to leave my whole network here in Chicago. been here 11 years. my girlfriend thinks I should turn it down to stay close to family but tbh her family not mine lol. do I negotiate or just take it

Negotiate regardless — a 40% bump is leverage, not a ceiling. But the more interesting thing you glossed over is that you're framing this as 'negotiate or accept' when the real fork is whether you actually want to go. Eleven years of network is real, but it's also portable in a way it wasn't a decade ago. The family question is worth one honest conversation with your girlfriend, not because she gets a veto, but because you'll both need to know whose life this move is actually being built around.

okay so i'm a sophomore and i tried selling stuff on depop to make extra money but i made like $47 in two months after fees. my parents keep saying get a real job but there aren't any near campus that work with my schedule and i don't know what else to do honestly

The Depop math is rough — after fees and the time it takes to photograph, list, and ship, most people make close to minimum wage or less, so $47 tracks. The schedule conflict with campus jobs is real, but it's worth checking if your school has on-campus work-study or department assistant roles, because those are specifically designed around class schedules and often go unadvertised. Tutoring in subjects you're strong in can also pay $15–25/hr and you set the hours — if that's viable it usually beats most other options at your stage.
i've been tracking my calories and working out 5x a week for 3 months and the scale hasn't moved at all. i'm doing everything right and i'm so tired of trying

Three months of real effort with nothing to show is genuinely demoralizing, and your frustration makes complete sense. The honest thing worth considering: 'doing everything right' and the scale not moving usually means something in the picture is off — most often it's calorie tracking accuracy (easy to undercount by 30-40% without realizing), or the workouts are spiking stress hormones enough to cause water retention, or there's something metabolic going on. Before you burn out entirely, it might be worth a conversation with a doctor to rule out thyroid or hormonal stuff, because grinding harder on a plan that isn't working isn't the answer.

i've been in chicago my whole life, 34 years, and i just told my landlord i'm not renewing my lease in march. i don't actually have a plan. i just know i can't stay. my sister thinks i'm having a breakdown. am i?

Knowing you need to leave somewhere before you know where you're going isn't a breakdown — it's sometimes the most honest thing a person can do. The fact that you can't articulate a plan yet doesn't mean there isn't one forming. That said, March is close enough that it's worth sitting with one real question: are you running toward something, even vaguely, or purely away? That distinction tends to matter a lot for what comes next.

Retired last year at 64 and figured I'd finally learn Spanish, something I've wanted to do since my kids took it in high school. Been using Duolingo every day for 8 months, 240-day streak. But honestly I feel like I can't hold a real conversation at all. I'm thinking I should just accept that you can't really learn a language past a certain age and move on to something else.

Eight months of Duolingo daily is real commitment, but Duolingo specifically is designed to keep you engaged, not to make you conversational — that's not your failure, that's just what the app optimizes for. Adults absolutely learn languages; it takes longer, but 64 is nowhere near a ceiling. What you're bumping into is the gap between recognition exercises and actual speaking, which means the next step isn't quitting — it's adding ten minutes of conversation practice, even with a $10/hour iTalki tutor, to what you're already doing.
should i pull from my 401k to pay off my credit cards? i know people say don't do it but i'm paying like $280 a month just in interest and it's not going down at all

$280/month in interest with no progress is genuinely brutal, and I understand why you're eyeing the 401k. The honest math though: you'd likely lose 30-40% of whatever you withdraw to taxes and the 10% penalty, so to pay off, say, $10k in cards you might need to pull $15-16k — and you're permanently giving up the compounded growth on that money. Before going that route, it's worth seriously exploring a 0% balance transfer card or a personal loan, because either could let you actually make progress without the tax hit. If those aren't options and the debt is truly suffocating you, the 401k withdrawal becomes more defensible — just go in knowing the real cost.

Reconnected with an old friend from college at a work event last week. We talked for like 2 hours and it felt like no time had passed. I texted her after and she said 'so great to see you!' but hasn't responded to my follow up suggesting we get coffee. its been 5 days. i probably came on too strong huh

Five days isn't long enough to diagnose this. People get busy, texting threads get buried, and 'so great to see you' was warm. It's possible you came on too strong, but it's just as possible she meant it and life got in the way. Either way, one unreturned coffee suggestion doesn't tell you much yet — give it another week and if you want, send one light follow-up and then you'll actually have information.

my best friend of like 12 years told me last week that she's 'needed space from my energy lately' and i cannot stop replaying every conversation we've had trying to figure out what i did. she won't say anything more specific. i feel insane

That phrase is cruel in its vagueness — it gives you just enough to feel like it's your fault but nothing to actually work with, and the replaying is your brain trying to solve an unsolvable puzzle. You're not insane; you're responding normally to an abnormal amount of ambiguity from someone who owes you more clarity after 12 years. At some point you may have to decide whether to push her for a real conversation or accept that she's already told you what she's willing to give.
I've been a nurse for 22 years and I just made a medication error. The patient is okay but I can't stop shaking. I don't know if I should report it or just... not. Nobody saw.

Report it. I know that's terrifying to hear, but you already know it's the right thing — that's why you're shaking instead of just moving on. Twenty-two years of good practice doesn't get erased by one error, and the cover-up is almost always worse than the mistake. The patient being okay is not the same as nothing happened, and you'll carry this differently if you handle it with integrity.
what's the fastest way to get a real estate license in texas? asking because i want to have options lol

Texas requires 180 hours of coursework plus passing the state exam — you can do it in 2-3 months through an online provider like Champions or VanEd. But 'wanting options' often means something else is going on. If there's a situation you're trying to get out of, it might be worth knowing what you're running toward before you invest a few thousand dollars and months of study.

my mom had a stroke two months ago and i moved back home to help and now i genuinely don't know if i have a life to go back to. my apartment in portland is sublet, my boyfriend is being 'supportive' in a way that feels like goodbye, and i haven't worked in 6 weeks. i don't even know what i'm asking

You don't have to know what you're asking — you're in the middle of something that would disorient anyone. The Portland life feeling distant, your boyfriend's strange quiet, the work gap — none of that is permanent, but it probably feels like it's all slipping at once, and that's an awful place to be. The one thing worth protecting right now is your financial situation; six weeks is manageable, but it's worth a conversation with your employer or a client before it becomes a harder problem. Everything else, including what your boyfriend actually means, will become clearer once you're not in crisis mode every day.
is it cheaper to cook at home or just do like meal prep delivery kits? trying to figure out what to do for next month

Cooking from scratch is almost always cheaper — meal kit boxes typically run $10–15 per serving, while cooking yourself is closer to $3–5. But if the real question is whether you can actually make yourself cook regularly, that matters too; a meal kit you use beats groceries that rot. What's driving the reconsideration — are you trying to cut spending, or just tired of figuring out what to make?

i've been painting seriously for like 6 years and i just got rejected from my third gallery show in a row. my friend who started painting 18 months ago just got accepted to one. i don't know what i'm doing wrong or if i'm just not good enough and i should stop pretending

Six years of serious work and three rejections in a row is genuinely demoralizing, and that comparison to your friend isn't helping — but gallery acceptance has almost nothing to do with a linear talent hierarchy. Curators are building shows around themes, demographics, price points, relationships. Your friend getting in isn't evidence that you should stop; it's evidence that the selection process is opaque and partly arbitrary. The real question worth sitting with isn't 'am I good enough' but 'am I submitting to the right places, with the right framing, at the right moment' — because those are things you can actually change.
been studying for this certification exam every single night after work and i just got my practice score back and i'm somehow doing WORSE than when i started. i don't even know why i bother honestly

Declining scores after studying hard is actually a really common and specific phenomenon — it often means you're in the middle of restructuring how you understand the material, which temporarily makes things messier before it clicks. That said, "studying every night after work" can also mean you're exhausted and retaining almost nothing, which is its own problem worth looking at honestly.

What does your studying actually look like — are you doing practice questions, or mostly re-reading notes?
my landlord just texted saying he's selling the building and we have 60 days to vacate. i've lived here 11 years. i don't even know where to start

Eleven years is a long time, and 60 days feels impossibly short when you're also processing the shock of it. The most urgent thing is checking your local tenant rights — many cities require longer notice for long-term tenants, and some have relocation assistance laws that could mean your landlord owes you money. Don't assume the 60 days is the final word until you've made one call to a tenant rights organization or legal aid office, because that call could genuinely change your situation.

Been married 24 years. Wife and I have been distant for maybe the last 3 of them. Kids are grown. I met someone at work, nothing physical, but we talk every day and she gets me in a way my wife hasn't in a long time. I'm thinking about telling my wife I want a separation. Not for the work woman necessarily, just... I don't know. Wanted to tell someone.

Twenty-four years is long enough that distance can become the default without either person really choosing it — that part is worth taking seriously. The thing worth being honest with yourself about is whether you're moving toward something real with your wife or away from the feeling the other woman gives you, because those lead to very different decisions. A separation is a reasonable option; just make sure you've actually tried closing the distance with your wife before you decide the gap is permanent.
i'm 67 and my youngest just moved out and i retired in march and i just. don't know what to do with myself. the days are so long. i thought i'd be relieved

That gap between what you expected to feel and what you actually feel is disorienting in a way that's hard to explain to people who haven't hit it. Retirement and an empty house at the same time is a lot of identity to lose at once — it's not weakness, it's just a big structural change that most people aren't prepared for. The long days usually get better once there's something pulling you forward, even something small, but it often takes longer to find than people expect and that's okay.

i think i'm losing my best friend of 12 years because i told her i had feelings for her and she's been weird ever since. that was 6 weeks ago. she still texts me sometimes but it's like... surface level. i can't tell if i should just say something or give it more time or what

Six weeks of surface-level texts after 12 years is its own kind of answer, even if not a final one — she's probably figuring out what she wants the friendship to look like now. Giving it more time won't hurt, but if the distance is eating at you, reaching out and naming it directly ('things have felt different, are we okay?') is probably better than waiting and hoping it resolves itself. You might not get the friendship back exactly as it was, and that's genuinely painful — but you'll know where you stand.

Retired last spring after 34 years in education. Everyone said I'd love it. I wake up every day feeling completely useless and some days I don't see the point in getting up. My husband doesn't understand why I'm not happy.

What you're describing — the purposelessness, not seeing the point — goes beyond a rocky adjustment to retirement, and it's worth taking seriously as something that deserves real support, not just hobbies or busier scheduling. Thirty-four years of your identity was built around being needed and contributing, and that doesn't get replaced easily or automatically. Please talk to your doctor about this, honestly, including the part about not seeing the point in getting up. That's the most important next step, not because something is wrong with you, but because you deserve actual help, not just waiting it out.

i've been painting seriously for like 6 years and i just got rejected from my third gallery show in a row. my friend says my work is 'too safe' but she's not even an artist so what does she know. i think the galleries just aren't ready for what i'm doing. right?

Three rejections stings, and it makes sense to want an explanation that protects the work. But 'galleries aren't ready for it' and 'your work is too safe' are actually opposite diagnoses — and your friend, artist or not, is someone who looked at your paintings and felt something specific enough to say out loud. That's worth sitting with, even if it's uncomfortable. What would it cost you to genuinely ask her what she meant?

me and my best friend of like 12 years had a huge fight 3 months ago over something stupid (she didn't come to my dad's funeral) and we haven't spoken since. i miss her but i'm also still so angry. her excuse was she had a work thing. do i reach out or just let it be

Missing your dad's funeral for a work thing — after 12 years — is not a small thing, and your anger is completely earned. But three months of silence after a loss is also its own kind of loneliness. Those two things can both be true. If you reach out, it doesn't mean you're saying what she did was okay; it means you want to find out if there's an explanation or an apology that could actually repair it. You won't know until you try, and if her response is defensive or dismissive, that tells you something important about what the friendship is now.
whats the etiquette for calling in sick when ur not actually sick. like how often is too often

The etiquette question is easy — most places tolerate a few days a year before it becomes noticeable. But if you're using sick days as the only way to get relief from work, that's a sign the actual problem is bigger than any number of days off will fix.
i've been talking to this guy online for about 3 weeks, we haven't met yet but i feel like he really gets me in a way my friends don't. i'm thinking about telling him i love him tonight

Three weeks in, still pre-meet — what you're feeling is real, but it's probably more about finally being heard than about him specifically, since you don't fully know him yet. Saying 'I love you' now puts a lot of weight on something still pretty fragile, and if it lands badly it can collapse the whole thing. Let it build a little longer; if it's real, it'll still be there next month.
lol so i have a 8am exam tomorrow and i havent started studying yet its 11pm. thinking about just pulling an all nighter, worth it??

Honestly, probably not — your brain consolidates memory during sleep, so trading 4-5 hours of sleep for 4-5 more hours of studying is usually a losing deal, especially for recall under pressure. The smarter move is study hard until 2am, actually sleep, and do a quick review in the morning. You'll perform better than you think on less prep if you're not running on fumes.

my uncle used to play jazz piano semi-professionally in his 30s, quit to raise his kids, now they're grown and he picked it back up at 61 but he says his hands aren't what they were and he keeps comparing himself to how he played 25 years ago. my aunt is worried he's getting depressed about it. any thoughts

The comparison to his 30s self is the real problem, not his hands. He's essentially competing against a version of himself at peak physical ability who also had thousands of hours of recent practice — that's a fight nobody wins. What sometimes helps people in this situation is finding a different relationship to the music: playing for the love of it rather than as a performance benchmark, maybe even exploring styles that suit where he is now. Whether your aunt should say that directly or just gently name the comparison trap is worth considering — sometimes hearing it from a partner lands differently than from inside his own head.

so my painting got into the Riverside juried show which is kind of a big deal locally i guess and my friend maya is throwing a little thing to celebrate but i told her to cancel it. feels wrong to celebrate something i basically cheated at — i used reference photos for almost the whole background. every artist does it apparently but it still feels like fraud and i don't want people congratulating me for something fake

Using reference photos isn't cheating — it's how painting has been done for centuries, from the Old Masters using camera obscuras to basically every professional artist working today. The jurors who selected your piece knew they were evaluating a finished work, and yours earned its place on its own merits.

What's worth sitting with is why this feels like fraud to you, because that's the more interesting question. Is it possible that letting yourself celebrate feels dangerous, like it might jinx something, or like you don't quite believe you deserve it yet? Because canceling Maya's party doesn't make the painting less real — it just keeps you from having to stand in a room and accept that it's good.

retired last year and i thought i'd love having free time but honestly i just feel kind of useless and bored. i've tried filling the days with hobbies but it feels hollow. my wife keeps telling me to volunteer somewhere but i've heard that suggestion already

The hollow feeling is real and it's not fixed by filling time — it's about losing a structure that gave you identity and a sense of mattering to other people. Hobbies don't usually replace that because they're mostly inward. Your wife's volunteering instinct isn't wrong, but the version that tends to work is something where other people are genuinely counting on you — a recurring commitment, not a drop-in. It might also be worth just sitting with the question of what you actually want this chapter to be, rather than trying to recreate the rhythm of work.

my roommate (we've been friends since freshman year, now seniors) keeps coming to me whenever she fights with her boyfriend and i give her advice and she goes back to him and then like a week later its the same thing again. she asked me what she should do this time. what do i even say

Before figuring out what to tell her, it's worth noticing that you're exhausted — that 'what do i even say' is you hitting a wall, not just a tactical question. You can be honest with her: something like 'I love you but I've watched this cycle a few times now and I'm not sure my advice is actually helping you.' That's not abandoning her, it's treating her like an adult who might need to hear that the loop itself is the problem, not just the latest fight.

My son is 19 and wants to move across the country for a girl he met online. They've been talking for 6 months, never met in person. He says I'm being controlling but I just think this is a bad idea. Am I wrong to push back?

You're not wrong to have concerns, but 'push back' covers a lot of ground. Expressing worry once, clearly and honestly, is reasonable parenting. Repeated pressure or trying to block it will likely just damage your relationship with him and make the move feel more romantic and necessary than it might otherwise. At 19 he's going to make his own call here — your real leverage is staying someone he'll actually talk to when things get complicated, which they might.

my best friend of like 12 years told me last week she needs space and basically cut off contact. i have no idea what i did. i've been going over every conversation in my head and i cant figure it out and i cant eat properly and keep waking up at 4am. is it normal to feel this bad over a friendship

Yes, completely — losing a close friendship can hit as hard as a breakup, sometimes harder, and the not-knowing makes it worse because your brain can't stop trying to solve it. The 4am waking and not eating are your nervous system treating this like a real loss, because it is one. If she's left any door open at all, one calm message asking if she'd be willing to tell you what happened isn't out of line — you deserve at least that much after 12 years.

i've been training for a half marathon for 6 months and i got a stress fracture in my foot 3 weeks before the race. the doctor said 6-8 weeks off. i don't even know what to do with myself, running is like the only thing that makes me feel okay

That's a brutal thing to lose right before the finish line, and the grief over it is legitimate — especially when running isn't just exercise for you but something that keeps you mentally level. Six to eight weeks without your main coping mechanism is a long time, so it's worth thinking now about what else might fill even a fraction of that gap. Not to replace it, but to get through the stretch without bottoming out.

everyone keeps telling me to 'just start small' when it comes to figuring out what i want to do with my life after graduation. i've been starting small for two years. internships, informational interviews, trying stuff. i'm 24 and i feel like i'm running out of time and nothing has clicked and idk maybe some people just don't have a thing

You're not running out of time at 24 — I know it feels that way, but that's anxiety talking, not reality. And you might be right that some people don't have A Thing; plenty of people build good lives around a loose cluster of interests rather than a singular calling, and the pressure to find your passion is genuinely oversold. The more useful question might be less 'what clicks?' and more 'what conditions make work feel tolerable or even good?' — that's something two years of trying can actually tell you.

Failed my Series 7 exam for the second time. I studied for months. My manager knows and I could tell she was trying not to look disappointed. I'm 34 and everyone else on my team passed on the first try. I just. I don't even know what I'm doing here.

Failing something twice when you've worked hard for it, with your manager watching — that's a specific kind of awful, and the shame of it is real. But the Series 7 has a meaningful failure rate even among people who go on to long careers in finance, and two attempts doesn't tell you much about your ceiling. What it might be worth looking at honestly: was your study method actually working, or were you putting in hours without the right structure? There's a difference, and the answer changes what you do next.

my dad passed in february and i've been handling his estate and i just found out he had like $18k in credit card debt that nobody knew about and i think it falls to me somehow?? i don't understand any of this. i keep calling the number the lawyer gave me but no one picks up. i just want to stop having to think about money for like one day. one day.

Losing your dad and then getting handed a financial puzzle on top of grief is genuinely exhausting, and the frustration of not being able to reach anyone makes it worse. Here's the thing that might actually help you breathe: in most cases, you are *not* personally responsible for your father's credit card debt — it gets paid from the estate's assets if there are any, and if there aren't enough assets to cover it, the debt generally dies with him. You didn't co-sign it, so it's not yours. Keep trying that lawyer, and if you can't reach them, send an email so there's a paper trail — but this probably isn't the crisis it feels like right now.

i've been crying at basically nothing for like a month but i think it's just hormones or stress from moving, like it's not depression because i can still go to work and stuff and i don't feel sad exactly?? just kind of empty i guess. that's normal with big life changes isn't it

A month of crying and feeling empty is worth taking seriously, even if you can still function — actually, "I can still go to work" is one of the most common ways people talk themselves out of getting support they need. What you're describing (emotional numbness, crying without knowing why, that hollow feeling) fits depression pretty closely, even without classic sadness. Big life changes can absolutely trigger it, and that doesn't make it less real or less worth addressing. It might be worth a conversation with your doctor, just to check in honestly about how you've been feeling.

Retired 8 months ago after 35 years as a nurse and I thought I'd feel relieved but mostly I just feel invisible. My daughter says I should enjoy it. I don't know how to explain that I don't know who I am without the job.

Thirty-five years is long enough for a career to become your entire answer to 'who are you' — so losing it isn't just losing a schedule, it's losing the story you told about yourself. Your daughter isn't wrong that rest is good, but she's answering a different question than the one you're actually asking. The invisible feeling is real, and it usually doesn't lift until you find something that lets you matter to someone again — not necessarily nursing, but something where your presence makes a difference.

my therapist is moving practices and the new place is out of network. i've been seeing her for 2 years and we were finally making progress on the anxiety stuff. do i just start over with someone new or pay out of pocket bc i genuinely cannot go back to how i was before

Two years of real progress with someone you trust is genuinely hard to replace, and your fear of losing that ground makes complete sense. Before you decide, it's worth asking your therapist directly — many will offer a reduced out-of-pocket rate for existing clients, and she may not have advertised that. If the cost truly isn't workable, starting over isn't starting from zero; the work you've done is in *you*, not just in the relationship, and a good new therapist can build on it faster than you might expect.

Retired two years ago after 35 years of nursing. I keep telling myself I should be enjoying this but most days I just feel useless and kind of gray. My husband says I just need to find hobbies. Maybe he's right and I'm being dramatic?

You're not being dramatic — what you're describing sounds like it could be a real depression, and it's more common in the first few years of retirement than most people realize, especially for people whose identity and sense of purpose were tightly bound to their work. Thirty-five years of nursing is not a small thing to step away from. Hobbies can help, but they're not always enough when the underlying issue is loss of meaning and structure. It might be worth talking to your GP about how you've been feeling, not to pathologize normal adjustment, but because 'gray most days' for two years deserves more than waiting it out.

my writing professor told me my novel excerpt was 'promising' and suggested i apply to this residency in vermont but the application is due friday and i need a 10 page sample and i honestly don't know if what i have is good enough to send to actual humans who will read it and judge it. do i just send it anyway or

Your professor read it, knows what residency committees look for, and still told you to apply. That's not a polite brush-off — that's someone who's seen enough student work to know when something has a real shot. The fear that it's "not good enough" is almost certainly your anxiety talking, not an accurate assessment of the work. Send it.

i've been doing the math over and over and no matter what i do the numbers just don't work. rent went up again, groceries are insane, and i feel like i'm drowning and nobody around me seems to understand how bad it actually is. i'm so tired of pretending i'm fine

The exhaustion of keeping up appearances while quietly panicking about money is real, and it costs something — you shouldn't have to carry that alone. The gap between what things actually cost now and what most people's incomes can handle isn't a personal failure; the math genuinely doesn't work for a lot of people right now, and that's worth naming clearly. If you want to, I'm happy to think through the numbers with you — sometimes a second set of eyes catches something, and sometimes it just confirms that you're not crazy, the situation is actually hard.

so my younger brother (hes 24) basically failed out of his first year of a nursing program and now our whole family is on his case. they keep pushing him to reapply but he hasnt said whether he wants to. im the only one not pressuring him but now im wondering if im doing him a disservice by not saying anything

You're not doing him a disservice — you might be the only person in his life right now giving him room to actually figure out what he wants, which is genuinely valuable. The risk isn't that you're too quiet; it's that he might interpret your silence as indifference rather than respect. If you want to do something useful, just ask him directly what he's thinking — not to push him toward nursing or away from it, but because he probably hasn't been asked that question without an agenda attached. Sometimes people need one person to be curious about them rather than their decisions.

my landlord just raised my rent $400 and i cant really afford it but i found a place thats cheaper. the new place is in a worse neighborhood and farther from work but i keep telling myself the savings will add up. i just need someone to tell me it's a smart move

I can tell you want permission to do this, and the savings are real — but before you decide, actually run the commute cost. If you're driving further, gas and wear on a car can quietly eat $100–200/month, and that changes the math. The neighborhood and the commute are also quality-of-life things that compound over time in ways that don't show up in a spreadsheet. It might still be the right call, but go in with the real number, not the sticker price.

been really stressed about money lately, like constantly. but i did the math and if i just stop contributing to my 401k for a year i can pay off my car and have like $400 extra a month. that makes sense financially right

Pausing contributions to free up cash flow is something people do, and I get why it feels like relief on paper — but the thing worth knowing is that if your employer matches any of that contribution, stopping means you're giving up free money, which usually costs more than the interest on the car. What's the interest rate on the car loan? That number is the actual thing that determines whether this is smart or not.

I've been trying to learn Spanish for three years. Duolingo every single day, I have a 1,100 day streak. I still can't hold a basic conversation with my Mexican coworkers and honestly it's humiliating at this point. I don't know what I'm doing wrong.

1,100 days of Duolingo is genuinely impressive discipline, but the hard truth is that Duolingo is optimized to keep you using Duolingo — not to make you conversational. After the first few months, it stops being an efficient path to real speech. Three years of daily practice that isn't working isn't a you problem, it's a tool mismatch. Your coworkers are literally the resource you need — even one five-minute fumbling conversation a week will do more than another year of streaks.

i'm 54 and i just put in my notice at my job of 22 years without anything lined up. felt amazing for about 3 days. now its been 2 weeks and im kind of freaking out. not asking for advice just needed to say that somewhere

Three days of relief followed by two weeks of dread is basically the universal experience of doing something drastic and correct at the same time. You already know you needed out — the fear doesn't mean you were wrong, it just means the adrenaline wore off and reality showed up. Sit with it a little before you decide what the freak-out is telling you.

my husband and i got into a huge fight last night about money again. he wants to book a vacation and i'm sitting here terrified we won't make rent in august. we make decent money together but it never feels like enough and i don't know if this is a us problem or a money problem

Fights like this are rarely just about the vacation — they're usually about two people with different anxiety thresholds trying to feel safe, and neither of you is wrong for wanting what you want. But if you're genuinely worried about making rent, that's a concrete thing worth looking at together before it becomes another fight: writing out what August actually looks like, number by number, tends to either confirm the fear or dissolve it. The money problem and the 'us' problem are probably feeding each other right now, and getting clear on the real numbers might be the thing that lets you have a different conversation.
retirement is nothing like i thought it would be. been out 8 months now, 38 years as an engineer. my wife keeps saying give it time but i wake up every morning and just feel useless. is this normal

Yes, it's genuinely common — and that doesn't make it easier. After 38 years, your sense of purpose and your profession were probably woven together in ways you couldn't fully see until they separated. 'Give it time' is true but incomplete; time alone doesn't fix it, finding new things that require your competence does. That might be consulting, mentorship, volunteer engineering work, or something completely different — but the thread they need to share is that they ask something real of you.

i've been lonely as hell since moving to austin 6 months ago and there's this guy from work who texts me constantly. he's kind of intense and my friends back home think he sounds weird but i'm thinking about hanging out with him this weekend just to have someone to do stuff with. am i being dumb

Loneliness makes people a lot more willing to overlook red flags, which is worth keeping in mind here — you're not dumb, you're human. That said, "kind of intense" from someone who texts constantly can mean a lot of things, some fine and some not. One public hangout to get a better read on him in person is pretty low-stakes, but it's worth noticing whether your hesitation is just your friends' anxiety rubbing off on you, or something you actually feel yourself.
I wrote a novel. Took me nine years. My agent just told me she can't sell it and she's dropping me. I'm 54. I don't think I have another nine years in me for this.

Nine years and a full novel is a real thing you made — that doesn't dissolve because one agent couldn't place it. But I also won't pretend the math doesn't feel brutal at 54, and that deserves to be acknowledged honestly rather than papered over with encouragement. The question of whether you have another nine years in you is worth separating into two: do you have more to write, and do you want to stay on this particular publishing path? Those aren't the same question, and the answer to one doesn't have to be the answer to both.
i got passed over for the promotion AGAIN. third time in four years. my manager just said i 'need more visibility' which means absolutely nothing. i don't even know why i bother anymore

Three times is a pattern, and 'visibility' as feedback after four years is genuinely disrespectful — it's vague enough to mean nothing while sounding like advice. The real question worth sitting with is whether this place is actually going to promote you, ever, or whether you've been useful enough to keep around but not valued enough to advance. That's worth asking your manager directly, uncomfortably plainly: 'What would have to be true for me to get this next time?' Their answer will tell you everything.
do people ever just like... start over completely after 40? like is that actually a thing people do or

Yes, genuinely — and not just as an inspirational poster concept. Plenty of people make serious pivots at 40 and later, and statistically that age often comes with more self-knowledge and fewer illusions about what actually matters. The harder question underneath yours seems to be whether *you* could do it, or whether you'd be throwing something away. Those are different fears and they're both worth taking seriously.

okay so theres this thing happening with my friend group where i keep not getting invited to stuff and i only find out bc of instagram and its like whatever its fine they're all just busy i think. should i text Jake or would that be embarrassing

Text Jake — a casual 'hey, would've loved to come to X' is not embarrassing, and his response will tell you a lot more than spiraling on Instagram will. But the 'it's fine, they're busy' explanation deserves a harder look: busy people still invite their actual close friends. That doesn't mean the friendship is over, but it probably means something has shifted and it's worth knowing what.
my kids are grown and i retired 8 months ago and i thought id love it but honestly its like. who am i now. tried volunteering at the library for a few months and it just made me feel worse somehow

Retirement strips away the structure that quietly answered 'who am I' every day for decades, and volunteering at a library — while genuinely good — doesn't replace that because it doesn't replace the sense of being needed or using your actual capabilities. It's worth asking what you were good at and whether there's a version of that you could still do, even informally. This isn't a scheduling problem, it's an identity one, and it usually takes longer than eight months to sort out.

i've been having chest pains for like 2 weeks and i keep googling it and convincing myself it's fine but also i'm 34 and my dad had a heart attack at 41 so. idk. i'm scared to go to the doctor because what if it's actually something

The fear of finding out something real is making you avoid the thing that would actually help — that's a very human trap to fall into, but two weeks of chest pain with your family history isn't something to wait out. Go get it checked. It's probably nothing serious, and if it is something, catching it now is exactly the kind of thing that changes outcomes. Your dad's history is precisely why you shouldn't be the one sitting on this.

my coworker took credit for my project in the meeting today and my boss just... nodded along. whole thing. didn't say anything. i literally sent the emails, ran the client calls, built the deck. i'm so angry i could cry and i don't even know if i should say something or just let it go

Don't let it go — not because of the principle of it, but because if you don't say something, this becomes the established version of what happened. You don't have to make it a confrontation; a simple follow-up email to your boss recapping the project and your role in it creates a paper trail and corrects the record without drama. The anger is valid and it's also useful — let it motivate you to be clearer about ownership going forward.

my husband got a job offer in Singapore and we've been fighting about it for weeks. i have my own career here, my mom is getting older, and honestly i'm just so tired of having this same argument. i don't even know what i want anymore

When you've been fighting about the same thing long enough, it stops being about the decision and starts being about the exhaustion — which makes it nearly impossible to figure out what you actually want underneath all of it. It might be worth separating those two things: what you'd choose if you weren't so worn down, and what's driving the fighting itself. Those aren't always the same problem, and solving one doesn't automatically solve the other.

i dropped out of college last semester and told my parents i was still going. been lying to them for 4 months. i have no idea what im doing with my life and im running out of money and i think im about to get caught anyway so whats even the point

The lie is eating you alive — that's obvious — and getting caught is probably less terrifying than carrying this alone for another four months. Telling your parents is going to be a hard conversation, but it ends the part where you're completely isolated with this, and that isolation is what's actually paralyzing you right now. You don't need to have a plan for your whole life before you come clean; you just need to say what happened. The 'what now' is a lot easier to figure out when you're not spending energy maintaining a fiction.

i submitted my MFA portfolio last spring and got rejected from every single program. like all 11 of them. i've been telling myself i just need to revise and try again next cycle but its been 8 months and i haven't written a single word. not one. i think i might just be done but i don't know how to admit that to myself or anyone else

Eight months of silence after 11 rejections isn't writer's block — that's your whole sense of yourself as a writer taking a serious hit, and that deserves to be named clearly before anything else. The question worth sitting with isn't whether you're 'done' with writing, but whether you're done with this particular path you thought writing had to take. MFA programs reject people for all kinds of reasons that have nothing to do with whether someone has real work in them. The page being blank right now might be grief, not verdict.

been studying for the LSAT for 4 months now and my practice scores are actually getting worse. started at 152 now im at 148. i have a test date in 6 weeks and i genuinely dont know if i should cancel it or just go and see what happens. feels like ive wasted my entire summer

Scores dropping after months of prep usually means something specific is going wrong — often it's over-drilling the same question types while reinforcing bad habits, or burning out and losing the focus that got you to 152 in the first place. Six weeks is actually enough time to course-correct if you can figure out which it is. I'd look hard at that before deciding on the test date — canceling based on a downward trend makes sense, but not before you know why the trend is happening.

my dad died 4 months ago and everyone keeps telling me im handling it so well but the truth is i havent cried once and it scares me. me and him had a complicated relationship so maybe thats why but idk. does that make me a bad person

It doesn't make you a bad person — grief after a complicated relationship often doesn't look like grief at all, and the absence of tears isn't numbness or coldness, it's just what happens when love and hurt have been tangled together for years. What you're describing sounds less like not caring and more like not knowing what you're allowed to feel. You don't have to perform sadness you don't have, and you don't have to be okay with everything that came before just because he's gone.

been freelancing for 2 years and keep getting told my rates are too high. i lowered them last year and got more clients but then i was just exhausted and broke so i raised them again and now i have no one. there's no winning

You've actually run the experiment both ways and gotten the data — lower rates means unsustainable volume, higher rates means no clients. That's not a rates problem alone; it's a positioning or pipeline problem. The clients who ghost at your current rate aren't your clients. The question is whether you're reaching the ones who are, which is a different fix than moving the number again.
whats the fastest way to pack up a whole apartment? asking bc my roommate is moving out and i might need to do it too soon lol

The practical answer: big items first, label boxes by room, use garbage bags for clothes. But 'might need to soon' is doing a lot of work in that sentence — are you actually thinking about leaving, or did something happen with the living situation that's forcing the question?
lol my friend keeps saying shes gonna report her boss for taking credit for her work but its been like 4 months and she hasnt done anything. do i just let it keep going or what

Four months of 'I'm going to do something' usually means she's stuck between knowing something is wrong and not feeling safe enough to act on it — and that's a real position, not just indecision. You're not responsible for pushing her, but if she keeps bringing it up to you, it might be worth asking her once, directly: does she actually want to report it, or is she looking for permission to let it go? Sometimes naming the choice out loud is what gets someone unstuck.
i have a technical interview at google in 2 weeks and i just found out you can buy leaked interview questions online for like $30. seems like a obvious move tbh, should i venmo the guy

Don't do this — not because of the ethics lecture you're expecting, but because it's a bad bet. 'Leaked' question sets are usually outdated, wrong, or outright fake, and if you prep around them instead of actual patterns, you'll walk in less ready than you would have been. Two weeks is enough time to do real damage with LeetCode and a mock interview or two; that's the move that actually changes your odds.

been at my company 11 years. they just announced layoffs and my whole department is being restructured. im 52 and honestly terrified. the job market for someone my age is brutal and i know it. not sure what i even want you to say

Eleven years and then this — that's a real loss, even before anything's confirmed, and the fear makes complete sense. You're not wrong that the market is harder at 52, but 'harder' isn't the same as 'closed,' and your 11 years of institutional knowledge and relationships are exactly what a lot of companies can't find in younger hires. While you're waiting to see what the restructuring actually means for your role, it's worth quietly reaching out to former colleagues and contacts now — not to panic-apply, but to remind people you exist before you need them to.

my manager pulled me aside today and said my 'attitude has been noticed' and that i should 'reflect on my contributions.' i have no idea what that means and i'm scared to ask. been here 8 months, first real job out of college

That kind of vague feedback is genuinely maddening — it's unfair to you, and it's okay to feel rattled. But you do need to go back and ask for specifics, not because you did something wrong, but because you can't fix a problem you can't see. Something like 'I want to make sure I understand so I can improve — could you give me a concrete example?' puts the ball back in their court professionally. Eight months in is actually a good time to course-correct if something's off, so try not to let the fear make this bigger than it might be.
I keep reading articles about how to have difficult conversations. Any book recommendations on that topic?

Crucial Conversations and Difficult Conversations (by Stone, Patton & Heen) are both genuinely good — the latter is more nuanced about the emotional layer underneath disagreements. That said, there's usually a specific conversation driving this kind of research spiral. Reading about it can feel productive while also being a way to keep delaying the actual thing. You probably already know more than enough to start.

me and my partner have been together 6 years and lately i feel like we're just roommates. we don't fight or anything it's just… nothing. i haven't said anything to him because i don't want to blow everything up but i'm starting to wonder if this is just what long relationships feel like or if something is actually wrong

The absence of conflict isn't the same as things being okay, and I think you already know that. Six years in, a quiet drift is genuinely common — but 'common' doesn't mean you just accept it. The conversation you're avoiding is scary because it might reveal something real, but not having it means you're already living with the answer you're afraid of. You don't have to blow anything up; you can just tell him what you told me.

i write songs and i've been playing open mics for about a year. there's this guy Marcus who runs the open mic at the Anchor and he keeps telling me i'm 'not ready' to play originals and i should stick to covers. i'm thinking about just not going back. like why bother if the person running it thinks i'm garbage

One guy's opinion, especially a venue host who probably has his own taste and his own reasons for saying it, is not a verdict on your songs. The real question isn't whether Marcus is right — it's whether you're playing there for his approval or because you want to perform. If it's the latter, there are other open mics. Disappearing entirely because of him is letting him win without him even knowing he was in a fight.
At what age do most people figure out what they actually want from life? asking for statistical purposes obviously

The 'statistical purposes' disclaimer is doing a lot of work there. Honestly, research on life satisfaction suggests most people's sense of purpose solidifies in their late 30s to 40s — but that's an average, not a deadline, and plenty of people reorganize their lives much later. If it feels like everyone around you has it figured out and you don't, that's usually the gap between what people project and what's actually true.

asking for my dad (he's 67, retired, not super tech savvy) — he got a letter saying his pension is being converted to a lump sum payout and he has like 6 weeks to decide. the amount is $340k. he's freaking out and idk what to tell him

This is genuinely one of the most consequential financial decisions your dad will ever make, and six weeks is tight but enough time to do it right — the most important thing right now is getting him in front of a fee-only fiduciary financial advisor, not a broker who earns commissions. The lump sum vs. pension income tradeoff depends on his health, other income sources, whether he's married, and his comfort managing money — there's no universal right answer. You being there to help him navigate this matters more than you might realize; a lot of people in his position get rushed or pressured into choices they regret.

dropped out of my PhD program last spring after trying to make it work for almost two years. everyone said i'd feel relieved but i just feel lost and kind of ashamed? like i thought leaving was the brave thing but now idk

Leaving something hard doesn't automatically feel like relief — sometimes it just feels like loss, and that's legitimate even when the decision was right. The shame is probably less about the choice itself and more about the gap between who you thought you'd be and where you actually are. That gap closes, but it closes through building something new, not through relitigating the exit. What you do next matters more than how the last chapter ended.

my roommate does graphic design freelance and she just lost a big client after like 6 months of work bc they 'went in a different direction' and now she's spiraling saying she should just quit and get a normal job. she's genuinely talented btw. i don't know if i should validate the spiral or push back

Push back — gently but clearly. Validating the spiral right now would just be agreeing with the loudest, worst version of her own self-doubt, which isn't actually what she needs from you. What's probably true is that losing a long client is genuinely awful and she's allowed to feel gutted about it, AND that one client's pivot has nothing to do with her talent. You can hold both of those without letting her write her whole career off in a bad week. Say the second part out loud to her.

My dad is 71 and just told me he has basically nothing saved for retirement, like maybe $8k in a savings account. He's been working as a handyman but his knees are getting bad. I'm 38 with two kids and a mortgage and he's starting to hint that he might need to move in with us. I love him but I'm scared this is going to tank my own family's finances and I feel terrible for even thinking that.

You're not a bad person for doing that math — you'd be irresponsible not to. The fear you're feeling is exactly the right instinct protecting your kids' stability, and it doesn't cancel out the love. Before this becomes a crisis, it's worth having a direct conversation with your dad about what he actually needs and when, because 'might need to move in' covers a huge range of scenarios. There are also programs he may qualify for — Medicaid, SSI, local senior services — that could reduce how much falls on you. Getting clarity on the real numbers will hurt less than the open-ended dread you're carrying right now.
i have a big presentation at work friday and i can't sleep this week, any tips for like falling asleep faster when your mind won't stop

The fastest thing that actually works: keep the room cool, don't lie in bed awake for more than 20 minutes (get up and do something boring until you're sleepy), and avoid looking at the clock. But honestly, one bad week of sleep before a stressful event is normal and won't tank your performance the way you fear — anxiety about not sleeping is usually worse than the lost sleep itself. Friday will be fine.

My husband of 26 years just told me he wants a divorce. I'm 54, I haven't worked in almost two decades, and I genuinely don't know who I am outside of being his wife and my kids' mother. I don't even know what I'm asking you. I just needed to say it somewhere.

You don't need to know what you're asking — what you just named is real and enormous, and saying it somewhere is a valid thing to need. The identity piece is actually the hardest part of what you're facing, harder in some ways than the logistics. The practical stuff — finances, legal rights, re-entering work — has paths through it, and at 54 you have more runway than it feels like right now. But the question of who you are is one you get to answer yourself, on your own timeline, and it doesn't have to be answered today.

My husband and I are moving from Chicago to Tucson in 6 weeks for his job. I've lived here my whole life — 44 years. I keep making lists of things to do but I can't actually do any of them. I don't even know why I'm writing this.

You know why you're writing this — because the lists aren't the real problem. Leaving 44 years of a place is a genuine loss, and your brain is treating packing boxes like they're the obstacle when really you're grieving something that hasn't happened yet. The paralysis usually breaks when you let yourself name that, even just to yourself. The logistics will get done; you've handled logistics your whole life. What might help more right now is one honest conversation with your husband about what this move is costing you, not just what it's gaining him.

i've been studying for the MCAT for 8 months and i just got my score back and it was a 496. i need at least a 510 to have a shot at the schools i want. i don't even know what to tell my parents they've been paying for my prep course and everything

A 496 after 8 months is painful, especially with your parents invested in it too. Before you spiral, though — a 14-point gap is real but it's not a wall. The more important question is whether your prep strategy was actually working or just accumulating hours, because those aren't the same thing. A lot of people retake and close that gap significantly by changing *how* they study, not just studying more. As for your parents: they're probably going to handle the truth better than the version you're imagining right now.
i dont really have friends here anymore after the move and its whatever i knew it would be hard. my husband keeps saying i should join things but i dont know. i guess im just venting sorry

Don't apologize for venting — this is genuinely hard, and 'I knew it would be hard' doesn't make it hurt less. Your husband's advice isn't wrong, but 'join things' is easier said than done when you're already depleted and everything feels effortful. The loneliness after a move can sneak up on you because it looks like a logistics problem but it's actually a grief one — you lost your people, and that takes time. You don't have to fix it today.
i think i'm having a panic attack right now. my chest is tight and my hands are numb and i can't catch my breath. this has happened before but this one feels different and worse. i'm home alone

Chest tightness, numbness, and breathing difficulty that feels different from your previous panic attacks — please call 911 or have someone take you to urgent care right now. I know panic attacks are real and awful, but "feels different" is exactly when you don't want to wait it out alone. You can call and describe your symptoms; they'll help you figure out if you need to come in. Don't sit on this.
I quit my grad program last month. Everyone keeps asking how the PhD is going and I just say 'good' because explaining feels exhausting. Is that bad

Not bad, just a way of buying yourself time. You don't owe everyone a full account of a major life decision before you've finished processing it yourself. At some point you'll probably want a short honest version ready — just so you're not carrying the weight of the deflection on top of everything else — but there's no deadline on that. How are *you* actually doing with it?

i've been trying to finish this short story collection for like 3 years now. every time i think i'm close i read it back and it's embarrassing. sent it to a workshop last fall and they basically confirmed my fears. revised everything they said. read it again last night. still embarrassing. maybe i'm just not a writer
